narrative:
(3) On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Val Wilson conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility was toured inside and out with facility administrator, Joshua Harris. The home is a two story residence with 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. Four clients were present at time of inspection. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom was measured to be 126 degrees, which outside of the range (105 degrees and 120 degrees). LPA's observed the administrator lower the temperature gauge on the water heater. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and double locked in a cabinet in the staff office/ garage closet. Cleansers/chemicals are double locked and stored in a cabinet in the garage. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office/garage. The First Aid Kit is located in the staff office/ garage and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors in the hallways and bedrooms were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detector located in hallways were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Joshua Harris. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, Visitation policies, and current menu. Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a double lock locked closet in the garage . The medication logs are kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Three clients were interviewed and indicated that they feel safe in the home and accorded their personal rights. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction.

Six client and ten staff files were reviewed during the inspection. All staff that work at the facility have Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearances. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, are no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to facility representative Joshua Harris along with a Confidential Names List (LIC 811). The following forms are being left with facility representative to be updated and returned to the licensing office within 30 days: LIC 308 (Designation of Facility Responsibility), LIC 309 (Administrative Organization), LIC 500 (Personnel Report), LIC 610 (Emergency Disaster Plan for Children’s Residential). Also the licensing office needs a copy of a current lease agreement within 30 days.

narrative: On February 11, 2023, the Department received a complaint report, with allegations that minor cause harm to another minor while in care due to lack of supervision and minor had access to chemicals at the residential facility. Confidential interviews did not provide consistent statements and there were no witnesses to the event. Confidential interviews and records reviewed for the incident did not provide a preponderance of evidence to prove or disprove the allegation C1 caused harm to C2 due to lack of supervision and C1 had access to chemicals at the residential facility. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. LPA conducted an exit interview and provided a copy of this report along with appeal rights to Drew Desmont, CEO.

During the investigation, LPA Saeteurn interviewed clients (C1-C3), staff (S1-S4), one witness (W2), and reviewed facility pertinent records. Confidential interviews confirmed the verbal exchange that took place on September 23, 2024, in which C1 was attempting to enter the facility garage and S1 informed C1 they were not allowed in the garage. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 was standing in the doorway entrance to the garage, preventing C1 from entering, due to C2 receiving medications from S2 in the garage and C1 having a history of attempting to retrieve restricted items from the garage. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was challenging S1 to do something about C1 attempting to get into the garage when S1 proceeded to walk towards C1. A review of a Special Incident Report (SIR) submitted by the facility to CCL detailed that C1 tried to run through S1 to get into the garage where a client had just entered to take their medication in privacy. The SIR included that S1 blocked C1 at the doorway and, with arms extended, redirected C1 out of the doorway, and secured the garage behind them. A confidential interview indicated that S1 pushed C1, however other confidential interviews revealed that S1 did not throw or push C1, but rather S1 proceeded to walk towards C1 with their arms out. Confidential interviews revealed that during the process in which S1 walked towards C1, C1 jumped back and fell onto the floor. A confidential interview indicated that C1 exclaimed, “S1 put hands on me” and proceeded to get up to walk to their room. The investigation did not yield witnesses to corroborate that S1 mishandled C1 during the exchange. Based on interviews conducted and record review, the allegation that facility staff mishandled a minor while in care is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Joshua Harris, Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Joshua Harris, Administrator, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.

narrative: On March 17, 2021, at approximately 9:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jazmond Harris conducted a phone call to the facility in order to obtain further information regarding the facility. LPA Harris spoke with Facility Manager, Kristy Bradford. LPA Harris asked to speak with Facility Administrator, Rushel Brooks. Facility Manager stated that Administrator was not present, but was on her way. LPA Harris asked Facility Manager how many staff members were present at the facility currently. Facility Manager stated she was the only staff member present. LPA Harris was advised that five clients were present. LPA Harris asked Facility Manager if there was only one staff member to five clients and Facility Manager stated there was. LPA Harris requested that Facility Administrator contact me at her earliest convenience. LPA Harris was contacted by Facility Administrator and advised that the current census of the facility is 4 clients. Facility Administrator stated the facility's ratio in from 10 PM until 9 AM is one staff member to five clients. LPA Harris asked Facility Administrator if the information was documented in her program statement or to her assigned analyst? Facility Administrator was not sure. LPA Harris expressed the concerns regarding the ability of one staff providing adequate care and supervision to four or five clients. Based on the information gathered, LPA Harris explained that due to the deficiency, the facility will be cited in violation for Interim Licensing Standards, Version 3.1: 87065.5 DIRECT CARE STAFF/CHILD RATIOS. This poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care. See page 2 for the cited deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report will be provided to Administrator. Signature will be on file.

On May 25, 2021 at 9:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson conducted a tele-inspection via Face Time due to COVID-19, with Facility Administrator Rushel Brooks to deliver a report regarding an office conference that was held on May 24, 2021, with VE and Daughters Happy Home Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), via MS Teams due to the COVID-19 pandemic. In attendance were: Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives, Regional Manager (RM) Lacresha Cook, Licensing Program Managers (LPM) Stephanie Hudak and Ann Valenzuela, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Carol Anderson and Babatunde Aborchie; STRTP representatives, Vilma Davis, CEO/Founder, Tatiana Sankar, CFO/Co-Founder, Roisin Doy, Head of Service and Rushel Brooks, Administrator; and Riverside County Placement Representatives, Nisha Elliott, Behavioral Health, and Karin Atkis, Supervisor of Out-of Home Investigations. The following issues were discussed: Complaints Personnel Requirements Admission Policies Extension for the provisional STRTP license (12 mos. expires 7/21/21) During the meeting, LPM Hudak discussed the increase of complaints that occurred in the last three years. In 2021 there were ten complaints, 2020 there were 12 complaints and 2019 there were eight complaints. LPM Hudak discussed the patterns of the complaints relating to care and supervision. Per administrator, stated that increase of issues at the facility were in relation to clients in the home wanting to be out in the community but couldn’t due to COVID pandemic.

LPM Hudak discussed what kind of indoor activities are being provided to the clients. STRTP representatives stated that due to COVID-19, the indoor activities consist of Arts/Crafts, games, gardening, and various puzzles. STRTP representatives stated for outdoor activities they were doing beach walks and community walks. STRTP representatives stated prior to COVID-19 clients were taken to YMCA on a regularly basis for swimming. STRTP representatives stated activities are being offered but clients do refuse to participate in the activities or client’s AWOL from the facility. LPM Hudak discussed the personnel requirements as it relates to staffing and crisis situations. STRTP representatives stated staff meetings are held every Monday. Staff goes over intervention techniques as incidents occur in the facility. LPM Hudak asked who the current Pro-Act trainer was and if current staff are trained, per the emergency intervention plan in their program statement. CFO stated she needs to attend the Pro-Act trainer re-certification course to do the training for staff. Ms. Doy stated she has been working with staff on different crisis intervention techniques and de-escalation communication with staff as she is present in the facility Monday through Friday 12-8:30pm. It was also discussed by CCL staff on what mental health services are being provided by the facility. STRTP representatives stated that most of the 1:1 therapy and drug and alcohol treatment is being provided by outside sources that include Vista Hill and McAllister. Ms. Doy stated she is a master’s level social worker, not licensed, and not currently being supervised by a licensed therapist. It was also discussed by Riverside County representative, Ms. Elliott, that crisis intervention plan and training has to be completed by licensed mental health worker. Again, the facility stated they currently do not have a licensed mental health professional providing those services and currently looking for someone to fill that role. Both LPM Hudak and RM Cook emphasized to the STRTP representatives that they must follow their approved plan of operation and program statement, especially regarding the emergency interventions they are utilizing within the program as this is a basis to some of the current complaint issues.

LPM Hudak also discussed admission policies and what the current plan is with accepting new placements. Ms. Brooks and Ms. Doy state, they are looking at compatibility when accepting new placements from the various counties. Current placements include clients from Riverside, Kern, and San Bernardino Counties. Riverside County representative, Ms. Atkins gave input on all the Child Protective Services Referrals that are receiving as well for their placements and they have seen an increase in lack of staff interventions. Lastly, the status of the STRTP provisional license was discussed. STRTP stated they started the process in 2018 for accreditation with Joint Commission, then stopped to work on STRTP application, and most recently started the process again. Currently, San Diego County Behavioral Health and Human Services is not contracting with them which has caused the facility to withdraw their Mental Health Application with the State of California. LPM Hudak provided information that per the current STRTP guidelines, in order for CCL to justify the extension of the provisional license past the 12-month expiration date, the facility needs to be in the process of obtaining Mental Health Approval and/or Accreditation. STRTP representatives were looking forward to applying for a contract again with San Diego County next year. Information that CCL received from San Diego County, was that new Mental Health contracts with San Diego County would not occur to 2023, which would be well pass the 18-24-month mark of the provisional license. LPM Hudak explained to facility representatives that they would need to make a decision on what their plan is for their facility since they did not have any confirmation of a mental health contract from a county to move forward with the provisional license extension. Suggestions of Transitional Housing facility or converting back to a Group Home for private pay or Regional Center was given.

At this time, CCL is requesting a Corrective Action Plan due by 6/24/21, to include the following: 1) What the plan is for the operation of the facility if the STRTP license expires. 2) What the plan will be for crisis intervention training and implementation in the facility until a licensed mental health professional is hired. 3) What is the plan for in-house mental health services until a licensed mental health professional is hired. In closing, all parties were satisfied with all information that was discussed during the meeting. A copy of this report was given to and reviewed with Facility Administrator Rushel Brooks

Confidential interviews revealed that clients had accessibility to drugs inside the facility by hiding the drugs in private areas on their body. Other confidential interviews indicated that staff check clients’ bags, conduct random room checks, and check the perimeter of the facility by looking around the trees and bushes for illegal drugs. Other confidential interviews did not reveal how the drugs were brought into the facility. Based on confidential interviews and information gathered during the investigation, the allegations that S1 had alcohol in the vehicle, S1 drinking alcohol in the presence of clients and lack of supervision resulting C2, C3, C4, C5 using drugs while in care, may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Administrator Rushel Brooks.

narrative: On September 7, 2021 at 9:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson met with Rushel Brooks, Facility Administrator for VE and Daughters Happy Home #2 in the San Diego Community Care Licensing (CCL) to deliver findings regarding an informal conference held on May 24, 2021 at 9:00AM, with VE and Daughters Happy Home #2 Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) facility representatives, via MS Teams due to COVID-19. During the informal conference the plan of operation was discuss and determine the facility was out of compliance with their plan of operation. The facility plan of operation is in violations of the Interim Licensing Standards STRTP (ILS) (Version 3.1). Based on interviews and information during the informal conference on 5/24/21, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that the facility plan of operation is substantiated. This pose an immediate Health and Safety risk to client in care. The facility cited for California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Interim Licensing Standards (STRTP)(ILS) (Version 3.1.) An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Rushel Brooks, Facility Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On September 3, 2021 at 9:35AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson met with Fac. Admin. Rushel Brooks. LPA conducted a tele-inspection of the facility on January 25, 2021 at 11:46 am and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Five of five clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5), five staff (S1, S2, S3) and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that S1 made an inappropriate comment to C1. Confidential interviews reported that S1 was in the living and C1 overheard S1 make a racial comment. Confidential staff interviews reported that S1 made a comment regarding race but was referring to someone on social media. Confidential interviews denied any inappropriate comments made towards any of the clients in care. Additional interviews reported that C1 got upset at S1 and began calling S1 derogatory names. There no other witnesses to this alleged incident. The interviews that were provided to the LPA were not consistent and did not provide any specific details regarding all of the alleged allegation listed above. Based on interviews and record reviews the allegation that S1 made an inappropriate comment to C1, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time.An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Fac. Admin. Rushel Brooks.

narrative: Confidential staff interviews reported that S1 did not make any inappropriate comments to any clients nor did S1 speak to the clients inappropriately. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 was never denied any approved visitation and while C1 was placed at the facility C1 had family approved overnight visitations. Confidential staff interviews reported that all of the staff treated all the clients the same and some clients had more privileges due to their behaviors and following the facility program. Confidential interviews reported that all of the clients were attending school virtually and had all the necessary equipment that was issued by the school personnel. The facility has two refrigerators and two freezers which had plenty of food that the clients accessed at any time. LPA was unable to interview C1 due to C1 refusing to speak to LPA. There no other witnesses to these alleged incidents. The interviews that were provided to the LPA were not consistent and did not provide any specific details regarding all of the alleged allegations listed above. Based on interviews and record reviews the allegations that S1 speaks inappropriately to the clients, staff did not allow C1 to have approved visitation, staff treats the clients differently than other clients, staff did not assist C1 with obtaining necessary equipment for school and the facility does not have adequate amounts of food, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Fac. Admin. Rushel Brooks
investigation_findings: 13On September 7, 2021 at 9:39AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson met with Fac,Admin. Rushel Brooks. LPA conducted a tele-inspection of the facility on February 10, 2021 at 03:01 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Three of four clients (C1, C2, C3, C4), five staff (S1, S2, S3,S4,S5) and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that S1 speaks inappropriately to the clients, staff did not allow C1 to have approved visitation, staff treats the clients differently than other clients, staff did not assist C1 with obtaining necessary equipment for school and the facility does not have adequate amounts of food.

narrative: It was reported that there was an physical altercation between two clients. It was stated that there was not enough supervision present which is why the altercation was conducted. Information obtained from Administrator and staff, stated there was three staff present during the altercation which sufficed the required staff ratio. Information obtained from staff member stated that they did feel that when incidents occur, more staff is needed. Information obtained from confidential interviews stated there was no concern regarding supervision. Information obtained from county social worker supervisor stated there was no known concern. It was also reported that minors were injured during the altercation and staff did not intervene. Information obtained from Administrator stated a client reported injuries and was immediately taken to be evaluated by medical personnel. Administrator stated that information was provided to the assigned county social worker and CCL. It was also stated that staff did not intervene. Administrator stated the facility was “hands off” and staff were not trained to physically intervene. Administrator stated that staff were encouraged and expected to verbally intervene. Information obtained from staff corroborated the information and stated after any incident clients were encouraged to be medically evaluated. Staff Member also stated that Client was taken to the hospital; no concerns. Staff Member also stated she did not intervene due not being Pro-Act trained or allowed to. Staff Member stated she did use verbal commands to try and terminate the fight. Information obtained from confidential and county social worker interviews stated they did not have information pertaining to the incident. Due to not being able to interview additional clients, LPA Harris was unable to make a determination regarding the findings. Based on interviews, the allegations that there was a lack of supervision resulting in minors engaging in verbal and physical altercations, minor sustained injuries while in care, and staff did not intervene during altercations, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time.

narrative: On March 19, 2021, Community Care Licensing received information which stated staff are verbally abusive to minors while in care while making a racial comment. It was reported that Staff Member #1 made an inappropriate comment. It was advised that Staff Member #1 stated, “I’m tired of this black shit.” It was reported that while watching television with another staff and client present, Staff Member #1 made the comment. Information from Administrator corroborated the information and stated that Staff Member #1 admitted to the allegation. Administrator stated Staff Member #1 was counselled and retrained regarding cultural sensitivity. Information obtained from staff interviews stated the inappropriate comment was made. Information from confidential interviews stated they were not present when the comment was made. Information obtained from county social worker supervisor stated there was no known concern. Facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Version three section 87072(d)(11) Personal Rights which posed a potential health, safety and/or personal rights risk to clients in care. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to Administrator Rushel Brooks.

deficiencies.description: 87072(d)(11) Personal Rights. narrative: On April 27, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information which stated staff did not prevent clients from smoking marijuana. It was reported that clients were able to smoke marijuana in the home. Information obtained from Administrator stated that clients did begin to smoke in the home without permission. Administrator stated staff would encourage clients to follow the program and listen to staff directives. Administrator stated when staff would observe clients smoking, staff would ask clients to stop and attempt to retrieve the contraband. Administrator stated authorized representatives and CCL were notified. Administrator denied that law enforcement was contacted. Administrator stated the facility did have drug abuse counseling for clients as well. Information obtained from staff corroborated the information provided by Administrator. Staff stated they would try their best to encourage clients to follow the rules. Information obtained from confidential interview stated that clients did smoke in the home, but staff did not allow clients; clients did not care about following rules. Information obtained from confidential and county social worker interviews stated they did not have information pertaining to the allegation. Due to not being able to interview additional clients, LPA Harris was unable to make a determination regarding the finding. Based on interviews, the allegations that staff did not intervene during altercations, Client sustained injuries while in care, and Client’s property was destroyed may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time.

narrative:
On September 15, 2020, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ann Valenzuela conducted a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) pre licensing inspection. LPA met with Executive Director, Lauri Burns. The facility is a single-story residential building with five bedrooms, three client bathrooms, staff office with a staff restroom, kitchen, dining area, laundry area with a washer and dryer, living room, family room and a group room to conduct group therapy. There is a two-car garage that is attached and used for back up storage and extra refrigerators. The staff office is where the facility stores personnel files, client files, and medications, sharps and funds that are stored within a locked cabinet. The office is kept locked when not in use and is only accessible to the facility staff. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris, observable hazards, and insects. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports/workout equipment, and televisions were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and were observed to be in working order; fire extinguishers were properly charged and serviced. The following required forms were posted in the facility: Weekly Menu, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Each of the five client bedrooms has proper lighting, adequate drawer space, all six beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water was tested and measured to be 114 degrees Fahrenheit which is in the required range of 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and a current first aid manual approved by the American Red Cross. SEE PAGE 2

CONTINUED FROM PAGE 1. In the backyard there is a swimming pool that is fenced in, licensee was advised to remove all pad locks to the gate. There is a sustainable garden where the clients can grow vegetables. Per Executive Director, no firearms or weapons are kept or allowed in the facility and smoking is prohibited. Licensee has previously been accredited through the Joint Commission, and once the facility is licensed the licensee will notify the commission to make them aware of the program change to update the certification. Current staff have caregiver background checks and have received criminal record and child abuse index clearance. LPA discussed the following with facility staff: Facility manager requirements, and AB388 requirements. Executive Director, Lauri Burns was advised that this pre-licensing report will be reviewed by the Department. The facility will be notified once they are provisionally licensed as a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). An exit interview was conducted with Executive Director, Lauri Burns and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility for signature. The original signed report will be in the facility file.

On October 8, 2020 at 11:15 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced inspection of the Vera Sanctuary I Short Term Residential Facility to verify the employment status of the individual (E1) identified on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated 10/08/2020. LPA met with Administrator, Christina Webb. The department received an Exemption Denial and Confirmation of Removal from the Caregiver Background Check Bureau (CBCB) on E1. Based on the evidence obtained during today's inspection, the LPA verified the individual is not present, employed or residing at the facility. LPA has advised the Licensee to disassociate the individual from their roster and submitted an updated LIC 500. Verification of removal is complete. A copy of this report was reviewed with and emailed to Christina Webb for signature, along with the LIC 811.

On July 2, 2021, at 12:14pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nicole Strickland met with Vera’s Sanctuary 1 Head of Service Michelle Menke to deliver a Case Management – Deficiencies report. Information received by Community Care Licensing (CCL) on April 1, 2021 revealed the Needs and Service Plan for Child #1 (C1) was not being updated at least every 30 days as required by Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) regulation 87068.3(a). ILS 87068.3 Modifications to the needs and services plan (a) The needs and services plan specified in Section 87068.2 shall be updated at least every 30 days to determine the following. Record review was able to provide evidence that C1 had an initial Needs and Service Plan created upon intake in November 2020 however, the facility was unable to provide documentation that any updates to the Needs and Service Plan had been done during the months of December 2020, January 2021, February 2021, or March of 2021. Confidential interviews revealed that the facility had no documentation of NSP’s being done during that time period. Confidential interviews and record review further revealed the facility does not allow resident to have or purchase cell phones. Record review revealed that there was no documentation that Child #1 (C1) was not allowed purchase C1’s own cell phone. Confidential interviews reported C1 was made to turn in the cell phone. This is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87072(d)(8)(B). ILS 87072 Personal Rights (d)(8)(B) all restrictions shall be documented in the child’s needs and services plan or the facility’s discipline policies and be signed by the child’s authorized representative. Record review could not provide the required documentation LPA observation on July 2, 2021 noted that the facility did not have a designated Facility manager present at the facility while four residents were present. LPA noted that this was a violation of ILS 87065(f). ILS 87065 Personnel Requirement (f) The licensee shall designate at lease one Facility Manager to be present a the facility at all times when one or more children are present. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

Based on confidential interviews and record review of facility documentation the facility is cited for violation of of ILS 87068.3(a) Modification to the needs and service plan, and violation of ILS 87072(d)(8)(B) Personal Rights, and violation of ILS 87065(f). Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) received email authority from Anasheh Sarfarian to allow Michelle Menke to sign on behalf of the facility. A copy of this report and appeal rights was discussed and provided to Head of Service Michellle Menke..

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nicole Strickland arrived to the facility unannounced and met with Facility Manager Morgan Salmans to deliver an amended report that was initially delivered on July 2, 2021.

Confidential interviews and record review could not confirm or dispute an incident had occurred. Confidential interviews deny witnessing any inappropriate interactions between S1 and C1. Confidential interviews could only provide that there was a weird vibe between C1 and S1. Confidential interviews further reported S1 had reported concerns with boundaries regarding C1. Confidential interviews were unable to provide what the boundary concerns were and what if anything was done regarding the concerns. Based on record review and confidential interviews, the allegation of Staff (Staff #1 (S1) sexually abused a minor (Child #1 (C1), may or may not have occurred, however it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. narrative: On 09/16/21 at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Torres met with Lauri Burns, Executive Director, for the purpose of continuing the post licensing inspection of the facility. During this inspection the LPA requested documents from the staff and client files for the file reviews. While the documents were being pulled, the LPA conducted confidential staff interviews. Due to time constraints, the inspection will have to be completed on a subsequent day. A copy of this report was provided to Lauri Burns.

On 09/13/21 at 10:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Torres met with Morgan Salmans, Facility Manager/Administrator Designee for the purpose of conducting a post licensing inspection of the facility. At 11:45 AM, Morgan led the physical inspection of the facility with the LPA. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s building and grounds, kitchen area, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, client bedrooms, bathroom/showers and facility vehicles used to transport clients. The facility grounds were clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games/computers were observed for children’s schooling and recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menu was posted. All other required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster Plan and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff's office. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The hot water in the client’s bathrooms was measured to be between 103 and 116 degrees. Per Morgan, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Chemicals and/or poisons are locked in the hallway closet. The LPA reviewed LIC 610C Emergency Disaster Plan, completed disaster training for staff and clients and completed emergency drills. Due to time constraints, the inspection will have to be completed on a subsequent day. A copy of this report was provided to Morgan Salmans.

Allegation #1) It was alleged there were no planned activities and in April and May of 2021 there was no outing/activity money available at the facility. Administration advised that they had forgotten to give the money to the facility. During the course of the investigation confidential interviews were conducted, it was reported to the LPA that S9 did not want to take the clients out because S9 was scared the clients would steal. The staff had the funds and ability to take the clients out but S9 did not want to. It was further reported to the LPA the staff did what they could given the COVID-19 Pandemic. The clients were provided the following activities: Taco Tuesday at Rosa’s Cantina, movies in the park outside on the facility grounds, an ice cream truck would come to the facility each week, pool days with a barbecue, trips to the salon to get their nails done, trips to the hair shop, Knott’s Berry Farm and Disneyland. However, other information was received that the clients would watch Tik Tok (social media) and videos all day. The staff and clients would go in the community and the clients would steal from the store. There was always plans for activities but there was never any money available. There were no funds for staff to use or petty cash. Allegation #2) It was alleged on a holiday between April 2021-July 1, 2021, one or two clients went to S4’s house for a few hours because staff called off and the facility was short staffed. Reportedly S4 was advised by Orange County Children and Family Services the clients could not hang out with S4’s 18 year old foster child. During the course of the investigation confidential interviews were conducted, the LPA did not receive any corroborating information on whether the clients went to S4's house and/or spent time with S4's foster child. It was further reported to the LPA, the clients were always in the staff’s care. If the clients did go to S4's home, there would have been a staff present. Allegation #3) It was alleged from April 2021-July 1, 2021, client #2 (C2) was not required to attend therapy. During the course of the investigation confidential interviews were conducted, it was reported to the LPA C2 was supposed to go therapy before or after work but C2 refused to go. When C2 was not working on the weekends, C2 still refused to go to therapy. The staff would try to get C2 to go to therapy but they could not force C2 to participate. However, other information was received that C2 did not have to attend therapy and needed to focus on working. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations there were no planned activities in April and May of 2021, there was no outing/activity money available at the facility, clients spent unauthorized time with S4's foster child and clients who had jobs were not required to participate in therapy may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, the LIC 811 Confidential Names and appeal rights were provided to Mariam Mott.
investigation_findings: 13On 08/03/22 at 12:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Torres conducted a subsequent complaint inspection for the purpose of delivering the investigative finding to the allegations listed above. The LPA met with Mariam Mott, Clinical Director. On 07/02/21, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging there were no planned activities and in April and May of 2021 there was no outing/activity money available at the facility, clients spent unauthorized time with S4's foster child and clients who had jobs were not required to participate in therapy. During the course of the investigation, the LPA conducted confidential interviews with seven staff. The LPA attempted to interview the three involved clients but they were not present when the LPA completed inspections to the facility, had been discharged from the facility or were on run away status. *** Continued on next page ***

narrative:
During the course of the investigation, the LPA conducted confidential interviews with seven staff. The LPA attempted to interview the three involved clients but they were not present when the LPA completed inspections to the facility, had been discharged from the facility or were on run away status. The LPA also completed a review of facility documentation. Allegation #1) It was alleged from April 2021-July 1, 2021, hot food was left out from 1:00 PM-9:00 PM. The LPA received corroborating information from staff that dinner would be prepared and placed on the kitchen counter or on top of the dryer by 3:30 p.m. There was no set time for dinner. The clients would serve themselves and eat when they wanted to. The food would not be refrigerated and left out overnight. When the staff arrived the next morning, they would dispose of the food. It was reported to the LPA this occurred multiple times. Allegation #2) It was alleged that staff #1 (S1) and staff #2 (S2) told client #1 (C1) to shut up and called C1, "Ghetto." S1 reported to the LPA, the incident occurred around 06/20/21. C1 was very aggressive, called S1 names and got in S1’s face. S1 told C1 the way C1 was speaking to S1 was ghetto and C1 needed to stop calling S1 the, “Work Nigger,” and “Work Nigga.” C1 also called S1 a, “Fucking bitch,” and “Bruh.” S2 denied making the alleged statements and further denied being present during the incident. During confidential interviews, it was reported to the LPA S1 was constantly inappropriate with the clients. A client would yell at S1 and S1 would yell back, tell them to shut up and get in the client’s face. It was further reported S1 admitted to the incident. S1 was frustrated about not receiving support from the administrator at the time. S1 apologized to the client. The LPA did not receive any evidence that S2 made the alleged comments. Allegation #3) It was alleged from April 2021-July 1, 2021, Anasheh Safarian (S3) was listed as the administrator of record. During this time, the facility had two administrators. S3 was the administrator during the day and Charmaine Linley (S9) was the administrator at night. S3 was present at the facility only four times from April 2021-July 1, 2021. S3 worked out the licensee’s corporate office in Sun Valley, CA. During confidential interviews, the LPA received corroborating information that S3 was not on the facility premises each week. It was reported S3 was the administrator on paper only. S3's work was performed at the licensee's corporate office. The facility submitted a letter and supportive documents to CCL, dated 04/08/21, indicating S3 was the administrator effective 04/08/21. The facility did not report to CCL that S9 was hired or that S9 would be an administrator in addition to S3. *** Continued on next page ***

Allegation #4) It was alleged that staff did not receive required training. There were multiple staff who supervised the clients in the facility swimming pool in May and June of 2021, but did not have water safety certificates. The facility was licensed on 09/15/20 but the licensee did not offer the water safety training prior to April of 2021. The LPA requested proof of completed water safety training from the facility for the staff who supervised the clients in the facility swimming pool in May and June of 2021. The facility submitted copies of the certificate of completion for the American Red Cross Water Safety for Parents and Caregivers for some of the staff but no proof was provided for S1 and staff #6 (S6). In addition, the certificate of completion for S2 was dated 07/15/21, after S2 had provided the supervision. Allegation #5) It was alleged from April 2021-July 1, 2021, the facility bathrooms and bedrooms were only cleaned on Monday (by a professional cleaning crew) and that on other days bathroom trash would be left overflowing and there were dirty counters and floors. On 6/10/2021, a client dyed their hair black and walked through the facility, staining floors in the hallway and bathroom. During confidential interviews, the LPA received corroborating information when the morning staff reported to work, the facility was dirty on a weekly basis. The trash was not taken out, the kitchen, living room and the clients’ rooms were dirty. The LPA completed a safety inspection of the facility on 07/14/21 at 11:10 AM. Although the facility was clean, the LPA observed black dye on the door jam in the client bathroom. Based on confidential interviews, document review and the LPA's observation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegations food was not stored in a safe manner, S1 spoke inappropriately to C1, facility administrator was not on the premises 20 hours a week, facility staff were not properly trained and the facility was not kept clean are substantiated. Facility is cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 80076(a)(14) Food Services, 80065(e)(2) Personnel Requirements, 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds and the Interim Licensing Standards Article 6 87072(c)(10) Personal Rights and 87064(b)(1) Administrator Qualifications and Duties on the next pages. A copy of this report, the LIC 811 Confidential Names, and appeal rights were provided to Mariam Mott.

Allegation #1) It was alleged from April 2021-July 1, 2021, the facility did not have enough milk or two days worth of perishable items. The staff would also feed the clients fast food. During the course of confidential interviews, it was reported to the LPA there was always a supply of fresh food. The food was purchased from Shamrock Foods Company (commercial food supplier) and delivered every Thursday. If the clients did not like what was on the menu, they were allowed to request other food items. The staff would then go purchase the requested food items. Four gallons of milk a were ordered each week. If the milk supply ran low, they would order through Instacart (grocery delivery service). The LPA completed a safety inspection of the facility on 07/14/21 at 11:10 AM and observed the food supply. There was an adequate supply of food and perishables. The LPA also obtained copies of invoices from Shamrock Foods Company from 05/01/21-7/8/21. The facility consistently ordered food each week, including milk and perishables. However, other information was received that the pantry was empty seven or eight times. One time was due to the house being bombed for bugs. Allegation #2) It was alleged from April 2021-July 1, 2021, that dated menu documentation was not available. The menus were posted a couple of times and they were outdated. During the course of confidential interviews, it was reported to the LPA the weekly menus were posted on the refrigerator. The menu copies were kept for months in the staff office. In addition, there were electronic copies of the menus. The LPA completed a safety inspection of the facility on 07/14/21 at 11:10 AM and observed four weeks of dated menus posted on the side of the refrigerator and the menu for the day on a decorative chalkboard on the kitchen counter. However, other information was received that the menus were not posted prior to 07/13/21. Allegation #3) It was alleged from April 2021-July 1, 2021, adults from the licensee's substance use disorder (SUD) site across the street from the facility were allowed to come into the facility with the clients and were left alone with clients and act as mentors to the clients. It was a regular practice to have staff working in the facility that did not have a criminal record clearance. It was alleged staff #10 (S10) did not have a criminal record clearance on 6/10/2021. S10 was allowed to supervise the clients prior to being fingerprint cleared. During the course of confidential interviews, it was reported to the LPA the clients were never left unsupervised with the adults from the SUD site. Vera's Sanctuary (VS) staff were always present. *** Continued on next page ***

The adult clients and VS clients had group sessions together on the VS porch for approximately two months and the adult clients would come to the VS swimming pool to hang out. The group sessions and the adult clients visits to the swimming pool were stopped by the facility after LPA Torres completed the 10 day inspection for this complaint on 07/14/21. The LPA verified through the CCL database that S10 had a criminal record clearance and was associated to the facility on 05/10/21. However, other information was received stated the clients would go across the street to the SUD facility to play pool (billiards) in the garage. The adult clients were also present in the garage and no VS staff were supervising the clients. This happened five times. It was a regular practice to have staff working in the facility that had not received a criminal record clearance. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations the facility did not have enough milk or two days worth of perishable items, menus were posted a couple of times and they were outdated, adults from the SUD site were allowed to come into the facility with the clients and were left alone with clients and it was a regular practice to have staff working in the facility that did not have a criminal record clearance may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, the LIC 811 Confidential Names and appeal rights were provided to Mariam Mott.
investigation_findings: 13On 08/03/22 at 11:28 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Torres conducted a subsequent complaint inspection for the purpose of delivering the investigative finding to the allegations listed above. The LPA met with Mariam Mott, Clinical Director. The LPA received verbal authorization from Anasheh Safarian for Mariam to sign for this report. On 07/02/21, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging facility staff would cook food and leave it out on the counter for the entire day and evening, staff told a client to shut up and called the client ghetto, the facility Administrator, Anasheh Safarain, is not at the facility 20 hours a week, staff members do not receive the "required outside training hours" and multiple staff who supervised the clients in the swimming pool did not have water safety certificates and the bathroom trash was overflowing and there were dirty counters and floors. *** Continued on next page ***

deficiencies.description:
80076(a)(14) Food Services. All foods ...which can cause food infections or food intoxications shall be stored in covered containers at 45 degrees F  (7.2 degrees C) or less.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Dinner was prepared and placed on the kitchen counter or on top of the dryer by 3:30 p.m. The food would not be refrigerated and left out overnight. 
This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility relinquished their license and was closed effective 03/05/22. Same as above.

deficiencies.description:
87072(c)(10) Personal Rights. Licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal right: dignity in *their* personal relationships with staff and other persons. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: S1 told C1 to shut up and called C1, "Ghetto." 

This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: S1 is still employed as a chef with the licensee's open facility. S1 is no longer providing direct care and has very limited and supervised contact with the clients. Personal Rights training will be provided to S1. Proof of completed training will be sent to LPA Torres by 09/02/22. Same as above.

deficiencies.description:
87064(b)(1) Administrator Qualifications and Duties. The administrator shall be on the premises for a minimum of 20 hours per week to manage and administer...with applicable law and regulation. 
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: S3 was not on the facility premises each week. It was reported S3 was the administrator on paper only. S3's work was performed at the licensee's corporate office. 
This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility relinquished their license and was closed effective 03/05/22. Same as above.

deficiencies.description: 80065(e)(2) Personnel Requirements. Adults who supervise while clients are using a pool or other body of water from which rescue requires the rescuer's ability to swim, shall have a valid water safety certificate. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Staff who supervised the clients in the facility swimming pool in May and June of 2021 did not have water safety certificates. No proof was provided for S1 and S6. The proof for S2 was dated 07/15/21. This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility relinquished their license and was closed effective 03/05/22. Same as above.

deficiencies.description:
80087(a) Buildings and Grounds. The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: When the morning staff reported to work, the facility was dirty on a weekly basis. The trash was not taken out, the kitchen, living room and the clients’ rooms were dirty.

This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility relinquished their license and was closed effective 03/05/22. Same as above.

narrative: (C1) was observed with a hicky and notes C1 participated in sexualized behavior. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute this was a consensual interaction, or that this was the incident resulting in the allegation of sexual abuse. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute the allegation. An additional allegation was received by CCL, alleging staff purchased drugs for minors while in care. No specific information regarding which staff or which minors were involved in this allegation was provided. Record review and confidential interviews were unable to provide evidence confirming or disputing this allegation. Two additional allegations were received by CCL alleging minors are not allowed to leave the home and staff demonstrate inappropriate forms of punishment. Specifically it was reported staff did not let any of the minors leave the home and staff refused to allow (child #1 [C1]) to leave the facility to purchase hygiene supplies as a form of punishment for not attending class. Record review and confidential interviews reported that none of the residents had community passes approved by their County Social Workers at the time of the allegation. Confidential interviews reported the facility provided hygiene products for the residents and if the residents wanted to purchase special items staff would take them and accompany them to the store. Confidential interviews could not confirm, or dispute minors were not allowed to leave the home and staff refused to allow C1 to leave the facility as a form of punishment. An additional allegation alleging staff do not ensure the minors are properly fed while in care was also received by CCL. Specifically it was reported that food is not satisfactory, and the good food was locked up. Confidential interviews reported that the minors wanted more of the unhealthy fast food type of meals and would complain about what the chef had made for dinner. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute the allegation. Based on record review and confidential interviews the minors are sexually abused while in care, staff purchased drugs for minors while in care, minors are not allowed to leave the home, staff demonstrate inappropriate forms of punishment, and staff do not ensure the minors are properly fed while in care, may or may not have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights to Andrea "Dre" Carmona.
investigation_findings: 13On October 13, 2022 at 2:00 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, arrived at the facility to deliver findings for the above allegations. LPA previously spoke with and received emailed permission from Vera’s Sanctuary 1 Administrator, Anasheh Safarian to meet with Andrea "Dre" Carmona and for "Dre" to accept and sign reports on behalf of Vera's Sanctuary 1. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility on September 28, 2021 at approximately 11:00 am and no immediate deficiencies were observed. The investigation included interviews with three staff (Staff #1 [S1], Staff #2 [S2], Staff #3 [S3]), four foster youth (Child #1 [C1], Child #2 [C2], Child #3 [C3], and Child #4 [C4]). In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On September 20, 2021, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging minors are sexually abused while in care. No specific information regarding which staff or which minors were involved in this allegation was provided. Record review revealed a Serious Incident Report dated 9/16/2021 noted Child #1 ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

narrative: Mena obtained conflicting information during interviews. Confidential interviews denied that any inappropriate sexual behavior had taken place between C1 and Child # 2 (C2). Confidential interviews also denied that staff did not fulfill reporting requirements or that S1 had engaged in an inappropriate relationship with C1. According to confidential interviews, S1’s relationship with C1 was more of an older sibling or mother-daughter relationship. Confidential interviews also stated that although C1 had gained access to a knife and alcohol on separate occasions, it was not due to a lack of supervision, but due to C1 smuggling in contraband without staff’s knowledge and C1 having taken or stolen key from staff where knives were stored. While other confidential information received by Licensing Office stated that these allegations had occurred. LPA Mena was unable to conduct a follow-up interview with Child # 1 (C1), due to C1’s current whereabouts being unknown. There were no other known witnesses to these allegations. Based on confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, the allegations that Child # 1 had access to alcohol and sharp object, and that facility staff did not fulfil reporting requirements, did not prevent inappropriate sexual behavior between clients while in care, and that Staff # 1 (S1) had engaged in an inappropriate relationship with C1, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena met with Program Director, Andrea Carmona to discuss the investigative findings for the above stated allegations. LPAs Cheraki Davis and Daniel Mena conducted an inspection to the facility on December 13, 2021 at 9:00am and on May 12, 2021 at 11:21am. No immediate hazards observed. Special Investigator (SI), Charlotte Jackson and LPA Mena interviewed five Staff (S1, S2, S3, S4 & S8), two foster children (C1 & C2), County Social Worker (CSW), Probation Officer (PO), Facility Administrator (AD), as well as reviewed police, client and facility records. Community Care Licensing received information on December 07, 2021 alleging that Child # 1 had access to alcohol, as well as a sharp object. Allegation also claimed that facility staff did not fulfil reporting requirements, did not prevent inappropriate sexual behavior between clients while in care, and that Staff # 1 (S1) had engaged in an inappropriate relationship with C1. Information obtained in confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegation with a preponderance of evidence. IB investigator and LPA

narrative: (**Continued from LIC 9099**) Additionally, two staff members (S1, S3) could not be reached for an interview after multiple attempts made by LPA Urena for an interview. Due to an absence without leave (AWOL) status C1 could not be reached for comment regarding the allegations. During investigation, a confidential interview could not provide details about the allegations involving C1, and S1 due to being hired after C1 left the facility and due to little interaction with S1. Confidential interview further stated that some clients did smoke while in care and smoked outside of the facility premises, which was against the program’s rules. Confidential interview denied hearing anything about S1 or C1 that pertained to the allegations. Additionally, S1, S3 and C1 could not be reached for comment. There were no other known witnesses to the allegations. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegations. Based on confidential interview and record review the allegation that a staff member took C1 to a smoking establishment, C1 smoked in the presence of staff members, staff members gave C1 a smoking device, and S1 inappropriately touched C1, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights will be emailed to Administrator, Anasheh Safarian. Copies of the original signatures will be placed with the complaint file.
investigation_findings: 13On May 2, 2023, at 1:06 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena spoke with Vera’s Sanctuary I Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Administrator, Anasheh Safarian to deliver the investigative finding of the above stated allegations. narrative:
On September 15, 2020, at 12:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ann Valenzuela conducted a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) pre licensing inspection. LPA met with Executive Director, Lauri Burns. The facility is a single-story residential building with five bedrooms, three client bathrooms, staff office with a staff restroom, kitchen, dining area, laundry area with a washer and dryer, living room, family room and a group room to conduct group therapy. There is a two-car garage that is attached and used for back up storage and extra refrigerators. The staff office is where the facility stores personnel files, client files, and medications, sharps and funds that are stored within a locked cabinet. The office is kept locked when not in use and is only accessible to the facility staff. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris, observable hazards, and insects. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports/workout equipment, and televisions were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and were observed to be in working order; fire extinguishers were properly charged and serviced. The following required forms were posted in the facility: Weekly Menu, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Each of the five client bedrooms has proper lighting, adequate drawer space, all six beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water was tested and measured to be 114 degrees Fahrenheit which is in the required range of 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and a current first aid manual approved by the American Red Cross. SEE PAGE 2

Per Executive Director, no firearms or weapons are kept or allowed in the facility and smoking is prohibited. Licensee has previously been accredited through the Joint Commission, and once the facility is licensed the licensee will notify the commission to make them aware of the program change to update the certification. Current staff have caregiver background checks and have received criminal record and child abuse index clearance. LPA discussed the following with facility staff: Facility manager requirements, and AB388 requirements. Executive Director, Lauri Burns was advised that this pre-licensing report will be reviewed by the Department. The facility will be notified once they are provisionally licensed as a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). An exit interview was conducted with Executive Director, Lauri Burns and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility for signature. The original signed report will be in the facility file.

On October 8, 2020 at 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced inspection of the Vera Sanctuary I Short Term Residential Facility to verify the employment status of the individual (E1) identified on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated 10/08/2020. LPA met with Administrator, Christina Webb. The department received an Exemption Denial and Confirmation of Removal from the Caregiver Background Check Bureau (CBCB) on E1. Based on the evidence obtained during today's inspection, the LPA verified the individual is not present, employed or residing at the facility. LPA has advised the Licensee to disassociate the individual from their roster and submitted an updated LIC 500. Verification of removal is complete. A copy of this report was reviewed with and emailed to Christina Webb for signature, along with the LIC 811.

narrative: On the above date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Residential Services Supervisor Katy Miller regarding Special Incident Reports (SIR) that were submitted to Community Care Licensing. The incidents took place on 05/13/2024 and 05/19/2024, and the SIRs were written to report incidents regarding staff utilizing prone restraints. LPA Bertoli inspected the facility and then discussed the incidents with Supervisor Miller. In the course of reviewing the incidents, Supervisor Miller stated that staff had engaged in prone restraints. Facility was given a Technical Advisory for ILS Version 5 Section 87095.01(a)(4) Emergency Interventions Prohibition. Based on records reviewed and interviews conducted on 06/10/2024, staff was found to have used prone restraints on the youth. The facility was also advised that their Program Statement would need to be revised for all their STRTP facilities to not allow prone restraints, and that staff needs to immediately be informed and re-trained so as not to utilize prone restraints. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joel Segura and Cheyenne McCambridge conducted an announced psychotropic medication inspection of the facility. LPA Segura and McCambridge met with Danielle Stewart who facilitated the tour of the facility, inside and out. The group home is licensed to serve eight clients, children and non-minor dependents. Currently in placement are eight clients. There were no clients present during the initial inspection of the facility. There were only two clients who are subject to this inspection. The facility's buildings and grounds appeared to be in compliance, and no deficiencies were observed during the inspection of the grounds. The inspection of the grounds took place at approximately 9:15am. At 9:30am LPAs Segura and McCambridge conducted a review of two client files. In the course of conducting the file reviews LPAs also interviewed direct care staff Bruno Llerena due to availability later in the day. At approximately 11am LPAs conducted a medication count inspection with medical coordinator Debbie Thompson. In the course of conducting the medication count inspection LPAs found that the facility PMARs have a documentation conflict. The facility's practice is to have a weekly PMAR; however, the week begins at the after school dispensing window in the middle of the day. Continued on 809C

The facility uses a PMAR printed and dated by the pharmacy. For C2 (C2, Client 2 see confidential names list LIC811 dated 08/17/2021) LPA found that the PMAR was dated for the week of 08/12-08/18 with columns labeled for the days of the week starting with Thursday through Wednesday. Medical coordinator indicated that since the medication weekly packs start effectively during the after school dosage, they end up documenting the last AM medication administered on Thursday the 19th on the space that corresponds for Thursday the 12th. The facility was advised to consider revising PMAR, see advisory note. At around 11:45pm LPA Segura conducted an interview with medical coordinator Debbie Thompson. Shortly after at approximately 12:30 an interview was also conducted with administrator Kristine Martinez. Staff file reviews were conducted by LPAs at around 12:30pm. No deficienceies were found during this inspection. There were no deficiencies noted at today's evaluation. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with the administrator Kristine Martinez.

deficiencies.description:
Health Related
Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions ofthe physician prescribing the medication and as authorized by the juvenile court order or parental authorization form. Based on interviews with staff and review of associated SIRS, the facility failed to meet this requirement. A client was accidentally given an overdose of her psychotropic medication.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES
narrative:
It was reported that on 05/05/2020, C1 was escorted and put into a safety hold due to C1 allegedly assaulting staff. Interviews revealed that C1 had a glue in his hand and S1 suspected C1 was going to use the glue for substance abuse which was what lead to the initial escort conducted on C1. It was informed to LPA that S1 was verbally prompting C1 to give the glue but C1 refused. Documentation and interviews revealed that C1 was put in an escort safe hold position in the hallway and it continued to inside of the restroom. S1 denied the allegation. Video footage dated 05/05/2020, LPA observed the following: At 00:17, S1 can be seen following C1. At 01:33 S1 and S2 can be seen conducting the escort position on C1 while C2 is watching the incident and C3 can be seen passing by. LPA did not observe physical aggression or assault from C1 towards staff during this time frame. LPA observed C1 in the escort position but LPA was only able to see S1 outside of the doorway of the restroom and a part of C1’s head; however, at 02:03, LPA observed there was a struggle that lead to S1, S2 and C1 inside the bathroom where it was not visible to the camera’s angle. At 02:09, C2 and C3 was watching what was taking place inside the restroom. At 05:08, S1 can be seen walking out of the bathroom and another staff comes into the bathroom which is S5. S3 came at the end and did not observe the incident. At 10:30, C1 was observed walking out of the restroom. It was reported that C1 refused nursing assessment. It was also reported that C1 called the police. Facility’s Internal investigation revealed that C1 indicated he was thinking about using the glue to huff because he was upset that he did not have access to any other substances. CFT Notes and Needs and Services Plan confirmed that C1 does have a history of severe substance use behavior; however, C1 denied wanting to use the glue as a substance. S4 indicated that she observe C1 sniffing the glue and that was when she asked for S1 and S2 to help assist. Interviews revealed that C1 was pouring glue on the floor. C1, C2, C3 and S1 confirmed that C1 was not observed being assaultive with S1 initially. Interviews revealed that C1 did try to get out of the escort hold and there was a struggle in the restroom. LPA could not determine if in fact C1 was extremely aggressive and swinging at staff due to inconsistent statements and no visibility on what occurred inside of the restroom. It was reported that C1 was kicking and scratching staff, C1, C2 and C3 denied this allegation. Emergency Intervention debriefing for C1 asked C1 the question of how were you in danger to yourself and/or others? It was written on the document that C1 indicated he started swinging at staff, yelling and getting aggressive. C1 denies putting hands on staff. Confidential interviews could not confirm if S1 pushed C1 but confirmed that a restraint was conducted. Continue on 9099-C

LPA could not confirm if C1 met the requirements of the initial escort due to inconsistent statements of C1 getting physically assaultive with staff or C1 possibly using the glue as a substance being the reason why C1 was put in an escort position. Per supportive evidence, it was revealed that on 05/27/2020, C1 was interviewed and marks or bruises were not observed on C1. Documentation confirmed that redness was observed on C1 but no injuries to report. Furthermore, on 05/27/2020, S1 resigned from the facility. Although S1 recollection of events could not be obtained by LPA, facility's UOR, Post restraint debriefing, and internal investigation revealed that S1 escorted C1 due to C1’s assaultive behavior which LPA did not observe assaultive behavior from C1 that took place outside of the restroom; in addition, LPA could not confirm what occurred inside of the restroom. Witness statements revealed that C1 did not appear to be in pain; however, it was reported that C1 had pain to his right ribcage and visible contusion to his left biceps and right shoulder blade. On 06/02/2020 an email from RP indicated that it was informed to the RP staff grabbed C1 by the arm causing bruising on his arm. LPA could not confirm if C1 was observed with marks or bruises on his ribcage by the RP due to RP being unable to recall if there was any redness or bruising to C1’s rib cage and what was said by staff. RP did recall seeing some redness on one of C1’s arms but can’t recall exactly which arm. Additionally, RP indicated that the subject’s injuries and statements made by staff should be documented in RP’s initial report; LPA was unable to obtain the Police Report at this time but if additional information. At this time, should additionally information be available, this case may be re-open for further investigation. LPA could not confirm if C1 obtained possible marks and bruises due to S1’s escort/ alleged pushing or during the process of C1 struggling trying to get out of the hold. Based on the information obtained during confidential interviews and inconsistent statements, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of the report will be emailed at the facility.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES
narrative: Confidential interviews revealed that staff would follow facility’s Early Intervention Plan by using early intervention techniques with C1 to try to convince C1 to not AWOL. This includes encouraging C1 to stay and reminding C1 of the dangers of AWOLing. Additionally, Staff would follow C1 until they lose site of C1 than make the calls to the authorized representative, Law Enforcement, the Child Abuse Hotline and submit a Special Incident Report. Furthermore, the reported incident occurred while C1 was on AWOL and per interviews, staff followed their emergency intervention plan to try to prevent C1 from AWOLing. LPA could not determine if Staff did not prevent minor from participating in inappropriate behavior due to the incident occurring when C1 was on AWOL status and Interview statements indicating that staff followed AWOL procedures. In addition, per CFT notes and C1’s Safety Plan, facility had a safety plan for C1 in efforts to decrease C1’s unsafe behavior. Based on the information obtained during confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of the report will be emailed to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On December 18, 2020 at 2:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted a follow-up complaint tele-visit for Vista Del Mar STRTP and spoke to Unit Supervisor Suzie Jeon. It was reported that C1 called Law Enforcement to report that she was kidnapped. It was reported that C1 AWOLed from the facility and an inappropriate encounter occurred while C1 was on AWOL.
