Continue 9099-C

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES
narrative:
S1 and S2’s ProAct Certifications; and S1’s Resignation Letter. It was reported that on 05/05/2020, C1 was escorted and put into a safety hold due to C1 allegedly assaulting staff. Interviews revealed that C1 had a glue in his hand and S1 suspected C1 was going to use the glue for substance abuse which was what lead to the initial escort conducted on C1. It was informed to LPA Yem that S1 was verbally prompting C1 to give the glue but C1 refused. Documentation and interviews revealed that C1 was put in an escort safe hold position in the hallway and it continued to inside of the restroom. S1 denied the allegation. Video footage dated 05/05/2020, LPA Yem observed the following: At 00:17, S1 can be seen following C1. At 01:33 S1 and S2 can be seen conducting the escort position on C1 while C2 is watching the incident and C3 can be seen passing by. LPA did not observe physical aggression or assault from C1 towards staff during this time frame. LPA observed C1 in the escort position but LPA was only able to see S1 outside of the doorway of the restroom and a part of C1’s head; however, at 02:03, LPA Yem observed there was a struggle that lead to S1, S2 and C1 inside the bathroom where it was not visible to the camera’s angle. At 02:09, C2 and C3 was watching what was taking place inside the restroom. At 05:08, S1 can be seen walking out of the bathroom and another staff comes into the bathroom which is S5. S3 came at the end and did not observe the incident. At 10:30, C1 was observed walking out of the restroom. It was reported that C1 refused nursing assessment. It was also reported that C1 called the police. Facility’s Internal investigation revealed that C1 indicated he was thinking about using the glue to huff because he was upset that he did not have access to any other substances. CFT Notes and Needs and Services Plan confirmed that C1 does have a history of severe substance use behavior; however, C1 denied wanting to use the glue as a substance. S4 indicated that she observed C1 sniffing the glue and that was when she asked for S1 and S2 to help assist. Interviews revealed that C1 was pouring glue on the floor. C1, C2, C3 and S1 confirmed that C1 was not observed being assaultive with S1 initially. Interviews revealed that C1 did try to get out of the escort hold and there was a struggle in the restroom. LPA could not determine if in fact C1 was extremely aggressive and swinging at staff due to inconsistent statements and no visibility on what occurred inside of the restroom. It was reported that C1 was kicking and scratching staff, C1, C2 and C3 denied this allegation. Report Cont. on LIC 9099-C.

Emergency Intervention debriefing for C1 asked C1 the question of how were you in danger to yourself and/or others? It was written on the document that C1 indicated he started swinging at staff, yelling and getting aggressive. C1 denies putting hands on staff. Confidential interviews could not confirm if S1 pushed C1 but confirmed that a restraint was conducted. LPA Yem could not confirm if C1 met the requirements of the initial escort due to inconsistent statements of C1 getting physically assaultive with staff or C1 possibly using the glue as a substance being the reason why C1 was put in an escort position. Per supportive evidence, it was revealed that on 05/27/2020, C1 was interviewed and marks or bruises were not observed on C1. Documentation confirmed that redness was observed on C1 but no injuries to report. Furthermore, on 05/27/2020, S1 resigned from the facility. Although S1 recollection of events could not be obtained by LPA, facility's UIR, Post restraint debriefing, and internal investigation revealed that S1 escorted C1 due to C1’s assaultive behavior which LPA did not observe assaultive behavior from C1 that took place outside of the restroom; in addition, LPA could not confirm what occurred inside of the restroom. Witness statements revealed that C1 did not appear to be in pain; however, it was reported that C1 had pain to his right ribcage and visible contusion to his left biceps and right shoulder blade. On 06/02/2020 an email from RP indicated that it was informed to the RP staff grabbed C1 by the arm causing bruising on his arm. LPA Yem could not confirm if C1 was observed with marks or bruises on his ribcage by the RP due to RP being unable to recall if there was any redness or bruising to C1’s rib cage and what was said by staff. RP did recall seeing some redness on one of C1’s arms but can’t recall exactly which arm. Additionally, RP indicated that the subject’s injuries and statements made by staff should be documented in RP’s initial report. Lastly, the Department received a copy of the Police Report which provided additional information for the complaint investigation. The Police Report indicated that C1 did indeed obtain injuries from the restraint to his left arm and right shoulder blade as there were bruises noticed by the Police Officers. Based on the confidential interviews conducted and documentary evidence obtained during the investigation the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. Per the Interim Licensing Standards for STRTP V 3.1 Section 87095.00 (c) (2) for the following deficiency was cited at the time of this visit. (See LIC9099-D) A copy of the report will be emailed to the facility for signature due to COVID-19 restrictions.

deficiencies.description: (c) Short-term residential therapeutic program staff may be justified in using restraints as an emergency intervention if all of the following conditions are met: (2) The force used does not exceed that reasonably necessary to avert the injury or danger. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on the documentary evidence obtained it was confirmed that C1 did indeed obtain injuries from the restraint to his left arm and right shoulder blade as there were bruises noticed which poses an immediate Health, Safety, Personal Rights risk to the children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Unit Supervisor will submit a written statement to the Department indicating when and how often staff will obtain training on the use of restraints by April 19, 2021.

investigation_findings: 13On May 13, 2021, Regina Martin, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) spoke with Susie Jeon Facility Director for the purpose of delivering complaint findings. The above-mentioned allegations were investigated by the California Department of Social Services (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Bureau, Investigator Robert Kujawa. On January 19, 2021, CCLD received a complaint investigation alleging child engaged in self-injurious behavior while in care and child was allowed access to hazardous items. Information obtained during the investigation including interviews and Incident Reports did not provide enough evidence to support allegations. Child #1 indicated that while AWOL (absent without permission) he would get multiple items he could use to self-harm. Child #1 also indicated that he was given a pencil sharpener to use by Staff #1 and used the blades to self-harm. Staff #1 denied that she provided Child #1 with a pencil sharpener. Staff #1 indicated that Child #1 was under continuous watch due to his history of self-harming. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES
narrative:
On _08/24/2021 at _9:15 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips & Meghan McGee made an unannounced visit to Vista Del Mar Family Services for the purpose of an Annual/Required Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Amy Jaffe Administrator and conducted a tour of the facility. There are currently nineteen (19) children placed in the facility. The program accepts clients from Department of Children & Family Services, Dept. of Probation and Private Placement's, and school district funded placement. This STRTP is licensed to serve 24 children ages 12-17 years of age, ambulatory only. This facility will also provide care to non-minor dependents. The facility has cameras that monitors both cottages/wings (Handler #1 and #2), living room, the rotunda room (also known as the lobby), and kitchen. The facility is located in a residential area with three cottages/wings, 18 bedrooms, several bathrooms, kitchen/dining room, 2 laundry rooms, and one clinician offices in each unit (three in total). Handler #1 is designated for the co-ed wing with boys and girls. Handler #2 is designated for the girls. The third wing is the administrative wing with offices for the administrators, clinician and all other staff. There was adequate closet and storage space for the clients. There are washers and dryers that were operable in Handler #1 and Handler #2. Handler #1- 4 Bedrooms with 2 twin beds, with closet space, and desks. 5 Bedrooms has 1 single bed, and with closet space and desks. Handler #2- 4 Bedrooms with 2 twin beds, has closet space, and desks. 5 Bedrooms with 1 twin size bed, with closet space, and desks. Overall, the facility appeared clean, safe and sanitary. The building is in good repair. The Facility has Offices for the Administrator, Clinician and other staff. All beds are in good repair. Each client has adequate closet and ample clothing. Each client has complete sets of towels, sheets, blankets and bedspreads. There is adequate hygiene and grooming supplies in both Handler #1 and #2. The kitchen is sanitary and in good repair. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair.

LPA observed one-week supply of non-perishable and two days of perishable foods, including nutritious snacks. All prescribed medications are locked and centrally stored in the Health Center; Medications are accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. No firearms or weapons are present in the facility. Medications and cleaning supplies are kept locked. The first aid kit is fully stocked. The hot water temperature is within the mandated range. The home is equipped with a fire alarm system; smoke alarm/carbon monoxide detector and verified that the fire clearance was inspected and found to be in compliance with the fire code. All fire extinguishers are charged. There are working telephone service for client's personal use. All trash cans have tight-fitting lids. All exits are free of hazards and all doors open freely. Facility posts child's rights if licensed to provide for six or more children. Clients in care are supervised and protected at all times. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA Phillips will return at a later date to review staff and client records and staff and client Interviews. No deficiencies were sited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and report was provided to facility administrator.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES
narrative:
On June 24, 2022@ 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips conducted a Case - Management inspection visit. LPA Phillips met with Jimmy Tyler to discuss the video footage of an incident on 02/15/2022, SIR # 797766. Brief Summary: On February 16,2022 , Community Care Licensing received an incident report for 02/15/2022 reporting restraint of Child #1 by Staff #3 & Staff #4 . LPA Phillips obtained video footage of the incident and observed Staff #3 initiate a a Pro Act restraint by grasping Child #1's left arm and pushed toward wall. LPA Phillips observed Staff # 4 grasp Child #1 right arm to begin wall restraint. During the investigation LPA Phillips conducted confidential interview, reviewed facility Pro Act certificates and video footage. Requested copies of Pro Act trainers current certification. Based on gathered information there is corroborating evidence that reveals Child #1 was improperly restrained by Staff # 3. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has therefore determined the facility is cited for violating Child #1's personal rights. cont on 809c .

the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has therefore determined substantiated findings for violation of personal rights by Staff #3 on Child #1 as evidence revealed Staff # 3 failed to perform correct Pro Act Restraint on Child #1. Staff #3s actions on Child #1 poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care. The facility is issued a citation in accordance with the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 1; 80072 (a)(3) Personal Rights. See page 809D for deficiencies Exit interview conducted; Appeal Rights issued, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Administrator.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara, Licensing Program Analyst Dahl Larios, and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection 11/08/22 at 9:30 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 7 out of 29 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 17 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 29 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 17 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 11/08/2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the Needs and Service assessments, Quarterly Report, and Family Safety and Crisis Plan, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. Licensing Program Manager Angela King observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Maricela Morales, Quality Assurance & Electronic Health Records System Manager.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES
narrative:
On November 29, 2022 at 11:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made an announced visit to STRTP for the purpose of conducting a Case Management, (Licensee Initiated). LPA met with Amy Jaffe, Administrator who granted access to the facility and together with LPA Phillips, a tour was conducted. The purpose of this visit is licensee is requesting a change, reducing capacity from twenty-four (24) to a capacity of sixteen (16) children. The facility is currently licensed to provide care and supervision for twenty (24) children, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only. There is a gated pool on the premises. Naloxone Hydrochloride waiver is on file. The census on the date of this visit is seventeen (17). Facility administrator reported to LPA Phillips there are currently three (3) discharges pending. The facility has cameras that monitors both cottages/wings (Handler #1 and #2), living room, the rotunda room (also known as the lobby), and kitchen. The facility is located in a residential area with three cottages/wings, 18 bedrooms, several bathrooms, kitchen/dining room, 2 laundry rooms, and one clinician offices in each unit (three in total). Handler #1 is designated for the co-ed wing with boys and girls. Handler #2 is designated for the girls. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials were observed. There are no firearms or weapons located at the facility. facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES
narrative:
On 07/25/202 @ 8:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips made an unannounced visit to Vista Del Mar Family Services for the purpose of an Annual Required Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Alma Marquez/Supervisor and conducted a tour of the facility. There are currently fifteen (15) children placed in the facility. This STRTP is licensed to serve 16 children ages 12-17 years of age, ambulatory only. This facility will also provide care to non-minor dependents. The facility has cameras that monitors both cottages/wings (Handler #1 and #2), living room, the rotunda room (also known as the lobby), and kitchen. The facility is located in a residential area with three cottages/wings, 18 bedrooms, several bathrooms, kitchen/dining room, 2 laundry rooms, and one clinician offices in each unit (three in total). Handler #1 is designated for the co-ed wing with boys and girls. Handler #2 is designated for the girls. The third wing is the administrative wing with offices for the administrators, clinician and all other staff. There was adequate closet and storage space for the clients. There are washers and dryers that were operable in Handler #1 and Handler #2 Handler #1- 8 Bedrooms with 1 twin bed, with closet space, and desks. Bedroom with 1 twin bed, and with closet space and desk currently not occupied. Handler #2- 8 Bedrooms with 1 twin bed, has closet space, and desks. 1 Bedroom with 1 twin size bed, with closet space, and desk currently not occupied. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility is clean, safe, and sanitary All beds are in good repair. Each client has adequate closet and ample clothing. Each client has complete sets of towels, sheets, blankets and bedspreads. There is adequate hygiene and grooming supplies in both Handler #1 and #2. The kitchen is sanitary and in good repair. cont on 809c

LPA reviewed the following during the inspection: Five (5) staff records review; the information regarding the Emergency Preparedness. LPA reviewed Criminal Records and confirmed that all current and former staff were also cleared. LPA reviewed The Administrator, Social Worker and Direct Care staff records. LPA reviewed the facility binder that included specific training's. Specific Training's include the following: Policies & Procedures; Health & Safety: Emergency Procedures: Medication; Trauma-Informed Care; Boundaries; Job Duties; and information about the Stakeholders. LPA observed one week supply of non-perishable and two days of perishable foods, including nutritious snacks. All prescribed medications are locked and centrally stored in the Health Center; Medications are accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. No firearms or weapons are present in the facility. Medications and cleaning supplies are kept locked. The first aid kit is fully stocked. The hot water temperature is within the mandated range. The home is equipped with a fire alarm system; smoke alarm/carbon monoxide detector. All fire extinguishers are charged. There are working telephone service for client's personal use. All trash cans have tight-fitting lids. All exits are free of hazards and all doors open freely. Facility posts child's rights if licensed to provide for six or more children. Clients in care are supervised and protected at all times. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Clients are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Clients live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Clients can contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsman person in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. The following documents or records are posted in the facility: facility license, complaint procedures, emergency disaster plan, facility sketch, menu, chores, house rules, children's personal rights. The following logs are maintained: daily log, awol log, visitors log, allowance log and fire drill log. cont on 809 c

LPA observed cracked window in Handler Unit Bedroom 4. LPA discussed with Administrator Amy Jaffe and was advised a work order ticket has been placed. Glass company will come on site to measure and repair window. Amy Jaffe advised work would take approximately two weeks and will send LPA a picture of completed work. LPA was advised maintenance staff will cover window with board to protect clients in care. The cracked window does not pose an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care. LPA was advised of the plan to repair window and Amy Jaffe will provide LPA with photos once work is completed. LPA will return to check facility vehicles and kitchen area. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at the time of the Annual Random Inspection. At the time of the inspection, the facility was clean and safe. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed Amy Jaffe.

facility_name: VISTA DEL MAR CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Raymond Canal, Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara, and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection on 11/2/23 at 12:00 pm based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 6 out of 26 Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 14 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 26 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 14 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 9/14/23). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, treatment plans, and safety plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPM King observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Amy Jaffe.

investigation_findings: 13This is an amended report from the original report dated 03/09/18. Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Esther Luna made an unannounced visit to the Vista Del Mar Child and Family Services or the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations and to deliver the findings. LPAs met with adminstrative assistant to discuss the findings. During the investigation process, it was determined that Staff #1 and Staff #2 use inappropriate restraint on client #1. LPA review video surveillance of the restraint on client #1, and observed staff #1 laying over the client #1 lower leg as a form of restraint. It was also observed, that staff #2 was sitting on client #1 leg during the restraint. LPA also observe staff #1 conducted a one hand restraint and pulled client #1 to a sitting position on the sofa by himself for a period of time until staff #2 arrived. (See confidential name list LIC 811 dated 03/05/2018). Meanwhile LPA was unable to obtain a statement from client #1 due to her awol and whereabouts are unknown. Through the course interviews LPA was able to conclude that the allegation of personal rights violation occurred. The department has concluded, based on the preponderance of evidence this investigation is substantiated- Continue on 9099D

deficiencies.description: 84300.1 (a) (8)	Techniques that can reasonably be expected to cause serious injuries to the child that require medical treatment provided by a health practitioner, licensed under Division 2 of the Business and Professions Code.  A health practitioner would include a physician, surgeon, osteopath, dentist, licensed nurse, optometrist, etc. Several staff use excessive and inappropriate restraint on client #1. by pulling the client on sitting position on the sofa and staff sat on the client’s leg during restraint.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee must submit a written letter explaining how they will ensure this incident won't re-occur and list a plan of action within 24 hours and emailed to LPA. Staff will need to be retrained on PRO-ACT within 30 days and a copy of the completion of training will be email directly to LPA. Licensee may request an extension with the LPA if training is not completed with the 30 days due 4/9/2018.

deficiencies.description: 80054(d) Penalties.  When a facility is cited for a deficiency and violates the same regulation subsection within a 12-month period, the facility shall be cited, and an immediate penalty assessment of $150 per cited violation shall be assessed for one day only; and thereafter, a penalty of $50 per day, per cited violation, be assessed until the deficiency is corrected.The facility was cited on 3/09/2018 due to staff conducting an inappropriate restraint.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: You will receive a bill by mail.

On 3/12/2025, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD), received a complaint alleging sexual abuse towards Youth (Y1) by an unidentified staff member while in care. The allegation was referred to CCLD Investigations Branch for assignment. Contacts and confidential interviews with the Reporting party, Facility Supervisor, Y1, Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS) Emergency Response Social Worker and review of related reports from the Department of Children and Family Services, revealed a lack of information to support the alleged sexual abuse. Youth has been removed as of 1pm on 5/31/23 and is being taken to San Francisco County. A copy of this report was provided at the conclusion of the inspection.

narrative: On March 13, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco met with Administrator, Aaron Holloway and Program Director, Brandi Boehme for the purpose of conducting a Case Management. The purpose of the inspection is to discuss two incidents dated 2/27/24, that indicated medication errors made by staff. LPA Tinoco reviewed incident reports from Wake Forest Facility (See LIC812 for details). LPA Tinoco discussed with Administrator the incidents. LPA highlighted the importance of administering medications appropriately. Administrator stated that there have been conversations with the staff responsible. Per Administrator, the errors were due to staff communication. Administrator will provide LPA with the training and conversations that have been conducted with staff by 03/20/24. The agency will bring on a nurse that will begin conducting audits and meeting with small groups of staff for a period of time to potentially reduce the errors. As a result of the incidents mentioned above, The Agency is being cited for the Interim Licensing Standards Section 87075(c) Health Related Services. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

On September 3, 2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, emailed the findings of the complaint investigation to Administrator, Carlene Logan. On May 11, 2020, Community Care Licensing Regional Office received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. The investigation included confidential interviews that consisted of, but were not limited to: Investigations Bureau (IB) Investigator Ruben Munoz interviewed Ref. #1 at the facility on May 21, 2020; LPA McGee interviewed the Administrator via telephone on May 21, 2020 and the County Social Worker (CSW) on September 3, 2020. The LPA obtained and reviewed the Needs and Services Plan. There were no reports for this incident. The investigation revealed that Ref. #1 denied the allegation and did not tell anyone that a staff at the facility sold Ref. #1 marijuana. The CSW revealed information that the allegation was made in order to get Ref. #1 into trouble. The CSW expressed no concerns with the care and supervision at the facility. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that an alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegations. A copy of this complaint along with the appeal rights were emailed to Ms. Logan.

narrative: On December 18, 2020 at 12:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted a Case Management (SB 484 Psychotropic Medications) tele-inspection of the facility via Microsoft Teams Meeting app. Remote "tele-inspections" of facilities are a part of Community Care Licensing Division’s emergency response to the spread of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). During this tele-inspection, LPA spoke with Tiffany Earnest, Facility Manager/In-house Social Worker and Samantha Combs, Facility Manager. All pertinent staff and client records were scanned and emailed to LPA Herring prior to the tele-inspection. Three out of 6 clients at the facility take psychotropic medications. LPA reviewed 2 staff records and 3 client records prior to the tele- inspection and continued review of records during the tele-inspection to obtain and/or clarify missing information. LPA inspected medications at 12:15 PM. LPA conducted a facility tour with Ms. Combs at 12:30 PM. LPA interviewed 2 staff members at approximately 12:45 PM. LPA interviewed 2 clients at approximately 1:05 PM. One of the three clients taking psychotropic medications ran away from the facility, therefore, LPA was unable to interview that client. LPA reviewed the facility's Plan of Operation with Ms. Earnest at approximately 1:30 PM. LPA provided Advisory Notes - Technical Assistance to the licensee. There were no deficiencies issued during the tele-inspection. LPA conducted an exit interview with Ms. Earnest at 1:50 PM. A copy of this licensing report was provided to the facility via email on 12/18/20 along with Confidential Names' list (LIC 811) and Advisory Notes (LIC 9102TA).

Information obtained from other confidential sources reported a complete body check couldn't have been done without the birth mother's approval because of the location where the bruises were reported. However, the minor was checked by his County Social Worker who stated she did not observe any signs of abuse. LPA has also learned the source of this complaint has a history of making allegations against facilities where his/her children are placed. Therefore, based on the information gathered through interviews and record review, there wasn't significant evidence to corroborate the allegation. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation. Therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted with Ms. Logan and a copy of this report was emailed for signature. There were no deficiencies cited during today's inspection.

The alleged victim was unable to participate in this interview process. The alleged victim has a one on one staff who dressed him for his family that stated there were minor didn't any bruises or marks on him. Another facility staff member who assisted the minor with his bath and dress the day after the facility received a call from ref.14 inquiring about the bruises minor.

narrative:
On 05/06/21 at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva conducted a Post-Licensing Tele-inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) as a result of COVID-19 related restrictions. LPA met with Administrator Carlene Logan and Facility Manager/In-House Social Worker Tiffany Earnest. The facility currently has a provisional STRTP license. The STRTP’s Mental Health Program Certification is pending approval. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) male ambulatory clients ages 10-17 and is also licensed to provide services to Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). There are six (6) clients currently in placement. PHYSICAL PLANT Overall, the facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The STRTP license, National Accreditation and Emergency Disaster Plan are posted in the facility. Passageways are unobstructed. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and other chemicals are kept locked in the garage and laundry room cabinets. Sharps and knives are kept inside a locked closet. Room temperature is maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperature does not exceed 120 degrees F. Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. The fire extinguishers throughout the facility are fully charged. Facility has a working telephone. First Aid kit is complete. All confidential files are in a locked cabinet inside the staff office. The facility has cameras installed in the common areas of the facility. There are no bodies of water in the facility. There are no firearms and ammunition in the facility CARE & SUPERVISION The staff to client ratio at the time of inspection was 3:6. Facility has non-perishable food for at least one week and perishable food for at least two days. Facility provides nutritious meals and snacks. Medications are centrally stored and locked in the hallway closet and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. The monthly menu is posted in the kitchen.

PERSONAL RIGHTS Children's Personal Rights are posted. Children live in a safe, healthy and comfortable home. Weekly activity calendar/schedule is posted. Children are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. Complaints information posters are posted in the facility. CLIENT RECORDS LPA reviewed three (3) client files. LPA reviewed Admission Agreements; health screenings; consent forms; weight records; ID and Emergency information; Needs and Services Plans; Immunization Records; TB test results; Safeguards for Cash Resources and Property/Valuables; and Personal Rights. Needs and Services Plan are assessed every 30 days and is updated as needed. STAFF RECORDS LPA reviewed three (3) staff records. LPA reviewed First Aid/CPR Certificates; fingerprint clearances, Child Abuse Index Checks; education verification, Personnel Records/Job Applications; health screenings; TB test results; Criminal Record Statement, Employee Rights, and annual training records. Facility staff meet qualifications and training requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the LIC809, LIC809C, LIC 858, and LIC 859 were provided to the above-mentioned facility representatives. There were no deficiencies cited during today’s tele-inspection.

Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged that staff are not treating a resident with dignity and staff encouraging residents to fight. Interviews conducted with C2-C4 denied the allegations of ever being mistreated or staff encouraging residents fight. Interview conducted with C2 stated that they recalled an incident with C1 being rude to Administrator and that C1 would talk down to others but stated they did not recall staff retaliating negatively to C1. Interviews conducted with S1-S4 had similar statements that they all received training in LGBTQI and did not recall seeing or hearing of any staff members not treating children with dignity or enticing children to fight. LPAs were unable to interview C1 due to C1 being reunited with biological family. LPA Mahecha and LPA Smith spoke with county social worker (CSW) who made similar statements in that C1 likes to be in control of situations and had challenges being in the home. However, LPAs obtained no specific information from interviews conducted of dates, times or occurrences of alleged allegations. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative via electronic mail. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

Additionally, LPA requested copies of any complaints made to staff from clients or C1 from January 2021 to present date. On 9/8/2021 LPA Mahecha reviewed documents received and interviews conducted.

The Department received a complaint alleging a client (C1) sustained bruising on his back. The bruises were reportedly observed on 7/15/21 during a visit. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with staff revealed C1 has a one on one staff. The duties of the one on one staff include assisting C1 with hygiene and getting dressed. Staff interviewed denied observing a bruise on C1’s lower back. Statements obtained from C1’s CSW indicated a follow up visit was conducted the day after the reported incident, 7/16/21. During the visit, CSW reported no bruises were observed on C1. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted did not provide corroborating evidence to support the allegation. Based on information obtained through interviews conducted and records reviewed the allegation is found Unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13An unannounced follow up complaint inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios on 11/12/21 at 11:35 AM. During the inspection LPA Larios met with Administrator Carlene Logan and delivered findings for the above mentioned complaint allegation. During the course of the investigation LPA Larios conducted interviews with three clients on 9/8/21, two staff on 11/1/21, two staff on11/2/21, three County Social Worker (CSW) on 11/1/21 and one CSW on 11/2/21. LPA Larios conducted a records review on 9/8/21 and obtained copies of the client roster, staff roster and contact information, shift logs, special incident reports and needs and services plans.

narrative: One alleged victim/client insisted being hit but could not recall why and if client sustained any injuries. The same alleged victim/client denied all the other personal rights allegations. Another alleged victim/client was not interviewed due to leaving placement and confidential records show that this client is AWOL. There were no witnesses found who can corroborate the allegations. Staff denied the allegations. Staff reported clients are redirected and not verbally or physically abused. One staff in charge denied any complaints or grievances from the alleged victim/clients. Staff in charge explained that inappropriate behavior by staff toward clients are not tolerated. No food or water is withheld from any client. Based on the above information, the allegations are closed as unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there was no preponderance of evidence found. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this signed report, the Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights forms were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during the inspection.
investigation_findings: 13On March 30, 2022 at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a complaint inspection at the facility to deliver the finding of the allegations. LPA met with the facility representative named above. The allegations were investigated by the undersigned LPA by conducting confidential interviews with current and former clients, staff and other related parties. LPA reviewed documents pertinent to the complaint investigation. The complaint alleged multiple personal rights violations. Three clients denied the allegations and explained that they did not experience or witness any physical altercation between the alleged victims/clients and any staff who work at the facility. Clients reported they are not talked to inappropriately by staff but are either counseled or redirected. Clients denied any staff withholding water from a client; clients can drink and eat when they want to, there is no permission needed from staff.

narrative: Staff denied the alleged allegations however further disclosed that in the past there have been some incidents where clients have been involved in physical altercations with one another, however, the staff is quick to get involved and separate clients. Staff indicated that they are always encouraging clients not to fight and advising them on other ways to communicate their feelings and or manage their stress by exercising, walking, or separating themselves from their direct environment. Staff providing mental health services met or exceeded the requirements required by the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards. Staff indicated that they work hand and hand with different agencies to provide the best treatment that benefits and helps their clients succeed. Information obtained from clients did not corroborate the above allegations and further disclosed that they felt safe and felt that they were receiving the care they needed furthermore clients stated that they had no concerns to their health and safety. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the STRTP Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On May 18, 2022, at 3:05 PM., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Winston Moroney, conducted a complaint inspection to the above Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Facility (STRTP) and met with the Facility Administrator Carlene Logan. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. On October 15, 2022, the California Department of Social Services Community Care Licensing Division received a complaint from Centralized Complaint and Information Bureau (CCIB) with the following allegations: Minors engaging in physical altercations, Staff encouraging physical altercations between minors in care, Unqualified staff facilitating mental health services and Facility unable to provide the level of care required by minors. The investigation of the above allegations was conducted by this LPA and it consisted of but not limited to a review of records, including the children’s needs and services plans, medical records, and interviews with 3 staff members on 11/2/21, 3 of 4 Clients (C1, C2, C3) on 11/2/21 (C4 declined to be interviewed), (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated May 18, 2022).

narrative: It was alleged that staff allow clients to smoke marijuana inside and outside of the facility. Three staff were interviewed, and all three staff denied the above allegation. There are six (6) clients placed at the facility, all six (6) clients denied the above allegation and stated that they have never witnessed staff allowing clients to smoke marijuana. It was also alleged that staff did not treat clients with dignity. It was alleged that staff threatens clients and uses profanity towards clients. Three staff denied the above allegation. All six (6) clients denied the above allegation and stated that they have never witnessed staff using profanity or threatening clients. It was alleged that staff illegally evicted client. It was alleged that staff denied clients re-entry into the facility due to Covid-19 after awoling. Three staff denied the above allegation. All three staff stated that clients are allowed back into after awoling and that clients are not denied entry the facility. All six (6) clients denied the above allegation and stated that staff allows them to enter the facility after awoling. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report as well as the LIC 811 was provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On June 15, 2022 at 11:10 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Timika Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegations listed above. LPA Martin met with the facility representative named above and discussed the findings. During the investigation, LPA Timika Martin conducted a record review on 4/29/22 and obtained copies of client’s needs and services plan (NSP’s) and special incident reports (SIR’s). LPA also requested copies of the LIC 500, staff contact information, staff trainings and protocols on clients returning to the facility after AWOL status. Confidential interviews were conducted by LPA Martin with Administrator and Staff 1 (S1) on 5/11/22; Staff 2 (S2), Client 1 (C1), Client 2 (C2), Client (3), Client 4 (C4), Client 5 (C5), and Client 6 (C6) on 5/12/22 via telephone (See Confidential Names List Form LIC 811 dated June 15, 2022). LPA Martin was unable to interview Client 7 (C7) due to the child no longer placed at the facility. LPA Martin made multiple attempts to contact C7.

narrative: An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios on 6/24/22 at 1:05 PM. During the inspection LPA Larios met with Administrator Carlene Logan. The purpose of the inspection was to issue a citation for the facility failing to inform the Department regarding Law Enforcement (LE) contacts involving clients. LPA Larios conducted a review of a Client’s (C1) (See Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated 6/24/22) file at the facility on 1/14/22. LPA Larios observed two (2) Special Incident Reports (SIR) regarding C1 running away from the facility. On 1/31/22, the Department obtained seventeen (17) LE records regarding C1, most of which consisted of the facility notifying LE that C1 had run away. On 6/23/22 LPA Larios requested the facility provide all SIR regarding C1 running away. The facility provided two (2) additional SIR. Facility cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards 87061(j) Reporting Requirements. Record review confirms the facility failed to notify Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) of incidents regarding law enforcement contact and minors at the facility.

The Department received a complaint alleging facility staff are smoking marijuana with clients. Staff denied the allegation. The investigation revealed a client was asked where he obtained marijuana and responded with a smirk. The client did not verbalize facility staff smoke with clients. Confidential interviews conducted did not provide evidence to support the allegation and maintained staff do not provide clients with, or smoke, marijuana. The complaint alleged the facility was not providing 2:1 staff to client ratio for a client in care. It was reported the facility was required to provide the 2:1 ratio while Client (C1) was at school. Records review and statements obtained from an interview conducted with C1’s school administrator revealed a Child Family Team (CFT) meeting was held and the facility offered to provide two staff during school hours but, the school did not approve it. The complaint claimed the 2:1 ratio was not met due to C1 allegedly walking to school during the month of January 2022. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted revealed C1 was transported to school by the facility and did not walk. During an unannounced inspection to the facility on 5/12/22 LPA Larios observed C1, two clients and three staff, meeting the required ratio. The complaint further alleged Client (C2) was run away from January 2, 2022 until January 5, 2022. Record review and statements obtained from an interview conducted with C2’s CSW, and others, revealed the facility contacted Law Enforcement, CSW and the Department regarding the runaway as required by regulations. It was reported the facility declined to conduct a welfare check or send staff to retrieve C2. At the time of the runaway, per C2’s CSW, C2’s roommate tested positive for COVID-19 and C2 was unwilling to return to the facility to quarantine. CSW returned C2 to the facility. Based on information obtained through interviews conducted and records reviewed the allegations are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated 6/24/22 were given to the above-mentioned facility representative. No deficiencies were cited.
investigation_findings: An unannounced follow up complaint inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios on 6/24/22 at 12:40 PM. During the inspection LPA Larios met with Administrator Carlene Logan. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings for the above-mentioned complaint allegations. The complaint was investigated by Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Branch (IB) Investigator Maria Barragan and LPA Larios. During the course of the investigation Investigator Barragan conducted interviews with a school staff and a client on 1/19/22, a County Social Worker (CSW) on 1/31/22, a facility staff and two facility managers on 2/3/22, two clients, a facility administrator and two facility staff on 2/16/22, others on 1/19/22 and obtained Law Enforcement (LE) reports regarding the investigation on 1/31/22. Investigator attempted to interview a client on 2/2/22. LPA Larios conducted interviews with one CSW on 4/25/22, others on 5/9/22, one CSW and one Supervising CSW on 5/10/22, three clients and one school administrator on 5/12/22, one Facility Manager and one Adminstrator on 6/23/22 and others on 2/16/22. LPA Larios attempted to interview one client during May 2022. (CONTINUED)

narrative:
On December 6, 2022, at 9:50AM, an unannounced Senate Bill 484 (SB484) Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), at Walt's Home For Young Men Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Carlene Logan. LPA Flores conducted a tour inside and out of the facility at 10:10AM. No deficiency was found. LPA Flores conducted a review of 3 children’s file at 10:45AM. LPA Flores observed the following deficiencies: Child Ref #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 12/06/2022). - Medication Ref #1 (M1). The count is not accurate, is off by 3 pills for the month of November. C1 was in home pass for 10 days, but notations reflect only 3 days and they were made in the space for “Medications Not Administered”, instead of the spaces for “Home Visits”. - The Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) for November 2022, there is no date of prescription, quantity of medication and refills initially prescribed. This is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87070.

cont.#2 87070 CHILDREN’S RECORDS. (b) The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child’s record: (13) A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child documenting all of the following: (B) The date of the prescription. (C)The quantity of medication and number of refills initially prescribed. (D) When applicable, any additional refills prescribed. Child #2 (C2). - Medication Ref #2 (M2), in the Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) for November 2022, there is no date of prescription, quantity of medication and refills initially prescribed. This is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87070. - Medication Ref #3 (M3), in the Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) for November 2022, there is no date of prescription, quantity of medication and refills initially prescribed. This is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87070. - Medication Ref #4 (M4). There is no separate PMAR. 87070 CHILDREN’S RECORDS. (b) The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child’s record: (13) A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child documenting all of the following:

cont.#3 (B) The date of the prescription. (C) The quantity of medication and number of refills initially prescribed. (D) When applicable, any additional refills prescribed. Child Ref #3 (C3) - Medication Ref #7 (M7). Currently the child is not taking the mediation. There is no documentation in the child’s file to proof that the medication was discontinued. The child’s JV-223 states that the medication was authorized. - Medication Ref #8 (M8). Currently the child is not taking the mediation. There is no documentation in the child’s file to proof that the medication was discontinued. The child’s JV-223 states that the medication was authorized. - Medication Ref #7 (M9). The PMAR for the month of December 2022, there is no date of prescription, quantity of medication and refills initially prescribed. This is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4, Section 87070 (see above). - The night dosage for M9 for November 18, 21, 23 was not administered (pill is still in the bubble pack), but the PMAR states that these dosages were administered. No Special Incident Report (SIR) was submitted to Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD). - Medication Ref #9 (M9). Medication count is not accurate. The PMAR states that it was administer, but the pills are in the bubble pack for November 2, 21, 28, 29. No SIR was submitted to CCLD. - PMAR shows that on November 16/2022, child refused the medication for M10, but the pill is in the bubble pack, no SIR was submitted to CCLD. - There is no documentation in the child’s file to proof that M10 was authorized by the Court or a physician.

cont.#4 LPA Humberto Flores was unable to complete the psychotropic medication inspection on this date and will conduct another inspection where citations observed today will be issued. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the STRTP representative upon completion. Exit interview with STRTP representative at 5:00PM.

narrative: It was alleged that the facility staff is allowing the minors in care to smoke marijuana in the facility, are over-medicating minors in care, and speaking inappropriately to the youths in care. Information obtained from (S1, S2, and S3) denied the alleged allegations indicating that they have worked at the facility for several years and have never observed or heard of any staff member allowing any client in care to smoke anything at the facility. Staff further disclosed that in the past they have had clients that would AWOL after school or from the facility and would return to the facility smelling like marijuana. Staff indicated that upon returning to the facility from AWOL, clients are instructed to conduct a self-search to prevent any contraband from entering the facility. Staff denied knowing or observing any client being over-medicated or using the medication as a chemical restraint. Staff indicated that type of behavior will not be tolerated and will be handled accordingly. Staff further indicated that all medications are in the form of pill packs that are properly labeled and stored individually with each client’s medication logbook to prevent any confusion. As to the allegation of staff speaking inappropriately to minors in care, staff denied the allegation indicating that all staff members are trauma-informed and have a great relationship with the clients. Staff further disclosed that from time to time they (staff) have had to raise their voices with clients to redirect them or prevent physical altercations between clients. Information obtained from Clients (C1, C3, and C5) denied the alleged allegations further indicating that they have never seen or heard of any clients smoking anything at the facility, however, have observed clients returning to the facility after AWOLING smelling of marijuana. Clients denied knowing or hearing of anyone being over-medicated by staff. C1 indicated that their medication is given at certain times and gets logged by staff in the medication logbook. As to the allegation of staff speaking inappropriately to youth in care, clients denied the allegation further stating that the staff is very supportive and provide them with whatever is needed. Information obtained from County Social Workers (CSW’s) (CSW1, CCSW2, and CSW4) indicated that they don’t have any concerns about the care and supervision that the facility staff is providing their clients. CSWs further disclosed that staff maintains great communication with them and are quick to complete whatever is requested in a timely manner. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Facility Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the above staff member.

(No statements were obtained from C2 or C4 due to their declining to be interviewed). Three County Social Workers (CSW1, CSW2, and CSW4) on 10/26/22. (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated December 8, 2022).

LPA met with Melissa Rodriguez- Facility Manager. Buildings and grounds was initiated and due to time constraints a follow up visit to complete inspection is needed. Exit interview conducted

It was alleged the facility has video cameras throughout the facility that records audio too, which could pose a violation of the client’s personal rights. Information obtained from S1, and S2 indicated that the cameras were installed prior to them working with the facility and provide security to the clients and staff. S1 and S2 were unable to provide any incidents where the client’s privacy has been violated nor have the clients reported any such violations to them. S1 further disclosed that all cameras are visible and are only placed in the facility’s common areas and on the exterior of the facility. Information obtained from S3 indicated that the cameras were added to the facility due to a previous incident that had occurred involving a client attacking their Social Worker and cash missing from the staff office. Furthermore, an addendum to the facility Program Statement was made and approved by Community Care Licensing (CCL). S3 indicated that all video that is recorded is kept for forty-five days and discarded unless required during an investigation. As to the camera in the staff office if needed due to privacy concerns staff can disconnect the camera, however, the facility also provides a room where the Social Workers and clients can have a private conversation. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Facility Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the Facility Administrator.

narrative:
On 06/02/23 at 12:00 P.M., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) went to Walt's Home For Young Men to continue an unannounced annual inspection. LPA met with Carlene Logan-Administrator. On 06/02/23 at 12:00 P.M., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at the facility. LPA met with Carlene Logan-Administrator. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) ambulatory children ages 10-18 years of age. There are currently five (5) minors in placement. This facility is a 4-bedroom, two (2) bathroom, two (2) story home. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There are no ammunition and firearms in the facility. LPA conducted a walk-through of the entire facility. Physical Plant The license, facility sketch, Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster form, Complaints poster, Foster Youth Bill of Rights, Complaints/Grievance policy, emergency phone numbers and menus are posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and sharps are kept inaccessible. Facility has non-perishable food for at least one week and perishable food for at least two days. Medications are centrally stored in a locked closet in the hallway. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in proper working order. Fire extinguishers are fully charged. Room temperatures are maintained at 76 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and was measured at a safe operating range. All sinks, showers and toilets were in working order. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. Adequate supply of beddings and linens were observed. Emergency exits are free from obstruction. Overall, the facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Continued...

Continued... Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conduct meetings to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. The facility has developed, maintained and implemented written complaint procedures. The facility is licensed to accept children ages 10-15. During records review, one (1) client is not within the age range specified in their license. Emergency Intervention Documentation of emergency intervention training for staff is on file. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least quarterly for each shift. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Core/Therapeutic Services Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. Client Records LPA reviewed five (5) client records. Client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; removal/discipline/complaints form and medication administration records. Continued....

Continued.. Staff Records LPA reviewed five (5) staff records. Based on records review, one (1) staff has not completed their TB testing. Administrator will email me proof when it has been received by staff. Documentation of the required education and experience requirements are maintained in the personnel file. Documentation of staff training are on file. LPAs interviewed five (5) staff members. LPA interviewed one (3) clients. Two (2) clients were unavailable for interview at the time of inspection. Three (3) deficiency citations, Technical Violation and three (3) Technical Advisory's were issued during today’s inspection, see LIC809D and LIC9102TV, LIC 9102AN. Plan of Corrections were discussed with the Administrator. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report was emailed to the administrator, LIC809D,LIC9102, LIC811 and appeal rights were provided to a Melissa Rodriguez-Facility Manager.

LPA Yamamoto conducted additional interviews with two staff on 5/19/23, one placement agency social worker on 6/6/23, one client and a family member on 6/9/23, three minors on 6/23/23 and two additional placement agency social workers on 6/30/23. LPA attempted to interview additional minors and placement agency social workers between 5/19/23 to 8/7/23 but the attempts were unsuccessful. Confidential interviews reveal that minors “played wrestle” with each other during placement. One minor, who refused to provide a statement, engaged in “body shots” with other minors. There was a video recording shown by one minor to support this. Information obtained by Investigator Munoz indicates that one minor sustained bruises during these mutual plays. Staff denied witnessing the identified minor being assaulted by other minors. The minor never reported sustaining any injuries to staff. In regard to personal belongings of one minor being stolen, staff were not aware that one minor had a phone. Staff encourage minors to keep certain personal belongings and allowance in the office for safekeeping. The minor never reported to staff any personal items being stolen or missing. Minor admitted to not reporting any personal belongings that went missing. Based on information obtained during the investigation, there is no preponderance of evidence found to support the allegations, so the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of the following reports were provided at the conclusion of today’s inspection: LIC9099, LIC9099-C and LIC811 Confidential Names. Appeal rights were provided and explained. There was no deficiency citation issued.
investigation_findings: 13On August 10, 2023 at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted an unannounced complaint inspection at the facility. The investigation includes the following: On 5/19/23, LPA Yamamoto conducted an inspection at the facility and obtained copies of pertinent documents, including, but not limited to, the incident reports, law enforcement contact reports, discharge reports, and needs and services plans. Those documents were reviewed by Investigator Munoz, including a report provided to him by Bakersfield Police Department on 5/23/23. Investigator Munoz conducted confidential interviews with two placement agency social workers on 5/17/23, family members of one minor on 5/22/23 and four minors and three staff on 5/26/23. Investigator Munoz made attempts to obtain statements from two other minors, but those attempts were unsuccessful.

narrative: Staff are informed either by social worker or the Administrator of clients’ needs and services plan. Staff try to work on each client’s needs and goals according to needs and services plan. Staff cannot work at the facility unless they receive their clearances. All staff did not work until their clearances before they started working. LPA Suh verified that all personnel obtained criminal record clearances. Regarding the staffing ratio, a review of Personnel Report (LIC 500) and staff schedule indicates that the facility meets the staff child ratio. Clients are taken for their clothes shopping at least once a month by a staff. Clients are provided with clothes allowance of $100 per month. Statements obtained from the confidential interviews did not provide sufficient information to corroborate the allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights explained and a copy of this report, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On January 9, 2024, at 11:25 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Suh conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. The LPA met with the representative named above and discussed the findings. The investigation included confidential interviews that consisted of but were not limited to: Administrator, four staff, and three clients on July 19, 2023. The LPA was unable to contact the County Social Workers (CSW) after several attempts. The LPA reviewed the Needs & Services Plan, Personnel Report, and weekly schedule. It was alleged that staff bullied youth and staff did not prevent youth from being bullied by another youth. Staff denied the allegations stating staff do not bully clients. Staff redirects clients if any client is being bullied by another client. Staff do not allow clients to skip school. Staff transport and drop off clients at school but clients leave the school grounds and come back to the facility as if they had not missed any classes. (cont.)

narrative: Page 2 The Department received a complaint alleging facility clients are involved in drug activities, had access to a firearm, and smoke marijuana on the facility premises. Staff denied the allegations. The investigation revealed the reported gun that was in possession of a facility client was not a firearm, but a toy BB Gun. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with clients indicate a client hid a BB Gun on his waist and brought it into the facility, where he later used it to shoot pellets at a neighbor’s property. The neighbor complained to the facility and the client surrendered the BB Gun to staff. Furthermore, the investigation did not provide evidence to corroborate the allegation that minors are involved in drug activities and smoke marijuana on the premises. All clients denied involvement in selling drugs and that staff permit clients to consume marijuana on the premises. Clients interviewed stated they are verbally counseled by staff or lose privileges if they are observed smoking marijuana. Interviews conducted with staff corroborated the client’s statements. Social workers interviewed denied observing clients under the influence or the odor of substances when visiting the facility. Based on information gathered from interviews conducted and record review, the allegation are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. Exit interview conducted and copy of this report was given to Administrator Logan. No deficiencies were cited.
investigation_findings: 13An unannounced follow up complaint inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios on June 11, 2024 at 2:11 PM. On 4/9/24, SI Jauregui obtained an incident report. Between 4/5/24 and 4/16/24, SI Jauregui conducted interviews with three facility staff and five clients. Between 4/17/24 and 6/6/24, LPA Larios conducted interviews with five clients, three staff and three placing agency social workers. LPA Larios attempted to interview three other social workers, but telephone contact attempts were unsuccessful. (Continued on page 2)

investigation_findings: 13On 6/22/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Johanna Lofton conducted an unannounced visit to Walt’s Home for Young Men STRTP with the purpose of delivering findings for the above complaint allegations. LPA Lofton met with Facility Manager Cherrelle Wilson and discussed the findings. During the investigation LPA interviewed facility staff and clients. LPA did not interview the complainant. During the investigation the allegations were denied. Facility staff denied any falsification of fingerprints. Staff must present their identification card when they go to get fingerprinted. Furthermore, the fingerprinting is conducted by a third party which is not controlled by the facility. Interviewed parties denied staff engage in verbal altercations with clients. Facility staff reported not engaging in any kind of altercations with the clients. It was reported the staff does use their stern voice when the clients are not listening or following directives. Clients denied getting in altercations with the staff. Clients denied having any issues with the staff.
