investigation_findings: 13On October 28, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Johanna Aracena conducted an unannounced visit to Walt’s Home for Young Men Short Term Residential Program (STRTP) with purpose of delivering findings for the above complaint allegations. LPA Aracena met with Facility Administrator Carlene Logan and discussed the findings. During the investigation of the allegations, LPA Aracena conducted confidential interviews with facility staff, facility clients, and County Social Workers. LPA Aracena was not able to interview the complainant. While conducting confidential interviews the allegation of staff handled minor in a physically inappropriate manner was denied. The allegation of staff spoke to minor in an inappropriate manner was denied and the allegation of staff threatened minors was also denied. the allegation of abuse was denied by interviewed parties. Confidential interviews raised no concerns of abuse from facility staff to any of the clients.

narrative: On October 18, 2024, the Department received a complaint alleging that staff did not provide a minor with adequate school supplies. It was alleged that staff withheld a minor's personal belongings. It was alleged that staff restricted minor's ability to place/receive phone calls. It was alleged that staff withheld food from minor. It was alleged that staff handled the minor in a rough manner. It was alleged that staff were not communicating with a minor's representative in a timely manner. And it was alleged that staff spoke to minor in an inappropriate manner. LPA's investigation revealed that the STRTP provides school supplies to clients as new school year starts. The STRTP screens incoming packages to prevent contraband, so although there may be a slight delay, the packages are ultimately delivered to clients. The facility notified clients' social workers of phone outage via email immediately. The facility requires clients to wash their hands before going in to refrigerator for food. interviews with staff reported that school supplies provided were not to client's liking, so he refused them. Staff stated that when youth asked for his package, staff was unaware it had arrived as it had already been moved to admin's office for safekeeping. Staff stated that though phone line was out, internet was still working, so client could have made calls over wifi from his cell phone. Staff stated client was asked to wash hands before going in to the fridge, refused, and tried to push his way past staff, who simply held their ground; reporting party stated that after speaking with minor, she understood this to be correct version of events. The facility social worker stated that she has been the one to engage authorized representative in communicating. Staff denied speaking to minor inappropriately, stating that he was who tended to call others out of their name. Professional contacts had no concerns over the allegations. Confidential interviews provided conflicting information, neither corroborating nor refuting allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are determined to be Unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited at this time. Exit interview conducted. A signed copy of this report, LIC9099-C, and LIC811 were provided to Administrator. Appeal rights provided.
investigation_findings: 13On January 24, 2025, at 10:15 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted a follow-up complaint investigation at Walt's Home For Young Men, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), for the purpose of delivering findings on the above allegation. LPA met with Carlene Logan. LPA's investigation consisted of the following: On 10/21/24, LPA spoke with reporting party; reviewed the facility file and complaint history; conducted a collateral inspection at a high school, interviewing an adult and attempting to interview a client; and performed 10-day inspection at STRTP, interviewing four adults and five clients. On 12/03/24, LPA interviewed one staff. On 12/04/24, LPA interviewed a County Social Worker, a staff, and reviewed documents obtained througout investigation including but not limited to personnel roster, client roster, house rules, a client's (C1's) (See LIC811 Confidential Names list dated 10/21/24) Needs and Services Plan, special incident report's related to C1, and emails between facility and County Social Workers alerting them to telephone outage at STRTP. LPA also reviewed Department databases, and reports from other agencies. (Continued...)

narrative:
On 5/6/21, at 10: 03 am Licensing Program Analyst conducted a scheduled pre-licensing virtual inspection with Director, Mr. Samuel Campbell. During the tour both the external and internal area of the home was observed. This is a new application for a Short Team Residential Therapeutic Program. This facility is a two story, four-bedroom home located in a residential neighborhood. All bedrooms are located on the second floor, on the first floor consist of the living room, dining room, kitchen, a family room, staff area with a bedroom, and laundry room. The first aid box appeared to be complete, smoke detector and carbon monoxide were tested and operable. The Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are connected to ADT alarm company. There's a bulletin board containing COVID 19 related information, emergency disaster plan, client information LIC 9020, complaint, grievance procedures, menu, activities log personal rights, house rules, the anit-bullying policy and facility sketch. The second floor has four bedrooms Bedroom # 1 vacate waiting for placement has two twin beds, a dresser and two personal locked lockers. Bedroom # 2 vacate waiting for placement has two twin beds, a dresser and two personal locked lockers. Bedroom # 3 vacate waiting for placement has two twin beds, a dresser and two personal locked lockers. Bedroom # 4 is designated as the administrative office the telephone, fax and computer

Overall, the facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed, and all doors open freely. There are no bodies of water in the facility. The home is centrally heated and air-conditioned. Staff records, client files and medications, disinfectants, and other toxic materials will be centrally stored and locked near the staff work area. During this inspection, LPA observed a surveillance camera installed outside the home and in the kitchen area. Mr. Campbell was advised to submit an addendum to the Short Team Residential Therapeutic Program statement to include the use of surveillance cameras inside the facility. The addendum should include the following reason for installing surveillance camera equipment; identify the areas where cameras are installed; procedures for operation of the cameras; personnel authorized to view the footage; surveillance advisory; procedures to ensure that children's personal rights are not violated. An exit interview was held with Mr. Campbell and a signed copy of this report was provided to Mr. Campbell via email.

On 03/22/22 at 8:55 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva conducted an unannounced Post Licensing Inspection at the facility. LPA met with Carlene Logan, Administrator. The facility currently has a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license. The STRTP’s Mental Health Program Application is pending approval. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) ambulatory male children ages 10-17 years of age. The facility also provides services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1 (C)(1). There are three (3) ambulatory minors currently in placement. The LPAs requested the following: Personnel Report LIC500, Client Roster, Board of Meeting Minutes, Clients and Staff Files. This facility is a two-story home with three (3) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, a staff office, kitchen, dining, a living room, and a laundry room. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There are no firearms or ammunitions in the facility. At 9:10 AM, LPA conducted a walkthrough of the entire facility. Physical Plant The license, facility sketch, personal rights, emergency disaster form, complaints poster, emergency phone numbers and food menu are posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and sharps are kept inaccessible in a locked closet. Facility has non-perishable food for at least one week and perishable food for at least two days. Medications are centrally stored in a locked storage room. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in proper working order. Fire extinguishers were fully charged. First Aid Kits were checked and found to be complete. Room temperatures are maintained at 76 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 115 degrees F. All sinks, showers and toilets were in working order. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. Adequate supply of beddings and linens were observed. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility

is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conduct meetings to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. The facility administrator and manager are the responsible and capable staff for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility. The facility has developed, maintained and implemented written complaint procedures. Core/Therapeutic Services Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least quarterly for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Client Records LPA reviewed three (3) client records. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. LPA observed that all three (3) clients' file do not contain signed removal/discipline/complaints form.

Staff Records LPA reviewed three (3) staff records. All staff have been subjected to criminal records review and have been fingerprinted and cleared with DOJ, FBI and CACI. The administrator meets the required qualifications and/or experience. Documentation of the required education and experience requirements are maintained in the personnel file. Facility Managers meet requirements. Documentation of staff training on file. LPA interviewed three (3) staff members. No client was interviewed due to two (2) clients being in school and one (1) client on AWOL at the time of inspection. At the conclusion of the inspection, LPA discussed the findings with the facility administrator. LPA issued one (1) Type B deficiency citation. LPA agreed to work with the facility administrator to collaborate with guidance to get the facility in compliance with ILS and Title 22 regulations. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report, LIC811, LIC809D and appeal rights were provided to the facility administrator.

On 06/21/2022 at 8:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at the facility. LPA met with Carlene Logan, Administrator. The facility currently has a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license. The STRTP’s Mental Health Program Application is pending approval. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) ambulatory male children ages 10-17 years of age. The facility also provides services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1 (C)(1). There are three (3) ambulatory minors currently in placement. The LPAs requested the following: Personnel Report LIC500, Client Roster, Board of Meeting Minutes, Clients and Staff Files. This facility is a two-story home with three (3) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, a staff office, kitchen, dining, a living room, and a laundry room. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There are no firearms or ammunitions in the facility. At 9:00 AM, LPA conducted a walk-through of the entire facility. Physical Plant The license, facility sketch, personal rights, emergency disaster form, complaints poster, emergency phone numbers and food menu are posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and sharps are kept inaccessible in a locked closet. Facility has non-perishable food for at least one week and perishable food for at least two days. Medications are centrally stored in a locked storage room. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in proper working order. Fire extinguishers were fully charged. First Aid Kits were checked and found to be complete. Room temperatures are maintained at 76 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 110 degrees F. All sinks, showers and toilets were in working order. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. Adequate supply of beddings and linens were observed. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is

clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. However, there are no window screens installed in all the bedrooms and living room windows as well as the sliding door leading to the backyard. Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conduct meetings to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. The facility administrator and manager are the responsible and capable staff for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility. Core/Therapeutic Services Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least quarterly for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Client Records LPA reviewed three (3) client records. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records.

Staff Records LPA reviewed two (2) staff records. All staff have been subjected to criminal records review and have been fingerprinted and cleared with DOJ, FBI and CACI. The administrator meets the required qualifications and/or experience. Documentation of the required education and experience requirements are maintained in the personnel file. Facility Managers meet requirements. Documentation of staff training on file. LPA interviewed one (1) staff member and one (1) client. The other two (2) clients were not present at the time of inspection. At the conclusion of the inspection, LPA discussed the findings with the facility administrator. LPA issued one (1) Type B deficiency citation. LPA agreed to work with the facility administrator to collaborate with guidance to get the facility in compliance with ILS and Title 22 regulations. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report, LIC811, LIC809D and appeal rights were provided to the facility administrator.

The Ref. #3 provided inconsistent statements regarding their experience at the facility: there was a statement that the accused staff yelled at Ref. #3, but denied that staff put their hands on Ref. #3; Ref. #3 provided no witnesses that overheard the alleged incident. During the Annual Inspection June 21, 2022, Ref. #3 informed LPA Pamela Silva, “Staff treats client good and they interact well with him.” LPA McGee toured the facility on July 14, 2022 and observed it to be safe, clean and in good repair. An interview with the Sr. Facility Manager, revealed that she washed the linen and cleaned the other clients’ bed. The Sr. Facility Manager stated that information regarding a vap pen being found was disclosed, but the facility was unable to confirm it. The Ref. #3 denied having inappropriate sized clothing. The LPA observed clothing listed on Ref. #3's Personal Property and Valuables for the months of April and May 2022, and observed $100 clothing allowance that was distributed for each month, April, May and July 2022. The investigation did not reveal that Ref. #3 had a medical problem. The LPA observed Ref. #3's health screening. An interview with the County Social Worker revealed no concerns about the facility and that Ref. #3 has a history of not telling the truth in order to be placed closer to the biological family. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegations. So, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding this allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On September 23, 2022 at 5:30 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, delivered the findings a complaint investigation to the facility. The LPA met with Direct Care Staff, Sepie Flowers. On July 5, 2022, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. Confidential interviews were conducted that included, but were not limited to: the Senior Facility Manager (see Confidential Names, LIC 811 Ref. #1 dated September 23, 2022), and one staff, Ref. #2 and one client Ref. #3 on July 14, 2022 at the facility; one County Social Worker (CSW) via telephone on August 30, 2022. The LPA reviewed correspondence and a signed statement from Ref. #3, the Case Plan, CFT Meeting Plan and Notes, Safety Plan, Special Incident Reports, Behavior Report, Client Personal Property and Valuables, Monthly Clothing Allowance Log and Health Screening. The accused staff denied the allegations of personal rights violations. The LPA observed a statement signed by Ref. #3 that Ref. #3 fabricated the allegations. There was a statement that Ref. #3 was forced to sign the statement.

narrative: Based on the information gathered, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that an alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights explained and a copy of this report, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On October 27, 2022 at 11:55 AM , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Suh conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the findings of an investigation concerning to the allegation above. LPA met with the representative named above and discussed the findings. During the investigation, LPA conducted interviews with three clients and staff on 8/24/22 and 9/22/22. LPA reviewed records on 9/8/22, 9/16/22, and 10/5/22. It was alleged that a client, Ref. #2 exposed themselves to Ref. #1 while they were in the living room watching television on 8/2/22 and that Ref. #1 reported the incident to a staff (Ref. #3) on 8/3/22. Ref. #3 denied having any knowledge of allegations. Three staff who were on duty did not witness Ref. #2 exposing themselves to Ref. #1. The alleged incident was not reported until 8/17/22. LPA attempted to interview clients, Ref. #1 and Ref. #2, however, they declined to be interviewed and stated they did not want to be interview.

narrative: Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged that staff hit minor. Staff denied the allegation. Staff stated that when children get disciplined, they are sent to their rooms or they have privileges/ electronics removed. Staff stated that they did not recall any instance or time when it was observed that a staff hit a child. Additionally, staff stated that they did not recall receiving any complaints from children of staff hitting them. Children denied the allegation. Children had similar statements that they were unable to recall any incident occurring where a staff hit or punched a child. Children stated that when they get into trouble, they are sent to their rooms on time out or that they would have privileges and or electronics taken away. One child stated that a staff grabbed their neck, choked them and took them to the ground, however, child was unable to identify when incident occurred and by what staff. Child also identified that no one else was present during alleged incident occurring. Documents reviewed identified no issues or complaints of staff hitting or punching children. Based on the information gathered, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form, and Appeal Rights were provided to Sepia Flowers-Facility Manager. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.
investigation_findings: 13On 4/13/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal made an unannounced visit to the Walts Home for Young Men II facility on behalf of LPA Dawn Mahecha for the purpose of concluding the above identified complaint investigation. LPA met with Sepie Flowers-Facility Manager and discussed the above identified complaint findings. Investigation consisted of the following: On 10/12/2022 LPA met with and interviewed facility manager, Senior facility manager and one (1) child (see confidential names dated October 12, 2022). LPA requested and obtained copies of current staff/ client roster, staff schedule, criminal record clearances, recent completed training's, children's Needs and service plans, case notes and special incident reports. Between March 25th and March 27, 2023 LPA Elnora Smith interviewed three children, staff and additional witnesses.

narrative: On 04/28/23 at 11:45 A.M. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced case management inspection at Walt's Home For Young Men 2 (STRTP). LPA met with Sepie Flowers-Facility Manager. Purpose of the visit was to follow up on multiple Incident reports, including multiple case management. During todays inspection, LPA reviewed pertinent documents associated to STRTP, interviewed two (2) staff, toured the home inside and out. Further Interviews will be conducted as necessary Additional time is needed to resolve this case. A signed copy of this report was provided to the STRTP.

Information obtained through confidential interviews and S1 admitting to leaving C1 unattended and unsupervised at Mary K. Shell on 12/20/22 is a Lack of Supervision Violation of the Interim Licensing Standards regulation 87065.2 (b) (1) Personnel Duties Direct care staff shall perform the following duties: “Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups.” If not corrected, it will have a direct and immediate risk to the health and safety of the children in care. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. The agency was cited, and a plan of correction was initiated. Appeal rights were provided and discussed with the STRTP Administrator. A copy of the report and the Confidential Name List (LIC811) dated October 7, 2022, was provided to the FFA Administrator, and an exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13On May 24, 2023, at 12:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the Walts Home for Young Men II on behalf of LPA Winston Moroney. LPA Mahecha conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and met with Samantha Combs – Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver a finding for the above complaint allegation. It was alleged that staff member (S1) did not provide adequate supervision to a minor in care (C1), by failing to abide by their personnel duties providing Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups. The investigation of the above allegation was conducted by LPA Moroney, which consisted of, but was not limited to, a review of records including the client’s needs and services plans, interviews with five Staff members (S1) on 4/25/23, S2 on 1/20/23, S3, S4, S5 on 3/7/23, 1 Client (C1) on 1/20/23, and 1 (OG) Mary K. Shell staff member on 1/19/23. (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated April 28, 2023).

deficiencies.description:
87065.2 (b) (1) Personnel Duties Direct care staff shall perform the following duties: “Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups.” If not corrected, it will have a direct and immediate risk to the health and safety of the children in care. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. The agency was cited, and a plan of correction was initiated.     
This requirement was met by evidence of:  Staff admitted to leaving child unattended for a period of time at a location.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will complete training with all staff members on ILS regulation and duties of poisition. Facility will also retrain staff on facilities policy of how to handle crisis interventions. Facility will provide proof of completed trainings to LPA Moroney by email by POC due date.

narrative:
On 05/26/23 at 1:40 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced case management inspection at Walt's Home For Young Men 2 (STRTP) and presented findings to K'Juan Mustin-Direct Care Staff/Facility Manager . Finding were based on visit conducted on 04/28/23, interviews with staff and clients, tour of home and review of pertinent documents. On 04/28/23, LPA met with two staff regarding C5 showing a gun on his phone, threatening to come to school with a gun and shoot it up, late reporting of incident report dated 03/09/23 received on 03/16/23. Interview with S2 revealed that she was given the Community Care Licensing Fresno office number from a staff member at Community Care Licensing Monterey Park. S2 did not have proof that she sent the initial report to the Fresno office, timely. LPA gave S2 the correct phone number and advised to CC me when sending. S2 admitted that she understands it was late. Advised S2 of prior late reported incident reports from 12/02/22, 12/21/22, 01/17/23, 01/29/23, 03/07//23 4/18/23, 04/19/23 (2).S2 was under the impression based on the verbiage at the top of hte LIC 624 LE, that she had 7 days to send the report. Advised S2 she does but the date of first occurrence, the licensing agency must be notified by the next business day. S2 was directed to this info at the top of the form. S2 said she understood and will follow including letting staff know. Based on this review and response from S1, Facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulation, Title 22, Division 6 Section 80061 (b) Reporting Requirements. Facility failed to report the incident within the next working day as required. continued....

...continued Regarding the picture of a gun on the phone, and threats to shoot up the school: LPA interviewed 2 staff, 1 client (no other current clients were placed at the facility during the time C5 was a resident), 1 social worker and spoke with police staff. No gun was found by the police department. No police report was made. Police did go to the home but never came back to do a follow up investigaton. C5 is currently incarcerated, based on information from social worker. C5 is no longer at the Walt's Home For Young Men 2. No citation given. Incident date 02/16/23: LPA conducted multiple interviews starting on 04/28/23 to 05/23/23. LPA interviewed 4 staff and 2 clients. It is found that C4 did assault S3 and was not defending himself. C4 is no longer a resident of Walt's Home for Young Men 2. C4 admitted to striking S3 first. LPA conducted a tour of the home on 04/28/23 at 3:08 P.M.,with S1. During the tour, LPA saw a grey Chevy Suburban parked on the premises with a rear side broken window on the drivers side. The window was taped but had an accessible opening, 1 inch wide and 5 inches in length of visible broken glass. There were pieces of glass on the ground near the rear drivers side tire. This glass poses an immediate risk to clients and staff. LPA saw multiple pieces of loose wood and metal objects ranging in length from 3-5 feet long. Some of the loose piece of wood had exposed rusted nails approximately 2 1/2 inches in length. These objects pose an immediate risk to clients and staff. Based on this review and visible evidence, the facility will be cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 Section 80087 (a) and 80087 (c). Plan of Action will be discussed. Exit interview conducted and signed copy of this report was provided to Direct Care Staff/Facility Manager along with LIC 811 (Confidential Names list). Appeal rights given.

deficiencies.description:
80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds: (a)	The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. (c)	 All outdoor...passageways,...and other areas of potential hazard shall be kept free of obstruction. 
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: LPA toured outside facility and witnessed broken glass, broken window, loose wood and metal on grounds.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will clean grounds of broken glass, fix broken vehicle window and remove loose wood and metal. Proof of correction will be pictures taken of grounds.  (POC) will be emailed to LPA by POC due date of 05/30/23

deficiencies.description:
80061(b) Reporting Requirements: Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, ..., a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours....In addition, a written report... shall This requirement was not met as evidenced by:
Based on record review and staff interview, it was determined that facility failed to report multiple incidents that occured from 12/02/22-04/19/23, within the agency's next working day as required.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will provide updated training on Reporting Requirements. Proof of correction will inculde a copy of the training attendance sheet and training topics covered. POC will be emailed to LPA by POC due date of 06/09/23 .

narrative: On 06/15/23 at 11:00 A.M. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced case management inspection at Walt's Home For Young Men 2 (STRTP). LPA met with Carlene Logan- Administrator. Purpose of the visit was to follow up on multiple Incident reports, including multiple case management's. LPA discussed late filing with administrator. Further Interviews will be conducted as necessary. Additional time is needed to resolve this case. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report along with 811 (Confidential Name List), was left with administrator.

On 10/12/2023 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Pamela Silva and Timika Martin conducted an unannounced case management inspection and met with Carlene Logan, Administrator. The purpose of the visit was to follow up on case carrying LPA’s concern that only two (2) Unusual Incident Reports (UIRs) were received since August 2023. The two (2) UIRs received were from incidents that occurred on 09/10/23 and 10/02/23. LPAs reviewed client records and interviewed Facility Manager S1 to check on incidents that may have occurred in the last three months. LPAs found that there were incidents from August 2023 to the present, that were unreported to the Department. Based on the information gathered, the facility was cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Section 80061 (b), see LIC809D. A previous violation of California Code of Regulations 80061(b) was cited on 05/26/23. Based upon repeating the same violation within a 12-month period, it is determined that an immediate civil penalty of $250 be assessed (see LIC421FC). Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report, LIC809D, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided to the facility representative.

deficiencies.description:
Reporting Requirements :  …Upon the occurrence.. of any events specified below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency’s next working day..or a written report shall be submitted within 7 days… This requirement was not met as evidenced by:
Based on record review and staff interview, it was determined that the facility failed to report multiple incidents that occurred from 08/2023 to present, within the agency's next working day as required.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide staff training on Reporting Requirements. Proof of correction will include a copy of the training attendance sheet and training topics covered. POC will be emailed to LPA by end of  POC due date.

87070(b)(11)CHILDREN’S RECORDS
The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child's record:Consent forms, completed by the child's authorized representative(s), to permit the facility to authorize medical care.
This requirement was not met by: Based on records reviewed, the JV220 or parental authorization was not obtained or on file for C2 which poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care which poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care.

deficiencies.description:
87068.2 (f) NEEDS AND SERVICES PLAN
The licensee shall obtain written approval from the child, if age and developmentally appropriate, and the child’s authorized representative prior to implementing the child’s needs and services plan.
This requirement was not met by: Based on records reviewed, the clients needs and services plan were not signed by the client's or their authorized representative which poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will obtain signatures on the NSPs from the clients and authorized respresentatives by the POC due date. If not, the licensee shall submit documentation of the attempts to obtain signatures. Licensee will provide proof via email by POC due date.

deficiencies.description:
87070(b)(13)(A)-(H)CHILDREN’S RECORDS. A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child documenting all of the following:(H) Staff initials for each time a psychotropic medication is taken by a child, as an.......
1. Initials shall not be pre-filled on the log. This requirement was not met by: 
Based on records reviewed, staff initials were missing on 10/12/23 but medication was administered for C2. C2 medication also appears that it was not administered due to medication count not matching with the PMAR which poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will provide staff training on medication administration. Licensee will provide proof via email by POC due date.

narrative: On April 16, 2024, at 3:00 P.M., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced case management inspection, at the above-named facility. The purpose of the visit was to follow up on a special incident report received by the Department on April 11, 2024, regarding the death of Client #1 (C1) (see LIC 811 confidential names list dated April 16, 2024). LPA Teal met with Administrator Samantha Combs. LPA requested a copy of C1's needs and services plan, date of placement including the assigned social workers information (Documents received). On April 12, 2024, Walt’s Home for Young Men 2 reported to the Department that on April 11, 2024, the Kern County Sheriff Coroner’s Office informed facility staff that C1 was deceased. It was reported that C1 had been at the coroner’s office since April 7, 2024. According to facility staff it is believed that the death is the result of a train accident, but neither facility staff nor the placing agency have been provided with the cause of death. On April 9, 2024, the facility reported to the Department that the youth left the facility without permission on April 6, 2024, at approximately 11:18 P.M. Facility staff filed a runaway report with Bakersfield Police Department on April 7, 2024, at approximately 3:18 A.M. and notified the Madera County Social Worker of the death on April 11, 2024. At this time, this is the most current information. LPA conducted an interview with C1's roommate. This case requires further investigation. Exit interview conducted. A signed copy of the LIC 809, LIC 811 including the appeal rights were given to Administrator Samantha Combs. There were no citations issued.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Juliet Robles and Pamela Silva on 10/17/24 at 11:30 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs met with Samantha Combs, Senior Facility Manager and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed one (1) of children’s records and three (3) of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed one (1) of children’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPAs interviewed two (2) of staff on site to discuss the facility's policies and procedures of operation. LPAs interviewed 0 of child currently prescribed psychotropic medication due to child's refusal. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPAs provided copies of this report and conducted exit interview with Senior Facility Manager, Samantha Combs.

*Amending document to add closing information for the Case Management* On July 11, 2025, at 1:05 P.M. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced case management inspection at Walt's Home For Young Men 2. LPA met with Samantha Combs-Facility Manager. Purpose of the visit was to follow up on a incident report. LPA discussed the SIR dated June 4, 2025. Youth attempted to stab another youth in the home after an altercation. Youth brought a concealed weapon into the home. LPA interviewed two (2) youth and one (1) staff. (See confidential 812's.) The case management inspection did not show that there were any violations. The inspection was completed. Based on interviews conducted no deficiencies were cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report including the appeal rights were left with the Facility Manager.

On 08/01/2022 at 8:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Noubar Yerkatyan conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at the facility. LPA met with Samantha Combs, Lead Facility Manager. The facility currently has a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license. The STRTP’s Mental Health Program Application is approved. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) ambulatory male children ages 10-17 years of age. The facility also provides services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1 (C)(1). There are three (3) ambulatory minors currently in placement. The LPAs requested the following: Personnel Report LIC500, Client Roster, Fire Clearance, LIC 610 C Emergency Disaster Plan, Board of Meeting Minutes, Clients and Staff Files. This facility is a two-story home with three (3) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, a staff office, kitchen, dining room, living room, and laundry room. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There are no firearms or ammunitions in the facility. At 8:50 AM, LPA conducted a walk-through of the entire facility. Physical Plant The license, facility sketch, personal rights, emergency disaster form, complaints poster, emergency phone numbers and food menu are posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and sharps are kept inaccessible in a locked closet. The facility has non-perishable food for at least one week and perishable food for at least two days. Medications are centrally stored in a locked storage room. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in proper working order. Fire extinguishers were fully charged. First Aid Kits were checked and found to be complete. Room temperatures are maintained at 76 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 110 degrees F. All sinks, showers and toilets were in working order. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in

good repair; equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. Adequate supply of beddings and linens were observed. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, the facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. However, there are no window screens installed in all the client bedrooms and living room area. Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conduct meetings to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. The facility administrator and manager are the responsible and capable staff for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility. The facility has developed, maintained and implemented written complaint procedures. Core/Therapeutic Services Facility provides core services and support to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least monthly for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Client Records LPA reviewed three (3) client records. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records.

Staff Records LPA reviewed three (3) staff records. All staff have been subjected to criminal records review and have been fingerprinted and cleared with DOJ, FBI and CACI. The administrator meets the required qualifications and/or experience. Documentation of the required education and experience requirements are maintained in the personnel file. Facility Managers meet requirements. Documentation of staff training on file. LPA interviewed two (2) staff members and attempted one (1) client; client refused. The other two (2) clients were not present at the time of inspection. At the conclusion of the inspection, LPA discussed the findings with the lead facility manger. LPA issued one (1) Type B deficiency citation. LPA agreed to work with the facility manager to collaborate with guidance to get the facility in compliance with ILS and Title 22 regulations. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report, LIC811, LIC809D and appeal rights were provided to the facility manager.

Facility cited for Violation of the California Department of Social Services Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, (Cal. Dept. of Social Services, STRTP ILS), Version 3.1, Section 87072 Personal Rights (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. S1 and C1 confirmed that S1 used inappropriate verbiage that was threatening towards C1. See 9099-D A copy of this report and appeal rights was emailed to the Facility.
investigation_findings: 13On November 23, 2020 at 3:47pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to Wayfinder Family Service STRTP and spoke with Kristal Audoma, Director. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating the allegation for Staff member threatened group home child, LPA conducted interviews with related parties and reviewed the following documentation: Special Incident Reports; Facility’s Internal Investigation; and Wayfinder Family Services Record of Discussion for S1. Documentation and witness statements revealed that S1 did admit that she did use inappropriate verbiage that was threatening towards C1 due to prior incidents leading up to this incident and in effort of defending herself. In addition, C1 confirmed the allegation. Facility’s Internal Investigation confirmed that the allegation occurred and in result S1 was demoted upon her return to work. Continue on 9099-C

deficiencies.description: 87072 (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (11) To be free of threat. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: S1 and C1 confirmed that S1 used inappropriate verbiage that was threatening towards C1.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: POC was discussed with Director Kristal Audoma and Licensee will have 30 days from this date to provide LPA with documentation for retraining staff on the guidelines and procedures for trauma-informed practices.

met_with: Ani Sargsyan, Associate Vice President, Residential Clinical Services
narrative: Additionally, LPA was unable to interview S1 after multiple attempts. LPA attempted to reach C3 but was unable to interview C3 after multiple attempts. Per C1’s Safety Plan and interviews, the facility supported C1 by having a room change, a one on one for close supervision during nocturnal shift and per client’s request, staff locked C1’s door; lock door from the outside but clients are able to go in and out of their rooms when they want. LPA was unable to determine if Facility staff did not intervene in a physical altercation between youths due to inconsistent statements; LPA could not obtain additional information due to being unable to interview pertinent parties; and lack of evidence. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred; therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. If there are additional information that arises, this case may be re-opened. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On December 30th, 2020 at 10am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted a follow-up complaint inspection via telephone and spoke with Ani Sargsyan, Associate Vice President, Residential Clinical Services. The purpose of the tele-visit was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating the allegation for Facility staff did not intervene in a physical altercation between youths. LPA conducted interviews, reviewed Special Incident Reports, 15 Minute Daily Operation Log, C1’s safety Plan, C1 and C2’s Needs and Services Plan. It was reported that on 04/29/2020 a fight occurred between C1 and C2 resulting in C2 punching C1 in the stomach. It was indicated that C1 was screaming and staff did not do anything. Interview statements revealed inconsistent statements. C1 confirmed that C1 punched him in the stomach. C2 confirmed he did hit C1 out of retaliation because C1 hit him first. C1 and C2 did confirm that a supervisor was there but statements were inconsistent. Interviews revealed that staff tried to intervene and that was how the fight ended but there was no confirmation on the names of the staff that was present. Continue on 9099-C

met_with: Ani Sargsyan, Associate Vice President, Residential Clinical Services
narrative: Additionally, LPA interviewed staff that was working that day and there is not one staff that can confirm that they witnessed the incident. Interviews revealed that it came to the attention of staff when they heard C1 screaming. In addition, C1 confirmed the allegation. The Special Incident Report in relation to this incident did not accurately the depict the incident that occurred. The incident occurred during a shift change and there were no designated Nocturnal Shift Staff located on the floor at 10:00pm to provide care and supervision for the clients in care. The 15-minute log dated on 02/02/2020 was not accurate as it documented a staff that did not work that day which is S5. Although it was indicated that C3 might have gotten the lighter during AWOL and C1 was not injured, there was no confirmation that Staff was present during the time of the incident which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care due to the contrabands that were involved. Based on the interview statements and documentation obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. Facility cited for Violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80078 (a): Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. Documentation and interviews confirmed that Staff was not present during the time of the incident between C1, C2, and C3. C3 retrieved a lighter and deodorant aerosol can and ignited spray from the can. C2 held C1 down while C3 sprayed on C1’s direction. Staff did not witness this incident and was aware of it when C1 ran downstairs and screamed. See 9099-D A copy of this report and appeal rights will be emailed to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On December 30th, 2020 at 9:55am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to Wayfinder Family Service STRTP and spoke with Ani Sargsyan, Associate Vice President, Residential Clinical Services. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating the allegations for Facility staff are not providing adequate supervision to minor(s) in care and Minor(s) in care had access to hazardous item(s), LPA conducted interviews with related parties and reviewed the following documentation: Special Incident Reports; 15 minute observation logs; S1 Record of Discussion; Shift Log; & C1, C2, and C3’s Needs and Services Plan. Documentation and witness statements revealed that on February 2, 2020, C1, C2, and C3 were running in and out of residents’ rooms. C3 retrieved a lighter and deodorant aerosol can and ignited spray from the can. C2 held C1 down while C3 sprayed on C1’s direction. Facility supervisor Staff 1 (S1) did admit verbally and in documentation that staff was not there to witness the incident. Continue on 9099-C

deficiencies.description: 80078 (a): Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:  Documentation and interviews confirmed that Staff was not present during the time of the incident between C1, C2, and C3. C3 retrieved a lighter and deodorant aerosol can and ignited spray from the can.  C2 held C1 down while C3 sprayed on C1’s direction. Staff did not witness this incident and was aware of it when C1 ran downstairs and screamed. which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to client in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: POC: Provide an all staff training to address care and supervision of STRTP clients and Retrain staff on accurately completing 15 minute logs. POC must be completed 30 days from today’s date.

met_with: Ani Sargsyan, Associate Vice President, Residential Clinical Services
narrative: At approximately 3:50 AM, the other clients began returning to baseline, but C1 did not. Due to C1 not returning to baseline, Law Enforcement called paramedics to transport C1 to the ER for further evaluation. On 05/18/2020, RP reported that C1 is medically cleared and ready for discharge but C1 cannot return to his group home due to his assaultive behavior towards others, and because he has vandalized the facility. On 5/18/2020 at 2:10:06 a Special Incident Report addendum was submitted which indicated C1 assaulted the staff by punching the staff in the shoulder area. The staff is seeking to press charges and file a restraining order against C1. CSW was called on 5/17/2020 in order to ask for immediate removal of C1 from STRTP Wayfinder Family Services due to youth C1's unsafe behaviors. Since staff were unable to get a hold of the CSW and Supervisor, Child Abuse Hotline was called. The ER CSW informed facility that they would be coming out to assess. A letter for intent to discharge C1 was sent on 05/14/2020 and to be effective immediately due to C1’s lack of engagement and participation in services. LPA could not interview RP to obtain additional information after multiple attempts. LPA could not interview S1 after multiple attempts. LPA could not obtain additional information due to being unable to interview pertinent parties. LPA could not determine whether or not the facility refused C1 to return due to lack of evidence. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred; therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. If there are additional information that arises, this case may be re-opened. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Staff did not allow minor to return to the facility. On December 30th, 2020 at 10:05 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sethany Yem conducted a follow-up complaint inspection via telephone and spoke withAni Sargsyan, Associate Vice President, Residential Clinical Services. The purpose of the tele-visit was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating the allegation for Staff did not allow minor to return to the facility. LPA conducted interviews, reviewed Special Incident Report, and Facility’s discharge notice to C1’s Social Worker. It was reported that on 05/16/2020 C1 AWOLed with peers and when the clients returned from AWOL, clients were under the influence by an unknown substance and displaying aggressive behavior, it was determined by staff and Law Enforcement that hands on / physical restraint was not an option for the safety of residents, staff and Law Enforcement. Continue on 9099-C

narrative: On January 11, 2021 at 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Regina Martin and Charmetha White initiated a Case Management Incident inspection (via telephone) to discuss and inform the Department’s investigation concerning Incident Report (SIR) #737093; Dated: January 1, 2021. The incident involves clients’ physical fatal assault on staff member and subsequent arrest. LPAs spoke with Facility Representative, Kristal Audoma, Facility Director/Administrator. The following information was requested: Client Roster, Personnel Schedule-(LIC 500) (including contact information); Client Records for all clients involved including: Client Intake/Assessment reports, Needs and Services Plans, Placement Agreement, Child and Family Team (CFT) Planning Matrix. Personnel Records: Personnel Application; Date of Hire; Job Description; Training; and past reprimands/disciplinary actions (if applicable) for all staffs involved. Please also submit all information pertaining to any facility internal investigation. LPA Martin requested information by email at Regina.Martin@dss.ca.gov. This incident requires further investigation. A copy of this report was emailed to Kristal Audoma for signature.

On April 7, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Regina Martin and Charmetha White conducted a follow-up Case Management - Incident inspection (via telephone) to discuss and deliver findings from the Department’s investigation concerning Incident Report (SIR) #737093; dated: January 2, 2021 involving clients’ physical fatal assault on staff member and subsequent arrest. LPAs spoke with Facility Representative, Kristal Audoma Facility Director/Administrator. On January 4, 2021, Wayfinder Family Services reported that on January 2, 2021 seven male clients, C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, C6 and C7, assaulted staff members, resulting in Staff #1’s (S1) death [see Confidential Names form, LIC811]. Interviews conducted with staffs involved and facility administration revealed consistent statements that S1 was attempting to intervene to prevent C2 from physically engaging with C1 on behalf of staff (S5) who was verbally redirecting C1 in attempts to de-escalate C1's assaultive behavior. During the scuffle S1 was head butted by C1 and thereafter six other youth began hitting kicking and pulling the staff’s hair. Four staffs (S3, S4, S5 and S7) intervened and pulled the clients off S1 while also being attacked by the youths. Staff members were able to assist S1 in walking away at which time two of the youth assaulted S1 again, causing S1 to fall to the ground. Once on the ground, the other youths hit, kicked and pulled the staff member’s hair again. Staffs were eventually able to assist S1 to exit the campus to await the paramedics. Law enforcement was contacted by the facility prior to the assault. When law enforcement arrived at the facility the youth ceased their assaultive behavior. Staff #1 was transported to the Hospital and passed away on January 3, 2021. Law enforcement arrested C1 and C2 on January 2, 2021. Five addition youths were also detained and await trial. Law enforcement’s investigation report is currently pending. (Continued on page 809-C)

Statements obtained during the investigation corroborate claims that two of the clients involved (C1 and C2) were the main individuals enforcing the assaultive behavior towards staffs while other youths seemed to join in as a means of teaming together against staff. While it is not known what exactly incited C1’s disruptive behavior, witnesses indicate C1 appeared to be under the influence of an unknown substance at the time of the incident as it was noted, C1 did not appear to be himself. Interviews and review of facility's incident report details revealed the facility made appropriate attempts contacting the Psychiatric Mobile Response Team (PRMT) and Law Enforcement at the onset of C1's escalating behavior. A review of facility records further revealed at the time of the incident the census was 16. Fifteen residents were present at the facility at the time of the incident; seven youths were actively involved in the incident. The remaining clients were not present at the scene nor witnessed the incident. There were a total of 10 staffs actively working on shift during the incident; five of whom were physically involved. Records indicate the facility was operating within approved staffing ratios. Based on the gathered information obtained from interviews capturing accounts of the incident from those involved, review of corresponding incident report, staff ratios, staff training and client records, revealed the facility was operating within STRTP required guidelines and further reveals the facility responded appropriately to address the situation. The results from the investigation found no deficiencies cited related to the incident. Exit Interview conducted. A copy of this report is provided to Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On April 7, 2021, Regina Martin, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) spoke with Kristal Audoma Facility Director/Administrator, for the purpose of delivering complaint findings. The above-mentioned allegation was investigated by the California Department of Social Services (CDSS) Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Bureau, Investigator Lorraine Patterson. On August 6, 2020, CCLD received a complaint referral alleging Staff is providing minors with illegal substances while in care. Information obtained during the investigation including interviews and review of related reports and medical documentation did not provide enough evidence to support allegation. Child #1 provided conflicting statements during investigation. Child #1 initially indicated that staff provided minors in care with edibles containing an illegal substance. Child #1 later stated he never reported that staff brought in edibles. Interviews did not reveal any evidence to corroborate the allegation. There were no witnesses of documentary evidence presented to suggest allegation occurred. It has been determined that the allegation is

narrative: Moreover, staff statements along with a review of Special Incident Report #737093 revealed that staff made attempts to contact the Psychiatric Mobile Response Team and Law Enforcement to assist with the situation. Additionally, staff stated they have received various job trainings, including Pro-Act and de-escalation training while working at the facility. A review of facility records further confirmed that staff involved have up to date trainings in their files. LPA’s were unable to obtain statements from the clients involved as all were detained and are awaiting trial. Based on information gathered and evidence obtained the staff have been properly trained and the facility was operating within STRTP required direct care staff to child ratio guidelines. Thus, the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. No deficiencies cited. Exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was emailed to the Administrator for signature.
investigation_findings: 13On April 7, 2021 at 1:50 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s), Charmetha White and Regina Martin contacted the above location for the purpose of delivering findings on the above allegations. LPAs spoke to Administrator, Kristal Audoma and discussed the findings. During the course of this investigation LPA’s interviewed pertinent parties and reviewed staff files. A review of facility records disclose there were a total of fifteen residents present at the facility the night of the incident and a total of seven staff members were physically working at the facility the night of the incident. However, staff interviews revealed there were a total of six staff and seven clients actually involved in the incident that occurred on January 2, 2021. Interviews confirmed the remaining clients did not witness the incident and were not involved. Interviews revealed that multiple staff tried to use verbal redirection and crisis communication to de-escalate the situation to no avail. Report continued on LIC 9099C.

13On 05/26/2022 at 1pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility for the purpose of delivering findings for a complaint investigation. Health and safety risk assessment were conducted upon arriving at the facility. LPA Karnsrithong met with Veta Talton, Assistant Director for Wayfinder Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF). During the investigation, LPA Karnsrithong conducted confidential interviews regarding the allegation, that staff did not seek medical attention for youth in a timely manner. Statements were inconsistent and did not produce corroborating evidence to support that staff did not provide medical attention to clients in care. During the investigation it was determined that a nurse’s station is located inside the facility premises to provide medical treatment for clients if needed. Due to lack of evidence obtained during the investigation, LPA determines that the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time meaning, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview conducted with TSCF Assistant Director and a copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

Therefore, it has been determined that the allegations are
