deficiencies.description: 87072(c)(11): To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, *exploitation,* infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: A POC was not issued as this facility is no longer in operation and has forfeited its license as of April 1, 2021.

investigation_findings: 13On September 27, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at Wayfinder Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) for the purpose of delivering findings for the above complaint investigation. LPA met with Wayfinder TSCF, Veta Talton. During the course of this investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews, gathered documentation, reviewed records and reports. Confidential interviews and records did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegation. Staff denied having to hide infants and stated no child has ever been placed in closets for any reason. Staff stated there were always staff on duty and anytime clients from Wayfinder STRTP attempted to come over to Wayfinder TSCF, staff would intervene and redirect in order to prevent altercations. Based on information obtained the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred. This facility is no longer in operation and has forfeited its license as of April 1, 2021. There are no deficiencies cited at this time.

met_with: Tony Weaver, VP, Clinical and Housing Services
investigation_findings: 13On October 20, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at Wayfinder Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) for the purpose of delivering findings for the above complaint investigation. LPA met with Tony Weaver, VP, Clinical and Housing Services. During the course of this investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews, gathered documentation, and reviewed records. Confidential interviews did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegations. Staff stated they always intervene and redirect clients from awoling, engaging in substance abuse, and physically aggression. Staff denied the facility had a rat infestation. Additionally, LPA was made aware there was a nurse’s station located on the premises that provided medical treatment for clients when needed. Moreover, documentary evidence reveal the program had an extensive policy on substance abuse and contraband. Based on information obtained during the investigation, the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview conducted with VP, Clinical and Housing Services. A copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: On 11/23/2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo conducted an SB484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection and met Melissa Williams, Administrator. The inspection was conducted via tele-inspection using facetime video due to COVID-19 restrictions at 09:15 AM. The facility was inspected inside and out. All staff files and medication documents/procedures were sent to this LPA on dates prior to the inspection. LPA reviewed three staff records on 11/13/2020 at 3:00 PM LPA interviewed one staff via telephone on 11/23/20 at 9:45 AM, second staff at 10:00 AM, and third staff at 10:15 AM. LPA did not interview or conduct file review of the youths in placement due to them being probation placement only LPA conducted an exit interview with Melissa Williams, Administrator. at 11:45 AM. No deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPA provided the summary report to the Administrator upon completion by email with a request for signature and a scan back to this LPA on this date.

The investigation revealed that the facility reported the incident with Client #4 hiding a knife in the client's bedroom and being discovered by a staff cleaning the bedroom to CCL via a Special Incident Report. It revealed that the facility discussed the incident at the Child and Family Team Meeting (CFTM). The investigation revealed that the facility contacts probation officers or law enforcement in order to conduct searches when weapons or drugs are brought into the facility. The investigation revealed that the Probation Officer has no concerns about the supervision at the facility. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that an alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding this allegation. A copy of this complaint was emailed to Ms. Williams.
investigation_findings: On February 26, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, emailed the complaint findings to Administrator, Melissa Williams. On September 28 2020, the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Regional Office (RO) received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. The investigation included confidential interviews that consisted of, but were not limited to: three staff, Erika Alvarado, Johnny Watson, Alejandro Reyes separately via telephone on February 25, 2021; client Ref. #1 (see Confidential Names, LIC 811 Ref. #1 dated February 26, 2021) via telephone on February 23, 2021; and Probation Officer, Gladis Munoz via telephone on February 26, 2021. The LPA reviewed the facility complaint history and special incident reports. The investigation revealed staff immediately intervened when Client Ref. #1 and #2 started to engage in a physical altercation. The LPA was able to corroborate immediate intervention via interviews with the staff and client #1. The investigation revealed that the facility reported to CCL Client #2's awols. It revealed that Client #2 was subject to consequences of no video games or wi-fi and had to undergo the facility COVID19 protocol which included quarantine. The investigation did not reveal that Ref. #2 received favoritism after awolling. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation.

narrative: The article was from a court case alleging the group home staff while employed with the Kern County School District was accused of sexting a student. The staff was acquitted of the allegation and have obtained all required criminal clearance to work or be present in a licensing facility. The group home administrator transferred S3 after receiving this complaint to avoid the appearance or implication that S3 would try to influence or interfere with the complaint investigation. As per the Administrator, S3 would not try to interfere with any investigations the group home wants to be transparent. The second allegation that staff does not prevent minors from being bullied. Based on confidential interviews LPA learned the facility staff works with the mental health staff to address bullying as well as staff stopping it when they observe it. During this complaint process, there were several conflicting and inconsistent statements. Therefore, LPA was unable to determine whether the above allegations were accurate or true and find the complaint allegations to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the allegation occurred. No deficiencies were cited.
investigation_findings: 13On 2/5/21, at 3: 30 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Gilmer conducted a follow-up complaint tele-inspection to the above facility and spoke to Administrator, Melissa Williams. The purpose of the call was to discuss and deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. While investigating the allegations, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Gilmer requested and received the following documents client case plan, personnel report, register of facility clients, personal record, and the daily shift log. LPA review the documents, interviewed the reporting party, five (5) foster youth placed at the group home; nine (9) staff; two (2) probation officers; and two (2) County Social Worker. The alleged victim was unavailable to be interviewed. (see Confidential name list dated 2/5/21) The allegation that a staff poses a risk to the children in placement was based on a criminal case involving a group home staff that one of the clients found on the internet.

narrative:
On July 14, 2021, at 10:15AM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection at Wendell House Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Melissa Williams, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to inspect the facility floor plan and records. LPA Flores and Melissa Williams toured the facility inside and outside. Overall the facility is clean and in good sanitary condition. The LPA Flores observed that the facility has 3 bedrooms. The passageways and entries are unobstructed. There is no swimming pool or body of water. The disinfectants and cleaning solutions were inaccessible to the children. The STRTP representative stated that there are no firearms/dangerous weapons. Facility has non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days. Facility provides, between meal, nourishment or snacks. Medications are locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. The temperature in the rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F) and the hot water temperature was at 106 degrees (F).

cont.#2 The carpet of the facility has stains and black spots. The facility representative stated that the last time that it was cleaned was on February 2021, and that it is difficult to conduct the cleaning with the children in the facility because due to the noisy of the cleaning equipment. The facility representative disclosed that there are no many places where the children can be taken while the carpet is been cleaned. Jay Williams stated that the carpet will be clean on Friday 7/16/21. LPA Flores observed that in Room #1 both beds were not made up and items were on the floor. In Room #3 (Master Bedroom) there is a bathroom that is been used by staff and other children in the facility. LPA Flores informed Melissa Williams that according to Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 3.1, Section 87087 (b) (5) No bedroom shall be used as a public or general passageway to another room, bath or toilet. An Advisory Note / Technical Violation was issued. Child Record: LPA reviewed a child's file. The file contain record of client’s admission agreement, medical assessment, consent forms, weight record, identification emergency information, appraisal and needs and services plan, immunization record, safeguards for property/valuables, personal rights form and cash resource information. The Medical Assessment form says "no results" for the tuberculosis test. Melissa Williams stated that the child's physician will be contacted to obtain a copy of the test.

cont.#3 Staff Record: An employees’ file was reviewed. The file contain the following documentation: First Aid Certificate, Department of Justice (DOJ)/Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) criminal record clearances, education verification, personnel record, health screening, criminal record statement, employee rights and tuberculosis test. A copy of this report, LIC858, LIC859 and LIC9102 were provided to the STRTP representative. Exit interview conducted.

It was alleged that staff encouraged youth to lie to law enforcement. It was also alleged that staff did not prevent youths from engaging in altercations. All five staff interviewed denied the above allegations. LPA conducted interviews with two clients. One client stated that the above allegations occurred, one client denied the above allegations and did not witness them. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On October 7, 2021 at 9:05 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegations above. LPA Martin met with the facility representative named above and discussed the findings. During the investigation, LPA Timika Martin conducted a record review on 9/15/21 and obtained copies of client’s needs and services plan (NSP), special incident reports (SIRs) and daily shift notes. LPA also requested copies of the LIC 500, staff contact information, staff daily shift schedule, staff trainings and restraint policy. Confidential interviews were conducted by LPA Martin with Client 1 (C1), Client 2 (C2), Staff 1 (S1) and Staff 2 (S2) on 7/29/21. Confidential interviews were also conducted with Staff 3 (S3), Staff 4 (S4), Staff 5 (S5), on 10/4/21 (See Confidential Names List Form LIC 811 dated October 7, 2021).

narrative: It was alleged that staff handled youth in a rough manner. Based on confidential interviews, staff handled C1 in a rough manner by grabbing C1 which resulted in both staff and client falling onto the floor. Based on records reviewed, this was an improper restraint. LPA conducted interviews with two clients. Two clients stated that the alleged allegation occurred. It was also alleged that staff speak inappropriately to youth. Based on a confidential interview, staff admitted to using profanity when clients are involved in altercations. Based on the observations, interviews and records review which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegations are found to be substantiated. Deficiencies are being cited in accordance with the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards Chapter 7.5 Version 3.1 section 87072(d)(11) Personal Rights (see LIC 9099-D). An exit interview was conducted and Plans of Correction were reviewed and developed with the licensee. A copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and left with the administrator of the facility whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.
investigation_findings: 13On October 7, 2021 at 9:05 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegations above. LPA Martin met with the facility representative named above and discussed the findings. During the investigation, LPA Timika Martin conducted a record review on 9/15/21 and obtained copies of client’s needs and services plan (NSP), special incident reports (SIRs) and daily shift notes. LPA also requested copies of the LIC 500, staff contact information, staff daily shift schedule, staff trainings and restraint policy. Confidential interviews were conducted by LPA Martin with Client 1 (C1), Client 2 (C2), Staff 1 (S1) and Staff 2 (S2) on 7/29/21. Confidential interviews were also conducted with Staff 3 (S3), Staff 4 (S4), Staff 5 (S5), on 10/4/21 (See Confidential Names List Form LIC 811 dated October 7, 2021).

deficiencies.description:
87072(d)(11) Personal Rights To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping…….
This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed revealed that staff are not using proper restraint/de-escalation techniques and are using profanity with clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide LPA Martin documentation indicating all staff are trained on proper restraints, de-escalation techniques and personal rights. Facility will provide trainings to LPA Martin via email Timika.martin@dss.ca.gov

narrative: On Tuesday, October 26, 2021 at 1:15 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Gilmer made an unannounced visit to this facility and met with Direct Care Staff, Sulma Navarro. The purpose of this visit was to discuss some documents Community Care Licensing received on September 8, 2021. However, when LPA arrived there was one resident and one Direct Care Staff working at the facility. LPA was later joined by Facility Director Jaye Williams at 2:01 pm, who addressed the plan of corrections. The Administrator Mrs. Williams also arrived at the facility during this visit. As per interim Licensing Standards Article 06 Personnel Requirement the licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when one or more children are present: This facility will be cited per the above violation. An exit interview was held with Direct Care Staff Sulma Navarro and a copy of the facility evaluation report and the Confidential names list.

On 11/4/2021 at 9:00 am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jenny Mundo and Pamela Silva conducted an SB (Senate Bill) 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection and met with Melissa Williams, the facility Director/Administrator. Currently, there are four (4) clients placed at the facility. One (1) of the four (4) clients is taking psychotropic medications and is placed by Kern County Department of Human Services (DHS). LPAs conducted a facility tour with the Director/Administrator at 9:30 AM. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. All medications are centrally stored, locked and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. LPAs reviewed the facility's Program Statement. LPAs reviewed one (1) client’s file and three (3) staff files. LPAs interviewed two (2) staff. LPAs were unable to interview one (1) client due to client not being at the facility. LPAs conducted an exit interview. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPAs provided one (1) Advisory Note - Technical Assistance (LIC 9102TA). A copy of this report was provided to the facility representative along with Confidential Names list (LIC 811).

On November 30, 2021, at 11:25AM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, at Wendell House Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Jay Williams. The purpose of the inspection was to gather information about the below incident reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). On 04/01/2021, the STRTP reported that Children Ref #1 (C1) and Ref #2 (C2) (see Confidential Names form LIC911 dated 11/30/2021) got in an altercation due to C1 was being loud and disruptive inside room #1, that C1 and C2 shared together. LPA Flores investigated the incident and interview Jay Williams. A review of the Children’s files was conducted, and copies were made upon request. The statement and documentation obtained revealed that C1 was yelling, cursing and slamming the door of room #1, C2 was not able to take a nap. Staff Juan Aguaya and Maricela Vargas intervened to de-escalate both children. C1 got into C2’s face and challenged him to “do something about it”.

cont.#2 C1 pushed Staff Juan Aguaya and Shontera Dixon to the bed, C2 threw a cellphone and frozen bottle of water at C1’s direction and Staff Maricela Vargas was hit on the face. Staff Maricela Vargas required medical attention due to injuries on her face. C1 was discharged on 05/27/2021, and C2 on 08/16/2021. Staff Maricela Vargas resigned on 03/11/2021. No further inspection is needed. No citation was issued. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

During this investigation, LPA Gilmer learned that the minor placed with Wendell has a history of swallowing foreign objects. The minor is required and was provided one on one supervision because of his history of swallowing objects. In confidential interviews it was reported that (S7) was with the minor at the cash register when the minor purchased two lighters. The minor took the lighters back to the facility went into the restroom and swallowed one of the lighters. The minor's one-on-one initially stated the minor jumped out of the car while he stopped to let pedestrians pass and by the time, he got inside the store the minor had already purchased his items. During a follow-up interview,with (S7) stated he was with the minor at the cash registerer, but he wasn't all up in his face watching what he purchased. Other interviews disputes (S7 ’s) claim that the minor jumped out of the car. And reported that (S7 ’s) account isn't correct. Based on interviews that were conducted, LPA Gilmer finds the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegation is found to be substantiated and the STRTP will be cited. Per the Title 22 Section 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. It was the responsibility of (S7) to ensure the minor was safe and as a result of the lack of supervision the minor purchased the lighter while (S7) was present and later swallowed it. An exit interview was held during the exit interview the appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13On 10/26/21, at 2:35 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Humberto Flores conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the findings to the above allegation. LPA Flores met with the Jay Williams, Executive Director to discuss the complaint finding investigated by LPA Belinda Gilmer. During the investigation, LPA Gilmer reviewed and obtain copies of the following: Client’s needs and services plan (NSP), facility communication log, register of facility client/residents’ forms, personnel form, and special incident reports (SIRs). On 09/10/21, LPA Gilmer spoke with the complainant, on 09/13/21, LPA Gilmer spoke with the Administrator and facility staff, on 09/27/21, LPA Gilmer spoke with two other facility staff, on 09/30/21, LPA Gilmer spoke with the facility staff, on 10/01/21, LPA Gilmer spoke with the foster child's County Social Worker, and on 10/13/21, LPA Gilmer spoke with the victim and the victim's one on one (S7).

deficiencies.description:
80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision:  The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.  
This requirement is not met as evidence by:
Based on confidential interviews the foster child has a one on one assigned to supervise him because of his history of swallowing objects.  Yet, the foster child's one on one allowed minor to purchase the two lighters.  One of which he ingested a lighter while at the facility. This poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide training in care and supervision to S7 and the staffs that transport children that are placed in the facility. A copy of the training will be sent to CCLD via mail by the POC due date.

narrative: The following allegations were made against the facility: Staff engaged in sexual behaviors in the presence of minors; staff intimidates minors; staff spoke inappropriately to minor; staff made minors feel uncomfortable, and staff did not report an incident to licensing. Confidential statements obtained during the investigation were unable to corroborate the allegations as there were no statements obtained to support the allegations. Facility staff denied witnessing or subjecting facility clients to any abuse. Facility staff also indicated that none of the clients has ever disclosed any abuse to them, and none of the clients has ever expressed that they were mistreated or bullied by any staff. Facility staff also denied that staff are engaging in sexual activities in the facility by either witnessing the activity or participating in the activity. Based on the information gathered, the allegations are unsubstantiated as the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met although the allegations may have happened or is valid. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.
investigation_findings: 13On January 13, 2022 at 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joshua Rarela conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegations above. LPA Rarela met with the facility representative named above and discussed the findings. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed the former and current facility clients on 7/13/21, 9/14/21, and 1/13/22, facility administrator and facility staff on 1/13/22 (see Confidential Names Form dated January 13, 2022). LPA also reviewed documents on 6/17/21 and 1/12/22 including placing agency referrals, facility incident reports and placing agency service logs. (CONTINUED)

narrative: On February 9, 2022, at 10:30AM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, at Wendell House Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with Melissa Williams. The purpose of the inspection was to review files. On 04/01/2021, the STRTP reported that Children Ref #1 (C1) and Ref #2 (C2) (see Confidential Names form LIC911 dated 11/30/2021) got involved in an altercation due to C1 was being loud and disruptive inside room #1, that C1 and C2 shared together. On 11/30/21, LPA Flores conducted the initial investigation and the initial findings for this incident were delivered. Additional documentation from the children’s files, for this inspection, was needed and collected today 02/09/2022. The STRTP representative stated that Staff Maricela Vargas submitted a worker’s compensation claim to request time off work in order to recover and fully healed the injury. No further inspection is needed. No citation was issued. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the facility representative.Exit interview conducted.

It was alleged that a staff member at the facility made inappropriate comments towards a client in care, telling them to act upon their suicidal ideations. In an interview conducted, one child stated that sometime between August 2021 and November 2021, a staff member stated that they should act upon their suicidal ideations in response to the child voicing their mental health struggles. The child stated that they understood the staff member may not have been seriously trying to get them to act upon their suicidal ideations, but that the comments were unprofessional and hurtful. In interviews conducted with two other children, both stated that they had not seen or heard of any staff members making those types of comments. One of the children elaborated and stated that the alleged victim did not get along with staff members, but that staff would never make comments like the ones alleged. In an interview conducted, the staff member that the allegations are centered upon denied making the comments. Two other staff members that were interviewed also stated that they had not seen or heard of any staff members making inappropriate comments like that towards clients in care. Staff members caught doing so would be immediately terminated from employment. Additionally, all staff members reportedly undergo personal rights training regularly. In an interview conducted, the child’s mental health therapist stated that the alleged incident had not been reported to him by the client and that they had not seen or heard of any staff members making any types of comments like that towards clients in care. A review of records indicated that around the time that this incident allegedly occurred, there were at least two instances in which there were concerns regarding the client’s mental health and possible self-injurious behaviors. In both instances, staff reportedly followed all proper procedures and obtained the assistance necessary to help the client through the situations. Based on interviews conducted and records reviewed, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the above allegation occurred. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met. Therefore, the allegations are deemed UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report, along with the Licensee’s Appeal Rights (LIC 9058 01/16) was provided to the Licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On February 04, 2022 at approximately 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raymond Wu conducted a follow-up complaint inspection with the facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegation above. LPA discussed the finding with the facility representative named above. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed clients on 11/23/21, staff members on 11/23/21, 12/31/21, and 02/04/22. LPA also reviewed documents on 02/03/22 including but not limited to client admissions agreements, their Needs and Services Plans, and Special Incident Reports. (Continued)

narrative: The investigation revealed that African American male staff were racially profiled, identified as Jamaican and accused of selling marijuana to Ref. #1. The Administrator denied that there were any Jamaicans working at the facility. Interviews did not provide any names of staff allegedly selling marijuana. Ref. #1 denied that the CEO handled Ref. #1 in a rough manner and denied observing staff place their hands on any other clients. Considering that Ref. #1 denied a personal rights violation about being handled roughly there was no special incident to report. A review of previous interviews of Ref. #1 indicated that staff may be annoying or rude, but Ref. #1 made no comments of violation of personal rights. The LPA reviewed Special Incident Reports and Needs and Services Plans for Ref. #1. The investigation revealed that the P.O. had no concerns about the facility. It revealed that the P.O. made unannounced visits to the facility and indicated that the facility is good about reporting. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegation. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On April 9, 2022 at 11:45 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, delivered the findings of a complaint investigation. The LPA met with Administrator, Melissa Williams. On September 10, 2021, the Monterey Park Children's Regional Program (MPCRP) received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. The investigation included confidential interviews, that consisted of, but were not limited to the: Administrator at the facility on November 15, 2021, the client's (see Confidential Names, LIC 811 Ref. #1 dated April 9, 2022) Probation Officer (P.O.) via telephone on March 23, 2022 and Ref. #1 at the facility on March 24, 2022. The investigation revealed that the allegation was denied by all the witnesses. The investigation revealed that Ref. #1 had gotten into trouble at school for smoking marijuana and based upon Ref. #1's admission had gotten caught by staff at the facility for attempting to smoke marijuana and had it confiscated.

narrative:
On 04/18/23 at 8:45 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Pamela Silva and Juliet Robles conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at the facility. LPAs met with Melissa Williams, Administrator. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) ambulatory children ages 12-17 years of age. The facility also provides services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1 (C)(1). There are four (4) minors and one (1) non-minor dependent currently in placement. This facility is a 3-bedroom single story home. There are no bodies of water in the premises. LPA Silva conducted a walk-through of the entire facility. Physical Plant The license, facility sketch, Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster form, Complaints poster, Foster Youth Bill of Rights, Complaints/Grievance policy, emergency phone numbers and menus are posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and sharps are kept inaccessible in a locked closet in the hallway. Facility has non-perishable food for at least one week and perishable food for at least two days. Medications are centrally stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in proper working order. Fire extinguishers are fully charged. Room temperatures are maintained at 76 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and was measured at 120 degrees F. All sinks, showers and toilets were in working order. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. Adequate supply of beddings and linens were observed. Emergency exits are free from obstruction. Overall, the facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair.

Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conduct meetings to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. The facility has developed, maintained and implemented written complaint procedures. Emergency Intervention Documentation of emergency intervention training for staff is on file. According to the facility manager, there have been no manual restraints recorded in the last 24 months. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least quarterly for each shift. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Core/Therapeutic Services Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. Client Records LPA Silva reviewed five (5) client records. Client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; removal/discipline/complaints form and medication administration records. During records review, all five of clients’ cash resources log do not show disbursements and balances. However, Administrator showed disbursement logs in a different form.

Staff Records LPA Silva reviewed three (3) staff records. All staff have been subjected to criminal records review and have been fingerprinted and cleared with DOJ, FBI and CACI. Documentation of the required education and experience requirements are maintained in the personnel file. Although training certificates were on file, documentation of initial training were not found in the staff files. LPAs interviewed three (3) staff members. LPAs were unable to interview clients due to all five clients were in school at the time of inspection. No deficiency citation was issued during today's inspection. However, a Technical Violation and a Technical Assistance were issued see LIC9102TV and LIC9102TA. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report, LIC9102TV, LIC9102TA,and LIC811 were provided to the Administrator..

On May 8, 2023 at 10:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a case management inspection at the facility. During this inspection, LPA met with the facility representative named above. The purpose of the inspection is to issue citations for the following deficiencies observed during a review of records by the Department. - Accepting placement of a client who did not meet the age requirement of the facility. - Needs and Services Plan of client was not signed by client and the clients’ authorized representative. These violations pose an immediate and/or potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. Deficiency citations were issued under California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80010 (a) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87068.2(f) Needs and Services Plan. A Plan of Correction was discussed with the facility representative. Copies of the following were provided at the conclusion of the inspection: LIC 809, LIC 809-D and LIC 811. Appeal rights given and explained.

Investigator Rippe conducted confidential interviews of the following: Facility Personnel on 12/5/22, 12/20/22, 1/4/23, 2/8/23, 2/16/23, 2/21/23 and 3/1/23; Bakersfield Police Department (BPD) Detective on 1/9/23, three clients on 1/12/23, and the Facility Administrator on 3/1/23. Follow up interviews were conducted as needed, between 12/7/22 and 3/2/23. It was alleged that facility staff did not prevent client from being sexually abused while in care. Confidential interviews reveal that two incompatible clients were placed in the same bedroom as roommates. Issues related to difference in ages, behaviors and background information were discussed with the Administrator by multiple staff prior to placement of client (C1) at the facility (see Confidential Names Form dated 5/8/23). There was also a dangerous sexual propensity noted on the other client’s (C2) Needs and Services Plan. Administrator still placed client (C1) with client (C2) in the same bedroom despite recommendation not to, citing that room changes would be too disruptive to other clients. There was no safety plan implemented. A few weeks after placement, client (C1) reported being sexually assaulted by client (C2). Details of the incident were disclosed by client (C1) to two staff and then later, to law enforcement. The incident was not reported by client (C1) right away due to threats made by the other client (C2). Administrator made room changes after the incident however, client (C1) was removed from placement. Other clients in placement were also removed after a report that client (C2) had inappropriately touched other clients in placement. Client (C2) denied the allegation. The Administrator denied being advised by any staff about the incompatibility of clients (C1 and C2). Other related parties gave consistent information when interviewed. Based on information obtained by Investigator Rippe from confidential interviews and records reviewed, there is a preponderance of evidence to support the allegation therefore, the allegation is substantiated. A deficiency citation is issued under California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80078(a) Responsibility of Providing Care and Supervision. This violation poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care. A Plan of Correction was discussed with the facility representative. Copies of the following reports were provided at the conclusion of the inspection: LIC 9099, LIC 9099-C, LIC 9099-D and LIC 811. Appeal Rights Forms were provided and explained. Per new Civil Penalty laws, Health and Safety (H&S) Code section 1548(E), a civil penalty determination is under review due to the substantiated allegation.

deficiencies.description:
The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Client was sexually abused while in care. Based on the background information of C1 and C2, there was no safety assessment completed and no written safety plan implemented by the facility prior to placing them together as roommates. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee will submit a written plan to ensure the safety and appropriateness of any room sharing arrangement by clients in placement. The plan must be submitted to the Department by email on or before the plan of correction due date.

narrative: On 5/19/23 at 9:55 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a case management inspection at the facility to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). LPA Yamamoto discussed the following with the facility representative named above. On 5/8/23, the Department concluded a complaint investigation on a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) which alleged that facility staff did not prevent client from being sexually abused while in care. Two clients were placed together in one bedroom even though there was no commonality in their ages, behaviors and background information to make them suitable roommates. The older client has a known dangerous sexual propensity towards younger children. Multiple staff expressed this concern to the Administrator, but clients were still placed together despite staff concerns. Based on the consistent statements obtained and records reviewed during the investigation, there was a preponderance of evidence that supported the allegation. The allegation was substantiated, and the facility was cited for Neglect/Lack of Supervision under California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80078(a). The Department has concluded an analysis and determined that an Enhanced Civil Penalty is warranted. Under Health and Safety Code section 1548(f)(1)(C)(ii), a violation that the Department determines results in physical abuse as defined in section 1548(f)(2) to a child receiving care through a STRTP, there shall be a civil penalty of $2500.00. Under H&S 1548, “physical abuse” includes neglect as defined in 11165.2 of the Penal Code, when the person responsible for the child’s welfare is a licensee, administrator, or employee of any facility licensed to care for children. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names Form, Appeal Rights, and the signed LIC 421-D (CRP) Civil Penalty Assessment – Death / Serious Bodily Injury / Physical Abuse were provided to the facility representative.

Based on the information obtained during the investigation, it cannot be determined whether the above allegations occurred. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the above-named facility staff.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Juliet Robles, and Timika Martin on 08/11/23 at 9:15 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs met with Desiree Gonzalez, Facility Manager and Melissa Williams, Administrator, and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed three (3) of children’s records and three (3) of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed three (3) of children’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPAs interviewed two (2) of staff on site to discuss the facility's policies and procedures of operation. LPAs interviewed three (3) children currently prescribed psychotropic medications. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Melissa Williams, Administrator and provided a copy of this licensing report.

Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged staff threatened resident with physical violence. Staff had similar statements and denied the allegation. Staff stated that one child has threatened staff and other children in the home, however staff denied that any staff threatened a child with physical violence or observed anyone being violent with any child. Interviews conducted with children had similar statements and denied the allegation. Children stated that they did not hear any staff threaten any children. One child stated they recalled hearing a story from another child of a staff making threats, however, child was unable to identify what staff and refused to speak of what child made statement. It was also alleged, staff called resident degrading names. Staff had similar statements and denied the allegation. Staff stated that they do not call children degrading names but have been called degrading names by children. Staff stated that some children use foul language and that it is protocol to redirect children to use better words when speaking to peers and staff. Children also had similar statements and denied the allegation. Children stated that they did not recall anyone calling them out of their name or anyone making derogatory statements. One child stated that they heard of a staff calling someone out of their name but was unable to identify which staff, when and where statement was made or in what context. Documents reviewed identified no issues with staff invoking physical violence or calling anyone a derogatory name. Although the allegations may have happened or may be true there is not a preponderance of evidence to support that the allegations did or did not happen. Therefore, this complaint is being closed Unsubstantiated. Exit interview was completed, no deficiencies cited, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator for review and signature.

narrative: This is a violation of the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards Chapter 7.5 Version 5 regulation 87072 (c)(1) To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. If the child is an Indian child, to live in a home that upholds the prevailing social and cultural standards of the child’s Indian community, including, but not limited to, family, social, and political ties. The specific violation was noted when the staff member (S3) admitted to making an inappropriate comment toward C1,” Why don’t you do us all a favor and go kill yourself” Statements obtained from S2 and C2 confirmed that the incident did indeed occur. If not corrected, it will have a direct and immediate risk to the health and safety of the children in care. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. The STRTP was cited, and a plan of correction was initiated. Appeal rights were provided and discussed with Mrs. Williams A copy of the report and the Confidential Name List (LIC811) dated February 9, 2024, was provided to the STRTP representative, and an exit interview was conducted.

No statements were obtained from C1, C3, and C4 due to clients declining to provide a statement to LPA. (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated February 9, 2024). Confidential statements and admission from S3 and a witness statement from S2 revealed noncompliance with (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards Regulation 87072 Personal Rights. (cont'd)

deficiencies.description: 87072 (c)(1) To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. If the child is an Indian child, to live in a home that upholds the prevailing social and cultural standards of the child’s Indian community, including, but not limited to, family, social, and political ties. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and an admission by staff member (S1) it has been found that (S1) did  an make an inappropriate comment by telling (C1) "Do us all a favor and go kill yourself."  This behavior poses a potential risk to the health, safety, and personal rights of the clients in their care.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Pamela Silva, Juliet Robles & Timika Martin on 09/05/24 at 9:00 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs met with Melissa Williams, Administrator, and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed two (2) of children’s records and three (3) of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed two (2) of children's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPAs interviewed two (2) staff on site to discuss the facility's policies and procedures of operation. LPAs interviewed one (1) of child currently prescribed psychotropic medications. One child was unavailable for interview at the time of inspection. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPAs conducted exit interview and provided a copy of this report to the Administrator, Melissa Williams.

LPA Mahecha reviewed documents submitted by facility and support agencies. Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged staff do not treat minors with respect. Interviews conducted with staff were similar in that all staff denied the allegation. Staff stated that children are treated with respect, dignity, and equality. Staff stated that children often are disrespectful towards staff, but children are redirected and encouraged to treat everyone kindly. Staff denied receiving reports of anyone complaining that staff were being disrespectful towards them. Interviews with children were similar in that children denied being treated disrespectfully at the home. One child stated that a staff that did treat them disrespectfully no longer worked at the facility would lie on them but denied that current staff treated anyone disrespectfully. It was also alleged facility does not have enough food for minors in care. Interviews conducted with staff were similar and staff denied the allegation. Staff stated that executive director goes grocery shopping on Tuesdays and buys ample food for all children in care. Additionally, if facility runs low on food staff will notify director and director will bring food when requested. Staff stated children are encouraged to participate in meal prep and cooking and have received no complaints regarding food being limited in the facility. Interviews conducted with children was similar in that children identified no issues with food or food amounts in the facility. Interviews with parole and county social workers identified no issues with the facility or children being placed in the facility. Documents reviewed identified no issues or concerns with staff being disrespectful towards children or facility not maintaining proper amounts of food. During initial inspection LPA McGee toured facility and observed ample food for children in care. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

narrative: On October 30, 2024, the Department received a complaint report alleging that staff S2 physically assaulted client C1. It was further alleged that S2 spoke to C1 in an inappropriate manner. LPA's investigation revealed that on October 26, 2024, at or around 5 p.m. through 6 p.m., C1 was eating dinner at the table along with S2 and S3, when C1 called S2 a "fat bitch." This resulted in S2 reacting by pushing C1's face down into his plate of food, which busted C1's lip. C1 called S2 a "bitch" again, which resulted in S2 flipping a couch over that C1 was on, with C1 bumping his head on a wall. C1 called S2 a "bitch" again, causing S2 to lift C1 by his shirt, pinning him against a wall. After C1 showered, he saw S2 and told him "your girlfriend sounds like a man," which resulted in S2 throwing a bottle of water at C1. C1 ran to the bathroom, with S2 flinching at C1, then telling C1 "if you come out of that bathroom, I'm going to make you shit yourself." C1 then ran into C2's room, where S2 picked him up by hugging his legs, and carried him out, bumping C1's head on the thermostat, before setting C1 down in his own room. C1 was offered first aid and medical attention, which were both refused. Confidential interviews, provided consistent statements that corroborated the allegations. Based on LPA's interviews which were conducted and record reviews, including an Incident Report dated October 27, 2024 and a Suspected Child Abuse Report (SCAR) dated the same, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22 STRTP Interim Licensing Standards Chapter 7.5 (Version 5), Article 06. Continuing Requirements 87072(c)(16), Personal Rights, are being cited on the attached LIC9099-Ds. The resolution to this complaint was discussed with the facility staff representative. A signed copy of all licensing reports were provided to facility representative. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were given and explained.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights: The licensee shall ensure that each child... is accorded the personal rights...To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, exploitation, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat...... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and documentary evidence, staff engaged in a physical altercation/contact with a client, which poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights risks to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
The Administrator disclosed that staff member was reported to authorities and employment was immediately terminated. 
Additionally, the STRTP will provide a refresher course to all staff on Personal Rights, including staff/client de-escalations. The Administrator will provide proof of the refresher courses by providing a sign-in staff roster sheet with employee signatures to LPA via email by 03/14/24.

Following deficiency is still outstanding : ILS 87095.65(d) The licensee must maintain a written record of the facility staff training. (due 4/21/25) - Emergency Intervention Training. On January 6, 2025, the Department received a complaint alleging that staff used an inappropriate form of restraint with a minor in care. It was further alleged that the STRTP did not comply with reporting requirements. LPA's investigation revealed that C1 did yell at S1 and pushed S1 out of the room and continued to pursue S1. S1 reacted by grabbing hold of C1's forearms, and sweeping C1's leg, causing C1 to go to the floor during the encounter. S1 has not completed his Managing Aggressive Behavior (MAB) training, the intervention training that the facility has been approved for. Per the facility, employees who are not certified are not to restrain clients. C1's case plan calls for employees equipped in this training. Document review of the Incident Report (IR) submitted by the STRTP revealed that the IR did not contain specific information required by Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) for incidents documenting the use of manual restraints Confidential interviews indicated that a restraint of C1 occurred, whether out of self-defense or otherwise. Based on LPA's interviews which were conducted and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22 STRTP Interim Licensing Standards Chapter 7.5 (Version 5), Article 10.3 Application Procedures 87095.22(j), Emergency Intervention Plan, and Article 06. Continuing Requirements 87061(i)(7)(A)(C) being cited on the attached LIC9099-D. The resolution to this complaint was discussed with the facility staff representative. A signed copy of all licensing reports were provided to facility representative. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were given and explained. This is an amendment of a report originally delivered 04/11/25, delivered on 05/02/25 by LPA Bonilla.

On January 6, 2025, the Department received a complaint alleging that staff engaged in a physical altercation with a minor in care. It was also alleged that staff antagonize the minor in care, with staff not leaving him alone while client was having a crisis. It was alleged that staff did not report an incident involving minor in care as necessary. Furthermore, it was alleged that staff do not accord respect to minor(s) in care, entering the client's room and not leaving. LPA's investigation revealed that on January 2, 2025, client C1 was having a rough day, by his own account and by account of all others interviewed. Staff (S1) did approach C1 and was asked to leave. As S1 left, C1 pushed S1, with C1 engaging into physical contact with staff, who sought to avoid confrontation. Staff denied provoking the altercation, and stated that he was only trying to de-escalate the client's already tense mood, and left when asked. Staff state that they treat all clients with respect. Staff stated that they do not antagonize the clients. Confidential interviews provided conflicting information, neither corroborating nor refuting allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are determined to be Unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited at this time. Exit interview conducted. A signed copy of this report, LIC9099-C, and LIC811 were provided to Administrator. Appeal rights provided. This is an amendment of a report originally delivered 04/11/25, delivered on 05/02/25 by LPA Bonilla.

deficiencies.description:
Emergency Intervention Plan 87095.22(j) Only trained staff as specified in Section 87095.65 will be allowed to use emergency interventions on children.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on document review and interviews conducted, a staff member not certified for restraints performed a restraint on a client, which poses a health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.

deficiencies.description: Reporting Requirements 87061(i)(7)(A)(C) Incident Reports... must include...: Date and time of other... restraints involving the same child in the past 24 hours. Description of what manual restraints were used, and how long the child  was restrained. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on document review, licensee did not include the date and time of other manual restraints involving same child in the past 24 hours; and description of what manual restraints were used, and how long the child was restrained. This poses a health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

narrative: On Tuesday, May 3, 2025, at 01:00 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted an unannounced inspection at Wendell House, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP).
