met_with: Desiree Gonzalez, Facility Manager Melissa Williams, Administrator
narrative:
On 04/03/25 at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Olena Maico conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at the facility. LPAs met with Melissa Williams, Administrator and Desiree Gonzalez, Facility Manager. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) ambulatory children ages 12-17 years of age. The facility also provides services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1 (C)(1). There are 2 minors currently in placement and one of them is on AWOL status. This facility is a 3-bedroom single story home. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There are no ammunition and firearms in the facility per the administrator’s statement. LPA Maico conducted a walk-through of the entire facility alongside with the Facility Manager. LPA requested LIC 500, LIC 9020, LIC 610C, LIC 309 and LIC 308 as well as the Emergency Drill records and Board Meeting records to be provided to the LPA. LPA compared Guardian roster to the facility roster and all the staff has clearance through the Guardian. Facility has current CARF accreditation expiring January 31st 2028, as well as Mental Health Services approval expiring November 16 2025. LPA observed the license, facility sketch, Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster form, Foster Youth Bill of Rights, Complaints/Grievance policy, menu and activity schedule posted in prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility in the living room and the kitchen area. Overall, the facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Facility just resurfaced their floor and when LPA arrived facility was organizing furniture in the rooms.

Physical Plant Facility has no cameras on premises. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and sharps are kept inaccessible. Sharps are locked in the kitchen closet. Facility has non-perishable food for at least one week and perishable food for at least two days in the fridge and meet the licensing standards. Medications are centrally stored in the office of the facility. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in proper working order. Fire extinguisher are fully charged and checked by the fire department October 2024. Room temperatures are maintained at 76 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and was measured at 120 degrees F. All sinks, showers and toilets were in working order. Currently each client has their own bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. Each client has the non-slip rug to use after shower. Emergency exits are free from obstruction. Kitchen had adequate number of dishes for the clients served. There are couches in the living room and the dining room to accommodate the clients. Fire place in the living room has cover and inaccessible to clients. Windows have blinds for client's privacy. Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conduct meetings to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. The facility has developed, maintained and implemented written complaint procedures and the procedures and forms are posted on the wall in the prominent place at the facility. Clients have the cash resources. Administrator provided LPA with minutes from 2024, the minutes for current period are being created. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least quarterly for each shift. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. LPA issued a technical assistance to the facility to comply with the regulation on updating the plan yearly and providing e-mail and phone numbers for the assigned personnel.

Core/Therapeutic Services Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. Head of Service oversee the therapeutic services for the clients Clients also visit Henrietta Weill Child Guidance Clinic for the therapeutic services. Client Records LPAs reviewed two client records. Client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; removal/discipline/complaints form and medication administration records. FC1 is on AWOL status and FC2 did not have TB test assessment on file. FC1 and FC2 psychotropic medication log was missing initials for multiple dates for the medication taken. FM checked the notes and medication was either taken or refused by the clients, but the log was not marked properly. Facility is issued deficiency for not following the psychotropic medication log procedures. Three (3) deficiency citations and a two Technical Assistance were issued during today’s inspection, see LIC809D and LIC9102TA. Plan of Corrections were discussed with the Administrator. LPA will return on another day to complete the inspection and review Emergency Intervention Domain and Staff files. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report, LIC809D, LIC811 and appeal rights were provided and explained to the Administrator.

On 04/07/25 at 9:15 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Olena Maico conducted an unannounced annual Inspection at the above facility. LPA met with Melissa Williams, Administrator. LPA continued annual inspection LPA started on 04/03/2025. LPA requested 5 staff files as well as the Emergency Intervention Plan training for the staff and the certificates and the certificate for the trainer. LPAs reviewed five (5) staff records (See LIC 811 List of Confidential Names dated 04/07/25). LPA reviewed staff health screening and TB test results, background clearance (DOJ, FCBI and CACI), driver license records, application, resume and educational records, as well as training records which includes trauma informed care, cultural awareness, behavioral support for youth, CPR/First Aid. LPA reviewed Administrator qualifications and they are in compliance with CCLD requirements. Head of Service flexibility request was approved for the facility by the Department of Health Care Services. Head of Service does meet education and experience requirements. LPA reviewed Emergency Intervention staff training and the training curriculum. LPA also requested the training instructor certificate from the Administrator, who conducts the MAB training for the staff. LPA did not observe training certificates for the MAB in the staff S3,S4,S5 files. LPAs interviewed two (2) staff members. LPA interviewed one (1) client.

Two (2) deficiency citations and two (2) Technical Violations were issued during today’s inspection, see LIC809D and LIC9102TV. Plan of Corrections were discussed with the Administrator. Copy of this report and LIC 809D was explaind and given to the Administrator as well as appeal rights.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Pamela Silva and Juliet Robles on 07/16/2025 at 9:50 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs met with Facility Manager, Desiree Gonzalez, and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed four (4) of children’s records and three (3) of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed four (4) of children’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPAs interviewed one (1) staff on site to discuss the facility's policies and procedures of operation. LPAs interviewed one (1) child currently prescribed psychotropic medication. During the inspection, the LPAs observed deficiencies (see attached 809D). A Technical Advisory was issued (see LIC 9102). Plan of corrections were discussed, and appeal rights were provided. LPAs provided a copy of this licensing report and appeal rights to Desiree Gonzalez, Facility Manager.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Hillary Hall arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management inspection following a record review. LPA Thorn conducted the case management. LPA Thorn reviewed records from the facility including: staff scheduling rosters, staff contact information, criminal record clearances, and staff training log for the last three months. Additionally, LPA Thorn interviewed facility administrator and 8 staff. One staff member was working directly with clients without the required clearances. On 8/30/23, the staff member informed LPA Thorn they had been working for the past 7 months and knew they did not have a criminal record clearance on file. On 9/7/23, Administrator confirmed the staff did not have the required clearances, and the staff was pending an exemption. The staff was put on leave on 9/1/23. The facility is issued a citation per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 6, Chapter 1, Article 3, Section 80019(e)(2): All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (2) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department An immediate civil penalty is being assessed, for $100 per day for a maximum of 5 days, resulting in a $500 civil penalty. A signed copy of this report, the LIC 809D and LIC 421BG were provided to the facility. Exit Interview was conducted and Appeal Rights were provided.

deficiencies.description: Section 80019(e)(2): All individuals subject to a criminal record review... shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (2) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department This regulation was not met based on : one staff member did not have a criminal record clearance prior to working at the facility which poses a potential risk to the health, safety, or personal rights of the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
As of 9/1/23 the staff worker was no longer working.
Administrator has implemented a policy that Administrator will confirm that all employees have criminal record clearances prior to hire.

narrative:
On 1/16/2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Hillary Hall arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Paige Woodard, Administrator. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required, Two year Annual Inspection of the facility. The facility was licensed 12/22/2022. LPA and LPM utilized the CARE Tool to complete the inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized, and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility is on a large campus with many buildings. Each client has their own bedroom in a dorm like setting. The dorm has 6 client bathrooms. All bathrooms were observed to be clean and fully functioning. The dining hall is separate from the dorms. Each client had a closet and dresser in good repair. Mattresses and bedding were observed to be clean. Clients were able to decorate their rooms with their personal belongings. The facility has a properly fenced pool, and opportunities for clients to access sports equipment. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, client personal rights, and emergency disaster plan. Smoke alarms, fire extinguishers and a first aid kit were observed to be current and within regulations. LPA observed the kitchen to have 3 restaurant sized refrigerators and freezers with at least 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food on hand. LPA observed client medications were stored in a locked file cabinet in the locked office. Client files are primarily electronic with paper files for clients locked in the Head of Service's office. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility currently has 16 clients, with a licensed maximum capacity of 16. Staff to client ratio is 1 to 4. LPA reviewed 5 staff files. Staff clearances were reviewed and all staff had required initial and annual training. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for staff. LPA interviewed three staff on site. Continued on 809C

Continued from 809 LPA Thorn interviewed three clients. LPM reviewed five client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements on file. Needs and Service Plans (NSP) for clients were reviewed. Three out of five clients did not have an initial NSP completed within 30 days. Five out of five clients' NSP were not updated every 30 days. Some NSP were duplicated. Four out of five NSP were not signed by the client. Five out of five NSP were not signed by the authorized representative. The facility did not have evidence of attempting to obtain signatures from authorized representatives. Clients were current on CHDP physical exams and dental exams. Clients prescribed psychotropic medications had current JV-220’s on file. Facility is issued three citations per Interim Licensing Standard Sections 87070(c)(1) Children's Records, 87068.2(a) Needs and Service Plans, and Section 87068.3(a) Modifications to Needs and Service Plans A signed copy of this LIC-809, LIC-809C, and LIC 809D, report was provided to the Administrator. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided

deficiencies.title:
Modifications to The Needs And Services Plan

(a) The needs and services plan specified in Section 87068.2 shall be updated at least every 30 days to determine the following

narrative: On 05.23.24 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived at facility unannounced for the purpose of a Case Management regarding a record review and met with Program Director. LPA interviewed Program Director and placing agency regarding timely medical records for youth. Program Director had indicated that there was a delay in obtaining the needed exams due to problems they have been having with both insurance coverage payments and delays due to providers not being able to schedule out appointments for clients within the 30 days. Program Director agreed to CC LPA on all emails sent to probation around this issue and to send a list of all clients who are being affected by the delay. A plan to mitigate the lack of timely exams has been implemented. No citations issued at this time.

met_with: Courtney Costello, Head of Service, Paige Woodard, Program Director
narrative: On 06.20.24 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced for a case management inspection for the purpose of following up on a Serious Incident Report. LPA met with Courtney Costello, Head Of Service and Paige Woodard, Program Director and reviewed the file for one client and interviewed the administrator and client. No citation was issued at this time

During the months of July-September 2024, 11 (24)hour serious incident reports were submitted to the Department without corresponding final reports being submitted. There were five incidents involving restraints which were not reported to the Department. Four staff were unable to explain to the LPA what the process is to report incidents. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. Three citations are being issued for violating Title 22, Division 6, Section 80028(a): Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision, Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87072(c)(17): Personal Rights, and Title 22, Division 6, Section 80061(b). A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and LIC-9099D were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided.

Regarding allegations of staff not addressing minors’ health care needs, interviews with staff and clients indicated the facility has a medic on site. However, some interviews denied medical care as being available for clients when asked. Staff and clients reported that clients had access to three meals and a snack daily, but statements differed regarding the quality and quantity of the snacks, and the process for how to address when a client misses a meal. One staff reported that if a client acts up, they are not given a meal. Interviews and record review were inconsistent regarding the allegations that staff inappropriately restrained a minor resulting in injuries, and staff handled minor in a rough manner. One staff reported observing another staff push a client against a wall, however, no clients interviewed corroborated this statement. Regarding the allegation of staff hitting a minor with a vehicle resulting in injuries, interviews were inconsistent. One client reported having stolen a golf cart at the facility, but not getting injured. No incident report was submitted to confirm any other client or staff involvement. Regarding the allegation of staff not intervening when a minor engaged in self-harm, interviews were inconsistent. An incident did occur in the stabilization room involving electrical wiring. Client and staff interviews provided inconsistent statements regarding whether the wiring was exposed or not, and accessible to clients. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegations may have happened, or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violations did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the facility on 12.19.24 for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with NAME, TITLE. LPA Thorn and LPA Lyta Vue conducted the complaint investigation. LPA opened the investigation with the facility on 10.11.24 and met with Paige Woodard, Program Director and conducted a Health and Safety Inspection. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed One Probation Officer, Three staff, and one client. LPA reviewed records including: Needs and Services Plan for one client, Intake form for one client, LIC 500, Placing Agency Contacts, Staff Training Log, and Incident Reports, and a video. Regarding a lack of supervision for the client the facility submitted an incident report stating that a staff was disciplined for sleeping on night shift. It was alleged that staff made inappropriate comments toward the minors. Client and three staff interviews corroborated that on occasion, staff speak inappropriately to the clients, or with a derogatory tone. Two staff spoke of this being an ongoing problem and staff need more training.

deficiencies.description: Responsibility to provide care and supervision: (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. this requirement was not met as evidenced by: Facility reported a staff fell asleep on night shift, posing a potential risk to the Health, Safety, and personal rights to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Program Director and Compliance Manager will spot check the PM program to ensure proper safety checks are made on clients and provide drop-in unannounced visits. Program Director will provide training for PM shift staff about supervision protocol. Director will provide LPA with sign-in sheets for training.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights: To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse and from corporate or unusual punishment, exploitation, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or acts of a punitive nature....This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Interviews were consistent that staff used inappropriate language toward clients, posing a potential risk to the Health, Safety, and Personal Rights to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Program Director will do training about personal Rights and will individually address issues reported by clients or staff who have concerns.

deficiencies.description: ......a report shall be made to the licensing agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition a written report containing information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to licensing agency within 7 days....This requirement was not met as evidenced by: 14 (7 day) reports were not submitted to the department between July-September 2024 and 5 restraints were not reported at all, posing a potential risk to the Health, Safety, and Personal Rights to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will provide process for timely reporting incident to the department and provide proof of training to staff who are involved in the process

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management following a record review of drug tests conducted on a youth at the facility. Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Hillary Hall conducted the record review. LPM reviewed records from the facility indicating 1 youth was drug tested 3 times during the time period of 12/02/24-1/31/25. Of the 3 drug tests documented, all were done for reasons listed as return from home pass, or day pass. LPM reviewed the Program Statement for the facility and found no policies and procedures regarding drug testing youth. LPM contacted the youth’s authorized representative who indicated they did authorize the youth to be drug tested, but were unaware the policies were not outlined in the facility Program Statement. LPM spoke with Program Director (PD) Paige Woodard on 2/4/2025 who indicated there were no known written or internal policies on drug testing the youth and the staff are not trained on drug testing. One citation is being issued per Title 22 Division 6, Section 80022(k): Plan of Operation: (k) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. A signed copy of this 809 and 809D was provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
Section 80022(k): The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Per record review and interview, one client was drug tested at the facility, which was not outlined in the program statement, posing a potential risk to the Health, Safety, and Personal rights of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will add drug testing protocol to the facility program statement and send it in writing to LPA. The protocol will include calling youth's social worker or probation officer to be granted permission to perform a drug test. All employees authorized to test will be trained by administrative staff.

narrative: It was alleged that a minor was sexually abused in care by another minor. All confidential interviews with staff and 5 of 6 youth interviewed indicate that they had no knowledge of this incident. Those staff and youth interviewed stated that neither minor had reported any concerns or complaints about being sexually harassed or abused by another youth in care. Records reviewed showed no indications of concerns or complaints being brought to staffs’ attention and that both minors ran away from the facility. Three confidential interviews revealed that both youths stated that they hated being at the facility and would often talk about leaving on their own. Six of Seven staff interviewed explained supervision to be appropriate and that protocol about supervision was in place and being followed. Based on LPA’s interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: On 08.28.25 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) NAME arrived unannounced at the facility on for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Paige Woodard, Program Director. LPA Thorn conducted the complaint investigation. LPA opened the investigation with the facility on 06.12.25 and met with Paige Woodard, Program Director. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed 6 youth and 8 staff. LPM Hillary Hall conducted one other confidential interview. LPA reviewed records from the facility including Placement Roster, prior complaint history, Serious Incident Reports, CFT notes, and case notes for 2 youth, and LIC 500.

narrative: On 11/17/2020, an unannounced SB484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian at 1:00PM. During the inspection, LPA met with Dorothy Shanklin, Administrator and Sammantha Wood, Direct Care Staff and inspected the facility inside and out. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via FaceTime. All file and medication documents were sent to this LPA on the dates prior to inspection. A medication count was also conducted by FaceTime on this date. LPA reviewed five children's records and reviewed two staff personnel records for the facility. LPA interviewed two staff via FaceTime at 2:00PM. LPA interviewed 5 children via Facetime. No deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Dorothy Shanklin, Administrator at 3:00PM. LPA provided the summary report to Dorothy Shanklin, Administrator upon completion by email with a request for signature and a scan back to this LPA on this date.

On December 14, 2020 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco conducted a Tele-Visit Case Management inspection for Youth Acceptance 1 and met with Dorothy Shanklin. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss a deficiency discovered during an interview. During interviews conducted with staff and youth it was disclosed that during the morning shift there was only one staff available for 6 youth in the home. This is a violation of the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5 Version 3.1 Articles 1 through 10. The Agency is being cited for violation of Section 87065.5(a)(1) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. The Department determined this to be an immediate risk to health and safety of the children in care at this time, therefore the interim licensing standards are being cited on the attached LIC809D. Due to COVID-19 An exit interview was conducted over the phone, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email. Signatures were also requested via email and will be documented on an LIC812.

On 2/08/2021, an unannounced SB484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Eduardo Barragan at 2:00 PM. During the inspection, LPA met with Dorothy Shanklin, Administrator and Samantha Wood, Direct Care Staff and inspected the facility inside and out. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via FaceTime. All file and medication documents were sent to this LPA on the dates prior to inspection. A medication count was also conducted by FaceTime on this date. LPA reviewed four children's records and reviewed two staff personnel records for the facility. LPA interviewed two staff via FaceTime at 3:10 PM. LPA interviewed four children via Facetime at 3:35 PM No deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Dorothy Shanklin, Administrator at 4:05 PM. LPA provided the summary report to Dorothy Shanklin, Administrator upon completion by email with a request for signature and a scan back to this LPA on this date.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lourey Bartolome called and spoke with House Manager Chris Toledo. LPA discussed with HM the incident that occurred in the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program where one of the youth in the home used the STRTP's cell phone and had access to inappropriate content that was on the phone. Staff was unaware that the youth had access to the inappropriate content. Staff was made aware after the fact. Based on the information the was obtained, there was a violation of the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5 Version 3.1 Articles 1 through 10. The Agency is being cited for violation of Section 87078(b) Responsibility for providing Care and Supervision. The Department determined this to be a potential risk to health and safety of the children in care at this time, therefore the interim licensing standards are being cited on the attached LIC809D. This report was emailed to House Manager and a signed copy was requested to be scanned back to LPA.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Lourey Bartolome and Lisa Slusher as well as Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Melanie Krage conducted a tele-visit as a result of Covid-19 related restrictions, and in accordance with Regional Office Memo (ROM 20-11-CCLD). The purpose of this inspection is to conduct a case management inspection. The associated LIC 811 (Confidential names list) note client names, dates of birth and admission dates. All Clients lacked current needs and services plans in the files provided to the department. Current NSPs were provided subsequently by the licensee. All clients placed following licensure as an STRTP on 9/23/19 lacked certification that they meet STRTP eligibility requirements and lacked a crisis management assessment. On this date, the facility is issued deficiencies for the following violations of CCR title 22, STRTP ILS Section 87068.1 (b)and (d) Intake Procedures.Youth

During the course of investigating the allegation, LPA conducted interviews with staff and clients. The information revealed inconsistencies. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the above allegations occurred therefore the above allegation is unsubstantiated No deficiencies were cited. A copy of the report was emailed to the House Manager.

13On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lourey Bartolome conducted a complaint inspection for the purpose of delivering the findings for the above complaint allegation. LPA spoke with Administrator Dorothy Shanklin. During the course of the investigation, Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted interviews, review of records and review of video camera footage from the facility. The information obtained during the interviews and video footage indicated that the Group home staff did not provide any de-escalation techniques prior to the restraint of a youth, the restraint which was also done inappropriately. Type B: This poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care. Based on the LPA’s observations, interviews, records review and camera footage, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegations are found to be substantiated. Facility was cited for The Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) Chapter 7.5 Version 3.1 Articles 1 through 10. The Agency is being cited for violations of Section 87095.00(c)(1) General Provisions.

deficiencies.description:
GENERAL PROVISIONS Short-term residential therapeutic program staff may be justified in using restraints as an
emergency intervention if all of the following conditions are met:
(1) The restraint is reasonably applied to prevent a child exhibiting assaultive behavior
from exposure to immediate injury or danger to self or others;

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, Review of Records and Video Footage from the facility, staff inappropriately restrained a youth, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: By due date, Administrator is to provide LPA with a copy of their staffing plans that indicate the facility will remain in compliance during a restraint. Administrator already provided LPA with a copy of the training that was provided to staff.

investigation_findings: 13On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lourey Bartolome conducted a complaint inspection for the purpose of delivering the findings for the above complaint allegation. LPA spoke with Administrator Dorothy Shanklin. During the course of the investigation, Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted interviews and review of documentation. Based on interviews and documentation, staff could of prevented inappropriate sexual interaction between youth and physical altercation between . Staff did not conduct the nightly checks and staff were not supervising the clients to prevent the above allegations from happening. Therefore the above allegations are substantiated. Type A: This poses an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care. Facility was cited for Title 22, Section 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision

deficiencies.description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision	 (a)	The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This regulation was not met as evidenced by: Staff did not conduct the nightly checks and staff were not supervising the clients to prevent the above allegations from happening. This poses an immediate risk to the health and safety of the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff have been written up and have been retrained. LPA received copies of the write ups. By due date, Administrator is to provide proof of the training that was provided to the staff.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst, Corina Carrillo conducted a Case Management Inspection on July 7, 2021 at 9:00am, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.7. 4 out of 12 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files as identified on the LIC 811 Confidential Names dated July 7, 2021, were reviewed. 2 out of the 12 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 5 youth were also interviewed. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Dorothy Shanklin, Administrator.

On this date, an unannounced annual inspection begins at the corporate office for Youth Acceptance 1. On this date, LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) observed employee files and training records through extended reach. All staff have appropriate fingerprint clearance. No deficiencies noted in areas observed.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisa Slusher travelled to the facility listed above to Continue the annual inspection begun on 9/17/21. The facility listed above is accredited through CARF and has current Mental Health Program Approval through Fresno County. The following were observed upon inspection of the physical plant: 1. Facility Grounds are clean and free of debris or observable hazard. 2. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. 3. Chemicals appropriately locked. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications observed. Observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications. 5. First aid kit complete with appropriate manual observed. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. 8. The house has 4 bedrooms, double occupancy, located on the second level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of nonperishable foods observed upon inspection. 10. Weekly menu posted and accessible to clients. 11.Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 12.Facility has two full restrooms in the house for client use, one half-bath (toilet only) all are operable. 13.Appropriate forms posted in view of facility clients. 14.No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility.

The following items were discussed and reviewed by LPA during Inspection 1. LIC 500 Reviewed to ensure appropriate staffing ratios, including Administrator, Social Work personnel, and Direct Care staff. 2. Administrator Dorothy Shanklin is present on-site a minimum of 20 hours per week. 3. Personnel files reviewed prior to today's inspection to ensure staff meet regulatory requirements. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Personnel Files are retained at the office at 5100 N. Sixth Street, Suite 171-172, Fresno 93710. 4. Client files reviewed on this date. Client and staff interviews conducted. No deficiencies noted in areas observed.

On this date, a case management inspection is conducted at the Imagine You office in Fresno, CA. Discussed facility program statement and mental health program. Discussed regulation updates and facility processes. Visit concluded.

On this date, a case management inspection is conducted by LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) Lisa Slusher. Met with Administrator Dorothy Shanklin. The purpose of this inspection is to follow up on issues that were uncovered during the course of an investigation. A Technical Advisory is issued for the following areas: The current point/discipline system does not meet regulatory requirements for trauma informed discipline procedures, nor does the written plan account for developmental differences, historical trauma or client-specific differences between youth in care, The facility is to submit updates by 1/21/22. A review of the facility's food costs for October of 2021 as well as interviews with facility personnel, youth and others indicates the facility's budget for food is below the USDA's recommendations. Interviews also indicate dissatisfaction with the quality and quantity of food served with meals. The facility is advised to connect with youth and current recommendations. A review of Volunteer Program information as well as personnel , client and other interviews indicates that The program implemented by the facility is not well-understood by personnel or clients. There is a discrepancy in information about how many hours are required, whether partial hours count, and whether behavioral issues impact client payment. The facility is encouraged to detail these items to make the program and details clear for all involved.

investigation_findings: 13On December 3, Liicensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisa Slusher conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at Youth Accep. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. LPA Slusher interviewed staff, clients and reviewed pertinent documents. Based on interviews conducted and information gathered, there were some discrepancies found. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to facility Administrator.

narrative: On this date, LPAs (Licensing Program Analysts) Lisa Slusher and Vanessa Galvan conducted a case management inspection at the corporate office for Youth Acceptance 1. The purpose of this inspection is to address issues from file reviews and physical plant inspection. On 1/26/22 LPAs observed and photographed small pieces of glass in the street in front of the facility. Reports by staff indicate this is left over from an incident on 1/13/22 where the window of a staff's vehicle was broken by facility clients. The pieces of glass, while small, are large enough for youth to utilize the pieces for self harm. A citation is issued on this date for CCR title 22, Division 6 section 80087(a)

investigation_findings: 13On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisa Slusher conducted a complaint inspection for the purpose of delivering the findings for the above complaint allegations. LPA spoke with Administrator Dorothy Shanklin. During the course of the investigation, Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted interviews and review of documentation. Based on interviews and documentation, clients have on multiple occasions been picked up late from school. On at least one occasion, client's journal was read by staff and pages were torn out. Clients have been brought religious pamphlets to read. During an incident in August of 2021, C2 (See LIC 811) pushed a table, hitting S1 in the chest. S1 became upset and threatened to break the nose of C2. Interviews conducted note that youth were not allowed a cell phone until level 4. There are no notations regarding cell phones in needs and services plans. Type A: This poses an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care. Facility was cited for Title 22, Section 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision and 87072(c) Personal Rights. A civil penalty is assessed on this date.

deficiencies.description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision  (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This regulation was not met as evidenced by: Youth have been picked up late from school on several occasions according ton interviews conducted.  This poses a threat to the health, safety or personal rights of clients in care.  This section was previously cited on 6/4/21.  A civil penalty of $250 is assessed on this date and will continue at $100 per day until corrected.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator, Administrator will take the school break to determine why youth are being picked up late and make appropriate changes to ensure youth are picked up on time in the future.

deficiencies.description:
87082(c) (8) Personal Rights-The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights:(8)	To make,*send,*and receive confidential telephone calls *and other electronic communications,* unless prohibited by court order.
(A)	Reasonable restrictions to telephone use may be imposed by the licensee. The licensee shall be permitted to:
(B)	All restrictions shall be documented in the child's needs and services plan or the facility's discipline policies, and be signed by the child's authorized representative.
(C)	Calls permitted to be restricted by subsections (A)1. and (A)2. above shall not include calls to the child's authorized representative, placement agency, family members (except by court order), social workers, attorneys, Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA), probation officers, *representatives designated by the child’s Indian tribe to participate in the juvenile court proceeding,* Community Care Licensing Division of the California Department of Social Services or the State Foster Care Ombudsperson. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Interviews conducted by LPA as well as a review of needs and services plans during course of investigation substantiate that youth's cell phone use is limited without appropriate notification in a needs and services plan.  In addition, phone calls to family are restricted to 15 minutes per day.  This poses a risk to the health safety or personal rights of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator, changes have been made to cell phone policy, and all restrictions will be client specific and noted in a needs and services plan.  Additionally, phone calls to family will no longer be limited unless in a court order.

deficiencies.description: 87082(c) (8) Personal Rights-The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights:(10)	To be accorded dignity in *their* personal relationships with staff and other persons.  This requirement is not met as evidenced by: S1 threatened to break C2's nose during an incident that occurred in August of 2021.  Additionally, clients' personal journals have been read and had pages torn out without cause.  Religious beliefs of staff have been imposed on youth, which has made clients uncomfortable.  This poses an immediate risk to the health, safety or personal rights of youth.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Adminsitrator, documentation of corrective action will be submitted by the end of the day to LPA L Slusher Via Email.

narrative: On this date, a case management inspection is conducted by LPAs Lisa Slusher and Vanessa Galvan. Discussed qualifications of Administrator. On this date, LPA provided a Technical Assistance advisory note regarding administrator qualifications and duties.

On 03/16/2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Lisa Slusher and Tamara Melikian conducted a case management inspection for the Youth Acceptance 1 facility. Met at the corporate office of Youth Acceptance 1 by Administrator Dorothy Shanklin. The purpose of the inspection is to issue a deficiency for personnel not having appropriate Emergency Intervention Training. The purpose of the inspection is to also issue a deficiency for Mental Health Rehabilitation Specialists (MHRS) being used as direct care staff impeding their duties as an MHRS. Deficiencies on the attached page.

deficiencies.title: Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. (e) A facility may count its certified administrator, facility manager, or a mental health rehabilitation specialist, as defined by the Department of Healthcare Services, towards its staff to children ratio, provided
deficiencies.description: (1) Doing so does not prevent the individual from conducting the specific duties for which they are is employed.(2)	Appropriate care and supervision is maintained.

narrative: On May 5, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tamara Melikian and Lisa Slusher conducted an unannounced case management inspection to issue deficiencies to the above facility. Met by Administrator Dorothy Shanklin. Reportable incidents occurred on April 9, 2022 involving C1, C2 and C3 (see LIC811 dated 05/05/2022) that were not reported to Community Care Licensing. In addition, an incident occurred on April 13, 2022 involving an emergency intervention technique with C3 (see LIC811 dated 05/05/2022). Incident report received by Community Care Licensing states that C3 needed to be manually restrained because C3 and the staff were on the stairs as C3 was trying to push through the staff to go upstairs. The incident report states that the "Manual restraint was needed due to client and staff being on the stairs in an area where the risk of injury would be more likely and result in greater severity". The report does not indicate that the client exhibited assaultive or aggressive behavior presenting an immediate danger to themselves or others. Deficiencies on the attached page. A copy of this report was given to Administrator Dorothy Shanklin.

On May 5, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tamara Melikian and Lisa Slusher conducted an unannounced case management inspection. Met by Administrator Dorothy Shanklin. The purpose of the inspection is to issue a deficiency for an incident that occurred regarding cash resources for former client C1 (see LIC811 dated 05/05/2022). The facility utilized a Pandemic EBT card issued to C1 to pay for facility groceries. The client left the facility in May of 2021. The card was received by the facility in August of 2021 and utilized in September of 2021, December of 2021, January of 2022 and February of 2022. PEBT cards are issued to the recipient and are not to be utilized by other individuals. Deficiencies on the attached page. A copy of this report is given to Administrator Dorothy Shanklin on this date.

deficiencies.title: Admnistrator Qualifications. (a)	The administrator shall have the following qualifications
deficiencies.description: (3)	Knowledge of and ability to comply with applicable law and regulation.

narrative: On the above date, an office meeting is held at the CCLD office at 1314 E. Shaw Ave., Fresno. Licensing Program Analyst Lisa Slusher, Licensing Program Manager Lourey Bartolome and Regional Manager Nelson Martinez were present for the Department. Imagine you representatives Dorothy Shanklin, Executive Director and Administrator) and Jeffrey Johnson, Chief Financial Officer and Emergency Intervention (CPI) instructor. The purpose of this meeting is to discuss the Non-Renewal of the Mental Health contract and Mental Health Program approval by Fresno County Department of Behavioral Health. The facility's MHPA will expire on June 30, 2022 and will not be renewed by Fresno County DBH. The facility is to submit a closure plan as described in PIN 18-03 by 5/30, regardless of the Licensee's plan for the facility. Additionally, the licensee, including board approval is to submit a plan for the future of the facility, describing how the licensee intends to move forward.

On June 2, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Lisa Slusher and Tamara Melikian conducted a case management inspection with the above facility. Met by Executive Director Dorothy Shanklin. The purpose of the case management is to issue a deficiency for the facility not having mental health program approval effective May 17, 2022. In addition, the facility will not have site certification or a contract effective June 30, 2022. Deficiency on the attached page. A copy of this report is given to Executive Director Dorothy Shanklin on this date.

Administrator, based on interviews and admission, has not been present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours per week. Staff person #1 (See LIC 811) did not have a fingerprint clearance prior to working with youth in the facility. Type A: This poses an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care. Type B: This poses a potential threat to the health, safety or personal rights of clients in care. Based on the LPA’s observations, interviews, records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegations are found to be substantiated. A copy of the report and Appeal Rights was provided to the agency. Facility was cited for The Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) Chapter 7.5 Version 3.1 Articles 1 through 10. The Agency is being cited for violations of Section 87072(c) Personal Rights, 87064 (a) Administrator Qualifications, 87078(b) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision, 87095.24(a) Runaway Plan, 87065.5(a) Direct Care Ratios, 80019(c) Criminal Record Clearance.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Lisa Slusher and Tamara Melikian conducted a follow-up complaint inspection with the above facility. Analysts met with Administrator Dorothy Shanklin. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of the investigation, Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted interviews with facility staff and foster youth and other interested parties as well as conducted a review of records including incident reports and police reports. The information obtained during the investigation substantiates the allegations. A review of the staff schedule notes only one staff person between 7:00 and 8:00am and only one staff member between 9:00 and 10:00 pm consistently. Interviews and staff schedule indicate other times when the facility has not met appropriate ratios. A review of needs and services plans for C1, C3 and C5 indicates a need for 1:1 Staffing. Additionally, several incident reports indicate as follow up that the facility is adding 1:1 staffing. The youth served by the facility have a high incident of suicidal ideations and attempts. Facility is not meeting the needs of these youth.

deficiencies.description:
87065.5	Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios	(a) 	In a facility with a licensed capacity of six or fewer children, there shall be coverage by direct care staff as follows:
(1) 	During the hours of 7 am to 10 pm, there shall be one awake and on duty direct care staff for every three children, or fraction thereof, present, at a minimum. This requirement is not met as evidenced by:  A review of facility schedule for January 2022 notes only one staff person on duty between 7:00 and 8:00 am and 9:00 and 9:00-10:00 pm daily.  This poses an immediate threat to the health, safety or personal rights of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator, Schedules have been updated to reflect appropriate ratios. Schedule provided to LPA on this date.

deficiencies.description:
87078	Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision 		  
(b)	The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's or nonminor dependent’s needs and services plan, or Transitional Independent Living Plan, and/or individualized health care plan for each child with special health care needs, as applicable, as necessary to meet the child's or nonminor dependent’s needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: A review of needs and services plans for C1, C3 and C5 indicates a need for 1:1 Staffing.  Additionally, several incident reports indicate as follow up that the facility is adding 1:1 staffing.  The youth served by the facility have a high incident of suicidal ideations and attempts.  Facility is not meeting the needs of these youth.  This poses a threat to the health, safety or personal rights of clients.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Per Administrator, facility has fewer clients and is able to address the client needs with staff.  Additional Staff have been hired. 

Schedule given to LPA on this date.

deficiencies.description:
Criminal Record Clearance- 80019(c)
(c)	Prior to the Department issuing a license, the applicant, administrator and any adult other than a client, residing in the facility shall obtain a California criminal record clearance or exemption as specified in Health and Safety Code section 1522(a)(4).  This requirment is not met as evidenced by: Interviews, staff schedule and fingerprinting records indicate that staff person #1 does not have a fingerprint clearance and performed the duties of a direct care staff as well as a MHRS.  This poses an immediate threat to the health, safety or personal rights of clients.  A civil penalty of $500 is assessed in accordance with section 80054(b)
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Dorothy Shanklin, this was an Administrative error in which the facility thought the staff person was cleared.  This staff person is no longer employed by the facility and the faciilty will ensure all staff have appropriate clearances and associations prior to employment or client contact.

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights(c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable.  In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights:
(10) To be accorded dignity in *their* personal relationships with staff and other persons.  This requirement is not met as evidenced by: C5 is deaf and requires translation services.  At the time of placement only one staff person used ASL and the facility was relying on C1 to provide some translation.  This poses an immediate threat to the health, safety or personal rights of clients.  This section was previously cited on 12/21/21.  A civil penalty is assessed on this date in accordance with section 80054(d). A dally penalty will continue until corrected.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Dorothy Shanklin, The facility has expanded services for the youth, including employing an interpreter and ensuring that C5 has full access to her iPad used for translation services.  Facility will contact the county for additional necessary ASL services.

deficiencies.description:
87095.24	Runaway Plan		  
(a)	The licensee must develop, maintain and, when necessary, execute a written runaway plan. The runaway plan must describe how staff will respond to the following:
(1)	Runaway child(ren).   This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Interviews and incident report reviews note that on multiple occasions, staff took additional clients either on foot or in facility vehicles to follow or search for runaway youth.  This is not part of the approved Runaway Plan included with the facility's program statement and is not in line with Trauma-informed care. This poses a threat to the health, safety or personal rights of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator, it is not the intent of the facility to have staff take additional youth with them to respond to runaway youth.  This has been communicated to staff and will no longer be a practice.

deficiencies.description:

(a) 	In addition to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80064, the following shall apply.
(1) 	The administrator shall be on the premises for a minimum of 20 hours per week to manage and administer the short-term residential therapeutic program in compliance with applicable law and regulation. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Admission of administrator, staff schedule and interviews all verify that Administrator has not been present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours per week.  This poses a potential threat to the health, safety or personal rights of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator, on site hours have been increased.  A staff schedule was provided to LPAs on this date, reflecting 32 on-site hours per week.  A post schedule will reflect the specific on-site hours by Administrator.  Deficiency Cleared.

investigation_findings: 13On the above date, LPAs (Licensing Program Analysts) Lisa Slusher and Tamara Melikian met with Administrator Dorothy Shanklin for the purpose of delivering the findings for the above noted complaint. During the investigation, LPA reviewed placement and file documents, receipts and conducted interviews. C1 was discharged from the facility in May of 2021 A P-EBT card was mailed to the facility in early August of 2021 in the amount of $1234.00. Receipts and other records confirm that the EBT card was utilized to pay for facility groceries in September of 2021, December of 2021, January of 2022 and February of 2022. The facility utilized more than $500 of the P-EBT funds. P-EBT funds are for the use of the recipient only. The facility failed to return the card to C1 and instead comingled client's funds with facility funds. Based on the evidence above, the allegation is

deficiencies.description: Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property and Valuables.  (e)	Cash resources, personal property, and valuables of clients shall be separate and intact, and shall not be commingled with facility funds or petty cash.  Facility utilized C1's P-EBT funds for groceries for the facility after client had been discharged from placement. This poses a potential threat to the health, safety or personal rights of youth.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Administrator, facility will reimburse and/or return funds in the full amount of the issued P-ebt card to the authorized representative for C1.  Verification will be submitted to CCLD by the due date.

met_with: Tamika Boyce, Marie Thomas, and Anthony Wagner,
narrative:
On June 4,2025 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Guadalupe Munoz and Gilbert Marquez conducted and announced pre-licensing inspection and completed Component III. LPAs met with Executive Directors, Tamika Boyce, Marie Thomas, and Anthony Wagner, The facility is a five bedroom two bathroom single-family, single-story home with an in ground pool and with an attached garage. The applicant is applying for a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) with the capacity of six ambulatory clients aged between 6-17 years old. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Clients will use a cordless telephone to make and receive confidential telephone calls. The facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors tested and were observed to be in working order; the fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The facility has a first aid kit that needs a thermometer. The applicants stated there were no weapons in the facility. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be stored and locked in the garage. Sharp knives will be stored in a locked in garage cabinet. Medication will be locked and stored in a cabinet in the staff office. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

The following required forms need to be posted in the facility: Personal Rights form, Foster Care Ombudsmen Poster and LIC 610 Emergency Disaster Plan, and Grievance Policy. The facility is set up as follows The entry hallway leads to an open living room that flows into the dining area and attached kitchen. There is a an open study area for clients that has two desks and will be equipped with one shared computer for clients. At the back of the home is a multi purpose room that will be used for family visits and private meetings. All shared living spaces have furniture in good condition. At the rear of the home is the pool. It is an enclosed structure that can be accessed through a sliding glass door. Facility is pending having pool secured in compliance with Title 22 Regulations. There are three client bedrooms that are designated for two clients per room with twin sized beds dresser and closet space for each client. Bedroom #1 is designated as the staff office and will house client files, staff files and centrally stored medication. Bedroom #2 is: designated for two clients, with two twin beds, built in dresser drawers and two closet spaces. Bedroom #3 is designated for two clients, two twin beds, built in dresser drawers and two closet spaces. Bedroom #4 is designated for two clients, two twin beds, two plastic dressers with three drawers each and closet space. Bedroom #5 is designated as a multi purpose room that can be used for family visitation and private therapy sessions. Each room has adequate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses. and a medication office.

LPAs observed the following areas that need to be corrected: Posting the required forms and information Closet Light fixtures need chains to turn on Individual Lock boxes for the storage of contraceptives for clients Seven days of nonperishable food Locked Personal Storage area for clients Pool cover/safety latch Window screens for the pool area windows Based on the facility pre-licensing inspection, the facility will make the corrections and LPA Munoz will return on Thursday June 19, 2025 to complete pre licensing inspection. All special incident reports (SIR's) will be sent via e-mail to: cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov. The reporting requirements were reviewed with the Applicant on this date. LPA explained that once the license is approved, all employees shall have an approved criminal record clearance for CCL and be associated to this facility. narrative: On March 03, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lisi Leon made an unannounced case management inspection for the purpose of delivering findings for the case management opened on January 4, 2023 involving a special incident report (SIR) that was received by Community Care Licensing (CCL) on December 06, 2022 involving Client #1 (C1) for being searched upon each facility entry. Confidential interviews revealed residential clients (RC) were searched upon AWOL, when they arrived home from school and on outings while being supervised. Other confidential interviews revealed upon return to the facility at any time an RC is being asked to empty all of their pockets or backpacks and all the RC must comply with the search. Further confidential interviews revealed RC have substance abuse issue and facility will find contraband in rooms upon daily search of rooms and staff were trying to prevent substance abuse and contraband in the facility. An additional confidential interview confirmed clients are being searched upon entry of the facility every time. The facility is being cited for violation of Personal Rights per Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) version four, Personal Rights section 87072(d). Refer to citation on 809-D. A copy of this report was discussed and given to facility representative along with appeal rights.

On December 29, 2022 at 08:20 AM, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA’s) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Lisi Leon arrived at Youth Development Center Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by facility Administrator Christopher Fowler (FA). The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There were four clients and two staff present during this inspection. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. Mr. Fowler led the physical inspection of the facility with LPA’s. The facility consists of four bedrooms and three bathrooms. One bedroom is used as the staff office and has a restroom inside that is also available for clients to use. There also a separate office that is used for therapy sessions. The facility has a dining area, a kitchen area, a living room, a staff office, laundry room, playroom and a garage. The laundry room is located off the hallway. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All the bedroom windows have the screens. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There were no bodies of water. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Televisions, a computer, board games, video gaming console, workout equipment, and books, were observed for client’s recreation time. There is an activities calendar posted and staff are getting back to scheduling outings and outside activities. Carbon monoxide detector is in appropriate working order and facility smoke detectors are also in working order. Fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. There is an extra freezer and refrigerator in the laundry room. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are stored in a locked box within a locked closet in the staff office. The hot water in the staff and client restrooms was deemed to be at a safe temperature. Per facility staff, there are no firearms or weapons in the facility. Continued on page 2

Chemicals and/or poisons are locked in a cabinet in the laundry room. Sharp objects/knives are stored in a locked box in the locked closet in the hallway. First Aid Kits are also stored in the hallway closet and in the staff office. closet and are complete. A First Aid Manual was also available. Medications were stored in a locked box in the hallway closet. It was observed that the licensee has cameras in common areas of the facility as well as the staff office, outside facing the front door and in the backyard facing the windows and side wall. There is an exception on file for the facility to use the cameras and the facility continues to meet the terms and conditions of the exception. Client files are kept in a locked file cabinet within the staff office. LPA’s reviewed four client files during time of inspection. All four of the client files reviews had required documents in the file. LPA's also reviewed five staff files and all of the files were complete and had had all required documents. All staff that work at the facility have Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearances, CPR/First aid and training hours. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, are no deficiencies found at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was reviewed and given to facility representative Christopher Fowler.

On January 26, 2024 at 1:35 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, conducted an unannounced collateral visit at Youth Development Center, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with Facility Manager, Breana Areyan. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a confidential interview with a client. A copy of this report, LIC 809, was provided to Facility Manager, Breana Areyan.

On December 1, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that minors had access to drugs while in care. Specifically, it was reported that three clients (C2, C3, C5) were all under the influence of drugs and alcohol. Confidential interviews stated that C3 tested positive for Benzodiazepines "Benzos" at the hospital. Confidential interviews could not confirm whether or not the Benzos were accessed at the facility. Confidential interviews stated further that C2, C3, and C5 tested positive for alcohol intoxication while at the hospital. Confidential interviews continued stating that once staff was aware of the clients condition they monitored clients and sought medical attention for C2, C3, and C5’s physical conditions. Confidential interviews could not confirm where or when the clients had access to alcohol. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute the allegation. Based on confidential interviews the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met and the allegations that C1, C2, and C3 had access to drugs while in care, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time.

(Continued from LIC9099) Video evidence was shared with Community Care Licensing (CCL) that showed the side/back view of a woman driving with two teens; one in the rear seat, and one in the passenger seat of the vehicle, used to transport clients. One of the teens was smoking what looked like a vape pen and blowing smoke. There was writing on the screen of their cell phone which said, “Staff Come Through.” The identity of the woman seen in the video was verified, by Community Access Network Administrator, as FSC. FSC was engaged in vaping in the company car while minors in care were present, and FSC’s employment was terminated on April 5, 2024. Based on confidential interviews and recorded video, the allegation that Staff engaged in vaping with minors while in care is SUBSTANTIATED. The preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standard, Version 5, Section 87074 (b) Transportation. An exit interview was conducted. Copies of this report, LIC 9099D, and appeal rights were explained and given to Jacqueline Gonzalez, Lead Facility Manager, on this date.

LPA was greeted by Jacqueline Gonzalez, Lead Facility Manager (LFM), and assisted with walk through. An update of facility roster was verbally given and updates to youth were addressed. A walk through of facility showed no deficiencies. There are 2 empty rooms that are ready for 4 placements when needed. LPA thanked Jacqueline Gonzalez (LPM) for their time.

Continued from LIC9099 They went about their day and did not see anything suspicious. Additional confidential interview reported that the behavior of staff could have been taken as flirtatious by minor in care but was not sure of minor’s interpretation. Other confidential interview revealed that staff did not engage in inappropriate interactions with minor(s) in care. According to confidential interview, the staff’s kindness must have been taken for a weakness, and the tattoo may have signified Jesus, but they were not sure. Confidential interview indicated that staff tries to be nice towards all youth in care, as it is what the job entails. Youth in care are emotional and go through issues, and staff try to be there for them to talk through situations if needed. Other confidential interviews revealed that they were shocked at the allegations. According to confidential interviews, the staff were all spoken to regarding their classifications and how to maintain dealings with youth so that it is not misinterpreted. Additional confidential interviews reported that there was no favoritism among staff and youth. They were unaware of any problems or inappropriate behaviors occurring between clients or staff. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that facility staff engaged in inappropriate interactions with minors in care may have occurred or is true, however there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation that facility staff engaged in inappropriate interactions with minors in care is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to Youth Development Center Lead Facility Manager, Jacqueline Gonzalez.

investigation_findings: 13On June 24, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Velasquez arrived unannounced to deliver findings regarding the allegation above. On February 7, 2025, the Department received allegation that staff do not provide adequate supervision resulting in minors engaging in physical altercations with other minors. narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Joon Choi and Cynthia Ramos on July 9, 2025 at 10:55 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs Choi and Ramos met with Administrator Guadalupe Arellano. LPAs were then assisted with a facility inspection where no immediate safety hazards were observed. LPAs reviewed three of child’s records and two of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs provided a copy of this licensing report to Administrator Guadalupe Arellano. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) arrived unannounced for the purpose of this visit is to follow up with the incident that occurred on June 27, 2025. Medication was issued to incorrect client on this date, and pharmacy was contacted. The dosage was partially more milligrams of strength and would cause drowsiness to client. There were no immediate dangers to client in care. Training of staff will be executed so that incident does not occur again. The issue during the issuing of medication occurred when out on a hike, staff grabbed the incorrect medication as an issue had just been gone over with a different client in care. Staff's attention was on that client, and for this reason the incorrect medication was drawn from container. Staff was instructed, trained, and disciplinary action taken. A copy of this LIC809 was reviewed with Jacqueline Gonzalez, Lead Facility Manager. There is no need for additional follow up.
