met_with: Youth Homes Pryor Administrator Christal Black
narrative:
At 3:33PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met with the home above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a Case Management inspection. The purpose of this Case Management Inspection was to address additional incidents that were discovered during Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives' record reviews and interviews. LPA met with Youth Homes Pryor Administrator Christal Black, who helped facilitate this inspection in Youth Homes Andersen Administrator Meghan Chapman's absence. Also in attendance were Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, Regional Manager Nelson Martinez, Youth Hoes Clinical Director Linda Callahan, Youth Homes Vice President of Residential Services Shatae Jones, and Youth Homes CEO Cameron Safarloo. See LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 09/04/2020. LPA Fremont requested a copy of the facility's most current LIC500 - Facility Roster to be submitted no later than end of business hours today, 09/04/2020. During an interview with S3 on 05/12/2020 at 1:30PM, S3 stated that she first learned of C1's sexual assault of C2 during a counseling session with C2. S3 went on to describe that when she found out about the assault, action was taken the minute it was reported. Upon review of Concord Police Department's report on the incident, it was found that C4 had disclosed details of the assault to S3 two days prior to C2's disclosure of the assault. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

S3 was interviewed again on 06/23/2020 at 11AM to ask clarifying questions. When asked why she did not report the physical and sexual abuse of C2 when C4 reported it, S3 stated that she did not believe C4 was telling the truth because C4 had a negative history with C1. When asked why she did not question C2 about the allegation the first time it was reported, S3 responded, "I can't answer that." S3 did not report this incident of suspected child abuse of a minor to CCL by the next business day and jeopardized Concord Police Department's (CPD's) investigation into the incident. By the time the incident was reported, it was too late for CPD to conduct a Sexual Assault Response Team (SART) Exam for C2, or collect potential evidence from C2's bedroom because the trash had been picked up already. Based on the information gathered, there is a preponderance of evidence that the licensee did not promptly report an incident of sexual and physical abuse of a minor to the proper agencies, including but not limited to Community Care Licensing, Concord Police Department, and Child Protective Services. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care. A deficiency is being cited per Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80061(b)(1)(G) Reporting Requirements. See the attached LIC809-D for details. During review of facility records, Incident Reports, and Needs and Services Plans for C1, C2, C3, and C4, it was found that at the time of the incidents of this complaint, C1 was noted as having high supervision needs, and enhanced supervision was recommended. According to the home above, enhanced supervision requires that a client have more frequent and thorough room checks, at least every 10-15 minutes. In an interview with S4 on 04/01/2020 at 11AM, CCL inquired about the supervision needs of each client, and S4 stated that he was unaware of C1 or any other client being on enhanced supervision. Regardless, S4 acknowledged that he was the only awake staff on duty at the time of the incident on 02/11/2020 when C1 choked C2 in the facility bathroom, and he did not call on-call supervisors for assistance with client supervision. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

Additionally, LPA Fremont conducted a case management inspection at the home on 05/14/2020 regarding an incident that occurred at the home on 04/23/2020 wherein C3 got into a physical altercation with S6, who is alleged to have hit C3 in the chest or the chin. Although the allegation that S6 hit C3 may have happened or is valid, based on conflicting and changing witness statements, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation happened. However, it was found through interviews with C3, S1, S6, S7, and S8 that just prior to the altercation, S6 and S8 were locked in the facility office eating lunch and S1 was out of the home running errands, leaving S7 to be the only staff in charge of supervising clients. According to statements by C3, S6, and S8, S7 was on a separate floor of the house from the clients, playing video games prior to the incident. Based on the information gathered, there is a preponderance of evidence that direct care staff at the home did not have the care, supervision, and protection of the clients as their first priority at the time. A deficiency is being cited per STRTP Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5, Version 3, Article 6, Section 87065.2(b)(1) – Personnel Duties. See the attached LIC809-D for details. During the process of finalizing this complaint, LPA Fremont inquired about the Needs and Services Plans for C1, C2, C3, and C4 from the time of the allegations. LPA Fremont received Needs and Services Plans for C1, C2, and C4 from Administrator Meghan Chapman on 08/04/2020 at 1:39PM, and C3's on 08/19/2020 at 1:25PM. Upon review of these plans, LPA Fremont observed that each of the client's plans were almost identical and appeared to be copied and pasted from a master plan, with only names, dates, and some other small changes made. Based on observations that Needs and Services Plans were not personalized to each client, there is a preponderance of evidence that the facility is not evaluating the individual needs and services of each of its clients. A Technical Advisory is being issued per STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5, Version 3, Article 6, Section 87068.2(a) - Needs and Services Plan. See the attached LIC9102 for details. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

Finally, based on the information above, observations by LPA Fremont and IB investigator Austin, interviews with staff, clients, and records review of facility files, Community Care Licensing provided technical advisory that the facility should re-evaluate its training needs, specifically in regards to Mandated Reporting, Client Care/Supervision, Personal Rights, and Personnel Duties. This plan to re-evaluate training needs will be discussed further in an upcoming Noncompliance Conference scheduled between Community Care Licensing and Youth Homes Andersen. A Technical Assistance is being issued per STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5, Version 3, Article 6, Section 87065.1(b) – Training Requirements. See the attached LIC9102 for details. Deficiencies, Advisory Notes, and Plans of Corrections (POCs) for the above deficiencies have been discussed with the home. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights discussed and provided, and a copy of this report was given to Administrator Meghan Chapman over email due to COVID-19 precautions.

narrative: At 2PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met with the home above over Zoom video conferencing for the purpose of following up on an incident that occurred at the home on 08/26/2020. LPA met with Administrator Meghan Chapman, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 4 clients. 4 clients and 3 staff were present during this inspection. (See LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 09/01/2020). LPA Fremont requested copies of all client's Needs and Services Plans from the time of the incident as well as plans that were modified after the incident to reflect program consequences, staff schedule for the 08/25/2020 PM shift to the 08/26/2020 PM shift, staff shift log from the 08/25/2020 PM shift to the 08/26/2020 PM shift, an LIC624LE Law Enforcement Contact Sheet for 08/26/2020, the facility phone number, and all staff phone numbers. LPA requested that all documents be submitted no later than 12PM on 09/02/2020. LPA Fremont conducted confidential interviews with S2, S7, and S9. . At this time, no citations are being issued. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Meghan Chapman with read receipt due to COVID-19 precautions.

met_with: Youth Homes Pryor Administrator Christal Black
narrative:
On 05/12/2020 at 1:30PM, Inv. Austin conducted an interview with S3. During this interview, S3 stated that none of the clients were on Line-Of-Sight or increased supervision at the time of the incidents mentioned previously. This is corroborated by interviews with S4 on 04/01/2020 at 11AM, and S2 on 06/04/2020 at 3:31PM, who both stated the clients were "on level" that week, meaning no client was on increased supervision. This is contradicted by interviews with S1 on 05/12/2020 at 2:25PM and S7 on 05/12/2020 at 2:52PM, who both stated that C1 had a violent past and was on Line-Of-Sight supervision the week of the incidents. This is also contradicted by a records review completed by LPA Fremont during a complaint inspection of the home on 02/24/2020 at 10AM. During this record review, LPA Fremont found that the home had copies of C1's intake paperwork from their previous placement at Youth Homes Cherry Lane, which stated that C1 was a high risk for violent and sexual behavior, and increased supervision was recommended. This is contradicted by a statement made by S5 in an interview with Inv. Austin on 05/06/2020 at 3:24PM, stating that the home does not often have a client's full history when they arrive at the facility. LPA Fremont has since received the Needs and Services Plans for C1, C2, C3, and C4 from the time of the complaint, and C1's plan notes they were on a high supervision level. During a forensic interview of C2 on 02/19/2020 at 2:09PM, C2 was asked how often staff check on the clients during the night. C2 stated that staff usually check on the girls every hour overnight, but that on the night of 02/10/2020, when C1 sexually assaulted C2 in their bedroom, the overnight staff did not perform room checks because they were sleep. This is corroborated by a forensic interview with C4 (C2's roommate) on 02/19/2020 at 2:45PM, who, although admitting she was under the influence that night, remembered the sexual assault but did not remember overnight staff checking on the clients that night. After several other interviews of staff and clients, Inv. Austin has not been able to determine which staff was on duty that night, due to conflicting statements. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

On 04/01/2020 at 11AM, Inv. Austin conducted an interview with S4. During this interview, S4 stated that on the night of 02/11/2020, when C1 physically assaulted C2, he witnessed C1 and C2 going into the bathroom, together and locking the door. S4 was the only staff member on duty at the home on the night of the incident. S4 states that he knocked on the door to tell the girls to get out of the bathroom, and heard what he described as "moaning noises" coming from the bathroom. S4 disclosed that he was texting his supervisor, S5, throughout the incident, not the on-call supervisor at the time. S4 acknowledged that S5 lived too far away (Sacramento) to respond to the incident, and he did not call the on-call supervisor to respond. In interviews with S1 on 05/12/2020 at 2:35PM, S7 on 05/12/2020 at 2:52PM, and S5 on 05/26/2020 at 3:24PM, all stated that if two clients have locked themselves in a bathroom and there is no female supervisor on duty to pick the lock, the staff on duty are supposed to call the female on-call supervisor to respond to the incident. S5 acknowledged in her interview that she was at her home in Sacramento at the time of the bathroom incident when S4 called her. When asked why she did not instruct S4 to call the female on-call supervisor to get support, she stated that everyone calls her because she always answers the phone. S5 also stated that she did not think C1 and C2 were in the bathroom as long as S4 thought, and she thought he estimated the time wrong. Finally, an incident report dated 02/12/2020, written by S9, states that on that day, C3 came up to S9 to tell her that C1 stole her phone the previous night, and she wanted to fight C1. S9 writes that she advised C3 not to take action. At this time, according to C1's Needs and Services Plan dated 02/07/2020, C1 should have been on high supervision protocol. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

S9 goes on to write that she was in the front yard of the house with other staff getting ready for the home's routine dump run when another client came out of the house to get staff's attention because C1 and C3 were in the upstairs hallway in a physical altercation. According to C3's medical records dated 02/12/2020, this altercation resulted in her being treated for a nail avulsion and neck strain/sprain. C3 was later seen for a follow-up appointment on 02/24/2020 and given a secondary diagnosis of concussion without loss of consciousness. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove that the licensee did not provide the level of care and supervision required by the clients it had in its care. Therefore, the allegations Lack of Care and Supervision resulting in a minor physically assaulting other minors, and Lack of Care and Supervision resulting in a minor sexually assaulting another minor, are substantiated. The facility is being cited deficiencies per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5, Version 3, Article 6, Section 87078(a) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. See the attached LIC9099-D for details. Additionally, due to the substantiated allegations above, and based on interviews with staff, clients, and review of facility records including incident reports involving C1, C2, and C3, the licensee denied its clients the personal right to live in a home free from physical or sexual abuse by allowing a client with a history of physically and sexually assaultive behaviors to be unsupervised around other clients. The facility is being cited per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5, Version 3, Article 6, Section 87072(d)(11) - Personal Rights. See the attached LIC9099-D for details. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Youth Homes Pryor Administrator Christal Black with read receipt due to COVID-19 precautions.
investigation_findings: 13At 2:42PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met with the home above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a Complaint Findings Delivery Inspection. LPA met with Youth Homes Pryor Administrator Christal Black, who helped facilitate this inspection in place of Administrator Meghan Chapman. Also in attendance were Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, Regional Manager Nelson Martinez, Youth Hoes Clinical Director Linda Callahan, Youth Homes Vice President of Residential Services Shatae Jones, and Youth Homes CEO Cameron Safarloo. See LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 09/04/2020. On 02/14/2020, the San Jose Children's Residential Regional Office received a complaint regarding C1 sexually assaulted C2 and physically assaulted C2 and C3. C1 was said to have sexually assaulted C2 in her bedroom on the night of 02/10/2020 by inserting the handle of a hairbrush into C2's vagina. C1 physically assaulted C2 by choking her when they were locked in the bathroom together on the night of 02/11/2020. The complaint also states that C1 and C3 were left unsupervised on 02/12/2020 while C1 was on high supervision protocol, allowing the two clients to get in a physical altercation that resulted in C3 being treated for injuries to her fingernails and head/neck. This complaint was taken as a complaint by Community Care Licensing's (CCL's) Investigations Branch (IB) and assigned to Inv. Rhonda Austin on 02/18/2020. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

deficiencies.description: 87078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: (a) The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's or nonminor dependent's needs and services plan [...] as necessary to meet the child's or nonminor dependent's needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observations, interviews with staff and clients, and records review of C1, C2, and C3's files, the facility did not provide the supervision its clients needed for their safety, as identified in their needs and services plans and previous Youth Homes Admission paperwork for C1. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee agrees to submit a plan to audit and address the following items no later than 12AM on 09/05/2020: Prudent Parenting Standards, STRTP regulations, Staff training, organization hiring practices, and the formation of a Crisis Team that provides extra support to on-duty staff.

deficiencies.description: 87072 Personal Rights: (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accordded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the the following personal rights: (11) To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse [...]. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews with staff, clients, and review of facility records including incident reports involving C1, C2, and C3, the licensee denied its clients the personal right to be free from physical and sexual abuse by allowing a client with a history of sexually and physically assaultive behaviors to be unsupervised around other clients. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee agrees to submit a plan to audit and address the following items no later than 12AM on 09/05/2020: Prudent Parenting Standards, STRTP regulations, Staff training, organization hiring practices, and the formation of a Crisis Team that provides extra support to on-duty staff.

met_with: Youth Homes Pryor Administrator Christal Black
narrative:
During the course of the investigation into this allegation, Inv. Austin conducted interviews with the following staff of Andersen House: S1, S2, S3, S5, S6, and S7. In an interview with S1 on 05/12/2020 at 2:35PM, S1 stated that Andersen House did not have problems with clients bringing weapons into the home. She also stated that if there was suspicion a client had brought weapons into the home, there would be an immediate room check. This is corroborated by an interview with S7 on 05/12/2020 at 2:52PM. In this interview, S7 stated he had never heard of clients bringing weapons to Andersen, adding that there would be a room search if a client was acting suspicious or showing concerning behavior such as self-injurious or substance abuse related behaviors. S7 also stated that he did not know if C1's room was ever searched for weapons. In an interview with S2 on 06/04/2020 at 3:31PM, S2 stated that she was also unaware that C1 had a history of possessing knives at the facility. This is corroborated by an interview with S6 on 06/24/2020 (time not specified in Inv. Austin's report), in which S6 stated she had never heard about C1 having knives at the facility and had never searched C1's room for weapons. S6 also stated that one time when C1 was on extended AWOL, she packed up C1's belongings and did not find any knives. In an interview with S5 on 05/26/2020 at 3:24PM, S5 stated that after C1's removal from the home, she was packing up C1's belongings and found a butter knife. S5 stated that she was not aware that C1 had a history of stealing knives or frequently exhibiting violent behavior until after C1 was removed from the home. S5 also stated that they do not often have a client's full history prior to them arriving to the facility. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

This is contradicted by a review of C1's file on 02/24/2020 by LPA Fremont, who found that Andersen House had C1's full history from their prior placement at Youth Homes Cherry Lane, including C1's admission assessment from Cherry Lane that stated C1 had an extensive history of physically and sexually assaultive behaviors, and was at high risk for substance abuse and CSEC behaviors. Although the allegation that a client has access to knives in the home may have happened or is valid, based on Inv. Rhonda Austin's observations and interviews with clients and staff, and LPA Fremont's review of facility files, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation that a minor has access to knives in the home is unsubstantiated. At this time, no deficiencies are being cited regarding this allegation. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights discussed and provided, and a copy of this report was emailed to Youth Homes Pryor Administrator Christal Black with read receipt due to COVID-19 precautions.

met_with: Youth Homes Andersen Administrator Donna Heimbruch
narrative:
On 03/04/2021 at 10AM, an announced Office Meeting was held to discuss a substantiated allegation of a lack of care and supervision resulting in a minor physically assaulting another minor which resulted in the minor sustaining a concussion diagnosed by a physician. The meeting was conducted virtually over Microsoft Teams due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Present in this meeting from Youth Homes Andersen were Administrator Donna Heimbruch and Youth Homes Director of STRTP Operations Ronnie Mabou. Present from Community Care Licensing (CCL) were Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont. The current census is 4 ambulatory female clients. On 02/14/2020, the Department received a complaint (Control #14-CR-20200214155207) alleging a lack of care and supervision resulted in a minor sexually assaulting another minor, a lack of care and supervision resulted in a minor physically assaulting another minor, and a client had access to knives. The investigation was referred to and conducted by the CCL Investigations Branch (IB). This investigation revealed that on 02/12/2020 C1 (Refer to LIC 811 Confidential Names), while left unsupervised with C2 while on enhanced supervision protocol, got into a physical altercation with C1 that resulted in C1 sustaining a concussion and multiple nail avulsion while in care. Interviews with clients and staff reveal that C1 and C2 were left unsupervised while all staff on duty were outside preparing for a scheduled dump run. C1 and C2 engaged in a physical altercation in the upstairs hallway, which resulted in C2 hitting C1's head against the floor repeatedly. Another client in the home had to go downstairs and outside to grab staff's attention and alert them of the fight that had broken out in the house. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

Staff were able to separate the two clients, and determined that C1 needed to go to the Emergency Room due to complaints of headache and blurry vision. C1 also had several of her fingernails ripped off during this altercation. At the Emergency Room, C1 was given a primary diagnosis of nail avulsion and neck strain/sprain. The ER doctor advised staff to bring C1 back to the hospital on 02/14/2020 for a follow-up appointment, which was not scheduled or followed through with by the home. On 02/24/2020, C1 complained to staff that she was feeling pressure and pain in her head when she bent down, and staff took her to Contra Costa Health Services for a follow-up appointment, 12 days after the initial appointment. At this appointment, C1 was given a secondary diagnosis of concussion without loss of consciousness related to her head injury from the altercation on 02/12/2020. In order to determine the cause of C1's injuries, LPA Fremont interviewed D1 to confirm C1's diagnosis. D1 reviewed C1's initial visit report, and stated that given the notes from the doctor that treated C1 on 02/12/2020, C1 presented with a headache, blurry vision, stumbling, blood rushing to the head, dizziness, and nausea. D1 stated that these symptoms are indicative of a mild to moderate concussion, and speculated that C1 was not diagnosed with a concussion on 02/12/2020 because her symptoms were mild. D1 stated that the mechanism of injury paired with C1's presenting symptoms are clear and consistent with a mild to moderate concussion. D1 stated that while the first doctor did not diagnose a concussion, what they have in their notes is the most important thing to look at. D1 noted that when C1 returned to the hospital 12 days later, she presented with pain behind the ears, dizziness, and sensitivity to light and loud noises, which are all signs of a concussion. D1 stated a concussion can last anywhere from a few days to several weeks depending on the mechanism and severity of injury, and that was why she diagnosed C1 with a concussion at her follow-up appointment on 02/24/2020. D1 concluded this phone call by confirming that although the first doctor did not diagnose a concussion at the onset of symptoms, based on the doctor's notes of presenting symptoms and mechanism of injury, she is positive C1 had a concussion without loss of consciousness at the initial appointment, with symptoms that persisted for over a week resulting in the follow-up visit on 02/24/2020. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

On 09/04/2020, the Department issued substantiated findings for two of the three allegations for the 02/14/2020 Complaint (Control #14-CR-20200214155207). The allegations "lack of supervision resulting in a client sexually assaulting another client" and "lack of care and supervision resulting in a client physically assaulting another client" were substantiated, and a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7.5, Version 3, Article 6, Section 87078(a) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision was issued. The Department has concluded an analysis and has determined that an Enhanced Civil Penalty is warranted for serious bodily injury. The Penal Code §243 defines serious bodily injury as "a serious impairment of physical condition, included, but not limited to, the following: loss of consciousness; concussion;bone fracture; protracted loss or impairment of function of any bodily member or organ; a wound requiring extensive suturing; and serious disfigurement." Health and Safety Code §1548(f)(1)(C) reads: “For a violation that the department determines constitutes physical abuse, as defined in paragraph (2), or resulted in serious bodily injury, as defined in Section 243 of the Penal Code, to a person receiving care at a therapeutic day services facility, community treatment facility, transitional shelter care facility, transitional housing placement provider, small family home, crisis nursery, group home, enhanced behavior supports home licensed as a group home, or short-term residential therapeutic program, the civil penalty shall be assessed as follows: (f) Two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500) for a facility licensed to care for 40 or fewer children.” Today, 03/04/2021, the Department will be issuing a Civil Penalty per Health and Safety Code §1548(f)(1)(C) for $2,500. The above was reviewed during the meeting, and Appeal Rights were provided. This report was sent via email to Administrator Donna Heimbruch, who agreed to sign the report and email back to LPA Fremont for the home's facility file.

met_with: Youth Homes Director of Operational Compliance and Services Ronnie Mabou
narrative:
At 2PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met virtually with the home above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a Noncompliance Case Management Inspection. LPA met with Youth Homes Director of Operational Compliance and Services Ronnie Mabou, who helped facilitate this inspection. Administrator Donna Heimbruch is currently out of work on medical leave, and Ronnie Mabou is filling in in her absence. Also in attendance was Youth Homes Vice President of Residential Services Shatae Jones and LPA AmyLe Tran. In October 2020, Youth Homes - Andersen met with Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives for a Noncompliance Conference. The purpose of the Noncompliance Conference was to address the following issues: 1. Client Supervision and Staff Ratios 2. Staff Training 3. Needs and Services Plans 4. Administration. Because of COVID-19 Shelter-In-Place directives and subsequent restrictions on physical visits to licensed facilities, CCL representatives have not been able to perform quarterly in-person Noncompliance Case Management inspections. After consultation with Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, a decision has been reached for LPA Fremont to conduct these inspections virtually. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

On 04/05/2021 at 3:54PM, LPA Fremont requested the following documentation to be submitted by email by 04/08/2021: - Updated LIC500 - Staff Roster and Schedule - 15 minute room check logs and staff shift notes for 02/19/2021 and 03/23/2021 - Needs and Services Plans for 3 clients - Most recent Executive Board Meeting Minutes - Staff meeting minutes for the week of 03/08/2021 - Staff Training log for January-March 2021 On 04/08/2021, LPA Fremont received the following documentation from Ronnie Mabou: - Needs and Services Plans for 3 clients - LIC500 - Training log for January-March 2021 - Staff meeting minutes for 03/10/2021 - Supervision log and staff notes for 02/19/2021 and 03/23/2021 On 04/12/2021 at 11:40AM, LPA Fremont received the Executive Board Meeting Minutes from Vice President of Residential Services Shatae Jones. Upon review of all documentation, no issues or concerns have been identified. During this inspection, LPA Fremont conducted interviews with Ronnie Mabou and Shatae Jones. During these interviews, LPA Fremont inquired about staff ratios and client supervision, staff training, administration, and day-to-day operations. Both interviewees identified that as a whole, Andersen House has seen improvement in all areas of concern addressed in their Noncompliance Plan. Challenges identified were barriers to hiring more staff due to the pandemic. At this time, no deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Ronnie Mabou, to be signed and returned over email for the facility file.

On 3/4/222 at 11:45 AM, LPA Alyssa Ng met with Ronnie Mabou, Director of Compliance and Operations at Youth Homes East Bay to discuss the opening of Anderson and their Non-Compliance Plan going forward. Ronnie says that Anderson will be ready to open once their Plan of Operations is finalized by CCL. In October 2020, Youth Homes - Andersen met with Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives for a Noncompliance Conference. The purpose of the Noncompliance Conference was to address the following issues: 1. Client Supervision and Staff Ratios 2. Staff Training 3. Needs and Services Plans 4. Administration. During this time, Anderson closed their facility dated 4/6/2021 due to lack of staffing and COVID. Youth homes had enough beds at their sister facilities East Bay and Pryor. When Pryor closed, clients were able to move to East Bay. After discussing the opening of Anderson, the Licensee will submit the LIC500 on the 20th of every month. LPA will ask randomly ask for at least two days of the following items per month; 15 minute room checks logs including names of the staff who preformed checks and overnight shift notes. Staff Training: Youth Homes has established a Training Plan for all staff to be completed by 10/01/2020 and addresses the following topics: Mandated Reporting (Laws and Regulations, Procedures and Timeframes for reporting, understanding physical and sexual abuse) Unconscious Bias Trauma-Informed Care ------ Continued on LIC 809 C----------

Aces (Adverse Childhood Experiences) STRTP Regulations Prudent Parent Standards Incident Reporting requirements, AB 388 When Anderson opens, the Licensee will submit a schedule of all upcoming trainings at the home, including the names of the trainers and an agenda for each training. Needs and Services Plans: Licensee will conduct in depth evaluations of each client upon admission, taking into account each clients past history. The licensee will develop individualized and personalized Needs and Services Plans for each client that address each clients particular needs and treatment goals. The Clinical Team is providing training re: Needs and Services Plans, going through each client's treatment and crisis plans in conjunction with the child's treatment team to make sure each section of the Needs and Services is tailored to each child and includes a plan to transition each child to a lower level of care. When Anderson opens, the licensee will conduct and submit to CCL quarterly audits of Needs and Services Plans to check for accuracy, completion, and to ensure that each client's plan is personalized to them individually. The Licensee will also submit 3 random Needs and Services Plans to LPA Ng for Review by the 20th of every month. Administration: Licensee will ensure that the program administrator is present at the home for at least 20 hours per week during normal business hours. On a quarterly basis, the licensee agrees to submit the following to LPA Ng: 1. Executive Board meeting minutes. 2. Weekly staff meeting minutes, to include a log of each direct care staff signing off confirming they have reviewed each client's Needs and Services Plans each week. Upon the request of the Licensee, CCL will request a Technical Support Program (TSP) visit at the home.

On 8/10/222 at 1:00 PM , Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Alyssa Ng and George Karkazis met with Ronnie Mabou, Administrator at Youth Homes Anderson and discussed their Non-Compliance Plan going forward. Anderson plans on opening in September. After discussing the opening of Anderson, the Licensee will submit the LIC500 before opening and on the 20th of every month. LPA will ask randomly ask for at least two days of the following items per month; 15 minute room checks logs including names of the staff who performed checks and overnight shift notes. LPA Ng discussed staff having required training before working at Anderson. The required training mist include the following topics: · Mandated Reporting (Laws and Regulations, Procedures and Time frames for reporting, understanding physical and sexual abuse) · Unconscious Bias · Trauma-Informed Care · Aces (Adverse Childhood Experiences) · STRTP Regulations · Prudent Parent Standards · Incident Reporting requirements, AB 388 · When Anderson opens, the Licensee will submit a schedule of all upcoming training's at the home, including the names of the trainers and an agenda for each training.

Needs and Services Plans: · Licensee will conduct in depth evaluations of each client upon admission, taking into account each client past history. The licensee will develop individualized and personalized Needs and Services Plans for each client that address each client’s particular needs and treatment goals. · The Clinical Team is providing training re: Needs and Services Plans, going through each client's treatment and crisis plans in conjunction with the child's treatment team to make sure each section of the Needs and Services is tailored to each child and includes a plan to transition each child to a lower level of care. · When Anderson opens, the licensee will conduct and submit to CCL quarterly audits of Needs and Services Plans to check for accuracy, completion, and to ensure that each client's plan is personalized to them individually. · The Licensee will also submit 3 random Needs and Services Plans to LPA Ng for Review by the 20th of every month. Administration: · Licensee will ensure that the program administrator is present at the home for at least 20 hours per week during normal business hours. Administrator Ronnie told LPA Ng that Kendra Sheldon will be the new Administrator but Ronnie will be the Interim Administrator until Kendra completes her certificate, training's, and on boarding. · On a quarterly basis, the licensee agrees to submit the following to LPA Ng: 1. Executive Board meeting minutes. 2. Weekly staff meeting minutes, to include a log of each direct care staff signing off confirming they have reviewed each client's Needs and Services Plans each week. LPA Ng told Administrator to send CCL needs and service plans when completed, completed trainings, and board meeting minutes closer to Anderson's opening date. A Technical Support Program (TSP) was discussed. Licensee will let LPA Ng know if they need TSP. No deficiencies were cited. A copy of this report was given to Ronnie Mabou, Administrator.

On 9/21/222 at 10:30 AM , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng met with Ronnie Mabou, Administrator at Youth Homes Anderson. The purpose of the visit was to do a facility walk-through due to clients getting moved from Youth Home East Bay Shelter. The facility placed the clients at Anderson on September 10th due to a fire incident. During the transition, all parties were informed including client's social workers and CCL was notified. At 10:34 AM, Administrator Ronnie and LPA Ng did a walk-through of the facility. LPA inspected the interior and exterior of the facility and grounds. There are no bodies of water or hazards on the grounds. The room and hot water temperatures are maintained within permitted ranges at 70 F and 115.9 F. Food supply meets the 7 day nonperishable, 2 day perishable supply mandate for all residents in care. The food storage is kept locked at night, the freezers are always locked, but residents always have access to water, milk, fruit, and makings for sandwiches. The residents also have access to an unlocked fridge freezer for snacks and frozen juice. First aid kit was inspected and observed to be complete. Smoke detectors were tested and are functioning. The house and grounds are well maintained. All bedrooms have clean linens and mattress pads. Knives and chemicals are locked and inaccessible to residents in care. During the walk-through, LPA observed holes in a clients room. LPA Ng was notified prior regarding the property damage. The holes were observed to be covered with duck tape and Administrator provided a work order. Repair is scheduled for tomorrow. LPA Ng also reminded Administrator that now that the facility has clients, the Non-Compliance submissions will begin.

As a reminder, the LIC 500 and 3 random Needs and Service Plans will be sent to LPA NG every 20th of every month. LPA will ask randomly ask for at least two days of the following items per month; 15 minute room checks logs including names of the staff who performed checks and overnight shift notes. The administrator will also conduct and submit to CCL quarterly audits of Needs and Services Plans to check for accuracy, completion, and to ensure that each client's plan is personalized to them individually. On 1/20/23 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced annual/required inspection to listed facility and met with Ronnie Mabou, Administrator. The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement are 4 clients. During this inspection, 3 clients and 6 staff were present in the home. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call, hand hygiene, and mask-wearing. LPA Ng toured the facility inside and out. The facility is a three story home and has 4 client bedrooms. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings and full sized beds. Each bedroom has drawers for extra storage space. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. The water temperature measured 124.5 degrees F. The thermostat measured 71 degrees. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps were located in a locked cabinet in the staff office. Extra linens are located in a closet in the hallway. The weekly menu was posted in the kitchen. LPA's observed at least 2 days of perishable foods and 7 days of nonperishable foods. The smoke detectors are in working order. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. LPA Ng interviewed 2 staff and 1 client. LPA toured the backyard and observed it to be free from hazards. The backyard is surrounded by a wooden fence with locked gates. The facility has a centralized AC unit in the side yard which is inaccessible to clients.

All client records complete with all of the required documentation. The facility had a separate file for each staff. All files were present except for one staff's TB test and three staff Child Abuse Index Check (LIC 198). LPA also found that all clients has their own separate binder of all required documents. Each psychotropic medication was did have its own Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR). All medications were consistent with these records. Staff has a centralized binder that contained their training, qualifications, and other personal information. LPA looked through all binders and were complete with all the required documentation. Resident and staff records were observed to be complete and the facility in compliance, with only the following exception: LPA Ng reviewed staff records and found staff did not have the Child Abuse Index Check (LIC198). Facility was cited under California Code Of Regulations, Title 22, Chapter 6, Section 80066 Personnel Records and 80019.2 Child Abuse Central Index. At this time, 2 deficiencies was cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Ronnie Mabou, Administrator .

At 1:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met virtually with the home above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a Non-Compliance Case Management Inspection. LPA met with Administrator Shawntrelle Butler, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 4 ambulatory clients. In June 2019, Youth Homes - Cherry Lane met with Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives for a Non-Compliance Conference. The purpose of the Non-Compliance Conference was to address the following issues: 1. Client care and supervision 2. Staffing ratios 3. Physical Plant of the home - specifically non-functional locks on client bedroom windows 4. Staff training 5. Planned activities Because of COVID-19 Shelter-In-Place directives and subsequent restrictions on physical visits to licensed facilities, CCL representatives have not been able to perform quarterly in-person Non-Compliance Case Management inspections. After consultation with Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, a decision has been reached for LPA Fremont to conduct these inspections virtually. On 10/26/2020 at 1:52PM, LPA Fremont contacted Administrator Shawntrelle Butler by email to request the following documents: 1. September Program Standards Sub-Committee Board Meeting Minutes 2. Shift noted and room check logs for September 22, 2020 3. September activities calendar (both planned and updated versions) 4. January-September training logs and sign-in sheets for each month. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

On 10/27/2020 at 5:15PM, LPA Fremont received all requested documents from Youth Homes Vice President of Residential Services, Shatae Jones. During this inspection, LPA Fremont conducted confidential interviews with S1, S2, and S3. LPA attempted to interview clients that were present in the home, but all clients declined to give an interview. S1, S2, and S3 were able to confirm that client supervision has been increased, and protocol for 15 minute client checks continues to be followed by all staff. All staff confirmed that client AWOLs have decreased since COVID-19 hit, and the clients continue to be happy and comfortable at the home. When asked about the window locks, all staff confirmed that broken locks have been removed and were replaced with functional self-latching closures. S2 and S3 both stated that staff have been reliable throughout the pandemic, and continue to show up to all scheduled shifts to provide full coverage of the home. All staff interviewed also confirmed that though COVID-19 has prevented some in-person staff trainings, there has been an increase in the frequency of trainings, including topics such as: 1. Client supervision protocol 2. Nurtured Heart 3. COVID-19 protocol and procedures 4. Pro-Act 5. Trauma-Informed Care 6. AWOL protocol Although COVID-19 has prevented many planned activities in the community, all staff were able to confirm that there has not been a lapse in planned activities since the pandemic started. Staff have continued to schedule new activities for the clients, and have also incorporated a system where clients can request specific activities that are incorporated into the activities calendar. Some examples of recent activities are: 1. Arts and crafts 2. Halloween decoration contest 3. Board and Card Games 4. Physical activities such as staff/client basketball games

LPA Fremont concluded this Case Management inspection by informing Administrator Shawntrelle Butler that another virtual Case Management inspection would be taking place in the next 3 months for the purpose of ensuring continued compliance from the facility. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Shawntrelle Butler with read receipt due to COVID-19 precautions.

S2 stated that C2 had bled where C1 had bitten and scratched her, but both clients declined medical attention. S3 also stated that 911 was called during the fight when staff noticed clients were bleeding from multiple areas on their arms, but both clients declined medical attention. S4 recalled seeing blood on both clients, but both declined medical attention and general first aid was administered on the scene. These statements are corroborated by an interview with C2 on 06/05/2020 at 2:20PM, who confirmed that she did suffer minor injuries from the fight, including bruises and a small area of torn skin that had bled where C1 bit her, but both clients declined medical attention. Based on the information gathered, including interviews with C2, S1, S2, S3, and S4, and review of incident reports and shift notes dated 03/04/2020 that describe injuries C1 and C2 sustained from their altercation, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove that C1 and C2 sustained injuries while in the care of the licensee, though both declined medical attention. Therefore, the allegation that a resident sustained an injury while in care is substantiated. Because both injured clients refused medical attention, and both were treated on scene where facility staff administered general first aid, no deficiency is being cited at this time. However, because C2 stated in her interview that C1 had bitten her, and due to the high risk for potential infection and disease transmission from human bites, an Advisory Note - Technical Advisory is being issued per Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80075(a) - Health Related Services. Please see the attached LIC9102 for details. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights discussed and provided, and a copy of this report was left at the facility with Administrator Shawntrelle Butler, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative:
At 2PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met virtually with the home above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a Noncompliance Case Management Inspection. LPA met with Administrator Shawntrelle Butler, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also in attendance were Youth Homes Vice President of Residential Services Shatae Jones, and Youth Homes Director of STRTP Operations Ronnie Mabou. Currently in care are 5 ambulatory clients. This virtual inspection is being held in lieu of a physical in-person visit to the facility due to the COVID-19 pandemic. In June 2019, Youth Homes - Cherry Lane met with Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives for a Noncompliance Conference. The purpose of the Noncompliance Conference was to address the following issues: 1. Client care and supervision 2. Staffing ratios 3. Physical Plant of the home - specifically non-functional locks on client bedroom windows 4. Staff training 5. Planned activities On 03/02/2021 at 3:12PM, LPA Fremont contacted Administrator Butler by email to request the following documents: 1. January 2021 Program Standards Sub-Committee Board Meeting Minutes 2. Shift notes and room check logs for January 17, 2021 3. January 2021 activities calendar (both planned and updated versions) 4. October 2020-January 2021 training logs and sign-in sheets (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

On 03/03/2021 at 2:49PM, LPA received all requested documents from Administrator Butler except for the Program Standards Sub-Committee Board Meeting Minutes. On 03/03/2021 at 3:05PM, LPA received the Board Meeting Minutes from Youth Homes Vice President of Residential Services Shatae Jones. During this inspection, LPA had a discussion with all present parties regarding the following topics: Physical Plant: All client bedroom window locks are functional and in place. The home recently closed temporarily to go through extensive renovations on the inside of the house. Renovations were successful and clients have since been placed back in care at Cherry Lane. The home is now planning renovations for the outside of the home, and will have a walkthrough of the home in the coming weeks to have plans made with a contractor. The home will submit renovation plans prior to commencement of said renovations. Staff Training: The home has been conducting monthly staff training. Facility administrators have received their initial 40-hour training again, all staff have had CSEC training, Introduction to Cultural Humility training, and weekly staff meetings to go over facility binders and staff log book updates. All staff have also received a refresher course on mandated reporting requirements. The home just started a 3 part series on Nurtured Heart Approach and Crisis Communication, and will soon be moving on to another series to update all staff on Pro-Act, crisis management, and manual restraints. Each series will be repeated twice so that if any staff miss the first round of training, they will have an opportunity to make up during the second round. There has also been an increase in focus on client Needs and Services Plans and making sure that lower level staff are aware of what each child's behaviors are and how to provide support for each child based off their individual plans. Upper level management has been encouraging stronger collaboration between staffing levels and communication with social workers regarding new and escalating behaviors. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

Care and Supervision: All parties indicated that the clients have been doing well since moving back to Cherry Lane, although they miss the relationships with their counterparts at the Youth Homes Pryor location. Administrator Butler indicated there have not been any issues with client supervision, and staff continue to conduct 15 minute client checks to ensure that all clients are safe and accounted for. Admin. Butler indicated there was one recent AWOL, but all clients have returned since and are doing well in the program. Planned Activities: Parties interviewed stated that clients have been playing board games, cooking, and baking. There is one client who enjoys cooking and she has had an opportunity to cook for the house a few times a week, as well as make revisions to the weekly menu. One child enjoys baking, and staff have been encouraging this as well. The clients play basketball outside the home, and also share a hoverboard that they like to play on. One of the newest clients used to go fishing before placement, so staff recently took them to Lafayette Reservoir to go fishing, and more trips are being planned. Staff are also planning a trip to the snow in the coming months. An outside agency recently "adopted" the clients' birthdays, and they are able to fulfill the children's birthday wishlists. There is also an outside organization providing food for the home, and staff have planned a youth cook-off utilizing this food. The organization also provides alternative foods that the kids may have not tried before, and staff are planning a taste-testing game. At this time, the home remains in compliance with Title 22 regulations. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Shawntrelle Butler to be signed and returned for the home's facility file.

met_with: Youth Homes Director of Operational Compliance Ronnie Mabou
narrative:
On 06/17/2020 at 2PM, LPA Fremont met with representatives of Cherry Lane over FaceTime to notify them of this allegation and to conduct interviews with staff and clients. During this meeting, LPA conducted the following interviews: S1 at 2PM, C3 at 2:20PM, S2 at 2:18PM, S3 at 2:25PM, S4 at 2:30PM, and S5 at 2:40PM. LPA attempted to interview C1 and C2 at this time, however C1 was away on AWOL, and C2 refused to give an interview. LPA also conducted interviews with S6 on 06/26/2020 at 9:46AM, and W1 on 06/17/2020 at 12:22PM. In an interview with W1, this witness stated that C1 and C2 had been running away multiple days per week and were sometimes gone for two nights at a time, only returning on the third day so their beds would be held. W1 had also heard from another client that C1 and C2 were engaging in Commercially Sexually Exploited Child (CSEC) behaviors while on AWOL in the surrounding community. S2 and S4 added to this statement, saying that they had heard C1 and C2 discussing wanting to make money and talking about a hotel. S2 also stated that the clients often returned from AWOL with money, and the clients refused to disclose where they got it. All staff interviewed stated that C1 and C2 had been AWOLing almost every day for a period of several weeks, sometimes leaving the facility multiple times in one day. This was corroborated by C3, who stated the clients were leaving almost every day. All staff stated that per facility protocol, when a child AWOL'd from the facility, staff would try to talk them down and would follow on foot or in the facility vehicle until they lost line of sight or it became too dangerous for staff to follow. S2 stated that there had been times where they could not follow C1 and C2 because they were the only staff on duty and could not leave the other residents. This is corroborated by a document titled "Staff Training: Runaway Procedure" sent to LPA Fremont on 06/19/2020 at 4:38PM. This document states the following: "If a youth is seen leaving, always follow unless you are a single coverage and cannot leave the other youth." In an interview with S6, S6 stated that if any clients required a hire level of supervision, staffing would be increased to make up for the supervision needs of the other clients. All staff interviewed confirmed that no additional staff had been added to supplement supervision for C1 and C2. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

When asked how the clients were getting out of the house, all staff stated that C1 and C2 either walked out of the font door, or climbed through the bedroom or bathroom windows. S4 stated the following: "They are AWOLing so often at this point, most of the time they will say 'Hey I'm leaving' and walk out of the house, or they won't say anything and just walk out." This is corroborated by C3, who stated, "It's a daily basis so it gets to a point where they [staff] can't do anything every time." When asked if C1 and C2's supervision needs had been updated in their Needs and Services Plans, S1 stated that changes had been made to reflect the clients' recurring AWOL behavior. This is contradicted by C2's Needs and Services Plan sent to LPA Fremont on 06/19/2020 at 4:38PM. In this plan dated 06/15/2020, it is stated that C2 was on "normal" supervision at the time, however it is also noted that C2 was at severe risk for AWOL behaviors. This plan also states that C2 was in possession of an unauthorized cellphone at the time, which they were using to set up AWOLs, and the client was AWOLing daily. When asked if they thought they were doing everything they could to prevent AWOLs, all staff stated they were, with the exception of S4, who stated "yes and no" and clarified that it depended on the staff and their comfort level with de-escalation and following clients. Based on the information gathered, including interviews with staff and clients and review of facility records, there is a preponderance of evidence that the supervision needs of C1 and C2 were not being met, allowing them to repeatedly AWOL from the facility by leaving through the front door. Based on a recent Administrative Action taken against the home for similar complaints and incidents, the home has put a plan in place to increase staffing, to increase the number of on-call Crisis Management Supervisors, and to regularly meet with clients' Child and Family Teams to address ongoing behavioral issues and to implement solutions to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future. Because of these recent changes, no deficiency is being cited at this time. To communicate best practice of client supervision going forward, an LIC9102 - Technical Violation was issued to the home for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80078(a) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Please see the attached LIC9102 for details. At this time, one Technical Violation has been issued per Title 22 Regulations. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Youth Homes Director of Operational Compliance Ronnie Mabou, to be signed and returned for the home's facility file.

In order to be able to inspect files that were inaccessible at the time of this inspection, LPA Fremont will be continuing this Noncompliance Quarterly Inspection on a separate day, when personnel files and client files will be reviewed, and staff and client interviews will be conducted. _________________________________________________________________________ On 08/24/2021 at 1:25PM-4:15PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont returned to Youth Homes Cherry Lane to finish their Noncompliance Quarterly Case Management Inspection. LPA met with Administrator Rozalynn Johnson-Spearman, who helped facilitate this inspection. During this inspection, LPA Fremont conducted a confidential interview with Administrator Rozalynn Johnson-Spearman. Ms. Johnson-Spearman indicated that day to day operations have been running smoothly. There have been no significant client incidents over the last few months, and staff and clients have a good relationship. Staff training has had consistent attendance. There have been no issues with client supervision or staffing ratios. The home has provided clients with a large variety of on-site and community planned activities, and there have been no complaints about activities. LPA reviewed files for all youth currently in placement, and found that C2 was missing their immunization record and their physician's report was incomplete and missing physician signature. The facility also keeps all clients' Safeguard for Cash Resources and Centrally Stored Medications Destruction Records in common files. An LIC9102 Advisory Note was issued to the home for CCR, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80070(a)(b)(1-14). Please see attached LIC9102 for details. On the previous day of this inspection (08/23/2021) LPA Fremont asked that all personnel files be made available for inspection by the time LPA returned to finish their inspection. On 08/24/2021, staff files were not available for review. A deficiency was cited per CCR, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80066(e) - Personnel Records. Please see the attached LIC809-D for details. At this time, two deficiencies are being cited and two advisory notes were issued. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Rozalynn Johnson-Spearman whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.title: Personnel Records

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Hugo Licea conducted a case management inspection on October 26, 2021 at 11:00am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. 3 out of 19 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files as identified on the LIC 811 confidential names dated October 5, 2021, were reviewed. 3 out of 19 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 4 youth were also interviewed. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedure were reviewed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Ronnie Mabou, Director of Operational Compliance and Services.

met_with: Ronnie Mabou- Director of Operational Compliance and Services
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted an annual inspection at Youth Homes- Cherry Lane. LPA met with Ronnie Mabou Director of Operational Compliance and Services (DOCS). The STRTP is licensed to serve 6 clients ages 12-18. The facility consists of 4 bedrooms (4 Double occupancy) and 2 bathrooms. At 11:35 AM, LPA Rollins toured the facility with DOCS inside and out. LPA observed the kitchen is clean. LPA measured hot water in the bathroom, kitchen sink and shower at 113.4 degrees F. The facility has plenty of non perishable and perishable food supply. Medication and knives are locked away. There are enough folks, spoons, plates and cups. All passageways are unobstructed. All smoke detectors are up to date and working. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. There are no firearms on the property. There are no bodies of water on the property. The facility is maintained at a comfortable temperature. Personal rights, floor plan, food menu and Emergency disaster forms were posted in clear view. Fire Extinguisher was up to date and carbon monoxide was in good working shape. At 12:30 PM, LPA reviewed four client files with DOCS. LPA observed all four client files to be complete and found no deficiencies. LPA observed all documentation to be up to date. LPA observed medication logs to be updated and current.

At 1:15 PM, LPA observed 5 staff files with DOCS. LPA observed staff files to be complete and documentation was update. LPA found no deficiencies. LPA observed all facility staff have completed there 40 hours annual training. LPA observed all training to be up to date and all certificates to be complete. During inspection, LPA receive an updated copy of the LIC 500 Personnel Report to maintain their file current. A review of Licensing Information System on December 10, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during the inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

This department has investigated the allegation, and although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility failed to act once made aware that the adult staff acted inappropriately with group home minor, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed, and no deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Hiett met with Administrator Felicia Martin regarding a complaint investigation at the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of the investigation, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hiett reviewed human resources documentation regarding the termination of the staff member named in the complaint. LPA Madeline Fremont interview interviewed 1 staff. The documentation did not identify any previous inappropriate behavior and Administrator Felicia Martin confirmed this. The facility acted immediately once the allegation surfaced and immediately terminated the staff member identified in the complaint. LPA Hiett did not find evidence that the interactions between the staff member and the youth was sexual or abusive in nature. LPA Hiett was unable to contact the youth for further details. Continued on LIC9099-C

met_with: Director of Operational Compliance and Services Ronnie Mabou
investigation_findings: 13On 5/27/22 at 12:25PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins delivered complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Director of Operational Compliance and Services Ronnie Mabou and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precations were taken, including mask-wearing and pre-visit screening call. During investigation, LPA reviewed facility records and conducted confidential interviews with residents and staff. LPA made multiple attempts to interview multiple residents, but multiple residents refused interviews and/or could not be located/reached for interview. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation pertains to two youth alleged to have hit other residents on multiple occasions. However, this was not witnessed by staff, and youth could not be interviewed to confirm. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents and staff, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is

met_with: Director of Operational Compliance and Services Ronnie Mabou
narrative:
The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. LPA is issuing one citation, per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87072 Personal Rights. See attached LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Director of Operational Compliance and Services Ronnie Mabou, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Police did not aid further. Staff searched, but youth could not be located. Licensee responded to the incident and determined that staff did not make appropriate internal notifications and did not follow intervention procedures, including restraining to prevent further harm. Confidential interviews indicate that the facility does not restrain to prevent unauthorized absences, as that is not permitted, but youth was a threat to self and needed medical treatment, so restraining would have been required per their procedures. Staff were terminated. However, it is not clear that the facility is in violation of regulatory requirements for admitting youth. Neither youth is still in care, and the licensee has temporarily closed the facility pending hire of new staff. Additionally, based on confidential interviews, the facility faced a staffing shortage which made it difficult to maintain appropriate staff to child ratios. However, interviews do not clearly indicate instances of shortage resulting in not meeting ratio. Staff have worked overtime to maintain ratios. As stated above, it was reported that a staff member had been the sole staff at the facility in the morning when four youth were present, but the staff member denied this. Licensee has now closed the facility pending hire of new staff. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or is/are valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents and staff, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Director of Operational Compliance and Services Ronnie Mabou, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 5/27/22 at 12:50PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins delivered complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Director of Operational Compliance and Services Ronnie Mabou and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precations were taken, including mask-wearing and pre-visit screening call. During investigation, LPA reviewed facility records and conducted confidential interviews with residents and staff. LPA made multiple attempts to interview multiple residents, but multiple residents refused interviews and/or could not be located/reached for interview. Based on confidential interviews, during an escalated event, a staff member made a statement toward a resident in care using a derogatory name and profanity. The licensee took disciplinary action upon the staff member taking responsibility and expressing remorse. The staff member was placed on probation and supervision and was mandated to participate in a re-training series, which the staff has completed. Per Ronnie, there have been no issues with this staff since. NEXT PAGE

deficiencies.description:
87072 Personal Rights
(c)(11) To be free of...emotional, or other abuse, and from...humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse...

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interview and record review, licensee did not ensure resident was not subjected to abuse due to a staff member making a derogatory statement toward a resident.  This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee immediately took disciplinary action, placed the staff on probation, made a supervision plan for the staff member, and mandated the staff member be re-trained.  The staff has completed the training, and training records have been submitted to LPA.

narrative: Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove that the licensee did not provide the level of care and supervision required by the clients it had in its care. Therefore, the allegation- Staff did not prevent inappropriate sexual interactions between children are substantiated. The facility is being cited deficiencies per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87072(c) – Personal Rights. See the attached LIC9099-D for details. Additionally, due to the substantiated allegations above, and based on interviews with staff, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove that youth had access to illegal drugs. Therefore, the allegations are substantiated. The facility is being cited deficiencies per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87078(a) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. See the attached LIC9099-D for details. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Ronnie Mabou .
investigation_findings: 13*Correction: In the statement "Three staff were aware that youth would go into other youths’ room even when they are not allowed and were aware of C1 and C2 (refer to 811) having sex with other clients inside the facility." It is C4 and C5 instead of C1 and C2. On 4/5/22 at 10:30 AM , LPA Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection with Youth Homes- Cherry Lane and met with Ronnie Mabou, Director of Operations and Compliance. The visit was conducted at the corporate office due to Cherry Lane being closed. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. This complaint was taken as a complaint by Community Care Licensing's (CCL's) Investigations Branch (IB) and assigned to Inv. Victoria McIntosh on 12/03/2021. During the investigation, it was disclosed that it was very easy to sneak drugs into the facility due to not being searched thoroughly. For example, on 10/25/2021, two clients took MDMA pills and were not checked on throughout the night. Two clients said that staff only checked when showing behaviors or smelling like marijuana and some staff are aware that client’s smoke marijuana and drink alcohol and do not get in trouble if it is not on the property. Three staff were aware that youth would go into other youths’ room even when they are not allowed and were aware of C1 and C2 (refer to 811) having sex with other clients inside the facility.

deficiencies.description:
80078(a) Responsibility for providing care and supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.

This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on observations, interviews with staff and clients, the facility did not provide the supervision its clients when youths would go into other youths’ room to have sex and have illegal drugs. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee agrees to submit a plan to audit and address the following items no later than 12AM on 4/6/22: Prudent Parenting Standards, STRTP regulations, Staff training, organization hiring practices, and the formation of a Crisis Team that provides extra support to on-duty staff to supervise clients in care.

deficiencies.description:
87072 (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (11) To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse [...]. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews with staff and clients, the licensee denied the clients personal right to be free from sexual abuse by allowing a client with a history of sexually and physically assaultive behaviors to be unsupervised around other clients. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee agrees to submit a plan to audit and address the following items no later than 12AM on 4/6/22: Prudent Parenting Standards, STRTP regulations, Staff training, organization hiring practices, and the formation of a Crisis Team that provides extra support to on-duty staff.

deficiencies.description:
80061(b) Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified..., a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report containing the information specified... shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by, Based on incident report sent to the department, facility did not let CCL know until a month later (Youth Homes supervisor was aware of the alleged rape on 10/25/2021 but did not send in a report until 11/30/2021. Based on the incident report sent to the department, facility did not report the incident within the required time. This poses a immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to conduct a training with all staff on reporting requirements and how to proper complete an incident report for submission in a timely manner. This training will include trainer information, date, length of training, and signed attendance sheet by staff. POC to be submitted to the department by 4/6/2022 by 11:59 PM.

narrative:
On 8/15/222 at 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Alyssa Ng met with Ronnie Mabou, Administrator at Youth Homes Cherry Lane and discussed their Non-Compliance Plan going forward. In June 2019, Youth Homes - Cherry Lane met with Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives for a Noncompliance Conference. The purpose of the Noncompliance Conference was to address the following issues: 1. Client care and supervision 2. Staffing ratios 3. Physical Plant of the home - specifically non-functional locks on client bedroom windows 4. Staff training 5. Planned activities In regards to training, Contra Costa offered to help with some of the on boarding training's to help reach the 40-80 hours. The training will be in-person and Online depending on the topic.. The facility is clean, safe, and sanitary. There are no firearms on the property. There are no bodies of water on the property. The facility is maintained at a comfortable temperature. During this inspection, LPA had a discussion with Administrator regarding the following topics: Stipulation and Waver; and Order dated 6/4/2021 On page 3 Section E: “Respondent shall submit the monthly quality assurance report to the department”. LPA requested all reports from 2021- present.

On page 4 Section 4: “The probationary period shall be extended by the total time during which the facility is not operating”. LPA Ng also asked if “Geriann Smith” is still the President, Board of Directors of Respondent. Administrator confirmed that Geriann Smith is still the Board of Directors of Respondent. LPA Ng told Administrator that CCL is still discussing the possibility of surrendering Youth Homes- Cherry Lane’s license and moving Youth homes East Bay license to this location. LPA Ng or the Department will reach out to Youth Homes when they get confirmation/update. LPA Ng asked if there was a plan in case the change in location does not pan out. Administrator said that they will follow through with the Probationary License. They plan on having less kids with more staff. 1 or 2 to 1 overnight. Nurse on site. They will utilize some of the current staff from Youth Homes- East Bay Shelter. Internally promote a licensed clinical director role from the agency. They will need time to recruit and train new staff so they plan to be ready by the end of October. A Technical Support Program (TSP) was discussed. Licensee will let LPA Ng know if they need TSP. No deficiencies were cited. A copy of this report was given to Ronnie Mabou, Administrator.

On 9/21/2022 at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced case management inspection with listed facility and spoke with Ronnie Mabou, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on a complaint regarding inappropriate touching. LPA Ng reviewed the IB report for complaint # 14-CR-20220624135456. The allegation, facility staff member inappropriately touched minor while in care, and found that it was a client who inappropriately touched the minor. LPA Ng asked Ronnie Mabou, Administrator the procedures for incidences like this and how staff use prudent parenting to ensure clients are safe and protected in their rooms, and the compatibility of roommates. No deficiencies were cited today. A copy of this report was given to Ronnie Mabou, Administrator.
