In June 2019, Youth Homes - Cherry Lane met with Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives for a Noncompliance Conference. The purpose of the Noncompliance Conference was to address the following issues: 1. Client care and supervision 2. Staffing ratios 3. Physical Plant of the home - specifically non-functional locks on client bedroom windows 4. Staff training 5. Planned activities The facility is clean, safe, and sanitary. There are no firearms on the property. There are no bodies of water on the property. The facility is maintained at a comfortable temperature. During this inspection, LPA had a discussion with Administrator regarding the following topics: Stipulation and Waver; and Order dated 6/4/2021 On page 3 Section E: “Respondent shall submit the monthly quality assurance report to the department”. LPA requested all reports from September 2022- present. On page 4 Section 4: “The probationary period shall be extended by the total time during which the facility is not operating”.

The facility plans on opening when they hire a clinician and direct care staff. Youth Homes has hired Melissa Geddis as a Clinician. Melissa Geddis will become the new Administrator for Youth Homes- Cherry Lane when she takes her Administrator Class in February 2023. No deficiencies were cited. A copy of this report was given to Ronnie Mabou, Administrator.

On 1/18/23 at 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Ronnie Mabou and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call, mask-wearing, and hand hygiene. LPA used the CARES Inspection Tool to conduct the inspection. There are no children in care and no staff currently working at the facility. The facility is temporarily closed pending the approval of a new administrator and the hiring of new staff. LPA toured the facility site and grounds and observed the facility to be in safe condition. Backyard was safe and clear from obstruction. Room temperature and hot water temperature were maintained within permitted ranges, at 68 F and 113.5 F, respectively. There are four double-occupancy bedrooms with beds in safe condition and clean linens. During the inspection, Interim Administrator Ronnie Mabou states that the facility plans on opening when they hire a clinician and direct care staff. Youth Homes has hired Melissa Geddis as a Clinician. Melissa Geddis will become the new Administrator for Youth Homes- Cherry Lane when she takes her Administrator Class in February 2023. At this time, no citations were issued at this visit. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report left with Administrator Ronnie Mabou, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 09/07/23 at 11:30 AM , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng met with Kendra Sheldon, Administrator and Ronnie Mabou, Director of Operational Compliance and Services for the purpose of conducting a facility inspection. LPA conducted a facility inspection due to a waiver issued by CCL that is dated 8/29/23. Listed facility is temporarily relocating their youth to Cherry Lane while repairs are being done for Andersen house. *Please note that although the youth are getting relocated to Cherry Lane , they are still under Andersen placement.* LPA Ng toured the facility inside and out. The facility consists of 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings and full sized beds. Each bedroom has drawers for extra storage space. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps were located in a locked cabinet in the staff office. Extra linens are located in a closet in the hallway. The weekly menu was posted in the kitchen. LPA's observed at least 2 days of perishable foods and 7 days of nonperishable foods. The smoke detectors are in working order. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. LPA toured the backyard and observed it to be free from hazards. The backyard is surrounded by a wooden fence with locked gates. The facility has a centralized AC unit in the side yard which is inaccessible to clients. At this time, 0 deficiencies was cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Kendra Sheldon, Administrator .

met_with: Kendra Walsh, Ronnie Mabou, Louie Jacobus, & Jana Corral
narrative: On 08/26/2024 at 10:30 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brenda Rodriguez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong conducted a Teams Meeting with the following team members from Youth Homes - Cherry Lane: Kendra Walsh, Ronnie Mabou, Louie Jacobus, and Jana Corral. The purpose of the meeting was for the team members from Youth Homes - Cherry Lane to further explain to LPM Wong and LPA Rodriguez their transition of residential log note process into the EHR System Welligent. Louie Jacobus, Director of Clinical Operations showed LPM Wong and LPA Rodriguez step by step about how the EHR System Welligent works. After seeing the breakdown of how the system works, LPM Wong and LPA Rodriguez agreed that it is a really useful system for residential log notes. LPM Wong agreed to use the system, but to test it out first and see how it goes for everyone in the team. The trial run will start September 5th, 2024. The Teams Meeting ended at 11:10 a.m.

On December 6, 2024, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood made an unannounced Case Management inspection to the above facility. LPA Singh-Sood met with Residential Facility Manager, Megan Chapman, who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of this inspection was to discuss a serious incident that had occurred between two clients in care. Facility staff had reported the incident to Community Care Licensing immediately. LPA Singh-Sood reviewed incident reports, conducted confidential interviews at which time it was determined that there had been a lack of supervision towards the care for the clients in care to be safe. It was also noted that there were not enough staff notes regarding the clients, instances, etc. despite the amount of instances the clients in care have had with each other from February-November 2024.. As such, the Facility was cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. An exit interview was conducted at 12:00 PM, and Ms. Chapman was provided a copy of the report.

Medication was stored and locked in the staff office in a locked cabinet within a locked safe. The facility is in good repair and clean. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. LPA Medina interviewed four staff members and no clients. LPA Medina reviewed client and staff files. All staff and client files were complete and in good order. LPA also fully reviewed Operational requirements. Inspection is not complete and a follow-up visit will be conducted. Four Technical Assistance were issued for California Code of Regulations 87072.2(a)(3), 87063(a)(8), 80019(e)(2), and 87065.1(d)(6)(A). There was one deficiency cited for California Code of Regulations 87072(a). Please refer to attached 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Meghan Chapman, Facility Manager .

On 06/12/25 at 1:05 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brenda Rodriguez met with Meghan Chapman, Lead Residential Manager regarding an incident report follow-up that was reported to CCL on 05/13/2025. LPA Rodriguez disclosed the purpose of the inspection and was granted entry into the facility. After conducting four (4) confidential staff interviews and one (1) confidential client interview, LPA Rodriguez wanted to inform the facility that no CCL regulations were violated regarding the incident report. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Meghan Chapman, Lead Residential Manager, Ra’Shena Martin, Clinical Director & Administrator and Ronnie Mabou, Director of Standards and Enrichment.

Control Number: 2006-FN On July 29, 2025, at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on a submitted Incident Report (IR). LPA met with Meghan Chapman, Lead Facility Manager. At the time of the visit, two staff members and three clients were present. The IR was submitted regarding an incident that occurred on July 21, 2025. According to the report, Client C1 allegedly snuck a male individual into their bedroom overnight. During the visit, LPA interviewed the Lead Facility Manager to obtain additional information regarding the facility’s plan to ensure C1 received proper follow-up support. LPA confirmed that the awake overnight staff was conducting routine checks during the time of the incident. LPA reviewed the program statement, which includes a house rule stating: “You have the right for staff to knock before entering your bedroom.” On the night of the incident, C1 reportedly requested that staff knock before entering, and it is suspected the unauthorized individual may have used this to remain hidden. The facility assessed this incident, along with prior incidents involving the client creating an unsafe environment for others. As a result, a discharge plan was developed, and the client was formally discharged on July 28, 2025. LPA reviewed video footage of the incident, as well as shift logs from the night in question, and confirmed that room checks were being conducted. Two clients declined to be interviewed by LPA. One staff and one client interview were conducted during today’s visit. An area of improvement was observed under California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Section 80078 – Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Please refer to LIC9102 for further details. No deficiencies were cited as a result of proper procedures done by staff. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Meghan Chapman, Lead Facility Manager.

During a complaint investigation at the facility on 03/02/2020, LPA Fremont reviewed C1's facility file, reviewed staff training material, C1's hospital visit records, incident reports for C1, and conducted an interview with S1. On 03/05/2020, LPA Fremont and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Saxon Turner traveled to Spectrum School in San Pablo, CA to interview C1. LPA returned to the home on 03/16/2020 with LPA Monica Pavia to obtain staff schedule for the week of the incident, and staff shift logs. At this time, LPAs also interviewed S2, S3 and S4. LPA Fremont traveled to Youth Homes - Pryor on 03/19/2020 to interview C3. Due to COVID-19 Shelter-In-Place directives, LPA Fremont conducted phone interviews with S5, S6, and S8 on 03/24/2020, S7, S9, S10, and S12 on 03/25/2020, and S11 on 03/26/2020. During interviews with C1 on 03/05/2020 at 12PM and C3 on 03/19/2020 at 9AM, LPA Fremont asked both clients what staff were usually doing when they are on shift. Both C1 and C3 stated that staff are usually on their phones, or watching TV in the living room. C1 also stated that they are not supposed to be in any part of the house or backyard without a staff member because they are on increased supervision. This is corroborated by C1's Needs and Services Plan, which stated that C1 was on 1:1 or line of sight supervision at the time, due to high frequency of AWOLs. This is also corroborated by staff training procedures which state, "The counselors on duty should always be aware of where all youth are at any given time." This is contradicted by incident reports dated 02/16/2020 and 02/17/2020, which state that staff members saw C1 and C3 leaving the property by hopping a fence in the backyard, while staff watched on from inside the home. Upon further review of incident reports dated from 02/14/2020 to 02/28/2020, LPA Fremont found that clients at the home frequently AWOL'd from the home at night when only one staff member was on duty and could not follow them without abandoning the other clients in the home. This is corroborated by an interview with S9 on 03/25/2020 at 12:22PM, in which S9 stated that the home has one staff on duty after 10PM, and two staff who float between 4 homes in 3 different cities. When LPA Fremont asked S9 if there was any effort made to increase staffing during the night to deter AWOLs, S9 said no, no effort had been made to increase staffing. When LPA Fremont asked C1 and C3 what staff do when they try to run away, both C1 and C3 stated that staff let them go and rarely follow. This is corroborated by an interview with S12 on 03/25/2020 at 4:34PM, who stated, "If I'm the only one on shift in the middle of the night, I let them go because I have to stay with the other clients." (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

In addition, it is stated in C1's Needs and Services Plan that they should be manually restrained during AWOL incidents because they can be a grave danger to themselves or others. When LPA Fremont asked all staff if they had ever used manual restraints on C1, all staff stated they never used manual restraints to prevent AWOL. This is contradicted by an interview with S1 on 03/02/2020 at 11:51AM, who stated, "C1 is automatic hands on because of her history and knows staff will restrain her from AWOLing because it is in her treatment plan." S6 also stated in their interview on 03/24/2020 at 11:52AM that, "It is the protocol to use restraints on C1 because she is high risk." This is also corroborated by the staff training manual which states, "Residents are not to be restrained from leaving the program by physical force except in situations of extreme danger to self or others, which may be due to age and would be noted in the Individual Crisis Prevention Plans." Based on the information gathered, there is a preponderance of evidence that the facility did not provide adequate supervision of a minor. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. A deficiency is being cited per Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80078(a) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. During a review of C1's hospital visit records and interviews with S1 on 03/02/2020 at 11:51AM, it was found that though C1 returned from one AWOL on 02/17/2020, they were not taken to the hospital until 02/19/2020. S1 stated that C1 refused to go to the hospital, even though she had told staff on duty she had unprotected sexual intercourse with a man in the community while on AWOL. This is corroborated by interviews with S4 on 03/16/2020 at 9:36AM, and S12 on 03/25/2020 at 11:52AM, who both stated C1 told staff right away upon return from AWOL on 02/17/2020 that she had unprotected sexual intercourse with a man in the community and she thought she might be pregnant. Medical records show C1 was taken to John Muir Medical Center on 02/19/2020 for a pregnancy test and Sexually Transmitted Infection (STI) screening, and returned on 02/21/2020 to have test results delivered. Furthermore, multiple staff interviews, as well as review of incident reports, show C1 returned from an AWOL with C3 on 02/21/2020, and C1 immediately told staff she had sexual intercourse with C3 multiple times while on AWOL. Medical records for C1 show that after this incident, C1 was not taken to the hospital for a pregnancy test and STI screening until 02/28/2020. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

Based on the information gathered, there is a preponderance of evidence that the facility did not seek timely medical care for a minor. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. A deficiency is being cited per Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80075(a) - Health Related Services. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. At this time, two deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights discussed and provided, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Felicia Martin with read receipt due to COVID-19 precautions.
investigation_findings: 13At 1:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met with the home above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a Complaint Findings Delivery Inspection. LPA met with Administrator Felicia Martin, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also in attendance was Youth Homes Vice President of Residential Services, Shatae Jones. This complaint was assigned to LPA Fremont on 02/24/2020. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

deficiencies.description:
80078: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the clients' needs. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on records review and interviews with staff and clients, the licensee did not provide the level of supervision necessary to care for its clients, and as outlined in their Needs and Services Plans. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a plan to retrain facility staff on providing Care and Supervision, as well as reviewing each client's individual supervision plan. This shall be submitted no late than 11:59PM on 11/04/2020.

deficiencies.description:
80075: Health Related Services (a) The licensee shall ensure that each client receives necessary first aid and other needed medical [...] services, including arrangment for and/or provision of transportation to the nearest available services. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on client medical records, incident reports, and interview with C1, on 02/21/2020 C1 told staff they had unprotected sexual intercourse while on AWOL, and staff did not take C1 for a pregnancy screening or STI screening until 02/28/2020, and the licensee did not provide timely medical care for a client in its care. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall retrain facility staff on health related services, including making a plan for transportation to these services, no later than 11:59PM on 12/03/2020.

narrative:
This allegation "Staff fractured foster child's shoulder" is in reference to C1 reporting that an incident occurred at the home in which S2 had picked him up and slammed him on the ground, fracturing his shoulder. In C1's medical record received on 06/29/2020, a report dated 02/05/2020 states that an X-ray was taken of C1's shoulder and showed a fracture of the proximal end of his right humerus with lateral displacement. A follow-up report from 03/13/2020 shows that C1 had another X-ray and was given a sling and Range of Motion exercises to aid his rehabilitation. Finally, a psychiatric evaluation of C1 on 03/28/2020 states that C1 reported getting into multiple altercations at the group home in the recent past prior to fracturing his shoulder. On 06/05/2020, Inv. McIntosh received a text message from S1, containing a video clip which showed C1 and C2 wrestling in the facility, and C2 slamming C1 into a table. This video was dated 02/02/2020. In an interview with C1 on 07/17/2020 at 1522 hours, C1 reported they had not seen or experienced any inappropriate interactions while residing at East Bay Shelter. C1 reported to this agency that on 02/04/2020, he was outside playing basketball at the home when S2 came outside and told him it was time to come inside. C1 states he refused, and in response S2 came out, picked up C1, threw him a few feet in the air, and C1 landed on his shoulder causing the fracture. C1 reported to this agency there were no other witnesses, and cameras in view of the incident were not functional at the time. When asked about the video of C1 and C2 wrestling in the facility, C1 stated he could not recall the date it was taken but thought it was from 1-1.5 weeks before he injured his shoulder. C1 identified the other child in the video as C2, and stated he did not sustain any injuries from this altercation, other than hitting his right elbow on the corner of the table. When asked if he played any sports that could have caused his injury, C1 stated he did not play any sports. This statement is inconsistent with a note sent home by W2 on 02/04/2020, which was sent to report to the home that C1 had complained of pain in his right shoulder after playing football earlier in the day. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

An interview with C3 on 10/08/2020 at 1226 hours contradicts the statements given by C1. C3 stated in their interview that C1 was lying about the incident with S2, and that it had never happened. C3 stated S2 caught C1 trying to climb through a female client's bedroom window, and S2 pulled C1 away from the window. C3 reported to this agency that C1 got made at S2 and told C3 he was going to get the home shut down. This is corroborated by Pleasant Hill Police Department Report #20-02-19-0055, which reports that C1 had made statements to S2 such as "I'm going to get you fired" and "I'm going to get this [place] shut down." Finally, C3 admitted to this agency that they were the one that had filmed the altercation between C1 and C2, but they did not think anyone had been injured as a result of the interaction. In an interview with W1 on 10/12/2020 at 1531 hours, W1 stated that C1 had told them about his shoulder hurting during a passing conversation at the home in the days following the alleged incident. W1 reported to this agency that C1 had stated his injury was the result of staff actions, but that C1 was elusive about the conversation and was smiling throughout the interaction. In an interview with W2 on 10/26/2020 at 1133 hours, W2 reported to this agency that on 02/04/2020, C1 had reported his right shoulder was hurting after landing on it during football in his Physical Education class. W2 reports they wrote a note to the home to report C1's injury. In an interview with W3 on 11/12/2020 at 0801 hours, W3 reported to this agency that C1's X-ray showed an early callus of the proximal humerus fracture, indicating the fracture was a few days old at the time the client presented at urgent care with his injury. W3 indicated this type of injury would have been caused by blunt trauma to the shoulder area, and could have been the possible result of being slammed into a table OR from someone throwing the client into the air onto the ground. In an interview with S3 on 11/17/2020 at 1155 hours, S3 reported to this agency they were unaware of any incident involving C1 other than the altercation with C2, which they were present for. S3 stated C1 was touching C2, they started arguing, and C2 slammed C1 onto the kitchen table. S3 reported that C1 later complained his shoulder and arm hurt, and S3 was told later that day that C1 had also reported pain to S2. S3 was unaware of any incident involving C1 and S2. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

In an interview with S2 on 11/23/2020 at 1628 hours, S2 reported to this agency that he had caught C1 trying to sneak through the bedroom window of a female client at the home, and S2 was also aware of the altercation between C1 and C2. S2 stated that after they caught C1 trying to sneak through the window, C1 blamed his shoulder injury on S2. S2 also recalls a day around the same time when staff were asked to come pick C1 up from school after injuring his upper body, but S2 was unaware of what happened, only stating this had happened before C1 sustained his shoulder injury. S2 denies throwing C1 on the ground, stating it would be impossible due to them being the same height and weight. This is contradicted by observations of C1 by this agency and examination of S2's driver's license which shows C1 and S2 are not of similar height or weight. S2 concluded their interview by reporting that C1 eventually apologized to him after the window incident. Finally, contact with Pleasant Hill Police Department Detective D1 on 08/11/2020 at 1107 hours confirms that D1 did not pull a case for this matter, and D1 indicated they could not substantiate the allegation due to conflicting statements. Review of Pleasant Hill Police Department Report #20-02-19-0055 also stated that Youth Homes conducted an internal investigation into this matter and reported conflicting statements from all parties and witnesses. This report continues that through further investigation in conjunction with Child Protective Services (CPS), this allegation could not be substantiated due to lack of evidence and conflicting statements. Based on the information gathered, including review of facility records, police records, medical records, and interviews with clients, staff, and witnesses, there is insufficient evidence to conclude that C1 sustained a fractured shoulder from being slammed onto the ground by S2. Although the allegation "Staff fractured foster child's shoulder" may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation did or not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. At this time, no deficiency is being cited. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Felicia Martin with read receipt, to be signed and returned over email due to COVID-19 precautions.
investigation_findings: 13At 11:03AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to the home above for an announced Complaint Investigation Inspection. The purpose of this inspection was to deliver findings for a complaint received for the home on 02/11/2020. LPA Fremont met with Youth Homes East Bay Shelter Administrator Felicia Martin, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also in attendance was Director of STRTP Operations Ronnie Mabou. Currently in care are 4 clients. (Please see LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 02/23/2021) On 02/11/2020, the San Jose Children's Residential Program Regional Office received a complaint for Youth Homes East Bay Shelter with one allegation: "Staff fractured foster child's shoulder." This complaint was assigned to LPA Fremont on 02/12/2020. Due to the serious nature of this allegation, this investigation was conducted by Community Care Licensing Division's (CCLD) Investigations Branch (IB) Investigator Victoria McIntosh.

narrative:
During an initial 10-Day Complaint Investigation Inspection at the facility on 03/18/2020 at 12:25PM, LPA Fremont met with Administrator Felicia Martin to discuss the nature of the complaint. Because this complaint is regarding the same incident as the complaint 14-CR-20200224152019 dated 02/24/2020, LPA Fremont only requested a copy of an incident report dated 02/19/2020. For this investigation, on the advice of Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Saxon Turner, LPA Fremont used documents and interviews from the complaint dated 02/24/2020 for relevant fact-finding. (See LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 02/23/2021) During an interview with S1 on 03/02/2020 at 11:51AM, LPA inquired about what C1 had disclosed to staff about their frequent AWOL's the weekend of 02/14/2020-02/17/2020. S1 stated that C1 admitted to having sex with another boy who wasn't a client, as well as C3, and "the weed man." S1 also stated that when C1 and C3 returned from one of their AWOLs, staff observed that both clients were covered in leaves from the trees outside. This is corroborated by an incident report dated 02/21/2020, which states that "S4 and S3 observed C1 and C3 running out the back door of the home and hopping the fence in the backyard. Upon return, C1 told staff that they had sex with C3 multiple times while on AWOL." This is also corroborated by an incident report dated 02/16/2020-02/17/2020, which states that C1 and C2 AWOL'd and C2 sold C1 to a homeless man in the community for "$2 and a bag of weed." During an interview with C1 on 03/05/2020 at 12PM, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Saxon Turner asked C1 what they told staff after they came back from this particular AWOL. C1 answered that she told staff she had sex with a man in the community. When LPM Turner asked C1 how staff reacted to this statement, C1 stated they said "Okay." During this same interview with C1 on 03/05/2020 at 12PM, LPM Turner also asked C1 about supervision at the facility. C1 stated that staff are on their phones a lot of the time. This is corroborated by an interview with C3 on 03/19/2020 at 9AM, who stated staff were on heir phones during shift. LPM Turner asked C1 what staff usually do when the clients try to run away, and C1 stated "They let me go, they only tried to follow me once." (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

LPM Turner asked if C1 was allowed to go outside, and C1 responded that they weren't allowed outside without a staff member because they are on line-of-sight supervision. This is corroborated by the Needs and Services Plan for C1 at the time, which also states C1 was on line-of-sight supervision, and manual restraints were permitted to prevent AWOL. This is contradicted by an incident report dated 02/21/2020 which states that staff watched C1 and C3 go outside and jump the fence. Based on the information gathered, there is a preponderance of evidence that the facility did not provide adequate supervision of a minor, and that a lack of supervision by the facility resulted in inappropriate actions between minors. Therefore, the above allegations are substantiated. Because the home has been cited for Lack of Care and Supervision for a previous complaint (14-CR-20200224152019 dated 02/24/2020), which was regarding the same incident as this complaint, and because the home has shown significant improvement in providing care and supervision based on each client's Needs and Services Plans, no deficiency is being cited at this time. An Advisory Note LIC9102 was issued for California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80078(a) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Please see the attached LIC9102 for details. At this time, no deficiencies are being cited. One Advisory Note was issued per Title 22 regulations. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Felicia Martin with read receipt due to COVID-19 precautions.

met_with: Interim Administrator Christal Black; Clinical Supervisor Giselle Supar
narrative: On 10/18/21, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility and met with Interim Administrator Christal Black and Clinical Supervisor Giselle Supar. At 4:30PM, LPA conducted an inspection of the kitchen and food. Food was observed to be organized, sanitary, and within date. However, there were two rodent droppings observed and photographed on top of the left side stack of plates in the cabinet next to the refrigerator. The droppings were small and on top of the plate, clearly visible upon opening the cabinet. Interim Administrator and Clinical Supervisor confirmed observation of droppings. LPA advised that the plate needed to be sanitized; Interim Administrator threw away the plate. LPA did not find any evidence elsewhere of an infestation. Interim Administrator stated that all dishware will be replaced and that dishware and dishware storage will be kept in sanitary condition. Interim Administrator also stated that an exterminator has been to the facility for pest control. LPA issued a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80076 Food Service. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Interim Administrator Christal Black, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 1/21/22 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng and Karmen Balhotra made an unannounced Case Management inspection to the facility and met with Giselle Supar, Clinician (S1) and Dennis Lemus, STRTP Administrator (S2). There are currently six clients in care. LPA Ng received a video showing a mouse crawling in the client’s room and also received a picture of a mouse trap. In the video received, the mouse was behind a light brown dresser. In the second video, it shows the mouse standing on the blue rug in the middle of the room. The mouse trap was located in between the light brown dresser and a skateboard. At 10:40 AM, LPA Ng and Balhotra conducted an inspection of the facility grounds. The facility has four bedrooms, a kitchen, dining room and living room and two bathrooms. LPA's toured the facility and while observing a bathroom, there was a door that is locked with a broken door siding that the lock was attached to. LPA Balhotra mentioned that the door needed to be fixed due to it being a safety hazard. S1 mentioned she has a work order for it. LPA Ng and Balhotra toured the rest of the facility and no safety hazards were present. LPA Ng and LPA Balhotra discussed the reason for the inspection with S1 and S2. S1 stated that they called the Terminix and the company was here on 1/11/2022. In addition, S2 was able to provide a invoice from Terminix for 12/08/2021 and 01/11/2022 with their next appointment being on 2/9/2022 from 2-4 PM. At this time, deficiencies were cited under California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80087 Buildings and Grounds. In addition, a Technical Violation was provided regarding the broken siding for a door located in the bathroom. An exit interview was conducted with S1 and appeal rights were provided. A copy of this report was left with S2.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Hiett met with Administrator Dennis Gonzalez via phone and Clinical Supervisor Giselle Supar regarding a complaint investigation at the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. Based on staff interviews and record review, client has a history of making false allegations when they believe that their placement may be terminated. The client was removed from the facility and subsequently left their new placement and their whereabouts are unknown and their cell phone is no longer in service. LPA Hiett was therefore unable to speak with the client. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that staff yelled at client or that staff did not treat client with dignity and respect. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with staff and no deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

narrative: Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents and staff, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Interim Administrator Ronnie Mabou, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 5/27/22 at 11:20AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Interim Administrator Ronnie Mabou and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing and pre-visit screening call. During investigation, LPA inspected the kitchen, reviewed facility records and conducted confidential interviews with residents and staff. Based on inspection, LPA observed facility food to be well organized and within date on initial inspection. On follow-up inspection, on 5/24/22, LPA observed one unopened package of basil with moldy leaves. The package was front and center in the refrigerator, and Administrator stated the item had been just picked up from the food bank and may have been missed. All other food was observed to be safe, quality, and within date, and food storage had been maintained in good condition and dated and organized according to expiration date. Based on confidential interviews, the facility had an issue with receiving old food from the food bank, but staff would throw it out and not use it. The procedure now is to carefully inspect all food prior to stocking kitchen, and staff have improved in following this procedure.

narrative: On 8/19/2022 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng and Program Policy Analyst Tharan Chahal conducted an unannounced visit to the listed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the psychotropic medications inspection. LPA met with Ronnie Mabou, Administrator. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility. LPA observed the facility to be clean, tidy, and in good repair. The home had a sufficient supply of perishable and non-perishable food. There were three staff members and 1 client present at the time of the inspection. The current census is five clients, four of the clients are at school. Four clients are currently on psychotropic medications. LPA reviewed four client files, three staff files, the centralized medication logs, and staff binder. LPA also observed the locked medications cabinets. At 12:20 PM, LPA observed Ronnie Mabou, Administrator do a medication count of all psychotropic medications, there were no issues with the pill counts. LPA reviewed the PMAR and found two staff initials missing. One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and cited from the California Code of Regulations and Title 22 during the inspection. LPA conducted an exit interview with Ronnie Mabou, Administrator at 3:30 PM, whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

On 9/2/2022 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced case management inspection with listed facility and spoke with Ronnie Mabou, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an incident involving a sexual relationship with former staff and client. LPA Ng reviewed the IB report for complaint # 14-CR-20220415161702. The allegation, staff engaged in inappropriate behavior with client, and found that both staff and client confirmed that they were in a sexual relationship but denied that staff was employed at the facility during that time. The investigator, Shannon Borton asked staff if they were aware of the relationship. Some staff heard about the client being in a relationship with an adult and some said they were unaware. The staff that heard about it stated that they found out after the client left Youth Homes- East Bay. LPA Ng asked Ronnie Mabou, Administrator the procedures for incidences like this and how staff use prudent parenting to ensure clients are getting the services they need. What kind of services, what staff are communicating to clients, and how often they check in with clients regarding safe sex and other health services. No deficiencies were cited today. A copy of this report was given to Ronnie Mabou, Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On 9/2/2022 at 9:30 AM, LPA Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection with Youth Homes- East Bay and met with Ronnie Mabou, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. This complaint was taken as a complaint by Community Care Licensing's (CCL's) Investigations Branch (IB) and assigned to Inv. Shannan Borton on 04/18/2022. During the investigation, it was discovered that staff worked at the facility from 2012-2017. Client was first placed in 2020. Both staff and client confirmed that they were in a sexual relationship but denied that staff was employed at the facility during that time. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that, Staff engaged in inappropriate behavior with client, therefore the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy was sent to Ronnie Mabou, Administrator.

13On 4/15/22 at 11:00, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made a visit to the facility to open a complaint investigation of the above allegation. LPA met with Administrator Felicia Martin and Ronnie Mabou, Director of Operations and Compliance and informed of the purpose of the visit. During investigating the allegation, LPA Ng conducted confidential interviews with facility staff, clients, social workers. Confidential interviews reveal conflicting stories about food being inaccessible to clients in care. At the facility, LPA opened the fridge and saw that there was lots of fruits and vegetables accessible to clients at any time of the day. the fridge did not have a lock or a place to put the lock. Based on interviews and records review, there was not enough evidence to prove that food is inaccessible to clients. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that food is inaccessible to residents, therefore the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy was sent to Ronnie Mabou.

13On 9/2/2022 at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at Youth Homes- East Bay and spoke with Ronnie Mabou, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During confidential interviews with clients and staff, all parties stated that client was in a restraint with their hands behind their back and on the floor. It was also confirmed that staff slapped client in the face. Based on LPA’s interview with Administrator and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations, Staff inappropriately restrained a minor while in care and Staff slapped a minor while in care is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR): 80072(a)(3): Personal Rights and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS): 87095(a)(1)(5): Emergency Interventions Prohibition. See attached LIC9099D for details. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Ronnie Mabou, Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
80072(a)(3) Personal Rights- (a)	Except for children’s residential facilities, each client shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to, the following: (3) To be free from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain……

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interview and record review, staff witnessed another staff slap the client in the face during their shift. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff was terminated, and Administrator will hold a training regarding Personal Rights. Training log will include the date, time, staff initials, and agenda. This is to be sent to LPA by 9/9/2022 by 4:59 PM.

deficiencies.description:
87095.01 Emergency Interventions Prohibition
(a) The following emergency interventions techniques must not be used on a child at any time. (5) Any restraint or containment technique that places a child in a prone position with their hands behind their back.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interview and record review, licensee did not ensure prohibited restraints were not used due to staff performing a prone restraint and holding a resident in restraint by holding the resident’s hands behind back while on the floor.  This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff was terminated, and Administrator will hold a training regarding Manual Restraints. Training log will include the date, time, staff initials, and agenda. This is to be sent to LPA by 9/9/2022 by 4:59 PM.

narrative: On 11/30/22 at 11:15 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced case management inspection. The facility is a one story home in a residential neighborhood. There were no cars outside. During inspection, it was confirmed that the above address is no longer a residential facility. Clinical Director Kendra Sheldon gave LPA Ng the license. Youth Homes- East Bay Shelter is officially closed and the license forfeited.

investigation_findings: 13On 11/30/22 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection with Youth Homes- East Bay and met with Kendra Sheldon, Clinical Director. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. This complaint was taken as a complaint by Community Care Licensing's (CCL's) Investigations Branch (IB) and assigned to Inv. Blake Williams on 07/29/2022. During the investigation, it was discovered that clients did not interact with each other and were on separate sides of the facility. All parties also stated that they have not heard or seen a staff member inappropriately touch a client while in care. Furthermore, clients did not engage in sexual acts with each other. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that, clients engaged in sexual acts with each other while in care and staff member inappropriately touched a client in care, therefore the above allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy was sent to Kendra Sheldon, Clinical Director.

narrative:
On 07/27/2020, LPA Balhotra traveled to the home to notify the licensee of this allegation, to tour the facility, and to conduct interviews with staff and clients. During this inspection, LPA Balhotra conducted interviews with the following clients and staff: C1, C2, C3, C4, S1, S2, and S3. In an interview with S1, S2 stated they had not personally witnessed rodents in the home, but had heard other staff and clients say they had seen them in the home. S1 stated that a client had recently caught a mouse in the snack closet, and Clark Pest Control came to the home the same day to remove it. In an interview with S2, S2 stated they had seen pests in the home, and that Clark Pest Control came out on a regular basis to set and remove traps. S2 stated they have started storing food in plastic bins with lids to try to mitigate the problem. S2 also stated they has personally seen pests in the pantry, garage, and living room. In an interview with S3, S3 stated they had seen a mouse approximately one month earlier, and two were caught in traps in the garage. S3 stated Clark Pest Control regularly came out to the home to set and remove traps. S3 stated the home is always kept clean, and staff deep clean every night. In interviews with C1, C2, C3, and C4, all clients confirmed they had seen pests in the house, specifically mice. C1 stated they had seen mice in the kitchen, and they thought the problem was that the garbage cans were kept in the garage. C2 stated they also saw a mouse in the kitchen, and they believed the rodents were coming in through a hole in the baseboards underneath the dishwasher. This is corroborated by a photo taken by LPA Balhotra during this inspection, which shows a small hole between the dishwasher and the floor where there is a missing piece of baseboard. C2 stated the house is always clean, and they believed the mice were coming in the house from the surrounding fields because the area is hot and dry. C3 and C4 stated they had also seen mice in the kitchen, and that Clark Pest Control frequently came to the house to spray for bugs and to set and remove rodent traps. C4 stated they had seen a dead mouse stuck in a glue trap in the kitchen, and sent a picture of the mouse to LPA Balhotra to verify this statement. The photo shows a Clark Pest Control employee holding a glue trap with a mouse caught in the glue. Other photos taken by LPA Balhotra during this inspection show rodent droppings in the cabinet under the kitchen sink, and a hole in the wall underneath the kitchen sink where the pests could possibly be coming through. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

On 08/28/2020 at 9:01AM, LPA Fremont received an email from Administrator Christal Black, which contained copies of invoices from Clark Pest Control for pest treatments. The first invoice dated 03/03/2020 states that Clark removed one dead mouse from a garbage can in the backyard. The second invoice dated 05/05/2020 states the Clark employee de-webbed around the windows and doors, treated for spiders, ants, wasps, and roaches, and set glue boards in the garage, kitchen, and pantry. The third invoice dated 07/14/2020 states the Clark employee de-webbed around the windows and doors, and treated the home for ants, spiders, wasps, and roaches. Finally, the fourth invoice dated 08/20/2020 states the Clark employee who conducted the inspection found no signs of bed bugs, and no signs of rodents in the home. Because of this, no chemicals or additional glue boards were applied to the home to continue pest mitigation. Based on the information gathered, including LPA observations, records review, and interviews with staff and clients, there is a preponderance of evidence that the facility had mice coming into the home at the time this complaint was received in July 2020. Therefore, the allegation "Facility has pests" is substantiated. Because of the licensee's continued efforts to eradicate rodents and bugs from the home through the regular utilization of pest control treatments by Clark Pest Control, and based on Clark Pest Control finding no sign of rodents in the home in August 2020, no deficiency is being cited at this time. An Advisory Note was issued for California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 7, Section 80087(a) - Buildings and Grounds. Please see the attached LIC9102 for details. At this time, no deficiency is being cited. One LIC9102 - Advisory Note was issued. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Christal Black for the home's records.
investigation_findings: 13At 1:36PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to Youth Homes Pryor to conduct an unannounced Complaint Investigation Inspection. narrative: On Tuesday, March 22, 2022 at 10:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa conducted an annual/required inspection at the above facility. LPA Ng met with Administrator, Christal Black. We did not get inside until 11:15 due to Administrator not having the keys. Direct care staff Felicia came and let us inside. The facility has not been operating since September of 2021 so the facility has been vacant. Therefore, LPA Ng did not use Inspection Tool during todays inspection. Please note, the facility has been in communication with CCL regards to their current status. LPA Ng toured the facility inside and out and found the facility to be safe and clean. Administrator Christal informed LPA Ng that repairs will be completed once they decide to open back up. There were some drywall patches and wood panels showing. During LPA Ng's walk thru, LPA observed the facility having some items packed in plastic bins for storage. The refrigerator and freezer were empty. LPA toured the upstairs and there were a total of 4 client bedrooms in the facility. Two of the client bedrooms are shared and two are single occupancy. All bed rooms were empty and three were storing plastic bins, mattresses, and bed frames. There are three bathrooms. One bathroom is located downstairs. The downstairs bathroom is only designated for the clients that live downstairs and the upstairs bathroom for the clients that stay upstairs. The staff bathroom is located in the staff office. Cleaning supplies, medication cabinet, and sharps are locked and located in the staff office. The Administrator stated that the listed facility is rarely in use. There was one occasion was when a client had COVID and one time when clients would go out on their outings and want a place to hang out. LPA Ng also advised the facility to check in with LPA when deciding to open back up so LPA can know what the facility current status is. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a follow-up complaint investigation to the above facility. LPA Ng conducted the complaint findings at Youth Homes sister facility, Youth Home- East Bay Shelter. LPA Ng met with Director of Operations and Compliance Ronnie Mabou. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA Mendoza gathered documentation, interviewed staff, authorized representatives, and one client. LPA Mendoza tried to interview all clients on several occasions however authorized representatives did not know their whereabouts. As a result, LPA Mendoza could not move forward with the interviews. The interviews revealed inconsistencies in explanations for residents' privacy not being respected by staff members. LPA obtained copies of staff shift notes for September and reviewed incident reports. LPA found no information which corroborates the information obtained from the parties interviewed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was left with the Ronnie, Director Of Complaince and Operations.

On 03/18/2025 at 4:10 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jasmine Cardeno made an unannounced visit to the building of the former facility, Youth Homes - Pryor. LPA knocked on the front door and observed staff and youth present in the home. LPA met with Behavorial Specialist, William Lowery, who facilitated the inspection. LPA informed Behavioral Specialist the purpose of the inspection is to verify that Youth Homes - Pryor is no longer operating as a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) or as a Licensed Chidren's Residential Facility. During the time of the inspection, three youth were present and three staff were present. Behavioral Specialist informed LPA that they are currently hosting an art event for the youth. At 4:15 PM, Behavioral Specialist facilitated a walk-through tour of the building. LPA observed both inside and outside of the building including the downstairs rooms that are used as office spaces for staff and a conference meeting room. In addition, LPA observed the kitchen, dining, and living room area. LPA followed Behavioral Specialist upstairs and observed the rooms to be used as therapeutic meeting rooms including a therapy room, art room, and a recreational room with board games, toys, and art supplies. LPA observed that there are no beds present in the building or signs of youth residing in the building. In addition, LPA observed the outdoor backyard of the facility and the garage area. LPA had a discussion with Behavioral Specialist regarding how the building is now operating currently as an office space for TBS workers and Agency employees, and is no longer operating as an STRTP. In addition, the building is being used as a space for events and activities to be held for youth. LPA observed the building of the former facility, Youth Homes - Pryor, is not being used as an STRTP. LPA observed that there are no clients residing in the facility. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Behavioral Specialist, William Lowery, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On November 5, 2020 at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted a Case Management (SB 484 Psychotropic Medications) tele-inspection of the facility via Microsoft Teams. Remote "tele-inspections" of facilities are a part of Community Care Licensing Division’s emergency response to the spread of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). During this tele-inspection, LPA met with Jamaica Smith, Program Director. All pertinent staff and client records were scanned and emailed to LPA Herring prior to the tele-inspection. LPA conducted a facility tour with Ms. Smith at 11:05 AM. LPA reviewed 2 staff records and 3 client records prior to the tele- inspection and continued review of records during the tele-inspection to obtain and/or clarify missing information. LPA also reviewed the facility's Plan of Operation prior to the tele-inspection. LPA inspected medications at 11:30 AM. LPA interviewed 2 staff members at approximately 12:15 PM. LPA interviewed 2 clients at approximately 1:00 PM. One of the three clients taking psychotropic medications has been admitted to a psychiatric hospital, therefore, LPA was unable to interview the client. There were no deficiencies issued during the tele-inspection. LPA conducted an exit interview with Ms. Smith at 1:30 PM. A copy of this licensing report was provided to Ms. Smith on 11/5/2020 via email with a request for signature.

Facility staff denied the alleged allegation and further indicated that all clients are provided three meals a day that consist of the five food groups (fruit and vegetables, carbohydrates, proteins, dairy, fats and oils) and an option for snacks in between meals. Staff further disclosed that prior to planning the monthly menu staff will ask the clients what type of meals they would like while making sure they adhere to the five food groups. 5 of 6 clients (1 client declined to be interviewed) denied the alleged allegation and indicated that they are provided three meals a day with snacks in between meals. Furthermore, clients stated that they are asked for their input when staff is planning the monthly menu. Information obtained from the CSW did not corroborate the alleged allegation nor had concerns to the health and wellbeing of any of the clients residing in the facility. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with Facility Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Information obtained from clients revealed that the allegation is false and that no client in the facility needs assistance with their personal hygiene. Furthermore, client stated that staff are supportive and go above and beyond to provide whatever is needed in a timely manner. Information obtained from the CSW indicated that the alleged victim was medically discharged by their doctor and being fully capable of conducting his daily living activities with very minimal help from facility staff. CSW further indicated that the facility staff have gone above and beyond in accommodating the alleged victim and has no concerns to the health and safety of any client residing in the facility. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. narrative: Information obtained through confidential interviews corroborated the allegation, facility staff (S1) acted aggressively toward minor (C1). Based on interviews and video footage the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegation that facility staff acted aggressively toward minor is substantiated. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care. The Facility is cited for STRTP Interim Licensing Standards Chapter 7.5 section 87072(d)(11) Personal Rights, To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. Appeals rights were provided, and a copy of the report and LIC 9099-D has been emailed to the facility representative mentioned above.

narrative:
On 10/07/2021 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jenny Mundo and Timika Martin conducted an unannounced Required Annual inspection at the above-named Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) facility. LPAs met with the facility Administrator Mario Barron and the Program Director Jamacia Smith. The facility is currently accredited by CARF effective 5/31/2021 and expires on 5/31/2024. The facility's mental health program was approved effective 6/21/2021 and expires on 6/21/2022. The facility's license will will be updated to reflect a permanent licensure. LPAs requested a copy of current resident roster and Personnel Report (LIC 500). Currently, the facility has five (5) minor residents placed by Humboldt, Kern and Tulare counties. Based on the review of Licensing Information System (LIS), all facility staff listed on the LIC 500 have received fingerprint clearances. The facility is a one-story home with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, a staff office, kitchen, dining area, a living room, and a laundry room. There are no bodies of water on the premises. The facility is licensed to serve up to six (6) ambulatory minors ages 12-17 years of age. At 11:00 AM, LPAs conducted a walkthrough of the entire facility. Physical Plant Sharps and knives are kept locked in the office closet. Per the administrator, there are no firearms on the premises. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are locked in the walk-in storage room located in the office. Temperature in rooms that the residents occupy are maintained at 71 degrees (F). The hot water temperature was measured at 117.7 (F). Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. The facility has two(2) fire extinguishers that are fully charged. Facility has a working telephone. Advisory notes and citation/s were issued to address physical plant issues observed.

Continued from pg.1 Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies Facility has two(2) toilets, two(2) wash basins, and two(2) showers. Individual privacy is provided in all toilet, bath and shower areas. Each resident has an individual bed in good repair; equipped with good springs and clean mattresses. The quantity of linen provided permits changing the linen at least once a week or more when indicated to ensure that clean linen is in use by clients at all times. Each client is provided with items used to maintain basic personal hygiene practices including but not limited to shampoo, soap, toothbrush, toothpaste, comb, toilet paper. Each client bedroom has closets and drawer space to accommodate the client's clothing and personal belongings. Health Related Services Medications are centrally stored and locked in the office cabinet and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. Food Service A written weekly menu is posted in an area accessible to the staff and clients. A review of weekly menu indicates that the facility provides nutritious meals and snacks. Facility maintains supplies of staple non-perishable foods for at least one week and fresh perishable foods for at least two days. There was one (1) Advisory Notes-Technical Assistance (LIC9102TA) and one (1) citation issued during the today’s inspection. Annual Continuation is required at a later date. An exit interviewed was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to facility representative.

On 11/19/2021 at 8:456 am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jenny Mundo and Pamela Silva conducted an SB (Senate Bill) 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection and met with Jamacia Smith, the facility Program Director. Currently, there are six (6) clients placed at the facility. One (1) of the six (6) clients is taking psychotropic medications and is placed by Humboldt County Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). LPAs conducted a facility tour with the Program Director at 9:00 AM. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. All medications are centrally stored, locked and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. LPAs reviewed the facility's Program Statement. LPAs reviewed one (1) client’s file and three (3) staff files. LPAs interviewed two (2) staff. LPAs were unable to interview one (1) client due to client being sick. LPAs conducted an exit interview. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. A copy of this report was provided to the facility representative along with Confidential Names list (LIC 811).

Staff denied the allegation further indicating that clients are well supervised by staff maintaining above the recommended Interim Licensing standards 1:4 staff to client ratio by having three to five staff members present at the facility. Staff indicated that if they are aware of a client wanting to AWOL staff will attempt to deter the client by verbally redirecting them while trying to determine what is trigging the behavior. Staff indicated that they try to provide a variety of activities to keep the clients busy and motivated to finish their program and hopefully deter the clients from AWOL. Information obtained from clients did not corroborate the above allegation further disclosing that they feel safe and are provided with whatever they need by facility staff. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Program Director. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the STRTP Program Director.
investigation_findings: 13On March 30, 2022, at 8:03 PM., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Winston Moroney, conducted a complaint inspection to the above Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Facility and met with STRTP Program Director Jamacia Smith. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegation. On October 4, 2021, the California Department of Social Services Community Care Licensing Division received a complaint from Centralized Complaint and Information Bureau (CCIB) with the following allegations: Staff did not prevent minor from AWOL. The investigation to the above allegations was conducted by this LPA and it consisted of, but not limited to a review of records, including the children’s needs and services plans, medical records, and interviews with 3 Staff members (S1, S2, and S3) on 10/14/2021, 3 of 4 Clients (C1, C2, and C3) on 10/14/2021, (C4 was AWOL at time of interview). (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated March 30, 2022).

narrative:
On 9/29/2022 at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jenny Mundo conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility listed above and met with the Program Director Jamacia Smith. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual Continuation from the initial inspection on 9/27/2022. DISASTER PREPAREDNESS PLAN Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drills at least monthly. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. EMERGENCY INTERVENTION PLAN LPA reviewed the facility's emergency intervention plan. The facility has used manual restraints twice and are documented in a log. Facility has an emergency intervention training curriculum. All staff members are trained on the facility's emergency intervention procedures. CLIENT RECORDS LPA reviewed four (4) client records. Client records are maintained locked onsite. CORE/THERAPEUTIC SERVICES The facility provides core services and supports to children as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and services to achieve permanency.

CLIENTS WITH SPECIAL HEALTH CARE NEEDS There are currently no clients in care with special health care needs. There was one (1) citation, two (2) Advisory Notes-Technical Assistance (LIC9102TA) and two (2) Advisory Notes-Technical Violations (LIC9102TA) issued during today’s inspection An exit interviewed was conducted and a copy of this report with appeal rights were provided to facility representative.

On 9/27/2022 at 10:25 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jenny Mundo conducted an unannounced Required Annual inspection at the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) facility. LPA met with the facility Administrator Mario Barron and the Program Director Jamacia Smith. The STRTP currently has thirteen (13) personnel, two (2) interns and six (6) clients in placement. The facility is a one-story home with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, a staff office, kitchen, dining area, a living room, and a laundry room. There are no bodies of water on the premises. The facility is licensed to provide services to 6 ambulatory male clients ages 12-17 and to Non-Minor dependents.. LPA conducted a walk-thru of the entire facility at approximately 11:00 AM. LPA obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: · LIC 500 Personnel Report · Client Roster · LIC 610C (Emergency Disaster Plan For Children’s Residential Facilities) · Written disaster and mass casualty plan of action · Accreditation · Board of Directors meeting minutes

PHYSICAL PLANT LPA observed the following signage posted in the living room, dining room, kitchen and office areas: group home license, accreditation, client activity schedule, facility menu, personal rights and grievance procedures. There is sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable food. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are locked in the walk-in storage room located in the office. Sharps & knives, medication, client & staff files are kept locked in the office and inaccessible to the clients. The facility has seven (7) complete first aid kits and a fire extinguisher located in the office. There is another fire extinguisher located underneath the kitchen sink; both fire extinguishers were serviced on 8/19/2022. Carbon monoxide/smoke detectors were tested and observed to be operable. The facility’s room temperatures was maintained at a safe and comfortable temperature. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 117.2 degrees F. There are no firearms on the premises. The facility phone system is operable. OPERATIONS The facility is currently accredited by CARF thru 5/31/2024. The facility's mental health program was approved effective 6/21/2022 and expires on 6/21/2023. STAFF RECORDS LPA Mundo reviewed four (4) Staff records. Staff records are maintained locked onsite in the staff office. All facility staff have received a criminal record clearance or exemption and child abuse index checks. One staff (S4) was missing a health screening and TB test. There were three (3) citations issued during today’s inspection. Annual Continuation is required at a later date. An exit interviewed was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to facility representative.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez on 11/01/22 at 9:30AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Gutierrez met with Mario Barron, Administrator and Jamacia Smith, Program Director. LPA together with Program Director inspected the facility inside and out. Currently, there are six (6) clients placed at the facility. Three (3) of the six (6) clients are taking psychotropic medications. LPA conducted a facility tour with the Program Director at 10:15 AM. All medications are centrally stored, locked and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. LPA reviewed the facility's Program Statement. LPA reviewed three (3) clients' records and three (3) staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA interviewed three (3) staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation.

LPA interviewed one (1) of the children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. The other two (2) clients were not available. No deficiency citation issued at this time. LPA conducted exit interview and provided a copy of this report to Program Director Smith.

C1’s representative confirmed the allegation was false and that there was no physical abuse towards C1 from any of the staff members. Based on the information obtained during the investigation, it cannot be determined whether the above allegations occurred. Based upon interviews, the complaint findings are unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the allegations occurred. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the above-named facility staff.
investigation_findings: 13On May 23, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Johanna Lofton, conducted a follow up inspection visit Youth Quest Guidance Center with the purpose of delivering findings for the above complaint allegation. LPA Lofton met with Jamaica Smith, Facility's Program Director. During the complaint investigation, LPA Lofton conducted confidential interviews with clients, facility staff, and social worker. The allegation was denied by interviewed parties. Facility clients and staff reported that C1 can get out of control at times and would have to be restrained at times due to getting violent and out of control.Iinterviewed facility clients denied seeing any staff member physically hit C1. Interviewed facility staff denied seeing the former staff physically hit C1. The investigation revealed that the staff member C1 reported as the perpetrator (S3), was not at the facility the day of the incident. Furthermore, the alleged perpetrator separated from the facility as an employee as of September 2022.

narrative: On July 21, 2023 at approximately 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raymond Wu conducted an unannounced Case Management visit at the facility for the purposes of citing recent deficiencies at the facility. A review of records indicated that the facility did not meet the reporting requirements for incidents that occurred on 05/25/23, 06/02/23, and 06/23/23. The incidents that occurred on these dates required at least verbal notification to the Department within 24 hours and a written incident report within 7 days. However, the 24 hour notification requirement was not met. The facility is being cited under CCR 80061(b) for Reporting Requirements on the corresponding 809D page.. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Licensee.

deficiencies.description:
80061(b) Reporting Requirements
Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours... This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on a review of records, incidents that occurred on 05/25/23, 06/02/23, and 06/23/23 were not reported to the licensing agency within 24 hours. This poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will re-train staff on reporting requirements and provide proof of training to LPA by 08/11/23.

met_with: Mario Barron Administrator and Zarion Holiday Facility Manager
narrative: On 8/30/23 at approximately 12:05PM., Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo and Irene Yamamoto conducted an unannounced Case Management. During this inspection, LPAs met with the facility representatives named above. The purpose this inspection was to discuss with Administrator the facilities procedure for reporting 24hr, notices to CCLD. Administrator was able to provide Analysts with proof that the 24hr. requirement was made on time for incidents on 7/20/23, 7/30/23 and 8/16/23. Moving forward Administrator advised that they would make 24hr. incidents notification though SIR email with following information : Date of incident and name/names of clients involved. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy off this report was given.

It was alleged that around April 2023, facility staff improperly restrained one client in care on multiple occasions which resulted in minor scratches. In an interview conducted, one client stated that facility staff were physically rough when conducting manual restraints but denied any type of physical abuse or corporal punishment in the facility. The client stated that in one instance, they sustained some minor scratches on their body as a result of being manually restrained. In an interview conducted, a second client denied any type of physical abuse or corporal punishment in the home and also denied that staff would be unnecessarily rough during manual restraints. In interviews conducted, three staff members denied the allegation and stated that the client in question exhibited a lot of behaviors that were physically dangerous to others as well as to themselves. As a result, they have had to use manual restraints on a more frequent basis with the client. Staff stated that there was one instance in which the client had to be held in a prone position and sustained a rug burn from the carpet. Staff stated that the client did not initially report this to them as they felt that it was an accident and not a serious injury. However, staff have began conducting more thorough body checks every time manual restraint is used since then. Staff stated that they receive manual restraint training every year through a qualified, contracted instructor. LPA reviewed facility video footage of instances in which the client had to be manually restrained. In the video footage, LPA observed instances in which the client was physically violent towards others as well as themselves, suggesting that manual restraint was necessary in those moments. LPA did not observe any indication of malice or intentional roughness on the part of staff conducting the manual restraints. A review of records revealed that the facility properly logged instances of manual restraint in the facility. Based on interviews conducted and records reviewed, there is not a preponderance of evidence to suggest that the allegation occurred. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met. Therefore, the allegation is deemed UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Licensee.
