narrative: On November 21,2023 at approximately 9:57 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo conducted an unannounced Case Management. During this inspection, LPA met with the facility representative Jamacia Smith was given a tour of facility by Shawn Love Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to address the late reporting of Special Incident Reports (SIR). Based on a review of records it was indicated that the facility did not meet the reporting requirements for an incident that occurred on 10/22/23. The incident required notification to the Department by telephone, email, or fax within 24 hours or by the next business day following the event, followed by a written incident report within 7 days of the incident. SIR for incident on 10/22/23 was submitted to CCL on 11/01/23. The written incident report within 7 days requirement was not met. This violation pose an immediate and/or potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. The facility is being cited under CCR 80061(b) for Reporting Requirements on the corresponding LIC809D page. This is a repeated violation of the same subsection within a 12-month period, an immediate civil penalty of $250.00; will be accessed. The repeated violation was addressed with the STRTP on 07/21/23 (LIC 809/809-D). Exit interview conducted. Appeal rights provided.

80061(b) Reporting Requirements
Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours...a written report...shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on a review of records, incident  that occurred on 10/22/23. SIR written report was not submitted to the CCL within 7 days following the incidents. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Project Director (PD) Jamaica Smith to follow up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing where two clients reportedly AWOL on 12/03/23 and had sexual interactions with one another. Client ref #1 (C1) and Client ref #2 (C2) (see LIC811 confidential names dated 01/10/24), when clients returned to the facility C1 had been physically assaulted and had visible injuries to face. C1 declined medical attention that night. The following morning Staff (S2) insisted that C1 have eye looked at and C1 was transported to seek medical attention and was diagnosed with an orbital fracture to eye. LPA reviewed SIR, staff schedules, program statement emergency Intervention plan, needs and service plans for C1 and C2, and obtained a copy of police report. LPA toured the facility. LPA Garibaldo noted both clients have AWOL history. LPA Garibaldo attempted to interview C1. C1 declined to be interviewed regarding this incident. LPA Garibaldo attempted to interview C2. C2 declined to be interviewed. Currently there is an ongoing police investigation regarding alleged assault. Based on the information gathered at this time, the facility took proper action regarding the incident in question and therefore no further follow up necessary at this time. Exit interview was conducted. No deficiencies were issued at the time of inspection. A copy of LIC809 was provided to the facility representative.

Page 2 The Department received a complaint alleging a facility staff (S1) assaulted a youth while in care. On November 14, 2023, a facility client (FC1) was observed with a red/purple bruise on his face that resembled a shoe imprint, and a red bruise on his upper left shoulder. It was alleged that on the previous night, S1 thrust FC1’s face into a headboard, and threw FC1 to the ground and stepped on his face. S1 denied the allegation and stated that on the evening of 11/13/23, due to aggressive behaviors, he placed FC1 in a prone restraint. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with staff did not support the allegation. Record review revealed law enforcement interviewed pertinent individuals regarding the alleged assault. There were no witnesses to the reported incidents. Based on information gathered from interviews conducted and records reviewed, the allegation is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. A copy of this report and confidential names form LIC811 dated 1/29/24 were given to the above-mentioned facility representative. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted.
investigation_findings: 13On 1/26/24 at 10:49 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios conducted a follow up complaint inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). During the inspection LPA Larios met with Director Jamacia Smith. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings regarding the above mentioned complaint allegation. The allegation was investigated by Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Bureau (IB) State Investigator (SI) Mariana Lomeli. During the course of the investigation, SI Lomeli conducted interviews with four staff, two administrators, three facility clients, and others between 12/05/23 and 1/11/24. SI Lomeli also obtained a Bakersfield Police Department report on 11/29/23 and reviewed the STRTP Program Statement on 12/14/23. On 11/22/23, LPA Larios conducted a record review and obtained copies of the LIC500, LIC9020, needs and service plan, special incident reports, staff identification, job description, discipline policy, and training records. Continued on page

narrative: S1 stood on the outside of C1’s bedroom door. C1 came up to S1 and began to curse at S1 and pushed and punched S1’s face. S1 restrained C1 by holding C1’s hand to prevent them from getting more punches. C1 then began to kick S1 and threatened to kill him. C1 bit S1’s right arm and head butt him. S2 tried to calm C1 and placed a pillow between C1 and S1 to shield C1’s head butts. C1 continued to make verbal threats against S1. Staff stated the client was not inappropriately restrained. Statements obtained from the confidential interviews provided contradictory information regarding the allegation and did not provide sufficient information to corroborate the allegation. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative via electronic mail.
investigation_findings: 13On January 9, 2024, at 1:10 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Suh conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the finding of an investigation concerning to the allegation above. The LPA met with the representative named above and discussed the finding. The investigation included confidential interviews that consisted of but were not limited to: five clients, three staff, and Program Director at the facility on July 26, 2023, two staff on August 18, 2023. The LPA reviewed client’s (C1; see Confidential Names LIC 811, dated January 9, 2024) Needs and Services Plan, Child and Family Team (CFT) Meetings Report, Qualified Individual Assessment Report Addendum, and Special Incident Report, and Personnel Report (LIC 500). It was alleged that staff inappropriately restrained a minor. Staff denied the allegation. C1 was on one on one supervision by staff (S1) due to C1’s history of AWOL. C1 had been pacing back and forth and S1 redirected them to relax and suggested to watch a movie with S1. C1 became agitated and walked back into their room.

This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs met with Jamacia Smith, Program Director and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed two (2) of child’s record and two (2) of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed two (2) of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPAs interviewed two (2) staff on site to discuss the facility's policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed one (1) of child currently prescribed psychotropic medication LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Program Director,Jamacia Smith. On 1/29/24 at 11:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios conducted an unannounced case management inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). During the inspection LPA Larios met with Director Jamacia Smith. On 11/13/24 at approximately 6:00 PM, a facility client (FC1) (See Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 1/29/24) was asleep in the facility living room. Staff (S1) attempted to awaken FC1 however, FC1 refused. Due to FC1’s unresponsiveness, S1 then physically escorted FC1 to his bedroom. As they entered the bedroom another client, FC2, kicked S1. Per an incident report dated 11/13/24, S1 placed FC2 in a containment after he was kicked. While S1 was containing FC2, FC1 hit S1 in the face with a pillow and punched him on the chest which resulted in S1 placing FC1 in a containment for two minutes. During a follow up interview conducted by the Department, S1 admitted to placing FC1 in a prone restraint on the bedroom floor between two beds. S1 stated FC1 was lying on his stomach with his head turned to the side. S1 stated he placed one hand on FC1’s back and his hand on FC1’s arm. S1 stated he released FC1 after a couple of minutes, once S1 observed FC1 was calm. FC1 was assessed by other staff on site and then fell asleep. Continued on page 2

Page 2 The facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Article 6, standard 87061(i)(7)(C) Reporting Requirements. The incident report dated 11/13/23 failed to describe the use of a manual restraint on FC1. In addition, the facility is cited for ILS STRTP Article 6, standard 87072(c)(1) Personal Rights. Per the facility Emergency Intervention Plan, escorts can be implemented when the client poses a danger to self, or others, or when staff determine a location is unsafe for client. In this situation FC1 was not a danger to himself, and did not require to be physically escorted to his room to sleep. In addition, the facility is cited for ILS STRTP Article 6, standard 87095.01(a)(4) Emergency Interventions Prohibition. Prone restraints may not be used on a child at any time. A copy of this report, LIC809D, LIC811 and appeals rights were provided to the above-mentioned facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

deficiencies.description: Reporting Requirements. Incident Reports must include the following: Incident Reports documenting the use of manual restraints must include the following: Description of what manual restraints were used, and how long the child  was restrained. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review an incident report submitted by the facility was lacking the required information regarding use a manual restraint on FC1, which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will train staff on incident report writing regarding use of manual restraint as required by ILS.  The facility will use the most recent version of ILS when planning the agenda. The licensee will submit a sign in sheet and training agenda via email on or before the due date to Christopher.Larios@dss.ca.gov

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, and below, as applicable: To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on statements obtained from interviews conducted with staff, S1's use of an escort was unwarranted and does not adhere to the emergency intervention plan, which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will retrain staff on de-escalation  and use of emergency intervention techniques.  The licensee will submit a sign in sheet and training agenda via email within twenty four hours to Christopher.Larios@dss.ca.gov

deficiencies.description: Emergency Interventions Prohibition. The following emergency interventions techniques must not be used on a child at any time; Prone restraint. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on S1 admitting he placed FC1 in a prone restraint during an incident at the facility on 11/13/23, which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to youth in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The faciltiy will review the current ILS and revise thier Emergency Intervention/ Runaway plan as needed regarding the use restraints.  The licensee will submit the revision to  Angelina.Garibaldo@dss.ca.gov and Christopher.Larios@dss.ca.gov by the POC due date or earlier.

narrative: An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios on 2/15/24 at 10:44 AM. During the inspection LPA Larios met with Director Jamacia Smith. The purpose of the inspection was to amend a plan of correction for a citation issued on 1/29/24. A copy of this report and amended LIC9099D were provided to the above mentioned staff at the conclusion of the inspection.

On June 12,2024 at 0:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo made an unannounced case management inspection to the facility and met Jamaica Smith Program Director. The purpose of the case management was to follow up on the Special Incident Report (SIR) the Department received regarding physical altercation between two clients. On 06/05/24, the Department received the SIR dated 05/29/24 regarding the incident. The SIR stated that client (C1) (see confidential names form LIC 811 dated on 6/12/24) left the facility and S1 followed behind C1. C1 made threats “to cut” S1 and C1 pulled out a black knife so that S1 could see it and ran off into the alley hiding behind a bush. S1 called the administration team for assistance and reported to Bakersfield Police Department (BPD) that C1 had a weapon on him. Program Director arrived and C1 stated he had something for her and handed the knife over to Program Director. C1 was transported back to the facility where a safety check was done, and BPD was notified of his return. At the time of the inspection, LPA spoke to Program Director regarding the incident. She stated the STRTP program conducted an internal investigation, and it was found that the knife did not come from STRTP, and all knives were accounted for. LPA reviewed knife inventory log and ensured facility knifes were secure in locked locker in office. Statements made by S1 indicates that the knife may obtained by C1 during AWOL. S1 stated she saw C1 pick up and object from ground. Client refused to reveal where the knife was obtained. No deficiency citation was issued at the time of the inspection. Based on information obtained through interviews and documentation provided, no follow-up is needed at this time. A copy of this report was provided to the facility representative, and an exit interview was conducted. There were no deficiencies cited during today’s inspection.

met_with: Jamacia Smith-Program Director, Zarion Holiday - Facility Manager
narrative: On 6/5/2024 at 11:11 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection at the facility and met with Jamacia Smith the facility’s Program Director and Zarion Holiday Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an unusual incident report the Department received on 5/24/24, regarding a sexual assault involving two clients (See Confidential Names list (LIC811) dated 6/5/24). The incident allegedly happened a month ago. No specific date and time reported. LPA conducted interviews and reviewed records. C2 denied the allegation. C1 alleged that the assault did occur, LPA received information that C1 was mad at C2 for a prior altercation and made the allegation against C2 to have him removed from STRTP. Confidential interviews also revealed that C1 has been making sexual threats against clients and clients do not feel safe around C1. Staff stated making nightly bed checks raging in time from every three to fifteen minutes. Staff notified Bakersfield Police Department on 5/16/24 and the incident is currently under investigation. Based on the information gathered, Administrator must implement a safety plan by end of day (6/5/24) and send LPA a copy of plan, stating how facility will ensure the safety of all clients in care. Administrator will also request an emergency Child and Family Team Meeting (CFT) with county social worker, placing social worker, mental health provider’s, facility administrator and facility director. Administrator will notify LPA of date of meeting. An exit interview was conducted and copy of the LIC 809 and LIC 811 were provided to the administrator. No deficiency citations issued at the time of the inspection.

On August 15, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo conducted a case management inspection at the STRTP and met with Jamacia Smith Program Director. The purpose of the inspection was to address violations that were revealed during the investigation of complaint 32-CR-20240607142405. LPA Garibaldo observed the following: The facility uses an "allowance deduction" system as a fine for property damage and as a form of discipline for C1, C2, C3 and C4. Records of clients' cash resources were missing supporting receipts for purchases, and full signature of clients. Facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80026(h)(1)(A) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property, and Valuables and 87026(c) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property, and Valuables. An exit interview was conducted, and the following reports were emailed LIC809, LIC 809-D, and LIC811 Confidential Names Form. Appeal rights forms were provided and explained.

deficiencies.description:
80026(h)(1)(A) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property, and Valuables (h) Each licensee shall maintain accurate records of account...
(1) Records of clients' cash resources ... Supporting receipts for purchases shall be filed in chronological order.A)Receipts for cash p... full signature or mark, and a statement acknowledging receipt of the amount and date received... This requirement is not met as evidence by:

The facility uses an "allowance deduction" system as a fine for property damage and disipline
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The Licensee will update and review allowance distribution policy to ensure supporting receipts for purchases shall be filed in chronological order and signatures are obtained. Licensee will re-train staff and send LPA revised policy and proof of re-training by 8/29/24.

deficiencies.description:
87026(c) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property, and Valuables
(c) The licensee shall ensure that a child's cash resources are not taken in the form of fines.
This requirement is not met as evidence by: Facility uses an "allowance deduction" system that resulted in client's cash resources taken in the form of fines.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee reimburse clients allowances that were deducted and will ensure that the form of discipline used in the facility is trauma informed, culturally relevant and age and developmentally appropriate. Facility will revisit their STRTP program statement to ensure these requirements are met. Licensee will send updated policy to LPA and proof of reimbursement by 8/29/24.

narrative: LPA conducted interviews with six clients. All six clients stated that they were unaware they had a monthly clothing allowance. Client statements also corroborate that they were not taken shopping monthly and have not been provided with adequate clothing by the facility. Four clients disclosed that a majority of clothing that clients currently have is largely what they had when arriving to the facility and stated that most of the clothing no longer fits or is poor condition. While conducting client interviews LPA observed three clients wearing jeans and shirts that appeared to be too small. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed there is a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation, therefore, the allegation is substantiated which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the child in clients in care Based on the information gathered, the allegation stated above is SUBSTANTIATED. A substantiated finding means the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. This violation poses an immediate and/or potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care. The facility is being cited under Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Article 6, standard Personal Rights 87072(d)(6)(A). An exit interview was conducted, and the following reports were emailed LIC809, LIC 809-D, and LIC811 Confidential Names Form. Appeal rights forms were provided and explained.

narrative: On October 2, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo conducted a case management inspection at the STRTP and met with Jamacia Smith Program Director and Zarion Holiday Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on previous violations. On August 15, 2024, the facility was issued a deficiency for using an "allowance deduction" system as a fine for property damage and as a form of discipline for C1, C2, C3 and C4. (See LIC811 Confidential Names list dated 8/15/24). Based on record review and interviews conducted with the program director and administrator the facility failed to reimburse clients within the time allowed. Citation is being reissued. Facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 87026(c) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property, and Valuables. An exit interview was conducted, and the following reports were emailed LIC809, LIC 809-D, and Appeal rights forms were provided and explained.

deficiencies.description:
87026(c) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property, and Valuables
(c) The licensee shall ensure that a child's cash resources are not taken in the form of fines.
This requirement is not met as evidence by: Facility uses an "allowance deduction" system that resulted in client's cash resources taken in the form of fines.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will reimburse clients allowances that were deducted, C1, C2, and C4. Licensee will mail checks to clients who no longer reside at the facility by certified mail and provide LPA with documentation and copies of checks no later than 5PM 10/11/24.

narrative: On October 15, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Angelina Garibaldo, Claudia Portillo and Licensing Program Manager Gustavo Garcia conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at the facility and met with Jamacia Smith, Program Director. LPAs stated the purpose of the inspection to the STRTP representative. One staff was interviewed. LPAs obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: LIC 500 Personnel and client roster MHPA Certificate LIC 610C Activity Calendar Food Menu *CARF accreditation extension was approved. New survey timeframe is October/November 2024. Annual compliance Review consisted of the following (7) domains: physical plant, operations, disaster preparedness plan, emergency intervention, staffing, core-therapeutic services, and client files. Only (3) domains were reviewed during today's visit: physical plant, operations, and core-therapeutic services. The following domains were partially reviewed disaster preparedness plan and emergency intervention plan (pending). Staff and client files will be reviewed on day two (TBA). LPM interviewed two staff and two clients. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report were provided to the Program Director.

Page 2 The Department received a complaint alleging the staff are blocking the doorway with items, staff do not properly maintain the facility grounds and staff are not properly trained. On 8/21/24 LPA Garibaldo toured the facility and observed a bed obstructing a door leading to the backyard. LPA Garibaldo also observed the toilet in the primary bedroom restroom was not properly installed, vanities in both restrooms were missing handles, vanity counter tops were chipped, vanity cabinet drawers were dirty and did not close properly, tiles on floors were missing, and walls were patched but not painted. Night stand and dresser in the primary bedroom were not in good repair, walls throughout the facility had holes that had not been patched, drawings on walls in client’s rooms, in primary bedroom the door had been replaced but not painted, electrical outlet in living room was missing a plate cover, patio cover in backyard was in disrepair, broken 2x4 on patio,wooden gate in patio was broken and in disrepair, and window screens were missing from all windows in the facility. In addition, LPA Garibaldo reviewed the facilities Initial 8-hour New Staff Core Competencies Training Tally Record, and it was revealed that the areas of training's failed to include the required Trauma-Informed Intervention and Treatment Practices and were not conducted by the appointed instructors. Statements obtained from staff disclosed that the 8-hour initial training's were conducted by the facility director. The facility failed to follow their own Plan of Operation for training of new staff. Based on information gathered from inspections, records review and interviews conducted all the allegations are Substantiated. Facility cited for violations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division 6, regulation 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds, 80088 (b) Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies, 80088 (3) Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies, 87078.2(a)(3) Trauma-Informed Interventions and Treatment Practices, and 87022 (6) Plan of Operation. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of LIC9099, LIC9099D and appeals rights were provided to the facility representative.

narrative: On October 29, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo conducted a case management inspection at the STRTP and met with Jamacia Smith, Program Director. The purpose of the inspection was to address the violations that were revealed during the investigation of complaint 32-CR-20240607142405. LPA Garibaldo observed the following: Based on record review, and information gathered from interviews the facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations Title 22 Div. 6 Chapter 1 Sec. 80022(b)(6) Plan of Operation. The licensee failed to ensure the initial 8-hour new hire trainings were conducted by the designated staff member(s) as indicated in their Plan of Operation. In addition, the facility is cited under violation of Interim Licensing Standards, STRTP, Article Sec. 87065.1(d)(1)(C) Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements. The licensee failed to include a trauma informed training as specified in Section 87078.2(a)(3) during new hire direct care staff 8-hour training. It was also revealed a new hire direct care staff was left alone and transported a client before meeting the requirements of the new hire 8-hour trauma informed training. The facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, STRTP, Article 06 Sec. 87065.1(1)(A)1 Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, and LIC 809D form were given to the above-mentioned facility representative. Appeals Rights were provided and discussed.

Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged Staff are allowing minors to vape and smoke marijuana. Staff denied the allegation. Staff stated that children are discouraged from smoking or vaping. Staff stated that sometimes when children return from running away children have been caught with vape pens or smoking paraphernalia. However, staff stated that if children are caught with these items staff will confiscate them. Interviews conducted with children also denied the allegation. Children stated staff do not allow them to smoke or vape in the facility and denied that staff gives them vapes or marijuana. It was also alleged; staff are allowing minors to wear inappropriate clothing. Staff denied the allegation. Staff stated that children are allowed to pick out their own clothes, but they are not allowed to buy clothing that has any sort of drugs or inappropriate language. Children denied the allegation. Children stated that staff do not allow them to wear or buy inappropriate clothing. Children stated they are only allowed to wear clothing that is appropriate for school. Lastly, it was alleged, staff does not ensure minor's educational needs are being met. Staff denied the allegation. Staff stated that children are enrolled in school and if they need extra assistance, they are given opportunities to make up credits or provided resources to assist them with schooling. Interviews conducted with one (1) child identified not receiving services or getting school assistance. However, child did not provide details as to what staff were not providing services or what circumstances surrounded child not receiving services. Interviews conducted with four (4) additional children denied the allegation and stated that they receive support and assistance in school and from facility staff. Documents reviewed showed no incidents of staff misconduct or staff allowing children to smoke or vape. Documents reviewed also showed no incidents or children wearing inappropriate clothing or that children’s schooling needs weren’t being met. Interviews conducted with witnesses showed that incidents of concerns were occurring outside of facility and staff jurisdiction. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative via electronic mail. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

narrative: On April 1, 2025, at 12:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo made an unannounced case management inspection to the facility and met Jamaica Smith Program Director. The purpose of the case management was to follow up on the Special Incident Report (SIR) the Department received regarding a client having weapons in his possession. On 01/20/25, the Department received the SIR dated 01/13/25 regarding the incident. The SIR stated that client (C1) (see confidential names form LIC 811 dated on 04/01/25) left the facility and S1 followed behind C1 and was able to get C1 to get into the vehicle and transport C1 back to the facility where S2 conducted a safety check, and 3 weapons were found in C1 backpack. At the time of the inspection, LPA spoke to Program Director and Facility Manager regarding the incident. S1 stated that it was no more than three minutes that C1 was AWOL and as soon as she noticed C1 was not in his room she got into the vehicle to look for C1. S1 noticed him two blocks away and was able to get C1 to get into vehicle. It was suspected that C1 hide the weapons in the bushes near the facility, since C1 had a safety check earlier that day when arriving at the facility. Program Director stated that perimeter searches have been conducted daily since they have noticed that the clients hide objects in the bushes. Based on information obtained through interviews no deficiency citation was issued at the time of the inspection. LPA will follow-up with Administrator regarding the perimeter searches, trimming of bushes and the installation of lights towards the back of the facility. A copy of this report was provided to the facility representative, and an exit interview was conducted. There were no deficiencies cited during today’s inspection.

On December 8, 2023, at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Timika Martin conducted an announced Pre-licensing inspection and Component lll at the above facility address. LPA met with Mario Barron and Jesse Celedon who will be the Administrator and CFO for this facility. The facility will be licensed for a capacity of six (6) ambulatory female clients ages 12-17 and services will also be provided to non-minor dependents. LPA CEO Administrator toured the facility. This is a one-story home that has four bedrooms, four bathrooms, staff office and bathroom, mental health office/ visitation office and a television/family room. Inside the home the following was observed: The facility a staff office used for storing staff/client files and locked medications and extra storage. There are locking filing cabinets, a desk, a chair, and computer monitors, two refrigerators and television monitors to view cameras in common areas inside the facility. There is a living room, dining, and kitchen area. There were sofas and a television in the living room and there is a table and chairs in the dining area. There is a television room with a television, computer desk with a chair and a small sofa. Each bedroom has two beds with beddings, linens, drawers, and closet space for the clients' use. Two out of the four bedroom have bathrooms inside of the rooms. There are 16 cameras located throughout the facility located in the following areas: two cameras in living room, two cameras in the kitchen, two cameras in hallway, two cameras in the staff office and eight cameras outside around the perimeter of the house. There was a refrigerator, a gas stove, kitchen utensils, plates, and dinnerware in the kitchen drawers/cabinets. The first aid kit was observed to be new and complete. The home has working telephones. There were working smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the dining area, living room, hallway and in each bedroom. The centralized heating and air were working. All medications will be stored in a locked box/cabinet with a lock located in the staff office. All client, staff and facility files will be stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office as well. Also observed were computers, a fax/copy machine in the office for staff use. All required postings were posted near the kitchen area.

Prior to today’s inspection the facility received fire clearance on 06/05/23. LPA discussed the facility procedures for 30-day updates of Needs and Services plans discussed. Facility to obtain Mental Health Program Approval within 12 months of effective date of licensure, will keep the department updated as to MHPA status, and will provide appropriate documentation to the department upon approval. Component III Orientation provided to licensee which included information regarding incident reporting procedures, including those specific to law enforcement contacts; facility, client and staff record requirements; application of prudent parent standards and client personal rights. This facility is pending licensure due to plan of operation and program statement being revised and under review. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the administrator.

On May 28, 2025, at 9:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Timika Martin conducted a pre-licensing inspection visit at Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA Martin met with Executive Director, Jesse Celedon and Facility Administrator, Mario Barron and toured the home. Physical Plant This facility is located in a quiet residential community. The facility consists of three (3) bedrooms, an Administrator Office and Mental Health Office, kitchen, dining area, laundry room and a backyard. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in excellent condition. Passageways are free from obstruction. Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies The home has toilets and wash basins for clients' use. Client bedrooms were observed to be clean, orderly, and contained twin beds. LPA observed clean pillows, bed sheets and blankets. The client’s bedroom has adequate closet and drawer space to accommodate the client’s clothing and personal belongings. Heath Related Services and Record Keeping The first aid kit will be centrally stored in the kitchen. The kit contains all required supplies. The client, staff files will be in a locked file cabinet located in the Administrator Office. The medication will be stored in a locked individual container located in the Administrator Office.

LPA also conducted Component III - Category Specific Orientation with the applicant. The following items were discussed and provided to the applicant: -Title 22 Regulations on Small Family Homes - Continuing Requirements (General Licensing Requirements) - Buildings and Grounds requirements - Personnel Records (forms) - Client Records (forms) -Reporting Requirements - Other administrative forms The provider was also briefed about the importance of incident reporting and client education. Prior to being licensed the following are still pending: -Administrator/Staff need to be associated to the facility. -Pending finalized copy of the Program Statement/Plan of Operation. LPA Martin will conduct a final review once the requested documents are submitted, manager approval and all requirements being met and a new license will be mailed to STRTP upon approval. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this form was emailed to the Administrator.

On November 6, 2020 at 2:15pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emelyn Sanchez P. conducted an announced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection for Youth Treatment Program. During the inspection LPA Sanchez P. met with Alley Jensen, Facility Administrator and Cassidy Craine, Medication Manager. LPA Sanchez P. conducted facility walk through on 11/06/2020 at 2:15pm. LPA Sanchez P. conducted two (2) children interviews on 11/03/2020. This is a two story five bedroom, three bathroom house that has a living room, kitchen/laundry area, staff office, therapist's office, detached garage, and outdoor space. Overall, LPA Sanchez P. observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA Sanchez P. observed adequate staffing at the facility to provide care and supervision to children in care. LPA Sanchez P. observed medication to be centrally stored, triple locked and inaccessible to clients and unauthorized staff members. Medication was observed tripled locked in Manager's Office/Medication Room. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted on 11/06/2020 at 2:55pm, and due to COVID-19 restrictions a copy of this report will be e-mailed to the Facility Administrator for signature.

narrative:
On 08/31/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez, conducted an unannounced inspection, at the above said facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection. LPA Hernandez was met by Alley Jensen facility Administrator (FA) , who granted access into the facility, who provided a tour of the entire facility, inside and out. This is a two-story family home with a living room and a fireplace that has been cemented with no chimney, a therapy room, Administrative office, kitchen, a dining area, five (5) bedrooms, three (3) full bathrooms and a detached garage, washer/dryer are in the kitchen area and the garage is set as recreational activities and extra perishable and nonperishable. The home is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA observed the following on the first floor: There is a supply of non-perishable food supply located in the kitchen. There are four working burners on the stove, a working dish washer, a microwave and refrigerator at the time of the inspection. Knives and sharps objects are stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. Cleaning supplies and tools are stored in a locked cabinet located above the washer and dryer in the laundry room adjacent to the kitchen. Medication is stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. There are 8 chairs and two dining tables in the kitchen area. There is adequate drinking glasses, plates and utensils in the home. There is a locked storage room under the stairwell for art and creative supplies. LPA observed one full bathroom adjacent to the three downstairs bedrooms. Page 1 of 3

Bedroom #1 is occupied by client #1 It has one (1) twin size bed, dresser and night stand. Bedroom #2 is occupied by client #2 it has one (1) twin size bed, adequate closet space and a dresser and night stand. Bedroom #3 is occupied by client #3. It has one (1) twin size bed, dresser and night stand. There are two linen and towel closets in the hallway. Administrator states that there are no guns or weapons on the premises. LPA observed the following on the second floor: There is administrative office was observed to be equipped with a locked closet that is also used for medication storage with a small fridge for any medications that may require refrigeration. LPA also observe and therapy room with storage utilized to lock the staff and clients’ files. There is a staff bathroom adjacent to the therapy room. The second floor also has a sensory room with two doors. Bedroom #4 is occupied by client #4. It has one (1) twin size bed, dresser, night stand and closet. Bedroom #5 is occupied by clients #5 . It has two (2) twin size beds, dressers, night stands and closet. LPA also observed several the signal buttons on the second floor (Bedroom #4, Bedroom #5, and the administrative office. When button is pushed a visual light and audible sound is emitted in the staff office downstairs. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are operable. All fire extinguishers are observed to be fully charged. All posting requirements are met. Administrator states there are no exterior or interior cameras on the facility property and LPA did not observe any cameras. The front yard and backyard are clear of debris. There are no bodies of water on the premises. The detached garage has a large open space with a desk and computers, two couches. Additionally, in a second room in the garage there was additional food storage and a second fridge for additional food items including an emergency food supply. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Page 2 of 3

Administrator Alley Jensen is present at the facility with a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. Licensee has obtained Mental Health Certification. The MH Certification is valid through 02/17/2022 . Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF. The Accreditation is valid through 09/30/2022. LPA will return to review personnel and clients files to ensure it meets regulatory requirements. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Personnel Files and client files are maintained on-site. Client and staff interviews will be conducted at a later date. The facility has two vehicles to transport clients: Auto #1: 2020 Honda Odyssey passenger van (charcoal). Administrator will email LPA a copy of valid insurance and registration Auto #2: 2018 Honda Odyssey passenger van (charcoal). LPA obtained a copy of valid insurance and registration PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 3.1, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility with the facility administrator whose signature on this form confirm receipt of this document. Page 3 of 3

The incident, which was received by the department, on 08/27/2021, involved Client #1[see LIC811 Confidential Names List form (LIC811), dated 08/31/2021, for names]. LPA discussed the incident with Alley Jensen which occurred on 08/26/2021, Client #1 (C1), who reported to staff that was sexually violated by a nurse at the hospital. LPA conducted confidential interviews. additional interviews are needed in order to closed this Case Management. At this time, the Department has made no determination on whether a violation has occurred. further investigation needs to be conducted PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 3.1, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. On September 18, 2020, Licensing Program Analyst initiated the complaint investigation, informed Facility Administrator of the investigation and requested file records. The investigation included, confidential interviews and contacts with, but not limited to, three facility residents, five staff members, San Luis Obispo Police Department staff and Detective, assigned San Luis Obispo County Social Worker and other related parties. The investigation further included review of client files, facility file history, San Luis Obispo Police report and forensic interviews of two residents. The investigation revealed corroborating evidence to support sexual abuse by S1 as record review and confidential interviews produced consistencies in statements and history to show inappropriate conduct by S1 towards children in care. Information obtained reveal S1 began making advances towards clients by playing a game which involved touching minor’s breast in a playful manner. It was disclosed S1 took clients on outings or walks and was often left alone with clients. S1's inappropriate behavior escalated and at some point S1 began engaging in sexual acts having sexual intercourse with C1 while at the program. On September 4, 2020, S1 was terminated from facility program due to unprofessional boundaries with the clients. Based on information from record review and confidential interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The Department has determined substantiated finding for sexual abuse by S1 on C1. These actions pose an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care. The facility is issued a citation in accordance with the Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5, Version 3, 87072 Personal Rights (d)(11) [See page LIC9099-D for cited deficiency]. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, Confidential Names List and appeal rights were provided to Facility Administrator. (Continued on page LIC9099-D)
investigation_findings: 13On February 4, 2022 at 1:25 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. LPA Martin met with Allison Jensen, Facility Administrator to discuss the investigative outcome. The investigation was conducted by Licensing Special Investigator Mariana Lomeli of the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigations Bureau. On September 15, 2020, CCL received an allegation that former Facility Staff member #1 (S1) sexually abused youth in care as S1 reportedly had an ongoing sexual relationship with former youth resident Child #1 (C1) for approximately six months (See LIC811, dated February 4, 2022). It was further reported that S1 had also touched youth resident Child #2 (C2) inappropriately on the breasts, thighs and buttocks areas while in care. This claim was previously reported and investigated as S1 was placed on administrative leave pending the investigation outcome. The investigation presented an unsubstantiated finding at that time, for which S1 could return to work. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

deficiencies.description:
Personal Rights To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, ... 
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Confidential statements, forensic interviews and record review revealed corroborating evidence that Staff #1(S1) touched Child #1(C1) and Child #2(C2) inappropriately touching their breast, thighs and buttocks areas. Evidence further reveal S1 had an ongoing sexual relationship with C1 for approximately six months while in care. This poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
S1 was terminated from employment at Youth Treatment Program on September 4, 2020.
Facility will be notified of scheduled meeting to further discuss investigation details and Department’s concerns. Licensee will be notified of specific date/time once determined.

narrative: the staff immediately called crisis support and then Law Enforcement. C1 and C2 confirmed that the staff was present the whole time during the incident. Also, during the interview with SW1 and SW2, stated that they have no concerns with the facility and the times they have been to the facility there are enough staff. Continue on LIC9099-C Although the allegation may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has decided that the allegations are unsubstantiated. If any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the findings can be changed. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 4.0, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On May 19, 2022 at 12:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell made an unannounced inspection to the above said facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations and deliver the findings for LPA Enrique Hernandez. LPA O’Connell met with Alley Jensen and discussed the investigative findings. On August 25, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging Facility staff is not properly supervising youths in care and Facility staffing is not sufficient to meet the needs of youths in care. Based on the confidential interviews conducted with all the parties involved during the investigation process and information gathered, the above allegations cannot be substantiated because, the interviews conducted did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegations. Even though C1 and C2 were cutting themselves with a plate, S2 tried different alternatives to deescalate the situation and when the clients refused to give the plate to S2, Cont on LIC9099C

narrative: On July 26, 2022 at 8:00am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Emelyn Sanchez P. and Olivia Rosas conducted an unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection for Youth Treatment Program. During the inspection LPA Sanchez P. and LPA Rosas met with Cailyn Ortega, Assistant Manager. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas reviewed three (3) client files and three (3) staff files. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas conducted one (1) client interview and two (2) staff interviews. Currently there are four (4) clients residing in the above facility. This is a two story house located in a residential area. The facility has five bedrooms, three bathrooms, a living room, kitchen/laundry area, staff office, therapist's office, detached garage (recreational room and storage space), and outdoor space. The outdoor space is free of obstructions. Overall, LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed adequate staffing at the facility to provide care and supervision to children in care. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed medication to be centrally stored, triple locked and inaccessible to clients and unauthorized staff members in the Managers Office. Medication was also observed to be double locked in Staff Office/Medication Room where medication is administered to the children in care. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be e-mailed and mailed to the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst Raymond Canal and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection on 10/10/23 at 11:40 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 21 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 21 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 3 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 9/14/23). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, and Crisis Intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Canal observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Alley Jensen.

Records reviewed including client file, incident reports and facility notes/discussion concerning related incident, determined not enough evidence to prove former resident was touched inappropriately by former S1. Although the allegation may have happened or be valid, documentary evidence is not sufficiently supported by the standard of proof. Therefore, the allegation is determined Unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations or Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Exit interview conducted and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report was left with Facility Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On September 4, 2024, at 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at the facility (relocation cite) to deliver findings concerning alleged sexual abuse. LPA Martin met with Allison Jensen, Facility Administrator to discuss the investigative outcome. On March 7, 2024, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that a former Facility Staff member #1 (S1) inappropriately touched a youth (former resident) in care as it was reported that S1 tried to touch and rape the youth at night while residing at the facility approximately 2-3 years ago (LIC811, dated 9/4/2024). The investigation revealed, reported allegations of Youth #1 being inappropriately touched by former staff member (S1) was previously investigated by the San Luis Obispo Police Department in February 2020 and the matter was closed. In September of 2020, the same allegation of being inappropriately touched by S1 was investigated by CCL Investigator Mariana Lomeli and substantiated regarding S1 sexually abusing minors in care. On September 4, 2020, S1 was terminated from facility. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

met_with: Western USA Regional Director Dr. Jason Plunkett, Administrator Temica Wooford & Asst. Western USA Regional Director, Ester Yu
narrative: On Thursday, February 25, 2021 @ 1:00PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kathy Landry conducted a Tele-Inspection phone call with representatives of Zoe International. In attendance on the call were Western USA Regional Director, Administrator and Assistant Western USA Regional Director. The purpose of the Tele-Inspection Meeting was to conduct a Component II Orientation. LPA Landry reviewed the deficiencies of the Application, Plan of Operation and Program Statement. Zoe International representatives were informed the Fire Inspection (STD 850) was received and cleared, LIC 404 Financial Information Release and Verification had not been received from bank(s) and the Emergency Intervention Plan was not reviewed (due to required Behavioral Specialist identification and signature). A detailed list (LIC 184) will be mailed soon reflecting the deficiencies and discussion regarding Zoe International Application. Zoe International representatives were informed they are still in need of a joint Technical Call with Continuing Care Reform (CCR), Component III (Community Care Licensing required forms instructions) and Pre-Licensing Inspection, prior to Licensure. This report was emailed to representatives listed above. Please feel free to contact me if you have further questions.

On June 29, 2021, at 2:45 PM Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection for the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPM/LPA conducted a tour of the entire facility. This facility will provide services to 6 female children, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only placed by LA County Department of Children and Family Services & Probation. The facility is located in a rural area with six (6) bedrooms designated for residents, 3 bathrooms, 2 staff offices, family room, dining/living room, kitchen, laundry room, therapist room & live in staff suite. Each bedroom has 1 twin bed with closet and drawer space. LPA observed adequate linens, hygiene products, board games, books, magazines, basketball court, soccer field and swimming pool is under construction.. LPA observed a separate building identified as multi purpose where online schooling & visitation and staff offices are located. Facility was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, incline ramps and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are inaccessible to clients. Facility personnel instructed to report violations of personal rights. Facility posts child's rights if licensed to provide foster care for six or more clients. Smoke alarm/carbon monoxide detector was in working order. Fire extinguishers are fully charged. Complaint procedure, personal rights, emergency disaster plan and menu were posted. Fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced.. There is adequate supply of non- perishable foods. There is adequate indoor/outdoor activity space. Medications will be locked in staff office. LPAs were informed they utilized a private water source/septic tank.

LPA discussed the following with Jason Plunkett, applicant: Mental Health program approval and accreditation discussed with applicant. Applicant has submitted application for accreditation. LPA was informed Staff #1 lives on the premises. LPA reminded staff that program statement must include that a staff is residing on the premises. LPM will follow up with staff if additional information is needed. LPA informed applicant that component 3 is pending LPA Landry will follow up with applicant. LPA was informed that security cameras are installed externally and internally however internal cameras have been set up. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Additional fencing is pending around the campus. LPA & LPM informed applicant any additional construction must be reported to licensing prior to starting work. Exit Interview conducted. A copy of this report was left with staff.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas made an announced inspection to the Zoe Home For Youth on 02/03/22 at 9:00am for the purpose of conducting Case Management- Licensee Initiated (Pool Waiver). LPA Rosas met with Staff#1(S1), and Staff#2(S2) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. The Zoe Home For Youth Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) facility provides services to six (6) female children, ages 12-17 years; ambulatory only placed by Los Angeles County Department of Children and Family Services & Probation. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 02/03/22. The following items were inspected with S1: The swimming pool is located in the multi purpose building. The building has surrounding fence that is at least five feet high and does not obscure the pool from view. The swimming pool is secured by automatic safety pool cover. LPA Rosas observed S1 walk in top of the cover. The pool cover is strong enough to completely support the weight of an adult. The flip switch to open and close the pool cover is kept in a key lock box. The key lock box is located inside locked gate that only designated staff has access to enter. LPA Rosas observed S1 open and close the automatic safety pool cover. LPA Rosas stated that safety cover should be kept locked while the pool is not in use. LPA Rosas received a copy of staff water safety certificates, and updated facility sketch (LIC 999). The pool waiver request is pending approval from Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD). There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On 02/03/2022 at 9:30AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia made an unannounced to Zoe Home For Youth for the purpose to conduct Post Licensing Inspection. LPA Rosas met with Staff#1(S1), Staff#2 (S2) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 02/03/2022. Temperature and health checks are conducted at the entrance in the sign-in area in the multi purpose building. LPA met with S1, who granted access into the multi purpose building, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant. This facility has a provisional Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and licensed to provide care and supervision for six (6) female children ages 12-17 years old, Ambulatory only. Children are placed by Los Angeles County Department of Children and Family Services & Probation. The facility is in the process of obtaining CARF. They are in the process obtaining Mental Health Approval with Los Angeles County. The facility is current with their annual fees. The facility is located in a rural area of 50+ acres. The facility has a pedestrian gate with coded locking mechanism surrounding the property. The self-catching latch when the gate is closed cannot be accessed on the outside. Facility staff and clients are given the locked code for the gate. To enter the property a iron driveway gate with buzz system is used. The property has two (2) separate buildings, park area, and hiking trail. There are bodies of water on the premises. The facility has pool with a safety automatic pool cover that is pending approval from the Department. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. Facility utilize a private water source/septic tank. The facility has eleven (11) exterior security cameras. L Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 1 of 4

LPA Rosas inspected the following: Multi Purpose Building (MPB): Facility utilizes the multi purpose building for schooling, visitation, and staff offices. The building has two (2) large rooms, one (1) outdoor bathroom, storage area, and temperature and health checks are conducted at the entrance in the sign-in area. The Education room is used a study area and has computer desks, and library. The Multi Purpose room is used as dance room, yoga, theater, and has locked storage. The multi purpose room has semi private work cubicle stations for staff and semi private counseling space. The spaces are kept locked. The Emergency Evacuation Plan is posted on the walls throughout the facility. Multiple fire extinguishers is located within the building and exit doors are label. A First Aid kit is kept by the private work cubicle. Outdoor Area: There are bodies of water on the premises. The facility has pool with a safety automatic pool cover that is pending approval from the Department. The building has surrounding fence that is at least five feet high and does not obscure the pool from view. The swimming pool is secured by automatic safety pool cover. LPA Rosas observed S1 walk in top of the cover. The pool cover is strong enough to completely support the weight of an adult and shall be placed on the pool. The flip switch to open and close the pool cover is kept in a key lock box. The key lock box is located inside locked gate that only designated staff has access to enter. The outside has garden beds, outdoor setting areas, soccer/grass field, basket ball area, two (2) storage sheds that are kept locked. The outdoor perimeter front yard, side yard and backyard were inspected and found cleared of debris and hazards materials. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. Home: There are six (6) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, two (2) staff offices, family room, dining/living room, kitchen, laundry room, therapist room, live in staff suite. Living Room: There is one sofa, sofa chairs, mounted TV. Dining Area: There is a table with eight (8) chairs. Kitchen: There is a gas stove with six (6) burners all working at this time. There is a detached oven currently working at this time. There is a microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The food service in the home is adequate with perishable/nonperishable food supplies. The cleaning solutions are made inaccessible to the clients and stored/ locked under the kitchen sink and under kitchen island. All trash cans have tight lids on. LIC 809-C Page 2 of 4

Staff Office: The home has (2) staff offices. The office is equipped office furniture (i.e desk, computers, printers).The medication is triple locked inside of the staff office by the kitchen. All the children prescribed medications are locked in the staff office and children files are kept in a lock cabinet. Staff office is located inside the main facility. The First Aid kit has the required items inside (age-appropriate, and scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic and First Aid Manual Guide. Laundry Room: The laundry room is located near the bedrooms. The laundry is equipped with two sets of washer and dryer units that was observed to be in good condition. The laundry detergent is made inaccessible to the children and is disputed according the load of the laundry. Disinfectants and chemicals are locked in cabinets made inaccessible. Garage: The attached garage is used as storage and is kept locked. LPA observed a staff displayed the utility shut-off valves outside of the home. Bedrooms: The clients bedrooms are occupied by one (1) client., Each bedroom is equipped one (1) twin sized bed, comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) wall closet with lock box for client to use. There is adequate lighting and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. Bathrooms: There are three (3) bathrooms. Bathroom #1 and Bathroom#2 is the common bathroom for the clients. It is a full-sized bathroom with a toilet, sink, and tub/showers. Bathroom #3 is located next to staff office. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA observed non-perishable foods for one week and perishable food for two days. The home has a multiple first aid kits. The have multiple fire extinguishers through the buildings. Disinfectants and poisons are inaccessible to the clients in care they are kept locked at all times. All knives and sharp objects are made inaccessible to the clients in care locked. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable. LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, and cleaning solutions. All windows were in good condition with screens and blinds. There were no security bars on the windows. LPA observed ample towels and linen closet. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 3 of 4

All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan, Children’s Personal Rights, and Ombudsman). The facility has a working cell phones and youths can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The Emergency Evacuation Plan is posted on the walls throughout the facility. The Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to youths. Licensee will report youth injuries requiring medical treatment. LPA Rosas received a copy of copy of Register of participants, Current Census, Personnel Report (LIC 500), Emergency Disaster Plan Protocols, Emergency Disaster Plan for Children's Residential Facilities (LIC 610C), Facility Sketches (LIC9099), Staff Water Safety Certificates. On 06/26/2021, LPA Smith informed facility that currently Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) are not approving internal camera waivers. Facility submitted ZHY Security Camera System Policy to CCLD. The facility has eleven (11) exterior security cameras. LPA Rosas informed S1 that interior cameras cannot be operable, until a camera waiver has been approved by the Department. CCLD will conduct in person physical inspection in order approve the waiver in the future. The pool cover is pending approval from Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD). A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 02/03/2022 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. LPA Rosas discussed with and advised If any changes or modifications to the program or facility physical plant need to be submitted to the Department for review and approval before implementing the new changes. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

LPM/LPA conducted a tour of the entire facility. This facility will provide services to 6 female children, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only placed by LA County Department of Children and Family Services & Probation. The facility is located in a rural area with six (6) bedrooms designated for residents, 3 bathrooms, 2 staff offices, family room, dining/living room, kitchen, laundry room, therapist room & live in staff suite. Each bedroom has 1 twin bed with closet and drawer space. LPA observed adequate linens, hygiene products, board games, books, magazines, basketball court, soccer field and swimming pool is full with water and has a locked cover. LPA observed a separate building (8144 B) identified as multipurpose where online schooling & visitation and staff offices are located. Facility was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, incline ramps and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are inaccessible to clients. Facility personnel instructed to report violations of personal rights. Facility posts child's rights if licensed to provide foster care for six or more clients. Smoke alarm/carbon monoxide detector was in working order. Fire extinguishers are all fully charged. Emergency disaster plan and menu were posted. Continued on 809 C

There is adequate supply of non- perishable foods. There is adequate indoor/outdoor activity space. LPA/LPM were informed they utilized a private water source/septic tank and propane tank for energy. Bedroom # 3 was unoccupied and there missing mattress that needed replacing. LPA was informed there are two (2) overnight staff with rotating shifts that do not live on the premises. LPA was informed that security cameras are installed externally. No firearms or weapons are in the facility. LPA/LPM discussed the following with Ester Yu, : Medications are locked in staff office. Medication log are current and up to date. There is one client that is taking psychotropic medication that needs to be separated on three (3) different logs. This was told to the FA The Complaint/Grievance Procedures and Personal Rights were not posted in the public area.. Additional fencing is pending and awaiting permits from the City. LPA & LPM informed FA any additional construction must be reported to licensing once the work is completed. Exit Interview conducted. A copy of this report was left with Ester Yu, Facility Administrator.

On August 31,2022 at 3:15 PM., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kuliema Calloway, made an unannounced inspection to the facility Zoe Home for Youth, for the purpose of conducting a Case Management inspection to address concerns regarding in incident report that was received on 01/06/2022 stating the following: On 1/06/2022 at 3:44 a.m., an SIR was received, (FA) went to check on client (AP) and the client began cussing at FA and picked up a plant and threw it.. AP went to the kitchen to get food from the refrigerator and was told by FA to wash their hands. AP cussed at FA and picked up a dining room chair and threw it towards FA and broke it. FA heard a loud bang and went to investigate to see that a different client, (AC) kicked a hole in the administrative office door. [ See confidential names list LIC- 811 for name identifiers]. The situation escalated. AP took keys belonging to FA. FA tried to call for de-escalation assistance and AP smacked FA's cell phone out of her hand and continued to destroy the property. Law enforcement (Sheriff Department) was notified, arrived, and took a report. The deputy asked FA if they wanted to press charges against AP and FA agree to file charges. FA, AP and AC are no longer employed or reside at the facility. On 8/31/22, LPA conducted an interview with current Facility Administrator indicated on this report. No further information was given. A copy of this report was left at the facility with Ester Yu, Facility Administrator.

On 02/29/24 at 09:15 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jhane Haynes made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection following an incident report received on 02/23/24. A client missed scheduled dose due to medication not being refilled timely. LPA met with Facility Administrator (FA) Esther Yu who granted access to the facility. LPA spoke with FA, reviewed the medication log and obtained memo sent to staff regarding medication monitoring. LPA observed a violation of the Interim Licensing Standards(ILS) was found and the facility will be cited for missing client dose. Per ILS Article 6 Sec 87075, one deficiency will be cited today. See LIC809-D for details. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

deficiencies.description:
(c)	Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication and in accordance with authorization requirements specified in Sections 369.5(a)(1) and 739.5(a)(1) of the Welfare and Institutions Code and Section 87070(b)(13). This requirement was not met by:

Based on interview and record review, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above by not ensuring medications are refilled timely which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will review medication training with staff regarding monitoring the supply of medication and provide signatures to LPA Haynes via email at jhane.haynes@dss.ca.gov by 03/14/2024.

narrative: On January 29, 2025 at 1pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility. The purpose of the visit is to conduct a Case Management investigation. LPA met with Administrator, and was allowed into the facility. On December 16, 2024 the department received a Special Incident Report #1198146 stating that on December 15, 2024 Child #1 reported to S3 that she was sexually touched by Staff #2. LPA conducted interviews and documents obtained. Child #1 was discharged from the facility on December 17, 2014 due to a Probation Violation of property destruction which occurred at the facility on the day of the allegation. Further investigation is needed to conclude this Case Management investigation. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of the visit.

On July 15, 2025 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Jones-Steward made an announced visit at Zoe Home For Youth to commence the SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9(a)(2). LPA Jones-Steward met with administrator Darchell Guidry and clinical director Lawrence Franklin. LPA also reviewed three staff files and conducted three staff interviews. The client was not available, thus she will be interviewed on July 15, 2025 when the inspection.

On the date above a pre licensing visit was conducted at ZND Residential by Licensing Program analyst (LPA) Les Inouye. I was met by Administrator Zeb Graves. A review of the Physical Plant was conducted including the Indoor Activity Space, Fixtures Furniture Equipment and Supplies and Outdoor Activity Space. Kitchen was clean and non-perishable items were observed in the kitchen. Bedrooms were observed. All rooms were appropriately furnished with storage area was observed. All chemicals and cleaning supplies were locked and secured. Smoke Alarms and Carbon Monoxide detectors were observed and operating. Back yard -there is no pool or hot tub, yard consisted of a lawn area with covered patio area. No staff are associated at this time. Zeb will be following up with Guardian for set up of an account. Guardian Application has been submitted. The physical plant was observed to be clean, safe, and free of hazards. Personal file for Zeb Graves was reviewed.
