narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Les Inouye conducted an unannounced inspection at ZND Residential and met with Administrator Zeb Graves, Tamara Heibert and Isaac Salinas regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on 2/17/24 regarding incident which occurred on 2/16/24. . The SIR stated the staff (S1) (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811) dated February 22, 2024 physical interaction (physical abuse) with client (C1) (see LIC 811). LPA conducted an interview with Zeb Graves, Tamara Heibert and Isaac Salinas. On the date of the incident S1, it is determined that the restraint was appropriate to intervene with C1 suicide attempt and no abuse or potential abuse was present. Due to work history and other factors S1 has been taken off calendar until additional training has been completed. Based on the information from the SIR and interviews, the STRTP clarified the issues of prior restraints and abuse and no further follow up is needed.

On August 14, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Leslie Inouye conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at ZND Residential located in Fresno CA. LPA met with Facility Manager Isaac Salinas and Administrator Zeb Graves. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 72 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced in March 2023. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed. STRTP was approved on April 19, 2023. The facility process of being approved through Fresno County Department of Behavioral Health, to be completed August 2024. No firearms or weapons are observed in the facility. LPA reviewed 4 client files, and 7 staff files. LPA interviewed 2 staff and 2 client. LPA discussed the medication logs, all required forms, intake process, needs and services plan with updates, STRTP Inter agency Placement recommendation, mental health services, and disaster preparedness plan and emergency intervention plan. No deficiencies are being cited on today’s visit. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of today’s inspection.

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Melissa Renovato and Complaint Specialist (CS) Charles Kinney, arrived at Z.N.D Residential for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Case Management inspection and met with Zeb Graves, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss reporting requirements. An incident occurred on or around December 2024 that involved an allegation that a staff (DSP1) pushed a client (C1) to the ground. A SCAR was completed by the facility on December 23, 2024, and was forwarded to parties, not including Community Care Licensing. In addition, an incident report was not received regarding the said incident of staff (DSP1) allegedly pushing client (C1). The Department determined this to be a potential risk to health and safety of the children in care at this time, therefore, this agency is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 Article 06 Section 80061(b)(1)(E) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision and Health and Safety Code 1558 (a)(2) Conduct Inimical and Interim Licensing Standard Version 5, Section 87061(i)(10). On , Complaint Specialist C.K. Kinney(CS), Licensing Program Analysts Melissa Renovato(LPA1) and Danny Macias(LPA2) made an unannounced visit to Z.N.D. Residential, Inc and met with Administrator Zeb Graves . On complaint control number 24-CR-20241025072509, with an allegation of Conduct Inimical, violation was SUBSTANTIATED by Licensing. The facility was cited for Health and Safety Code Section 1558(a)(2) Conduct Inimical, and Interim Licensing Standards section 87072(c)(16) Personal Rights. On December 27, 2024, A case Management Inspection was also conducted and the facility was cited for violation of ILS section 87072(c)(1) Personal Rights. Due to staff having inappropriate relations with a client, an enhanced civil penalty is being assessed. The complaint alleged that clinician had been having sexual relations with a client in the home. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty law, H&S Code section 1548 (f)(1)(C)(i), the Department will be issuing an immediate civil penalty of $2,500.00. An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report, LIC 811 Confidential Names List, LIC 9058 Appeal Rights and a Civil Penalty Assessment - Serious Bodily Injury/Physical Abuse (Form 421-D) were provided to at conclusion of inspection.

met_with: Zeb Graves, Administrator and Ary Corona, Head of Service
narrative:
On April 4, 2025 at 11:00am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Melissa Renovato and Danny Macias, arrived at ZND Residential STRTP and met with Head of Service (HOS) Ary Corona for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. No other staff or clients were present at the time of inspection. LPA provided the HOS the entrance checklist and requested the necessary documents. LPA Olivia Medrano arrived to assist at 1:15pm. Zeb Graves, Administrator (AD) and S2 arrived during the inspection; however, AD was in and out of the facility. The facility currently houses six male youth and is staffed with one administrator, one house manager, one office administrator, one head of service, one clinical supervisor, and five direct care staff. The facility was inspected inside and out. LPA observed the facility temperature is maintained at a comfortable 71 degrees Fahrenheit. The water temperature is at a comfortable 118 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA observed the kitchen to have a full size refrigerator and is operating at a safe temperature. There is at least one week supply of nonperishable and a two day supply of perishable foods. At 3:28pm, LPA Renovato observed stainless steel cleaner and polish for the oven. LPA Renovato discussed the importance of locking away the disinfectants with HOS and S1. S1 immediately locked the oven cleaner away with other disinfectants. LPA Renovato observed the dining room and living room to be spacious with adequate space for all clients to fit comfortably. Furniture throughout the dining room and living room were observed to be in good repair. LPA Renovato observed the laundry room to be filled with adequate linens, towels, and bedding. LPA Renovato observed the first aid kit fully stocked and up to regulation standards as well as additional first aid supplies in additional spaces. Continued on 809-C...

Continued from 809... LPA Renovato observed the smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were fully functioning and tested. Three fire extinguishers were observed to be up to date on service and were observed to be full, last service date was January 2025. LPA Renovato observed the bathroom shower in master bedroom (Bedroom one) to have some mold, a leak in the toilet area, and missing the toilet paper dispenser with holes on the wall in that place. The bathroom in bedroom one is free of accessible chemicals. Bedrooms were observed to have adequate space and storage for clients and furniture was observed to be in good repair. Blinds in bedroom two are not in good repair as some parts are broken. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. Garage space was observed to be utilized to store additional food in locked refrigerators and a space for clients to work out. The facility has no bodies of water or firearms. The facility has one sports utility vehicle. LPAs reviewed five client and five staff files. LPAs interviewed one staff member and one client. A review of staff files indicated that all facility staff have received child abuse index clearances and fingerprint clearances. Facility was observed to have all required posters visible in a common area including Foster Youth Bill of rights and license. The facility is approved through Fresno County Department of Behavioral Health through September 24, 2025. Due to time constraints and a family emergency for a staff member, annual was not able to be completed on this date and will be completed at a later date.

investigation_findings: 13On August 8, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Melissa Renovato conducted an unannounced visit to Z.N.D Residential STRTP in Fresno, CA in order to deliver the findings of the above allegations and met with Isaac Salinas, House Manager. On July 8, 2025, the above allegations were referred to Community Care Licensing for investigation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff and clients which revealed that S1 spoke to C1 inappropriately and acted in a threatening manner toward C1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names List). The investigation included an inspection of the Facility, confidential interviews, and review of records. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove the above allegations occurred therefore this allegations are

deficiencies.description:
87072 Personal rights (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights...(16) To be free of intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including...aids to physical functioning.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interview, the licensee did not ensure that clients were free of threats which poses an immediate risk to Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee terminated employment of S1 to ensure that client's personal rights are no longer violated. Licensee provided LPA with a copy of the termination letter sent to S1.

deficiencies.description:
87072 Personal rights (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights...(15) To be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interview, the licensee did not ensure that clients were accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff, which poses an immediate risk to Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to persons in care.

(SFH). A LIC 184, Letter of Application Revisions and Facility Evaluation Report (LIC 809) was emailed to applicant for corrections. The applicant signature for this form will be placed in the file.

On July 3, 2024, at 9:10AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal a Pre-Licensing inspection at A Family Matters Home. LPA met with applicant Brandon Curtis who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Applicant is applying for a application for a small family home (SFH) Downstairs: Bedroom #1, It is furnished with a full bed . It will sleep one client. The room will be converted with two twin bed if another client is placed. There is also a family room, a living room, dining area, a kitchen, storage and one bathroom. Upstairs: Bedroom #2 master bedroom , It is furnished with a king bed . It sleeps the applicant and his wife. Bedroom #3, it is furnished with a twin loft bed and sleeps bio-son Bedroom #4, the room is furnished with a daybed and sleeps the bio daughter Upstairs also the locked laundry room. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. Continued on LIC 809-C

Continued from LIC 809 Inside the facility there fireplace properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. Medications are locked in the kitchen cabinet area. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in locked kitchen cabinet. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 120 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit were accessible with all required items, and it was in the kitchen cabinet. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. Component III video was view with the applicant. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request to be licensed for small family home will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Applicant/Licensee

facility_name: A PEAR N SON FAMILY HOME
narrative:
On June 23, 2025, at 11:15AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Adaleyci Caballero and Cynthia Ramos completed a pre-licensing inspection of A Pear N Son Small Family Home (SFH). LPAs met with Applicant Ebony Pearson who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. There are no clients in placement. The townhouse is a two story building with two bedrooms and two full bathrooms which are set up as follows: Bedroom #1- It consisted of one queen bed. The bed had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep applicant. Bedroom #2- It consisted of a set of bunk beds with a ladder and rail. The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. A living room, kitchen, two car garage, and a patio. The garage will be utilized for storage. The clients' bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the clients' belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom. The seven smoke detectors were checked and working properly. The Carbon Monoxide detectors were combined with the smoke alarms. The home’s central air conditioning module was in the patio. The water heater was in the garage. The appliances were in working order.

Medications will be locked in a box inside the filing cabinet in the living room. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of perishable food and non-perishable food. The home had a trash can for storage of solid waste with a tight fitting lid. There was one fire extinguisher present in the home located in the kitchen. It was observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. The First Aid Kit was located in the living room accessible to clients in care. There are no firearms in the home. There is no pool in the home. The community pool is gated and inaccessible to children. There is no backyard. Corrections: Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610), Personal Rights, Grievance procedures, Facility Sketch, and Visitation Policies need to be posted and accessible to the public. Clients' and staff files Safeguard for cash resources Telephone service on premises Drawer space for clothing and personal belongings Toys, games, books, and educational materials Hot water temperature was at 121.3 degrees Fahrenheit. Component III was conducted. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to applicant Ebony Pearson via email. The application will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager Abdoulaye Traore once corrections are submitted to LPA.

On April 15, 2024, at 11:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson conducted a prelicensing inspection to licensee a Small Family Home. LPA met with applicant/licensee Brook Hernandez. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant/licensee Brook Hernandez. Applicant/Licensee Brook Hernandez is applying for a capacity Small Family Home for 6 ambulatory clients. The home is two story residence located on a residential street. Downstairs includes a living room, dining room, kitchen, family room, with half bathroom. Bedroom #1, two twin beds with night stands, and dresser drawer with an adjacent bathroom with an exit door. Upstairs there are four bedrooms: Bedroom #2, Two full beds for two clients. Bedroom #3, One bunk bed for two clients. Bedroom #4, One full bed for one client Bedroom #5, Applicant/Licensee’s bedroom. Bathroom located in the hallway. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. Cameras are in common areas throughout the facility.

Cell phones will be used instead of land line. The cell phones will be fully charged at all times. All hazardous items will be properly made inaccessible to areas where children . The medication and First Aid Kit will be locked the hallway closet. Sharp knives will be locked and inaccessible in the locked kitchen drawer. Cleansers/chemicals will be locked and stored in locked cabinet in garage. There were no guns or weapons as stated by applicant/licensee Brook Hernandez at this time. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Hot water temperature reading at 111 degrees. The Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610c), Personal Rights posted for children to view. The backyard where children can play was completely fenced and free of hazards. The applicant/licensee Brook Hernandez has been informed that the address to this facility is available to the public. All special incident reports (SIR's) will be sent via e-mail to: cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov. The applicant/licensee Brook Hernandez was provided with an updated Guardian personnel summary at the time of this visit and understands that once the license is approved, all employees and volunteers shall have an approved criminal record clearance for CCL and be associated to this facility. The fire clearance has been approved. Based on the facility pre-licensing inspection and facility records’ review, no deficiencies were noted at time of the inspection An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Applicant/Licensee Brook Hernandez.

On 12/12/24 at 11AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted the announced Prelicensing Inspection. LPA met with Applicants Abraham Siwoku and Adedolapo Adebesin. LPA toured the facility site and observed the facility to be clean and well-maintained. The facility is a 2-story house in a residential neighborhood. There is one kitchen and two bathrooms specifically for client use, and all were observed to be in highly sanitary condition. There is a common space for visitation and activities. Hot water measured within the required range. The bedrooms offer two beds each as well as personal storage space. The facility will serve children ages 3 to 17, ambulatory only. The applicants currently have two biological children in their care and agree to notify the licensing agency if there are any changes to the household size. The applicants have submitted a complete application packet and plan of operation. All requested revisions were made. The applicants have relevant work experience and hold valid first aid certificates and have demonstrated understanding of the program's plan of operation. Items to complete prior to licensure: - Applicants will obtain a house phone and provide number to LPA. - Applicants will obtain tweezers for the first aid kit. - Completion of Component III Category-Specific Orientation/Training. This facility will be ready for licensure once the above are completed and Licensing Program Manager Isabel Diego has reviewed and approved the application. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Applicants.

On March 5, 2025, at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez began a pre-licensing inspection and component III for Adedayo Family Home Small Family Home for an initial license. LPA met with applicants Tolulope and Adedapo who led a tour of the entire home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicants. The applicants are applying for 2 ambulatory children ages 0 to 17. Currently there are no children placed in the home. The home is a two story building with 5 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of an entry way with all required postings such as visitation policy, personal rights, facility sketch, and emergency disaster plan. Bedroom #1 was downstairs and was fully furnished with a queen size bed, dresser and closet space that was currently vacant and will be utilized for a client. There was bathroom #1 that was fully functioning with water temperature reaching 109.8 degrees F. There was a storage closet that was filled with coats and shoes. The kitchen was clean and sanitary with locked knives and sharps stored under the stove. There was a medicine cabinet in the kitchen that was locked and will store client medication. The refrigerator/ pantry were fully stocked with perishable and non-perishable foods. Proper storage of all food was discussed. There was a fire extinguisher up to date and the First Aid kit was accessible with all required items. There was also a dining table and living room space with couch, TV, and a fire place that was properly screened. Telephone land-line service was missing. The upstairs consisted of bedroom #2 that was fully furnished and had a queen size bed that was utilized for applicants biological child. There was bathroom #2 that was fully functioning with two side by side sinks and one locked cabinet storing cleaning supplies/ chemicals. There was also a loft area that was used as a family room with couches and TV. Bedroom #3 was also upstairs and was fully furnished with closet and drawer space and had a queen size bed that was currently vacant and will be used for a client. There was also bedroom #4 which was the master bedroom for applicants that had bathroom #3 and a locked closet that will store clients files in a locked cabinet . Bedroom #5 was a vacant guest room that had a queen size bed and dresser/ closet space.

Upstairs also had a laundry room that stored blankets, linen, towels and extra hygiene supplies. The laundry detergent/ essentials were locked in a cabinet. Trash cans for storage of solid waste in bathrooms did not have tight fitting lids. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. There was no pool or other body of water and there are no guns or weapons as stated by applicants at this time. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: (2) lock boxes for cash resources and medication Obtain telephone land line Trash cans need tight fitting lids in bathrooms After corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA so that another inspection can be completed. Component III orientation was also completed this day of March 5, 2025 Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicants Tolulope and Adedapo Adedayo.

On May 8, 2024 at 9:05 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes completed a pre-licensing inspection of Adom Small Family Home. LPA met with Applicant Ben Adom who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no clients in placement. The home is a two story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Applicants) has one bed and two cribs and will sleep the applicant and two infiants. · Bedroom #2 (daughters) has one bed and sleeps the daughter. · Bedroom #3 (sons) has one bed, it sleeps the son. · Bedroom #5 (Client’s) has 2 beds, it will sleep two clients. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, laundry room, two car garage, an office, and the backyard. The Client’s bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two client’s will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom. The four smoke detectors were checked, and they were working properly. There are two carbon monoxide detectors in the home one is located in downstairs in the hallway and one is located upstairs in the hallway. The two carbon monoxide detectors where checked and were working properly. The home’s central air conditioning module was located on the side of the house. The home’s hot water heater was located in the garage. The appliances were in working order. The client’s files will be locked inside a locked file box in the kitchen. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid and was present. The sharp knives are in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The medications will be located in a locked cabinet in the kitchen.

The hot water in bathroom one (master) measured to be 110.8 degrees Fahrenheit, in bathroom two was 114.2 degrees Fahrenheit and in bathroom three 119.1 degrees Fahrenheit. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible and is located in a cabinet in the kitchen and contained all required supplies. There was three fire extinguishers present in the home one is located in the kitchen, one is located in the hallway leading to the laundry room and one is located upstairs in the hallway. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. There are no firearms in the home as stated by the applicant. There is no pool or other body of water at the home. The backyard where clients will have access to play is fenced. The following correction needs to be made: Lock needs to be add to the Laundry room door due to cleaning products. At 9:50 AM a component III was conducted. An exit interview was conducted. Application will be forwarded to the Licensing Program Manager for Licensing.

On June 5, 2025 at 9:20 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez conducted a pre-licensing visit for a change of location at Agnes Small Family Home. LPA met with Licensee Agnes Ogbatue who led a tour of the entire home. The licensee is applying for a capacity of 2 children ages 0 to 17. The home is a one story building with 5 bedrooms and 6 bathrooms. There was an outside entry way that consisted of a play room with bathroom #1 then there was the front door entry way that consisted of a closet storing extra household items, a pool table, formal living room with couches, fire place and television. There was a hallway with locked cabinets storing medications and first aid kits. There was a laundry room that had fire extinguisher #1 and locked cabinets storing cleaning supplies/ laundry detergents. Bathroom #2 was fully functioning with water temperature measuring 137.3 degree's Fahrenheit licensee understands water temperature needs to measure between 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. Bedroom #1 had a queen size bed, a desk area, a large walk in closet and bathroom #3 that was fully functioning that will be utilized for one client and is currently vacant. The kitchen had locked knives/ sharps in a cabinet, the refrigerator and pantry were fully stocked with 3 days of perishable and 7 days of non-perishable foods. There was a locked liquor refrigerator and a locked cabinet under the sink storing cleaning supplies and a dining room table with adequate seating. There was a family room with couches, television, a screened fire place and a land line telephone. Postings such as visitation policy, personal rights, menu, and emergency disaster plan were posted at this time. There was a movie theater room with adequate seating and a large screen. A hallway with fire extinguisher #2 and cabinets with extra linen and blankets. There was bedroom #2 that was licensees bedroom and had a crib, bathroom #4, and two walk in closets. Bedroom #3 had a queen size bed with a large walk in closet and bathroom #5 that would be utilized for one client- the room is currently vacant. There was fully furnished bedroom #4 for licensees child

with a full size bed, closet space, and shared bathroom #6 with bedroom #5. Bedroom #5 had two full size beds fully furnished with a walk in closet and was occupied by licensees two biological children. There was a study that had a desk, computer and closet for storing clients locked cash resources, records, and personnel files. The study also had an exit door leading to the front of the house where the entry way to the play room was. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawers and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. There was two garages both free of hazards. There was several trash cans that needed lids. There were no weapons/firearms as stated by licensee. The backyard was very large and had several fenced off areas that had gates with latches. There was also a built in underground pool that had a fence surrounding it measuring 4 feet 2 inches. Licensee understands that the surrounding pool fence needs to be measuring 5 feet high. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: - Trash cans in laundry room and bedrooms to have tight fitting lids - Pool fence to be measuring 5 feet high - Water temperature to be measuring between 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. After corrections are completed, licensee will notify LPA so that another inspection can be completed. On June 19, 2025 at 10:05 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Agnes Small Family Home (SFH) and met with licensee Agnes who led a tour of the home. The purpose of this visit is to ensure corrections were made from the pre-licensing inspection on June 5, 2025. The licensee is applying for a capacity of 2 children ages 0 to 17. The home is a one story building with 5 bedrooms and 6 bathrooms. There was an outside entry way that consisted of a play room with bathroom #1 then there was the front door entry way that consisted of a closet storing extra household items, a pool table, formal living room with couches, fire place and television. There was a hallway with locked cabinets storing medications and first aid kits with all required elements. There was a laundry room that had fire extinguisher #1 that was operable and locked cabinets storing cleaning supplies/ laundry detergents. Bathroom #2 was fully functioning with water temperature measuring 119.4 degrees Fahrenheit. Bedroom #1 had a queen size bed, a desk area, a large walk in closet and bathroom #3 that was fully functioning that will be utilized for one client and is currently vacant. The kitchen had locked knives/ sharps in a cabinet, the refrigerator and pantry were fully stocked with 3 days of perishable and 7 days of non-perishable foods. There was a locked liquor refrigerator and a locked cabinet under the sink storing cleaning supplies and a dining room table with adequate seating. There was a family room with couches, television, a screened fire place and a land line telephone. Postings such as visitation policy, personal rights, menu, and emergency disaster plan were posted at this time. There was a movie theater room with adequate seating and a large screen. A hallway with fire extinguisher #2 and cabinets with extra linen and blankets. There was bedroom #2 that was licensees bedroom and had a crib, bathroom #4, and two walk in closets. Bedroom #3 had a queen size bed with a large walk in closet and bathroom #5 that would be utilized for one client- the room is currently vacant. There was fully furnished bedroom #4 for licensees child with a full size bed, closet space, and shared bathroom #6 with bedroom #5.

Bedroom #5 had two full size beds fully furnished with a walk in closet and was occupied by licensees two biological children. There was a study that had a desk, computer and closet for storing clients locked cash resources, records, and personnel files. The study also had an exit door leading to the front of the house where the entry way to the play room was. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawers and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. There was two garages both free of hazards. All the trash cans in the home had tight fitting lids. There were no weapons/firearms as stated by licensee. The backyard was very large and had several fenced off areas that had gates with latches. During the inspection LPA observed the underground pool to have a mesh fence surrounding it that was measured to be exactly 5 feet high. There was a self close pool gate with a latch and swung away from the pool. The pool also had an operable pump system to keep it clean. Based on this inspection of the home, the following corrections were made: - Trash cans in laundry room and bedrooms had tight fitting lids - Pool fence was measuring exactly 5 feet high - Water temperature now measured between 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit at 119.4 degrees F. Based on this inspection, all corrections were made and the home is appropriate for a capacity of 2 ambulatory clients. The request of license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final review and approval. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to licensee Agnes Ogbatue.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith conducted the Component II - Face to Face Interview with Chizoba Agunenye, Applicant. Application and program statement was reviewed and discussed with Mr. Agunenye. The applicant will oversee a small family home, Agunenye Residence. The following documents were received and verified by LPA and LPM: 1. LPA and LPM verified the orientation certificate for Component I. 2. LPA and LPM made a copy of Licensee's ID for the records. 3. LPA and LPM verified criminal record clearance for applicant. 4. LPA and LPM reviewed the Program Design which was out of compliance with Small Family Home Regulations and General Licensing Requirements. Applicant will refer to application instructions to revise and adhere to Section B Documents: B7-B9. Licensee will provide more details when revising B7: Facility Program Description, including: adding more details for Goals, Purpose, and Program Methods, adding specific community resource examples for Activities, adding the "maintenance of clients cash resources" in Basic Services and specifying anonymity in Registering Complaints. Licensee Licensee will provide more details when revising B8: Rules of Discipline including adding specific discipline tactics and practices for clients (Licensee can also include positive incentive structures) and specific reasons for discharging a client. Licensee will provide more details when revising B9: Admission Policies including, adding a sample admission form, changing the NSP's to be created by the Social Workers, and including a physician medical assessment. Licensee will also add sections that cover "House Rules, Visitations, Program Modifications, and Refund Policies."

LPA and LPM reviewed application and Program Design and returned to applicant for revision. Applicant will submit updated Program Design by 3/7/2025. LPA and LPM discussed with applicant which placement agency applicant would be working with to receive clients from. LPA and LPM also discussed Licensing Duties and Responsibilities, specifically Small Family Home Regulations, section 83064. LPA and LPM scheduled a Pre-Licensing visit for Agunenye Residence for 3/7/2025 at 9AM. Exit interview completed.

Bedroom also has extra blankets and pillows, games, books, a TV, and a bench with extra storage. The closet is storing licensees clothes, Applicant agreed to remove personal belongings and allow only for client storage in the clients room. Bedroom #3: is set up as an office with a desk. Smoke alarms located in every bedroom were tested during the inspection and they were all in working condition. Bathroom #1: is located adjacent to bedroom #2 and #3. It is clear of all cleaning solutions with a working toilet, sink, and shower. The water temperature is measured at 105 degrees F. Extra towels and hygiene product are located in the room. The home will utilize Tesla Model Y 2021 and 2014 Nissan Altima to transport clients in care. Current automobile insurance is with Mercury Insurance Company. Insurance and registration is current. Applicant will ensure that cleaning solutions located in the laundry room are made inaccessible. Applicant will ensure that the knives in the kitchen will be made inaccessible. Applicant agreed to install a land-line will ensure that a working phone is provided for the clients at all times. Applicant will obtain a pool cover to ensure client safety around the pool. Applicant will change application to a requested capacity of 1. Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to the applicant. LPA will follow up with applicant for the next visit to finish up pre-licensing inspection.

This bed · Bedroom #2 (Master) has one Cal King size bed and one toddler bed; it will sleep the applicant and one infant client. · Bedroom #3 (Bio Child ) has one full size bed, It will sleep the bio child. · Bedroom #4 (grand parent) had one queen size bed, it will sleep the grandmother. · Living room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, an attached two car garage, a laundry room, storage closet, and the backyard. The Client’s bedroom was arranged so that no more than two clients will share the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. ***Continued to LIC 809-C***

***Continued from LIC 809*** There was a smoke detector/carbon monoxide detector located in the hallway. The smoke detectors and the carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. The home’s central air conditioning module was located outside of the home in the side yard. The home’s hot water heater was located inside the garage. The fire place is covered. The appliances were in working order. All sharp knives were located in the garage in a locked cabinet. The client’s files will be locked inside a locked file cabinet in the garage. There was adequate food storage space. A proper storage of all food was discussed. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight fitting lid and was located in the kitchen. The client bathroom also had a trash can with a working lid. Cleaning supplies were located in garage in a locked cabinet. The water temperature of the house was observed to be 109.6 degrees Fahrenheit. The water temperature of the client bathroom 1 was observed to be 110 degrees Fahrenheit and the house temperature was observed to be 78 degrees Fahrenheit. Medications were located in the locked cabinet in the garage. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible with all required items included and located in the upstairs hall cabinet. A fire extinguisher was present in the home and located on the wall in the laundry. It was observed to be properly charged. Applicant stated there were no weapons/firearms in the home. LPA observed there were no swimming pool. The backyard where clients will have access to play was completely fenced. The facility sketch, emergency plan, and client rights were hung on the wall by the downstairs bathroom. The applicant is scheduled for Component III on October 10, 2024. Applicant was advised to contact their LPA within 30 days after the placement of the first client. The request for a license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval . An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant

This is a two story, single family residence with 4 bedrooms, 3 bathrooms, kitchen, dining, 2 living spaces, backyard, front yard and attached garage. All appliances, microwave, oven, stove top at the time of this inspection were working and operable. Water temperature was tested and water temperature was measured at 118.2 degrees Fahrenheit. Downstairs Bedroom (Guest bedroom): Consists of one (1) queen bed, closet and desk (no clients utilizing bedroom Two downstairs closets were observed. One closet towards the front of the home being used as medication storage, files, knives and cleaning supplies. Second closet being used for coats and additional clothing/ storage items.

Upstairs: Bedroom 1: Consisted of two twin beds, two night stands, two side lamps and closet space available. Bedroom had mounted TV. Bedroom 2: Consisted of two twin beds and closet space available. Bedroom had one floor lamp, TV and chair. Water temperature was tested and measured at 120.6 degrees Fahrenheit. Laundry room: Consisted of washer/ dryer, sink and was free of clutter or debris All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide machines were tested and tested audible at the time of this inspection. Front/ Backyard: were observed to be clean and free of debris or clutter. LPA observed two tables and 5 chairs in back yard providing ample seating for clients in care. Garage: Split in two sections half being salon set up with chairs and maintained emergency supply kit. Second half utilized as strictly storage. Front entry: Consisted of sanitation area and seating, with log for visitors LPA went over forms with applicant and identified where applicant could retrieve those documents. LPA went over documents received and information provided with Program Statement and Fire clearance. Applicant maintained to fully stocked First Aid kits. Items to repair: 1. Water temperature should be between 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. Water in upstairs bathroom tested at 120.6 degrees Fahrenheit 8088 (Furniture and Fixtures (1) Hot water temperature controls shall be maintained to automatically regulate temperature of hot water delivered to plumbing fixtures used by clients to attain a hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F (40.5 degrees C) and not more than 120 degrees F (48.8 degrees C).

2. Light fixture in downstairs bathroom needs cover 3. Screens in upstairs bedroom 1 and 2 need to be replaced or repaired 4. Storage space/ dressers for all clients to have two dressers for storage of personal items in each bedroom. Both bedrooms observed did not have proper dresser storage space available for clients in care. 5. Post food menu, activities list and visitor/ COVID screening log. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection and a copy of this report was emailed to applicant for record.

Upstairs: Bedroom 1: Consisted of two twin beds, two plastic dressers and closet space available. Bedroom had mounted TV. Water temperature was tested and measured at 107.8 degrees Fahrenheit. Laundry room: Consisted of washer/ dryer, sink and was free of clutter or debris All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide machines were tested and tested audible at the time of this inspection. Front/ Backyard: were observed to be clean and free of debris or clutter. LPAs observed ample outdoor seating for clients in care. Front entry: Consisted of sanitation area and seating, with log for visitors LPA went over forms with licensee and identified where licensee could retrieve those documents. LPA went over emergency disaster plan and plan of operations. Licensee maintained a fully stocked First Aid kit. LPAs reviewed current LIC500, associations and verified documents were posted and available for review. Currently home has no placement's. Last placement's were removed from home 12/20/2022. LPAs were unable to interview children. Exit interview completed the following deficiencies were cited and a copy of this report was emailed to licensee.,

It was alleged that a lack of supervision resulted in unexplained injuries to a minor in care. In an interview conducted, the caregiver stated that she was changing another minor in care when one minor who was jumping/playing on the bed fell and hit their face against the edge of the bedframe. The caregiver stated that she took the child to the emergency room and the child was discharged without a CT scan. The caregiver stated that the physician did not have any immediate concerns and instructed her to monitor the child for symptoms of a concussion. No follow-up visits was reportedly necessitated unless a change in condition was observed. Due to the age and cognitive conditions of the children, interviews were unable to be held. A review of records confirmed that a visit with the physician was conducted and that no follow-up visits were necessitated. An interview conducted with the county worker revealed no concerns of a lack of supervision or neglect by the caregiver. Based on interviews conducted and records reviewed, there is not a preponderance of evidence to suggest that the above allegation occurred. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met. Therefore, the allegation is deemed UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Licensee.

On 8/3/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha for the purpose of a Case management- Annual continuation cite observed deficiencies inspection. LPA met with Administrator and discussed the below identified citations. Citations were observed during inspections completed on 7/20/2023 and 7/26/2023: 1. 80019 (d)/ 1522 (e)(1) HS (a)(d) CRC 80019 Criminal Record Clearance (a)The Department shall conduct a criminal record review of all individuals specified in Health and Safety Code Section 1522(b) and shall have the authority to approve or deny a facility license, or employment, residence, or presence in the facility, based upon the results of such review. (D)Any staff person, volunteer, or employee who has contact with the clients. 2. 80022(a) Plan of Operation (a)Each licensee shall have and maintain on file a current, written, definitive plan of operation. 3. 80023 (a) Disaster mass casualty plan (a)Each licensee shall have and maintain on file a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. 4. 80065 (f)(1-7) 80065 Personnel Requirements: (f)All personnel shall be given on-the-job training or shall have related experience which provides knowledge of and skill in the following areas, as appropriate to the job assigned and as evidenced by safe and effective job performance. (1) Principles of nutrition, food preparation and storage and menu planning. (2) Housekeeping and sanitation principles. (3) Provision of client care and supervision, including communication. (4) Assistance with prescribed medications which are self administered. (5) Recognition of early signs of illness and the need for professional assistance. (6) Availability of community services and resources. (7) The licensee of a Group Home or Adult Residential Facility that has been approved by the Department to utilize secured perimeters shall meet the staff training requirements as established by the Health and Safety Code section 1531.15(e) and the California Code of Regulations, Title 17, Division 2, Chapter 3, Sub chapter 4, Article 12, Section 56070(b).See page 2 continuation

5. 80066 (a) (1-12) 80066 Personnel Records (a)The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator and each employee. Each personnel record shall contain the following information: (1) Employee's full name. (2) Driver's license number if the employee is to transport clients. (3) Date of employment. (4) A statement signed by the employee that he/she is at least 18 years of age. (5) Home address and phone number. (6) Documentation of the educational background, training and/or experience specified in licensing regulations for the type of facility in which the employee works. (7) Past experience, including types of employment and former employers. (8) Duties of the employee. (9) Termination date if no longer employed by the facility. (10) A health screening as specified in Section 80065(g). (11) Tuberculosis test documents as specified in Section 80065(g). (12) For employees that are required to be fingerprinted pursuant to Section 6. 80090 Health and Safety Services Child abuse/ Neglect reporting. The client is able to care for all aspects of the condition for himself/herself or assistance in the care of the condition is provided either by an appropriately skilled and licensed professional, or by facility staff who receive supervision and training from a licensed professional. (A)Training shall include hands-on instruction in both general procedures and client specific procedures. (B)The licensee obtains from the licensed professional written documentation outlining the procedures and the names of facility staff who received the training. (C)The licensee ensures that the licensed professional reviews staff performance as the licensed professional deems necessary, but at least once a year. (5)The licensee agrees in writing to comply with all aspects of the client's care plans. Page 2 see page 3 continuation

7. 83064 (e-j): (e) The licensee shall ensure that caregivers meet initial and ongoing training requirements regarding the child's right to non discriminatory care as outlined below: (1) Fair and equal access to all available services, placement, care, treatment, and benefits. (2) To not be subject to discrimination or harassment on the basis of actual or perceived race, ethnic group identification, ancestry, national origin, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, mental or physical disability, or HIV status. (f)The licensee shall ensure that individuals, who provide care and supervision of a child in a facility, have training on the existing laws and procedures regarding the safety of foster youth at school as contained in the California Student Safety and Violence Prevention Act of 2000. (g)The licensee shall ensure that individuals, who provide care and supervision of a child in a facility, have received instruction on cultural competency and sensitivity relating to, and best practices for, providing adequate care to lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender youth in out-of-home care. (h) The licensee shall ensure that both caregivers and the licensee meet initial and ongoing training requirements regarding the training topics described in Section 16501.4(d) of the Welfare and Institutions Code. i)The licensee shall complete training related to the reasonable and prudent parent standard as specified in Health and Safety Code section 1522.44(c). (j) The licensee shall complete training that includes the following topics: (1) Children’s right to receive sexual and reproductive health care and information. (2) Children’s right to have their sensitive health information kept confidential. (3) The duties and responsibilities of the assigned case management worker and the licensee to ensure that children can obtain sexual and reproductive health services and information. (4) Guidance about how to engage and talk with children about healthy sexual development and reproductive and sexual health in a manner that is medically accurate, age or developmentally appropriate, trauma informed, and strengths based. (5)Information about current contraception methods and how to select and provide appropriate referral resources and materials for information and service delivery. 8.83066 (a)(1)83066 Personnel Records for Specialized Small Family Homes (a) The licensee shall ensure that the personnel records of all persons subject to the requirements of Section 83065.1(a) contain the following: (1)For any training or additional training from which the licensee or other in-home health care provider is exempt: 9. 83075(e)(1) Health Related (e)When providing family health care, the licensee shall ensure that the child's physician or designated registered nurse has assigned the specific task(s) and has provided adequate practical and written instruction. (1)The date, time and content of the initial contact with the physician or nurse shall be documented and maintained in the child's file. Page 3 see page 4 continuation

Observations made with possible health and safety concerns: 1.On 7/20/2023 Staff#1 observed in facility not cleared handling files and assisting with client. This poses a risk to clients in care that staff are not authorized to work in facility without being fingerprint cleared. 2. On 7/20/2023 LPA observed no written plan of operation within facility. This poses a risk to clients and staff in that no detailed plan of operation was observed in maintaining safety protocols for the way in which the home operates. 3. On 7/20/2023 LPA observed no detailed disaster mass casualty plan or handbook. This poses a risk to clients in that in cases of a disaster or emergency facility has no written plan of action or handbook to provide emergency staff in how to care for clients in care. 4. On 7/20/2023 LPA observed no current training for staff last training's were completed in 2020 for Administrator and 2012 for one staff. No other current training's were observed during inspection. This poses a risk to clients in care in that staff are not receiving current information on regulations, laws or in how to care for clients. 5. On 7/20/2023 LPA observed staff files to be incomplete without identified documents within the regulations for all associated staff. This poses a risk because with incomplete documentation in staff files; clients, placing agencies and licensing do not see record of staffs qualifications, duties or health screenings. 6. On 7/26/2023 Interviews conducted with staff identified staff not receiving training or knowledge of mandated reporting for child abuse and neglect. This poses a risk in that staff do not know how to properly notify correct agencies if observe child abuse/ neglect. 7. On 7/20/2023 LPA observed no updated or on going training completed by any associated staff including Administrator. This poses a risk as staff are not meeting the annual requirement of on going training's. 8. Personnel records did not have maintained record of training's completed. This poses a risk as unknown if staff completed training's or are in compliance with state regulations in attending specific training's for working in a small family home. On 7/26/2023 LPA observed picture of registration for staff enrollment in continued training. 9. On 7/26/2023 LPA observed no medical documentation in child's file of doctors visits or documented check ups. This poses a risk as no information was observed in clients file identifying health visits or proper documentation of medications. Exit interview completed, the following deficiencies were cited and civil penalty issued a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Administrator. Page 4

narrative: On 9/2723 the Department received a complaint alleging the Small Family Home administrator (AD) has not taken C1 to the dentist; has not enrolled C1 in school; has not followed C1’s medication as prescribed and C1 does not have a bed that meets C1’s needs. Based on the information gathered during confidential interviews, relevant parties denied the allegations indicating C1 has been taken to the dentist twice and each time C1 has become aggressive towards the dentist. The dentist has requested C1 be sedated, and AD is waiting for C1’s social worker to get court approval for C1 to be put under anesthesia. C1 has been enrolled in school however since C1 does not have any pervious education history, C1 needs an individualized education plan (IEP) to determine if C1 will be enrolled in person school or be home schooled. LPA reviewed doctor visit notes which indicate C1’s prescription for Clonidine is not working and a letter dated October 5, 2023, indicated it was advised C1 stop taking Clonidine patch and Clonidine due to C1 being allergic. Doctor’s notes indicated C1 was seen by a doctor on 6/1/23, 6/8/23, 7/25/23 and 10/5/23. AD indicated C1 had a modified bed due to C1’s weight and C1’s pervious social worker had approved the bed. AD stated C1 now has a single bed that accommodates C1’s size. LPA observed a single bed when LPA visited the facility. AD sent a picture of C1’s bed which shows C1 has a single bed. FYA indicated C1 is enrolled in school and is waiting for a final decision on if C1 will attend in person school or be home school. FYA stated it was not AD’s fault that C1 was not enrolled in school and indicated it was due to C1 not having any school history documentation or a valid IEP. LPA reviewed C1’s completed medication logs for May, June, July, August, September, and October 2023. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegations is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above. There were no deficiencies cited.
investigation_findings: 13On December 19, 2023, at 10:25 Licensing Program Analyst Larry Cabral (LPA) conducted a follow-up inspection for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint allegations. LPA Cabral met with the Small Family Home Administrator Raven Campbell. During the investigation, LPA Cabral interviewed one facility staff (AD) and attempted to interview one client (C1) on 10/3/23(see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated December 19, 2023). LPA Cabral interviewed one county social worker (CSW) on 10/3/23. LPA interviewed one regional center coordinator (RCC2) on 12/13/23 and attempted to interview another regional center coordinator (RCC) on 12/12/23. LPA interviewed a school foster care advocate (FYA) on 12/12/23. LPA reviewed incident reports, health and education passport, medication logs, C1’s fact sheet, doctor, and dental visit documents. LPA reviewed an email for the dentist and a letter for a doctor. LPA reviewed the county’s delivered service logs.

narrative: On January 11, 2024 at 9:25 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Larry Cabral conducted a follow up case management inspection and met with Small Family Home Administrator Raven Campbell . The purpose of the visit was to amend a licensing report for a complaint. The licensing report was amended and signed by the facility representative mentioned above. An exit interview was held with the representative above and copies of the reports were provided.

On 9/27/23 the Department received a complaint alleging the Small Family Home administrator (AD) has not taken C1 to the dentist; has not enrolled C1 in school; has not followed C1’s medication as prescribed; C1 does not have a bed that meets C1’s needs and facility’s staffing needs are not being met. Based on the information gathered during confidential interviews, relevant parties denied the allegations indicating C1 has been taken to the dentist twice and each time C1 has become aggressive towards the dentist. The dentist has requested C1 be sedated, and AD is waiting for C1’s social worker to get court approval for C1 to be put under anesthesia. Investigation revealed C1 has been enrolled in school however since C1 does not have any previous education history, C1 needs an individualized education plan (IEP) to determine if C1 will be enrolled in person school or be home schooled. An IEP is being developed by the school to meet C1’s educational needs. LPA reviewed doctor visit notes which indicate C1’s prescription for Clonidine is not working and a letter dated October 5, 2023, indicated it was advised C1 stop taking Clonidine patch and Clonidine due to C1 being allergic. Doctor’s notes indicated C1 was seen by a doctor on 6/1/23, 6/8/23, 7/25/23 and 10/5/23. LPA reviewed C1’s completed medication logs for May, June, July, August, September, and October 2023. AD indicated C1 had a modified bed due to C1’s weight and C1’s previous social worker had approved the bed. AD stated C1 now has a single bed that accommodates C1’s size. LPA observed a single bed when LPA visited the facility. AD sent a picture of C1’s bed which shows C1 has a single bed. Confidential interviews indicated C1 always has two staff supervising C1. Staff does not leave C1 unattended and C1 is always supervised. LPA observed two staff present at the facility each time LPA made an unannounced visit to the facility. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegations is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above. There were no deficiencies cited.

narrative: DSP had begun a tour of the home with LPA when S1 arrived about ten minutes later with a bag from a chain drug store. S1 excused herself for not being home to greet LPA's arrival, but stated where she had been, and took over the tour of the home. Individual and confidential interviews with S1, DSP, S2 and S3 were consistent in telling of S1's morning errand routine. It was also alleged that S1 is not at the facility the required amount of time. Confidential interviews with S1, DSP, S2, and S3 were consistent in placing S1 as regularly present at the home and providing for regular supervision of C1 by responsible staff in the event S1 was absent while on errands for the home and/or C1. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited at this time. Exit interview conducted. A signed copy of this report, LIC9099-C, and LIC811 were provided to Raven Campbell, Licensee. Appeal rights provided.
investigation_findings: 13On March 5, 2024, at 9:00 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla arrived unannounced at the All Together Small Family Home (SFH) (See LIC811 Confidential Names list dated 01/31/24) for the purpose of delivering findings on the above complaint. LPA met with Raven Campbell, Licensee (S1). On January 29, 2024, the Department received a complaint alleging that S1 does not live at the facility. It was also alleged that S1 is not at the facility the required amount of time. During the investigation, LPA reviewed the SFH's file, prior complaint history, arrived unannounced at the SFH, conducted interviews with S1 and staff (DSP, S2, & S3), and took a tour of the SFH. On January 31, 2024, LPA met with S1 at the home during an unannounced visit. While S1 was not present in the home when LPA arrived, LPA was allowed into the home by DSP and made aware that S1 had recently left to local pharmacy to pick up medication for client in care (C1). (Continued next page...)

narrative:
On 8/16/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the All Together Small Family Home (SFH) for the purpose of an Annual required inspection. LPA met with Administrator and together did a walk thru of the facility. LPA observed the following: his is a two story, single family residence with 4 bedrooms, 3 bathrooms, kitchen, dining, 2 living spaces, backyard, front yard and attached garage. LPA observed the following: Downstairs: Kitchen: LPA observed kitchen to have required perishable and non-perishable food storage for children in care. Appliances, microwave, toaster over, stove top at the time of this inspection were working and operable. Fire extinguisher observed full charged. Living spaces: LPA observed living spaces to be clean and free of clutter Dining room: Consisted of table and 2 chairs/ additional dining seating provided in kitchen area Downstairs bathroom: Bathroom has one sink, toilet and shower/ tub combination. Water temperature was tested, and water temperature was measured at 121.1 degrees Fahrenheit. Downstairs Bedroom (Guest bedroom): couch, twin bed and mounted TV Two downstairs closets were observed. One closet towards the front of the home being used as medication storage, files, knives, and cleaning supplies. Second closet being used for clients coats and additional clothing/ storage items.

Upstairs: Bedroom 1: Consisted of two twin beds, two plastic dressers and closet space available. Bedroom had mounted TV. Bedroom 2: Consisted of one king bed, TV stand and closet space available. Room is occupied by one client with destructive behaviors. LPA observed patches and repairs to wall for safety for client. Master bedroom: Consisted of 1 queen bed, attached bathroom and walk in closet Bathroom: Consisted of double sinks, toilet, bath/ shower combo. Water temperature was tested and measured at 118.5 degrees Fahrenheit. Laundry room: Consisted of washer/ dryer, sink and was free of clutter or debris All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide machines were tested and tested audible at the time of this inspection. Front/ Backyard: were observed to be clean and free of debris or clutter. LPA observed ample outdoor seating for clients in care. Garage: Split in two sections half being salon set up with chairs. Second half utilized as strictly storage. Front entry: Consisted of sanitation area and seating, with log for visitors LPA went over forms with licensee and identified where licensee could retrieve those documents. LPA went over updating documents and maintaining separate logs for cash resources and personal belongings.. Licensee maintained a fully stocked First Aid kit. LPA reviewed current LIC500, associations and verified documents were posted and available for review. Currently home has one placement. LPA was unable to interview children due to child being non- verbal. However, client was observed to be groomed and comfortable in home and around staff. Exit interview completed the following deficiencies were noted and cited during this inspection. A copy of this report and citations was provided to Administrator.

On June 23, 2021 at 12:32PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez conducted an unannounced required annual inspection of the small family home. LPA met with Administrator Sarah Paul. LPA toured the facility inside and outside with Administrator. The home is a two-story residence with eight bedrooms and five bathrooms. There are currently six clients in care. The small family home is licensed for four non-ambulatory and two ambulatory clients ages three to seventeen years old. There are eight bedrooms, living room, dining room, kitchen, and five bathrooms. The six bedrooms are used for the clients. The clients’ 4 bedrooms downstairs have two twin beds and adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The clients’ bedrooms are arranged so that there is no more than one client per bed. There are three bathrooms for the clients to share. The bathrooms are clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom sink was measured to be 117.5 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. Cleansers/chemicals are inaccessible and locked in the garage. The sharp knives are locked in the laundry room. The First Aid Kit contained all required supplies and is stored in the medicine closet. The clients’ medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the medicine closet at the end of the hallway. The medication logs are kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were operable. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 3-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Three clients’ and three staff files were reviewed during the inspection. The files appeared to be completed and in order. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Personal Rights, Facility license, and Emergency Disaster Plan. Based on today's inspection, and file review, there were no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to Administrator Sarah Paul.

It was also reported that S1 comes to work at the facility smelling like alcohol and cigarettes. It was also reported that S1 is not properly trained to work at the facility. Confidential interviews revealed that there was no suspected physical abuse to C1 and C2. Confidential witness statements revealed that staff are properly trained. Confidential witness statements revealed that a third party had stated that staff are not properly trained. Confidential witness statements also revealed that it is unknown where the information came from regarding whether or not S1 works at the facility while under the influence. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the allegations that C2 sustained a fracture while in care, C1 sustained injury while in care, S1 works while under the influence of a substance, and S1 is not properly trained, are unsubstantiated. Meaning, although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, along with appeal rights were explained to LVN Tye Espinoza. Due to printer malfunction, this report will be emailed to LVN Tye Espinoza.
investigation_findings: 13On September 22, 2022 at 10:44am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Adrian Mendez, arrived unannounced to the facility and met with Licensed Vocational Nurse (LVN) Tye Espinoza to deliver the finding for the above stated allegations. The investigation was conducted by Community Care Licensing Investigations Branch (IB) Special Investigator (SI) Rey Lyyjoki and included interviews with six facility staff, and one confidential witness. In addition, facility records, and medical records were reviewed. On April 20, 2022, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received allegations that a resident sustained a fracture while in care, a resident sustained injury while in care, a staff works while under the influence of a substance, and facility staff not properly trained. It was reported that C1 was observed having 10 stitches on C1’s forehead. It was also reported that C2 was observed having a cast on C2’s leg due to C2 sustaining a tibia fracture at the facility. It was also reported to be believed that C1 and C2 may have sustained the injuries as a result of physical abuse at the facility. Cont. on 9099-C

On 08/27/24 at 12pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz, LPA Jacqueline Garcia and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela arrived to Aloe Special Care Home, a Small Family Home (SFH) for the purpose of amending LIC 809 that was signed on 08/15/24 and to complete the annual inspection that began on 8/15/24. LPA and LPM met with Licensee, David Chase and Administrator, Sarah Paul. On 8/15/24 LPA Munoz began the unannounced required annual inspection, on that date LPA observed that clients C1-6 are over the license age threshold. Upon initial inspection date, LPA also observed four non-ambulatory clients residing in the SFH therefore exceeding their license ambulatory status. Licensee reported that in 2020 they licensed an adult home for C1-C6 to be transferred to, however, the home has not been approved by Regional Center. Licensee reported that they have submitted the program description to Regional Center back in 2020 and has not had any response regarding the approval process and is unsure what is needed to get the home approved. LPA and LPM confirmed Adult Licensed Home, Chase Special Care Home. LPA completed 5 client file review and all required documentation met regulation requirements. LPA reviewed 5 staff files and observed four staff that did not meet staff clearances. The SFH is being cited for Title 22 Continuing Care Requirements (CCR)Section 80010(a) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status and Health and Safety Code (HSC) Section 1522(c)(1) Administration and CCR Section 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance. Civil Penalties were assessed for each staff that is not cleared.

LPM Valenzuela discussed with Licensee David Chase that CCL is going to place the facility on a plan to follow up weekly on the process of Regional Center Approval and when the clients will be transferred to the adult facility. LPA completed exit interview with David Chase and Sarah Paul. LPA provided a copy of this report, LIC 811 dated 8/27/24 and Appeal Rights were provided to designees.

deficiencies.title:
Criminal Record Clearance

(e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility

narrative:
On September 19, 2024, at 1:00 p.m., Children Residential Program (CRP) Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela, Adult Senior LPM, Alisa Ortiz, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Garcia met with Aloe Special Care Home Small Family Homes (SFH) Licensee, David Chase, SFH Administrator, Sarah Paul, and Orange County Regional Center Representatives, Jacqueline Puente and Christina Pham at the CRP Orange Local Office for an informal office conference. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the following issues and concerns with the Licensee for Aloe Special Care Homes regarding Title 22 Continuing Care Requirements Section 80010(a) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status. On 8/27/24 Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted an unannounced annual inspection and cited the SFH for allowing adult clients to live at the facility. Upon file review CCL determined that all clients in placement were over the age of 22 years. Licensee stated that they have always wanted to continue the care of the client’s longer term, as they had them since the age of 3 years. Licensee stated that they had no intention to be out of compliance of Title 22 Regulations as they had submitted an application and were licensed to provide services for adult clients at the Fountain Valley facility, however Regional Center delayed the process which brought them to their current status. Licensee stated they have submitted a new application to the Adult Senior Residential Care application unit on 9/13/24. Licensee changed original plan of having the Fountain Valley Home vendorized by Regional Center to serve the adults clients, as it would be more efficient to change location of the SFH to the Fountain Valley location and turn the current SFH into a licensed Adult Residential Facility for the clients to remain in the same home. LPM Ortiz stated the application was received by the Application Unit on 9/17/24, in addition, there has been communication with the Application Unit and there is an understanding that the application will be expedited. ****CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE 809-C.

LPM Valenzuela asked Regional Center Representatives regarding the length of time it will take the Regional Center to approve the vendorization of the Adult Residential Facility. Regional Center Representative Jacqueline Puente stated they could not confirm a timeframe, however David Chase stated he believes it can be approved by 9/23/24. David stated he has been in communication with Regional Center and has made requested revisions to their Program Statement. On 9/19/24 the following plan was identified: · Licensee submitted Adult Residential Facility application on 9/13/24 to the Adult Application Unit. · Application was received on 9/17/24 and will be expedited. · LPA Munoz will communicate weekly with the Licensee. If there are any modifications to the current plan or there are any questions, please contact LPA Guadalupe Munoz at guadalupe.munoz@dss.ca.gov or (949) 701-3475. A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to Licensee David Chase. The signed report will be placed in the facility file.

LPA met with Sarah Paul, Facility Administrator and David Chase, Licensee. LPA toured the facility inside and outside. The home is a two story residence with eight bedrooms and five bathrooms.
