There are two common living room areas, dining area and kitchen. There are 3 client bedrooms downstairs for non ambulatory clients. Each bedroom have twin beds and adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings and medical devices. The clients’ bedrooms are arranged so that there is no more than one client per bed. There are three bathrooms for the clients to share. The bathrooms are clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom sink was measured to be within regulatory requirements. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 3-day perishable supply of food. There were variety of snacks available for clients as well. The sharp knives are locked in the garage. Cleansers/chemicals are inaccessible and locked in the garage. The clients’ medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in the medicine closet at the end of the hallway. The medication logs are kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were operable. The First Aid Kit contained all required supplies and is stored in the medicine closet. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

LPA completed six client file reviews and all required documentation met regulation requirements. Five staff files were reviewed during the inspection. The files are complete and meet regulation requirements. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Personal Rights, Facility license, and Emergency Disaster Plan. Licensee reports that there are no fire arms in the home. The SFH is still in the process of getting licensed for the Adult Residential License(ARF) and reported that on 7/14/25 they completed Component III and pre license visit for the ARF licensing process. Based on today's inspection. LPA observed that clients C1-6 are over the license age threshold. The SFH is being cited for Title 22 Continuing Care Requirements (CCR)Section 80010(a) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status. An exit interview was conducted with Sarah Paul and a copy of this report and LIC 811 dated 7/14/25 was reviewed and provided to Administrator Sarah Paul.

On July 29,2025 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Guadalupe Munoz and Stefani Mutialu conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection visit for the change of location to the ALOE Special Care Home, Small Family Home. LPAs met with licensee, David Chase and conducted the inspection of the home. The facility is a four bedroom two bathroom single-family, single-story home with an in ground pool and with an attached garage. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Clients will have access to a telephone in the living room to make and receive confidential telephone calls. Inside the home the fireplace was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors tested and were observed to be in working order; the fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The facility has a first aid kit with all of the required items and a First Aid manual. The applicants stated there were no weapons in the facility. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be stored and locked in the garage. Sharp knives will be stored in a locked kitchen cabinet. Medication will be locked and stored in a cabinet in the hallway of the home..

The following required forms were posted in the facility: Personal Rights form, Foster Care Ombudsmen Poster and LIC 610 Emergency Disaster Plan, and Grievance Policy. The facility is set up as follows The entry hallway leads to an open living room that flows into the dining area and attached kitchen. All shared living spaces have furniture in good condition. At the rear of the home is a sliding glass door that leads to the backyard which has a jacuzzi and pool. The backyard patio is gated with a 5 foot fence that meets the regulation standards. There are three client bedrooms that are designated for two clients per room with twin sized beds dresser and closet space for each client. Each room has adequate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses. Bedroom #1 is: designated for two clients, with two twin beds and ample closet spaces. Bedroom #2 is designated for two clients, two twin beds and ample closet spaces. Bedroom #3 is designated for two clients, two twin beds and ample closet space. Bedroom #4 is designated as licensees bedroom. It includes an en suite bathroom. The home is equipped with non ambulatory ramps at front entrance and back exit of home. Client bathroom is in the hallway in front of the bedrooms and it includes a walk in shower to meet the needs of non ambulatory clients. All special incident reports (SIR's) will be sent via e-mail to: cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov. The reporting requirements were reviewed with the Applicant on this date. LPA explained that once the license is approved, all employees shall have an approved criminal record clearance for CCL and be associated to this facility. The request to be licensed for a small family home will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Applicant/Licensee, David Chase.

On June 3, 2021 at 12:30 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kourtney Williams arrived at the small family home to conduct an unannounced annual inspection. When LPA Williams arrived at the facility wearing a Community Care Licensing (CCL) identification badge, the doorbell was pressed by LPA, and an unknown woman answered the door. The woman stated the Licensee Sharee Williams was not at the home. The woman then called Licensee Sharee Williams on the phone with LPA outside the home. Licensee refused LPA entry into the facility via telephone and stated that the home didn’t have any placement since 2016. LPA confirmed with Licensee that the home was still licensed by CCL and regardless of placement status, the annual inspections are required. LPA informed licensee that CCL has the inspection authority of the facility and refusing entry is a violation of the CCL regulations 80044. As a result, the home will be cited and LPA asked Licensee if she was going to proceed with facility closure. Licensee stated that she will close her facility and the facility door was abruptly shut with no further communication with LPA Williams. LPA Williams was unable to complete annual inspection and retrieve signature of the Licensee for this refused inspection. Inspection document emailed to tstc_n@yahoo.com on 06/03/21.

On November 17, 2021 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at Ameen Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting an Annual Random Inspection. LPA met with the Licensee, who granted access to the home and together a tour of the entire home was conducted. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision services for three (3) developmentally disabled children, ages 3-17 years old, ambulatory only. The census today is zero (0) and living in the home currently are the Licensee, the Licensee’s Adopted son, and Licensee’s Legal Guardian Child. The program accepts Regional Center Placement Children. The facility is set up as follows: This is a single-story 3 bedrooms 1 bathroom, home located in a residential area. The home has a living room, dining room, kitchen, and a backyard. Living Room: is equipped with a sofa, bookshelves, a small wooden table, and a mounted flat screen television. Dining Room: is equipped with a table and four (4) chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with a four (4) burner stove/oven, a refrigerator/freezer, a toaster oven, and a microwave. There is also an exit door leading to the side of the home. Bedroom #1: is occupied by Licensee’s Legal Guardianship child. The room is furnished with a two-tier bunk beds with appropriate railing to prevent falling, closet, drawer space, working light, and an exit window equipped with security bars. Bedroom #2: is occupied by Licensee’s Adopted son. The room is furnished with a two-tier bunk beds with appropriate railing to prevent falling, drawer, closet space, working light, and an exit window equipped with security bars. Bedroom #3 is occupied by the Licensee. The room is furnished with a Futon, drawers, closet space, working light, bookshelves, a small desk, and an exit window with security bars. All security bars were tested and found to be in working order. Report continued on LIC 809C.

LPA observed one (1) fully charged fire extinguisher in the home. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. Medications are stored in a locked box inside a locked kitchen cabinet and made inaccessible to children in care. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in a locked cabinet under the kitchen sink. Sharp knives are kept in a locked box located in Licensee’s bedroom. The hot water was tested and found to be at a safe temperature. The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. The First Aid Kit was checked and found to be complete. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. There was no swimming pool, hot tub, spas, nor similar bodies of water located at the facility. Emergency numbers are posted in a prominent place. Licensee has completed three hours of annual training. Licensee has a current CPR/First Aid card which expires 10/06/2023. LPA reminded Licensee to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Licensee acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. During the visit, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Small Family Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. The home currently has no staff or clients placed in the home. Licensee was issued an advisory note regarding ongoing training hours. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTER 4 no deficiencies were cited during this visit. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Licensee.

On June 24, 2025 at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adaleyci Caballero met with applicant Belinda Addo for a Component II of the application process. LPA A. Caballero went over revisions needed for the application prior to license that are due no later than July 24, 2025. LPA gave a copy of the LIC 184, Notice of Application Revision, and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed to the application. A copy of this report was provided to applicant via email. Original signed copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On July 16, 2025 at 9:45AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adaleyci Caballero completed a pre-licensing inspection of Amor Small Family Home (SFH). LPA met with Applicant Belinda Addo who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. There are no clients in placement. The one-story building with four bedrooms and two full bathrooms which are set up as follows: Bedroom #1- It consisted of one queen. The bed had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep applicant and significant other. Bedroom #2- It consisted of two single beds. The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. Bedroom #3- It consisted of two single beds. The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. Bedroom #4- It consisted of two single beds. The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. A living room, kitchen, dining area, laundry room, three car garage, backyard, and a patio. The garage will be utilized for storage.

The clients' bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the clients' belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom. The five smoke detectors were checked and working properly. The Carbon Monoxide detectors were combined with the smoke alarms. The home’s central air conditioning module was in the backyard. The water heater is located in the outside of the house. The appliances were in working order. Medications will be locked in a filing cabinet in the licensee's bedroom. The home had a trash can for storage of solid waste with a tight fitting lid. Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610), Personal Rights, Grievance procedures, Facility Sketch, House Rules, and Visitation Policies were posted and accessible to the public. There were three fire extinguishes present in the home located in the kitchen, entrance, and the garage. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. The First Aid Kit was located in the dining area accessible to clients in care. There are no firearms in the home. There is no pool or any body of water in the home. The hot water temperature was at 119.4 degrees Fahrenheit. Corrections: Toys, games, books, and recreational and educational materials. Client bedrooms emptied and cleaned ready for placement Extra linen and towels A supply of perishable food and non-perishable food. Licensee's bedroom with belongings to reflect licensee residing in the home Component III was conducted. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to applicant Belinda Addo via email due to technical difficulties. The application will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager Abdoulaye Traore once corrections are submitted to LPA.

On 3/13/25, LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) Carrie Palmer conducted an announced visit to the above Small Family Home for the purpose of relocating. The applicant has not moved into the facility. LPA Palmer will return to complete a 2nd licensing inspection prior to issuing a license. LPA Palmer took a tour of the facility. The facility is a one story single family residence with 5 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, kitchen, living room, laundry room, backyard, front yard and garage. The facility appears to be clean and safe. At this time, the facility is not ready to be licensed. The facility representative states the anticipated move in date will be determined at a later date and will email LPA Palmer said date. LPA Palmer will return to complete the licensing inspection at a later date. .

On Monday February 26, 2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes met with Applicant Arianna Sattiwhite via Microsoft Teams to complete a Component II interview. A pre-licensing was scheduled for 3/11/2024. A signed copy of this LIC 809 will be placed in facility file.

On March 11, 2024 at 1:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes completed a pre-licensing inspection of Amor Small Family Home. LPA met with Applicant Arianna Sattiewhite who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no clients in placement at this time. The home is a one story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has one bed will sleep the applicant. · Bedroom #2 (Client’s) has two twin beds, it will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #3 (Client’s) has two twin beds, it will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #4 (Client’s) has two twin beds, it will sleep two clients. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, an attached two car garage, laundry room, and the backyard. The Client’s bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector / carbon monoxide detector in every bedroom. The six smoke detectors / carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. The home’s central air conditioning module was located in the back yard. The home’s tank less hot water heater was located inside the garage. The appliances were in working order. The client’s files will be locked inside a cabinet in the kitchen. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid and was present. The sharp knives will be in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The medications will be located in a locked cabinet in the kitchen.

The hot water in the master bathroom measured to be 106.2 degrees Fahrenheit, in bathroom 2 106.5 degrees Fahrenheit, and in bathroom 3 106.5 degrees Fahrenheit. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible and is located in cabinet in the kitchen and contained all required supplies. two fire extinguishers were present in the home both are located in the laundry room. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. Licensee stated there were no weapons/firearms in the home. There is no pool or other body of water at the home. The backyard where clients will have access to play was completely fenced. The following corrections need to be made: · Lock needs to be installed on the kitchen cabinet where medications will be stored A component III was conducted at 2:00 PM with Applicant. An exit interview was conducted. Application will be forwarded to the Licensing Program Manager for Licensing.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection visit to the facility on January 20, 2021 beginning at 10:30 AM. LPA met with Staff (S1) who was currently on shift duty with four clients in care. LPA asked to speak to the Licensee Maria Tauro or the designated person in charge. Staff S1 stated Licensee was currently in the Philippines. S1 Stated other staffs S2 and S3 had left to transport a client in care to a medical appointment in San Francisco. LPA asked for the designated employee in charge during Maria Tauro’s absence. S1 stated staff S4 was not present and S1 did not know their phone number. S1 contacted S2 and S3 via telephone regarding LPA’s visit. Staff S2 then informed LPA that the Licensee Gabriel Tauro was on his way. Licensee Gabriel Tauro arrived at approximately 11:00 AM. LPA introduced herself and explained the purpose of the visit was to conduct a Case Manager due to the Decision and Order that had been discussed via the teleconference on 1/19/2021. On today’s date, LPA completed a Health and Safety inspection of the home, inside and outside. LPA was joined by Rukaiyah Jones, Valley Mountain Regional Center Community Service Liaison at approximately 11:14 AM for the inspection. This facility is a two story, five-bedroom, three-bathroom home. On the second floor are three bedrooms for clients in care. Each bedroom sleeps no more than two clients and each client is afforded their own beds, dressers, and closet space. Each bedroom contains an operating smoke detector. There are also operating smoke detectors in the upstairs hallway, downstairs hallway. During inspection of one client bedroom, LPA observed one dresser had a bottom broken drawer. There is one bedroom designated for the live-in Licensee, Maria Tauro. This bedroom was observed to be locked. Inside contained both staff and client files. There is one empty bedroom downstairs not being used currently. CONTINUED ON LIC809-C

LPA observed the kitchen to be fully stocked with both perishable and non-perishable food items. Medications was observed to be in locked cabinets. Cleaning supplies and sharps was observed to be locked under the kitchen sink. The door to the garage was locked. LPA observed the garage contained storage boxes and extra cleaning supplies and household items such as toilet paper and paper towels. During the inspection of the backyard, LPA observed a shed which was locked. LPA observed about 8-10 piles of dog feces in the backyard play area, which is accessible to clients in care. The facility is being cited for violations of California Code of Regulationa, Title 22, Section 80087(a) Building and Grounds: The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was given to the Licensee, Gabriel Tauro

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Shoua Xiong and Robert Sandles conducted an unannounced inspection visit to the facility on January 26, 2021 at approximately 10:00 AM. LPAs met with Prince Dela Cruz, Care Giver and explained the purpose of today’s visit was to conduct a Case Management regarding the Decision and Order that went into effect January 25, 2021, stating the closure of the facility. On today’s date, LPAs conducted a physical inspection of the facility. LPAs confirmed that the facility no longer has any clients in the home. This facility is no longer licensed by the Department effective 1/25/21. No deficiencies were cited on today’s date. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Prince Dela Cruz, Care Giver.

An Office Meeting was conducted today in the Sacramento Regional Office. The scheduled call was conducted via Conference line on 01/19/2021 at 4:00pm due to COVID-19 and pre-cautionary measures. The purpose of this office meeting is to discuss the Decision Order that was set in place. Present in the meeting was the Regional Manager Stephanie Doab, Licensing Program Manager CRP Dara Campos, Licensing Program Manager, ASCP Liza King, Licensing Program Analyst, CRP Shoua Xiong, Licensing Program Analyst, ASCP Ashley Boothe, Licensee Angel’s Haven, Angel’s Haven 2 and Angel’s Haven 3 Gabriel Tauro, Valley Mountain Regional Center Division Manager Katina Richison, Valley Mountain Regional Center Community Services Manager Brian Bennett, and Valley Mountain Regional Center Community Services Liaison Rukaiyah Jones. All parties agreed the Decision and Order was received. Angel’s Haven 8407 Clifford Dr has 5 residents currently in the home. Angel’s Haven 2 9337 Snow Creek Circle has 0 residents currently in the home. Angel’s Haven 3 3331 Wyoming Court has 6 residents currently in the home. Notice of Defense was not provided by the Licensee. Notifications has not been given to the residents. Licensee was made aware that an action has been taken by the Department and a Change of Ownership is not an option at this point. Per the Decision and Order the licenses for Angels’ Haven, Angel’s Haven 2 and Angels Haven 3 are revoked as of 01/25/21. The Administrator Certificate of Gabriel Tauro is revoked as of 01/25/21. Both individuals will be excluded from any involvement with care facilities and and/or individuals of care facilities licensed by the Department for the remainder of your lives. CONTINUED ON LIC809-C

Issues discussed during the meeting were: · Closure Plan – Relocation information for each resident · A completed resident roster · Civil Penalties shall be issued if residents are not relocated by 01/25/21 at which time the facility will be deemed unlicensed The facility has stated they will do the following to achieve continued and substantial compliance: · Submit a Closure Plan to be submitted by Close of Business tomorrow 01/20/21 · Submit a copy of notifications given to residents/responsible parties regarding Decision and Order to be submitted by Close of Business tomorrow 01/20/21 · Submit a completed resident roster with contact information · Submit relocation information of each resident for intended relocations and actual relocations Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the Licensees, Gabriel Tauro and Maria Tauro.

On December 10, 2021 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducing a required/annual inspection of the facility. LPA met with Marie Yadao, Administrator and Licensee and completed the required/annual inspection of the facility. The facility is a Small Family Home, consisting of five bedrooms and two bathrooms. There are a total of four clients, one non-ambulatory client. Two out of four clients share a bedroom, and are compatible to do so. There are a total of three live-in staff, including the two licensees, and one Direct Care Staff. During the course of the inspection, LPA reviewed four client files and nine staff files, and observed all required documentation was present and filed. Interviews were conducted with one client, three out of four clients in care are non-verbal and an interview was unable to be completed. Interviews were conducted with four staff. The facility was observed to be clean, organized, and free of debris and clutter. The home contained a living room, a kitchen, dining room, and multi-media/activity room. The dining room and multi-media room had a table for the clients to sit and eat, and complete activities and homework. The client bedrooms were observed to contain an individual bed, clean linens, and storage space for client property. The facility license, facility sketch, emergency plan, emergency telephone numbers, and fire clearance were observed to be posted in a prominent place. The fire extinguisher was observed to be in a prominent location and was charged, up-to-date and was last serviced in the last year.

There was a hall closet with extra blankets and linens. There was a hall closet with client activities, games, and craft items. The refrigerator and freezer and pantry held enough perishable and nonperishable food in the home in a quantity to meet the needs of the next three meals and the between meal snacks. Client medication was observed to be locked, kept separate per each client, and medication administration documentation was in compliance with CCL regulations. A complete first aid kit was observed and inventoried. The garage also contained extra food storage in the freezer and refrigerator. The garage also stored storage items, and activities. The front and backyards were observed to be well-maintained and free of debris and hazards. The backyard contained a gazebo, a table and chairs, a garden, play area, and a basketball hoop. The facility smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are present and were tested and are in working condition. The water temperature of the facility was tested at multiple sources, including two client bathroom sinks, and the kitchen sink, and was observed to measure at 128 degrees F. The licensee stated they had a new water heater installed recently and LPA observed the setting on the water heater was set to Low. The licensee stated that they will ensure the temperature is lowered and until then will purchase a thermometer to test the water temperature prior to clients bathing or showering. The facility is out of compliance with 80088(e)(1). The facility is being cited for deficiencies of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Chapter 1, section 80088(e)(1), which poses a potential. health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. See 809-D for citation and Plan of Correction information. An exit interview was conducted with Marie Yadao, Administrator. A copy of this report, and appeal rights, were reviewed and provided to Marie Yadao, Administrator.

On 12/01/22, at 10:41 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Uchenna Ajaero, met with the License Marie Yadao to conduct an unannounced Annual/ Required inspection of a single story facility. This facility is a Small Family Home. It consists of five bedrooms and two bathrooms. There are a total of four clients, one non-ambulatory client who was home, two clients share a bedroom and one female client who has a room to herself. There are a total of three live-in staff. These are the two licensees, and one Direct Care Staff. At 10:50 am, we started a walk through of the facility for the inspection. The facility was observed to be clean, organized, and free of debris and clutter. The home contained a living room, a kitchen, dining room, and multi-media/activity room. The dining room and multi-media room had a table for the clients to sit and eat, and complete activities and homework. The clients bedrooms were observed to be bright, contain an individual bed, clean linens, clothes were organized in the closet and there were multiple storage space for client property. It was observed that several documents were posted on the board for easy access. The facility license, facility sketch, emergency plan, emergency telephone numbers, and fire clearance were observed to be posted in a prominent place. The fire extinguisher was observed to be charged and up-to-date and was last serviced in the last year. In the hallway were two closets. One contained extra blankets and linens. The other one contained client activities, games, books and craft items. The refrigerator and freezer had enough food to last more than 2 days. The pantry held enough nonperishable food that will last more than 5 days. There were varieties of snacks in the home.

During the course of the inspection, LPA reviewed four client files, and observed all required documentation was present and filed. The facility did not have the current Personal Rights poster and LPA Ajaero provided them with the current copy. Interviews were not conducted with three clients because, these clients are non-verbal. There was one verbal client and he was interviewed. Interviews were conducted with three staff. Clients medications were observed to be locked. The garage contained extra food storage in the freezer and refrigerator. There were labeled boxes for office items and activities. The front and backyards were observed to be clean and well-maintained and free of debris and hazards. The backyard contained a large table with chairs, a small side garden, an open play area, and a basketball hoop. There was a locked shed at the back and it contained decorations for several seasons. The facility smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are present and were tested by the staff. LPA observed that they were in working condition. The water temperature of the facility was tested at multiple sources, including two client bathroom sinks, and the kitchen sink, and was observed to measure at 111 degrees F. An exit interview was conducted with Marie Yadao, Administrator. A copy of this report, and appeal rights, were reviewed and provided to Marie Yadao, Administrator.

On December 2, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero arrived at the above facility and met with Marie Yadao, the Licensee for the purpose of continuing the required unannounced annual inspection. LPA Ajaero completed the Personnel Review of all staff working at this facility both full time and part time staff. LPA compared them to the list of staff on Guardian who are associated with this facility and who are cleared and eligible to work in the facility and there were no discrepancies. LPA Ajaero completed the LIC 859 file review for 4 staff members ensuring their documents were up to date and in compliance. LPA Ajaero Reviewed the medications of all the youths at this facility. LPA completed the annual inspection on today's date. Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero completed an exit interview. No Title 22 citations were issued during this 2 day inspection. A copy of this report, has been provided to Marie Yadao, Licensee.

On 11/08/23, at 09:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts, (LPA) Connie Goldie and LPA Monica Roberts made an unannounced visit to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. LPAs were greeted at the door by Assistant Administrator Ludy Valdez (S2) who contacted Administrator Marie Yadao who arrived shortly after. One youth was home at the time of arrival. Administrator (A) assisted LPAs with the inspection. S2 stated the 4 clients are due home between 2:30 PM and 4:00 PM. At 10:00 AM, LPAs conducted a physical plant tour. At the front door entry, LPAs observed a copy of license, personal rights poster and fire clearance permit. LPAs observed two fire extinguishers in the home that were in compliance with pins. LPAs proceeded through living room and formal dining area. LPAs had clear access, furniture was in excellent condition and LPAs observed adequate seating for all staff and clients. In the hallway, LPAs observed activity closet, spare linen closet, individual daily schedules including meal times for each youth. The home was a comfortable 70 degrees. The home has a functioning washer and dryer that was purchased this year. Secured cabinetry above washer and dryer included chemicals. There is one dual shared bedroom and two individual bedrooms for the youth. Bedrooms were observed to have organized closets and proper bedding, good lighting and an overall clean appearance. There are two bathrooms, which have trash cans with lids, and the water temperatures recorded at 106 degrees, within compliant range of 105-120 degrees. Soap and paper products were readily available. Kitchen had a fully stocked pantry labeled with expiration dates, refrigerator and freezer with at least 2 days of perishables and 5 days of non- perishables. Emergency disaster kit with flashlight, walkie talkies and emergency food was present. First aid kit is complete. Medications and sharps were locked. All cabinets and appliances were in good working condition. P&I is secured in kitchen cabinet. Additional room off of formal dining contained double locked staff/client files, emergency disaster plan, staff schedules, incident report requirement postings and a youth corner with toys and stuffed animals. The back yard contained a locked shed with holiday decor, a basketball hoop, a dining table and chairs and vegetable garden. (Continued on LIC809-C)

LPAs observed a fence board with exposed nails, a bed frame against the fence and an unsecured base to the basketball hoop which may pose a safety risk. Administrator addressed these concerns immediately. Upon trying to enter the garage, the exit door was partially blocked by objects in storage. This is a potential safety risk. Administrator immediately cleared the door for full operation. A generator and extra storage cabinets holding food and briefs were present. Hot water heater was functioning. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. LPA's observed one youth in his bedroom, and were granted permission by youth to enter. Facility van had no inside or outside damage, insurance and registration are both current, first aid kit, spare tire and fire extinguisher were present. The ramp to aid non-ambulatory youth is in working order. The van has working seat belts and is overall clean. Care tool domains completed during todays inspection include: Physical Plant, Operations, Staffing, and Client Records. LPA Goldie also interviewed three staff members. During inspection, two Type B Title 22 deficiencies were observed. See 809-D. Additionally, two technical violations and one technical assistance will be issued. These are not deficiencies. LPA will return to complete annual on a subsequent visit. Exit interview was conducted at 4:00 PM with Ms. Yadao. A copy of this report along with appeal rights were discussed and provided.

On 09/12/2024, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts, (LPAs) Connie Goldie, Elena Gonzalez-Soto and Jean Stidman made an unannounced case management inspection. Three staff are present and one client. Marie Yadao, Administrator assisted with the inspection. LPA's conducted a walk through of the three bedroom, 2 bath home inside and outside. The tour began in the family room. LPA's observed confidential information, Client registrar and Staff Guardian information, on the bulletin board in a public viewing area. LPA Stidman requested these documents be relocated to the office to protect client and staff confidentiality. LPA's observed a live-in staff bedroom and administrator bedroom. We went to the backyard and observed a shed with holiday decor secured. Behind the shed is a gate. Both side yards were free of debris. LPA's observed kitchen to have adequate perishables and non-perishables. LPA's observed dining area and living room to have adequate seating and lighting. LPA's observed one dual bedroom with appropriate furniture. Bathroom number one was observed to have a hole created by door handle. LPA suggested placing a plate to cover the hole and safeguard the wall. LPA observed laundry area cabinets to be unsecured and to have bleach accessible. LPAs observed bedroom number two to have appropriate linens and furniture in place. LPA's observed hanging cords/extension cord next to dresser in bedroom three that poses a safety hazard. Ms. Yadao stated the lamp would be relocated to remedy this safety issue. Three staff interviews were conducted. A record review of LIC622 forms was conducted. LPAs observed 3 of 4 residents (C1, C2, C3 ) missing centrally stored forms for September 2024 and 1 resident (C4) was missing July, August and September 2024. The facility was cited for four Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6 regulations; Buildings and Grounds 80087(a) and 80087(g) and Client Records 80070(c) and 80075(b)(10). Please see LIC 809-D for the deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted with the above administrator and a plan of correction was completed. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were given during the inspection.

deficiencies.description:
Buildings and Grounds 80087 (a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and interview, the licensee did not ensure safety as a hanging cord/extension cord was in bedroom three and there is a hole in the bathroom wall behind the door which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will  submit photos of repaired wall and safely secured cords by POC due date to LPA Goldie via email.

deficiencies.description:
Buildings and Grounds 80087(g) Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, poisons, firearms and other items that could pose a danger if readily available to clients shall be stored where inaccessible to clients.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and interview, the licensee did not ensure chemicals were secured over the washer and dryer which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will submit photos and ensure the cabintry locks are functioning. Administrator will lock laundry door until the cabinet locks are replaced. Administrator will provide receipt of purchase to the Department by POC due date via email to LPA Goldie

deficiencies.description:
Client Records 80070(c) All information and records obtained from or regarding clients shall be confidential.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and interview the client registrar was observed to be in a public location in the home which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will place the child roster in the emergency binder. LPA observed that it was relocated.

deficiencies.description: Client Records 80075 (b)Each record must contain information including, but not limited to, the following: (10) Record of current medications..and instructions, if any, regarding control and custody of medications. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and interview, it was observed that 3 of 4 residents C1, C2 and C3 did not have centrally stored forms for September 2024 and C4 is Missing July - September 2024 which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will provide copies of September 2024 documentation by close of business 09/13/2024 to the Department via email.

narrative:
On 12/16/2024, at 10:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced visit to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Direct Support Professional Editha Baybayan (S1) who contacted Administrator Marie Yadao who arrived shortly after. One youth was home at the time of arrival. Administrator (A) assisted LPA with the inspection. Administrator stated the 4 clients are due home early today as it is a early out day for school. At 10:50 AM, LPA conducted a physical plant tour. At the front door entry, LPA observed a copy of license, personal rights poster and fire clearance permit. LPA observed two fire extinguishers in the home that were in compliance. LPA proceeded through living room and formal dining area with adequate seating for all staff and clients. In the hallway, LPA observed an activity closet and a linen closet. The home was a comfortable 71 degrees. In the laundry room,.secured cabinetry is located above washer and dryer which stores chemicals. There is one dual shared bedroom and two individual bedrooms for the youth. Bedrooms were observed to have organized closets and proper bedding, good lighting and an overall clean appearance. There are two bathrooms, which have trash cans with lids, and the water temperatures recorded at 107.9 degrees, within compliant range of 105-120 degrees. Soap and paper products were readily available. Kitchen had at least 2 days of perishables and 5 days of non- perishables and a menu is posted. Emergency disaster kit with flashlight, walkie talkies and emergency food was present. First aid kit is complete. Medications and sharps were secured as required. P& I is secured in a kitchen cabinet. Additional room off of formal dining contained double locked staff/client files, emergency disaster plan, staff schedules, incident report requirement postings and a youth corner with toys and stuffed animals. The back yard contained a locked shed with holiday decor, a basketball hoop and a dining table and chairs. LPA observed van to have tires with appropriate tread, working headlights, turn indicators and seat belts. Continued on LIC809C

Smoke/carbon-monoxide detector tested and compliant. Care tool domains completed during today's inspection include: Physical Plant, Operations, Staffing, and Special Health Care Needs. LPA Goldie interviewed five staff members and one client. No deficiencies were cited during today's inspection. LPA will return to complete Annual inspection on a later date. Exit interview conducted at 3:45 PM and reports were discussed and provided to facility.

On 12/19/2024, at 11:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie met with Program Administrator (PA) Marie Yadao to continue unannounced/required Annual inspection. PA stated that two staff and one client are currently in the facility. Three clients are at school. Care Tool domain client records was completed during today's inspection. During inspection, one Type B Title 22 deficiency was observed. See LIC809-D. One technical violation was issued. This is not a deficiency. Annual inspection has been completed upon receiving plan of corrections. LPA conducted exit interview with Ms.Yadao at 2:15 PM. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was left at the facility.

On 06/03/2021 at 10:15 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) M. Lopez conducted an unannounced annual required Inspection. LPA met with co-licensee/Administrator Arturo Lopez who led the tour of Angels Haven Small Family Home(SFH). LPA inspected the facility interior and exterior. There were two clients one female and one male residing at this facility three guardianship children reside in the home. The home is a six-bedroom and a four and half-bathroom home, and it is set up as follows: • Bedroom 1 had 2 twin-size bed and sleeps two guardianship children. • Bedroom 2 had 2 twin- size bed and sleeps one client and one vacancy. • Bedroom 3 had 1 twin-size bed and a modified crib. It sleeps one client and one guardianship child • Bedroom 4 was the licensee master bedroom and sleeps licensee and spouse (co-licensee). • Bedroom 5 was the licensee’s biological son’s room and sleeps one biological son. • Bedroom 6 was the staff room with 3 single beds. . Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room and each bedroom includes adequate drawers and closet space for two children’s belongings. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible and locked in laundry room where children will not have access. Medications were locked in the medication closet. Cleansers/chemicals were stored in a locked laundry room. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen above the oven. The first aid kit was accessible and had all the required items. Facility has non-perishable foods for more than one week and perishable food for more than two days. There were no guns or weapons as stated by the administrator at this time. Water temperature was tested and was safe at 113. Smoke detectors in all rooms were tested and operable. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The Emergency Disaster Plan, Facility Sketch and Title 22 Personal Rights were posted at this time.

The backyard was fenced with a wrought iron self-closing fence surrounding the pool. The access gate swings away from the body of water. The height of the wrought iron fence is 60", spacing horizontal bars is 56" apart, and it's 2" from the ground on hard surface. The pool was in compliance with the title 22 Regulations. Two client files were reviewed including the Medication Administration Record (See Confidential Name List- LIC 811 dated on June 06, 2021). Two staff files were reviewed and facility personnel meet staff qualification and training requirements. Licensee’s and staff’s CPR and First Aid card were current and will expire in 2022 and 2023. Children and staff records are organized. All staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances. There is no deficiency observed during today’s visit. The home is in compliance with Title 22 Regulation. An exit interview was conducted and this report was reviewed with co-licensee/Administrator Arturo Lopez and a copy of this report was provided.

On July 25, 2022 at 11:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson made an unannounced visit to the facility for an annual/required visit. LPA met with Licensees Christine French and Arturo Lopez, who accompanied LPA on a tour of facility. LPA inspected the facility interior and exterior. There are three clients residing at this facility. Also, two guardianship children residing at the facility. One staff was interviewed. Clients are unavailable to be interviewed. LPA reviewed client records, staff files, clients’ medication log, current disaster plan, client roster, first aid kit and smoke alarms were checked and operable. The water temperature reading at 106. There is a sufficient amount of perishable, nonperishable foods and snacks available. There is a sufficient amount of Jevity Enteral and Peptamen formula for clients. Menu was posted. Area evaluated were kitchen sharp items and knives are kept in a locked cabinet in the kitchen above the oven. The cleaning supplies and toxic were stored are locked in the laundry room. The bedroom had adequate storage for clothing. Medications are locked in a closet near the living room. Age appropriate games and activities are available for clients and Personal Rights are posted. Licensee Arturo Lopez stated there are no weapons or firearms in the facility. LPA observed in the pool area, a 5ft. 2 inches wrought iron fence that surrounds the entire pool area, the access gate swings away from the body of water, a self- closing and self- latching device closed on its own. Based on observations made during the inspection, no deficiencies observed during today’s visit. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was given to Licensee Arturo Lopez.

The following documents are posted in the facility: facility license, facility sketch, menu and personal rights. A review of Guardian on June 21,2023 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse index check clearances. The following documents are posted in the facility: facility license, facility sketch, menu and personal rights.

Licensee Arturo Lopez stated there are no weapons or firearms in the facility. LPA observed in the pool area, a 5ft. 2 inches wrought iron fence that surrounds the entire pool area, the access gate swings away from the body of water, a self- closing and self- latching device closed on its own. Based on observations made during the inspection, no deficiencies observed during today’s visit. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was given to Licensee Arturo Lopez.

On June 27, 2025 at 12:18 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an unannounced annual required Inspection. LPA met with Christine French, Administrator who provided LPA with an indoor and outdoor tour of the facility. The home is a six-bedroom and a four and half-bathroom, with living room, dinning room, kitchen, and medication closet. Two bedrooms are for client use. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room and each bedroom includes adequate drawers and closet space for children’s belongings. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. Water temperature was tested in the client bathroom to be at 105. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible and locked in laundry room where children will not have access. Medications were locked in the medication closet. The first aid kit was accessible and had all the required items. Cleansers/chemicals were stored in a locked laundry room. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. There are adequate supplies of Katefarms Pediatric and Peptamen nutrition formulas for clients that are feed to G-Tube. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher are properly charged and serviced. CONTINUED....

Facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured with a wrought iron fence. The enclosure was measured to be 5 feet with a self-latching gate that swings outward. Per facility administrator there are no firearms in the home. LPA observed the following items posted: Grievance Procedures, Emergency Disaster, Facility Sketch, Personal Rights, Rights of Individual with Developmental Disabilities, COVID guidelines and Facility License. LPA reviewed five out of five staff files and three out of three client files. LPA conducted one staff interview. LPA was unable to interview three clients due to their limited verbal abilities. Based on today's inspection there are no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this signed report was provided to Christine French, Administrator.

On August 20, 2025, at 09:20 a.m., a Component II orientation was conducted at the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program Regional Office with Angie's Small Family Home's (SFH's) applicant Angela Silva. Present for the Department were Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Brent Lockhart, Amber Hunter, John Bonilla, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jean Herring. The purpose of the meeting was to review and discuss the facility's Application Instructions for a Facility License (LIC281) submission. LPAs and LPM went over Section A Licensing Forms and Section B Supportive Documents of the Licensee's application that were missing forms, needed corrections and /or revisions. LPA Bonilla instructed Licensee to make corrections and/or revisions to the appropriate sections of the application (Sections A and B) and then resubmit to LPA via email on or before September 5, 2025. LPA Bonilla advised the applicant that all documents including Section B revisions will be reviewed by LPM Jean Herring. Exit interview conducted. Meeting adjourned.

On April 14, 2025, at 10 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Butler, arrived at Anne Kariuki Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Applicant, Anne Kariuki who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior of the home was conducted. Currently living in the home is the Applicant, her husband, 1 biological child, and 2 adopted. The home is set up as follows: This is a 6 bedrooms, 3 bathrooms 2 story home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, family room, dining room, breakfast nook, kitchen, laundry area, loft area with a pool table sectional couch, TV, and desk, gated pool, and an attached garage. Living room: is equipped with 2 couches, love seat, coffee table, mounted TV. The living room also has sliding glass patio doors leading to the backyard. Dining room: is equipped with glass table with 6 chairs. Breakfast noon has a table with 4 chairs. Family Room: is equipped with 2 couches, love seat, 2 coffee tables, mounted tv, and fireplace with a screen. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a 6 burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), microwave, and a dishwasher. Sharp knives are kept in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. LPA observed a covered trash can, cabinet space, plates, cups, and eating utensils. LPA observed perishable food items in the refrigerator, and non-perishable food items. The Applicant will ensure that 3 nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to the clients. Continued on LIC 809-C

Laundry room: is located downstairs. Bedroom #1: {Upstairs} Applicant's son's bedroom has a full bed, dresser, closet space, working lights, and windows. Bedroom #2: {Upstairs} Applicant's daughters bedroom has 1 twin size beds, toddler bed, dresser space, closet space, working lights, and windows. Bedroom #3: {Upstairs} vacant: 2 twin beds, dresser space, closet space, working lights, and windows. Bedroom #4: {Upstairs} vacant: queen bed, crib, dresser, working lights, and windows. Bedroom #5: {Upstairs} Applicant's bedroom has king bed, crib, tv, closet, dresser, working lights, windows, and attached bathroom. Bedroom # {Downstairs} vacant: full bed, dresser, closet space, working lights, and windows. LPA found all bathrooms to be clean and in working order. The hot water was tested and found to be with 105-120 (F). Backyard: Equipped with a gated pool, 2 locked sheds, and back yard area. Attached garage: with 2 cars and additional refrigerator. Vehicle: The Applicant will use a 2000 Sienna Toyata, and the insurance is valid through December 2025 Continued on LIC 809-C

The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. Medications will be kept locked in the dining room, and medications requiring refrigeration will be in a locked refrigerator in the garage. The home’s temperature is maintained by central air/heating. LPA observed 2 fully charged fire extinguisher. Extra linens are stored in the linen closet upstairs. The smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. First Aid kit was found to be be complete. The home has alarms on the front l doors and the monitoring device is located in the Applicant's bedroom. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. LPA reminded Licensee to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Applicant will ensure grievance process, Disaster Plan, Discipline policies and procedures will be posted in living room area. During the inspection, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. LPA informed applicant that a Component II meeting will be held on April 22nd at 2:00 p.m. via Tele Orientation. Fingerprints for all adults and persons helping with the care of the clients in care will need to be completed. Applicant will camera's to the Program Statement.. Continued on LIC 809 C

Applicant informed that the following corrections will need to be made. hole in door in bedroom #4 needs to be repaired applicant needs to create a Guardian account Fire Department needs to conduct an inspection of the home applicant will remove the wood near the table in the back yard An exit interview was conducted. A copy of report will be emailed to Applicant,Anne Kariuki at agmugi407@gmail.com.

On April 22, 2025, at 2 PM, a Component II Office Visit was held to discuss the application received for Anne Kariuki Small Family Home located at 30056 Penrose Lane Castaic, CA 91384. Attending Component II were the following individuals: Anne Kariuki, Applicant, Erika Butler, Licensing Program Analyst. The purpose of this Component II meeting was to review and discuss the incomplete application and Program Statement and to resolve any outstanding concerns that may have existed. Program Statement Applicant needs to revise the Program Statement. Email revisions to erika.butler@dss.ca.gov. The Applicant's fingerprints and fire inspection are pending. A copy of this report will be emailed to the Applicant, Anne Kariuki.

On May 5, 2025, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Erika Butler conducted a Small Family Home (SFH) Component III office meeting with Applicant, Anne Kariuki . LPA Butler met with Applicant to discuss forms required to be maintained, available, and posted at the facility for inspections. We discussed child and personnel records that are required to be documented, retained and available for inspection. We also discussed specific requirements, concerns and issues operating a SFH, such as, reporting requirements, personnel requirements, supervision, intake issues, compatibility, removal/discharge policies, complaint procedures, transportation, health services, food, hygiene, visitation, personal property, searches, and community sensitivity. Licensing of facility is pending final approval due to fire clearance, and revisions to Program Statement. A copy of this report was provided to the Applicant, Anne Kariuki.

On June 13, 2025, at 2:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Orlando Areizaga and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez met with Applicant, Annie Kihonge for the purposes of conducting a Component II in-person Meeting at the Sacramento Regional Office. The following topics were discussed: Applicant currently has a Family Resource Home ran by the county. Applicant currently has 3 children from the county. Annie can only accept Developmentally Delayed Client from the Regional Center. LPM Rodriguez explained the option for Annie. Option 1 to continue the application process and potentially be denied and not be able to apply for 2 years. Option 2 to withdraw from the application process to then reapply at anytime. Applicant, decided to withdraw their application. LPA Areizaga printed a copy of the LIC 281 and LPA's notes of the program statement review. Applicant will send LPA an email with the official notice of withdraw. At the time LPA will ensure the application is withdraw from the system. A copy of this report was discussed with Applicant, Annie Kihonge and a copy of this report was printed.

LPA gave a copy of the LIC 184, Notice of Application Revision, and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed to the application. On April 16, 2025, at 9:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adaleyci Caballero completed a pre-licensing inspection of Anza Small Family Home (SFH). LPA met with Applicant Ashley Trino who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. There are no clients in placement. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and three full bathrooms which are set up as follows: Bedroom #1- It consisted of two single beds.The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. Bedroom #2- It consisted of two single beds. The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. Bedroom #3- It consisted of two queen beds. The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep applicants' bio children. Bedroom #4- It consisted of one king bed. It will sleep applicants. Bedroom #5(first floor)- It consisted of one full bed. The bedrooms serves as a guest bedroom. A living room, kitchen, dining room, loft, laundry room, office, three car garage, and a backyard. The garage will be utilized for storage.

The clients' bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the clients' belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom. The seven smoke detectors were checked and working properly. Smoke Detector and Carbon Monoxide detectors are combined. The home’s central air conditioning module was in the backyard. The water heater was in the garage. The appliances were in working order. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of perishable food and non-perishable food. The home had a trash can for storage of solid waste inside a sliding cabinet. The hot water was at a temperature of 107.2 degrees Fahrenheit. There was two fire extinguishers present in the home located in the dining room and upstairs hallway. It was observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. There are no firearms in the home. There is an empty pool at the home that will not be utilized and will be enclosed by a wooden fence. The backyard is fully fenced and free of debris. The home has eight cameras on the outside premise of the home.

Corrections to be made: Client and staff files needed. Client safeguard for cash resources. Sharp knives, chemicals, and medications need to be locked and inaccessible to clients in care. First Aid kit with all required supplies. Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610), Personal Rights, Grievance procedures, Visitation Policies, and Activity and Food Schedules need to be posted. Picture of wooden fence to enclose empty pool. Camera Usage added to Program Statement PIN 24-09-CRP An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to applicant Ashley Trino. Application will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager Abdoulaye Traore once corrections are submitted to LPA.

On July 29, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adaleyci Caballero conducted a Component III with applicants Ashley Trino and Caleb Reid as part of the Small Family Home application process. On June 17, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez met with applicants David and Elizabeth Arko-Mensah this date for a Component II. On August 13, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Arko-Mensah Small Family Home for a pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with David and Elizabeth Arko-mensah who led a tour of the entire home. The applicants are applying to serve three ambulatory clients ages 0-17 years old. Currently there are no clients in care. The home is a two story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms. The entry way consisted of a living room with couches, a dining room with a large table, a poster board with facility sketch and non-discrimination notices, and musical keyboard. There was a family room with couches, TV, and a screened fireplace, a kitchen with a fire extinguisher, a dining table, first aid kit with all required elements, a locked cabinet storing cleaning supplies/chemicals. The pantry and refrigerator were fully stocked with perishable and non-perishable foods. Bathroom#1 was fully functioning with a toilet and shower/ bath tub however the water temperature was measuring 130.8 degrees Fahrenheit. Applicants understand that the water temperature needs to be between 105-120 degrees F. Bedroom #1 was also downstairs and was utilized for applicants biological daughter and was fully furnished with a full size bed. The upstairs had an office that had a desk, a locked cabinet for storing clients files/ personnel records, several lockers for storing, medication, client cash resources/ personal property, and another first aid kit. There was a poster board with emergency disaster plan, personal rights, daily activities schedule, complaint flyer posted. There was bathroom #2 that had dual sinks that were both functioning, a toilet, and shower/tub. Bedroom #2 had two twin size beds with dresser/closet space, a desk and all required bedding that will be utilized for two clients- currently vacant. Bedroom #3 was for applicants biological son and was fully furnished with a full size bed. There was a loft with books and extra household items. Bedroom #4 was

the master bedroom for applicants that was locked at all times and fully furnished with a king size bed and bathroom #3. The laundry room was accessible to clients but did not have proper storage for locked detergents/bleach. LPA observed there to be two beds for client use which is not sufficient enough for the capacity of three that the applicant is applying for. Applicant understands there needs to be adjustments made to LIC200. All bedrooms were arranged for one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There was no pool or other bodies of water. There was a side gate that had a latch for an emergency exit. The garage stored extra household items, an extra refrigerator that will store client medication in a lock box, and two deep freezer for frozen goods. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. As stated by applicants, there were no weapons/firearms in the home. All trash cans had tight fitting lids. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: Request for a capacity decrease on LIC200 Telephone land line service Water temperature to be between 105-120 degrees F Locked cabinet in laundry room for detergents After corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA so that the request for licensure can be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Component III orientation was also completed this day of August 13, 2025. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicants Elizabeth and David Arko Mensah.

On 12/02/2020 at 02:30 p.m., due to COVID 19, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez conducted a tele-inspection with Licensee Maria Arroyo to conduct a case management inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an incident that occurred on November 29, 2020. During the inspection, LPA toured the facility, reviewed a child file information, and conducted confidential interview with licensee. Information related to the incident was obtained. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPA advised licensee to resubmit a written incident report to Community Care Licensing and provide supporting documents discussed. A copy of this report was emailed to Licensee Maria Arroyo with "read receipt" notification to verify that the licensee received the LIC809. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.

On January 18, 2022 at 9:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez conducted an unannounced annual/required inspection to the facility. LPA met with licensee Maria Arroyo who accompanied LPA on a tour of the facility. There are two female clients in care and are non-ambulatory (bedridden) and non-verbal. LPA inspected the facility interior and exterior. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The living room consists of a television with a spacious living room and large couch. The facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. Both clients residing at the facility are fed by G-Tube and fed per doctor orders of time & frequency. The facility has over two weeks supply of G-Tube Feedings(Pediasure & Replete-Fiber.) The facility has air conditioner throughout the house and maintained at a comfortable temperature. Hot water temperature measures 115.0 degrees. Licensee stated there are no weapons or firearms at facility. Medications are locked and centrally stored in kitchen cabinet. First Aid kit is located in kitchen cabinet. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, mattress covers and mattresses are in good repair. LPA observed clean bath towels, and washcloths available for clients. The cleaning solutions and toxic chemicals are locked in the cabinet in the locked laundry room. The are no pools at the facility. LPA observed in the backyard a 6ft high chain link fence that surrounds the horse corral. LPA observed in the horse corral, three automatic water dispensers, installed on the fence inside the horse stalls that are inaccessible to clients. (see continuation form LIC9099-C dated 01/18/22)

LPA reviewed Physical Plant, Operations, Disaster Preparedness, and Emergency Intervention. LPA conducted staff and client file reviews and interviews. LPA conducted 1 of 1 staff interviews, 1 of 1 staff file reviews, 0 of 0 client interviews and 2 of 2 client file reviews. Based on record review of 2 of 2 client files, the licensee did not maintain a written authorization of the child's (C1 & C2) parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. The facility is being issued a citation in accordance with the Title 22, Section 83070(b) (11). See LIC809-D dated 01/18/22 for the cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and this report, appeal rights and LIC 811 was reviewed with Licensee Maria Arroyo.
