On April 18, 2025 at 8:50 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui arrived unannounced to the facility and met with Maria Arroyo for the purpose of conducting a Case Management inspection to check on the health and safety of the clients in care. No immediate deficiencies were observed or cited during today's case management inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Maria Arroyo, Licensee.

On November 22, 2022 Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Babatunde Aborchie, Karen Beal and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore met with applicant Muhammed Ziblim this date for a Component II. LPAs and LPM went over revisions needed for the application prior to licensure. LPAs and LPM gave a copy of the LIC 184, Notice of Incomplete Application, and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed to complete the application. Copy of this report was provided to applicant.

On December 23, 2022 at 10:15 AM, a pre-licensing inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie. LPA met with Licensees Muhammed Ziblim and Asana Mutawakil. The purpose of the visit was to evaluate the facility for a possible license for a small family home of capacity of two ambulatory children for downstairs bedroom as requested by Licensees. The licensees are requesting to be licensed for a small family home with capacity to serve a total of two ambulatory children. During this inspection, LPA and Licensees inspected the facility inside and out. The home consists of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1, It was furnished with two twin beds. It will sleep two clients. It is currently vacant There were also a family room, a living room, dining area, a closet, a pantry and one bathroom. Upstairs: Bedroom #2, Master bedroom. The room consisted of one Cal king sized bed. It sleeps the applicants/Licensees Bedroom #3, The room was furnished with a full-sized bed. It sleeps a biological daughter age 8 years. Bedroom #4, The room was furnished with a full-sized bed. It sleeps a biological son age 10 years.

Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. Inside the facility the fireplace was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in the kitchen cabinet area above the refrigerator. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the garage cabinet. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in the locked cabinet in the kitchen. There were no guns or weapons as stated by applicants at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 110 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit were accessible with all required items and it was in the kitchen cabinet. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request to be licensed for a small family home will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Applicants/Licensees

Regarding the allegation that LS1 was forcing religions traditions onto FC1, a confidential interview stated LS1 did not force any religion traditions onto FC1. The confidential interview further stated that FC1 had freedom of religion. Another confidential interview was not specific if FC1 was asked to take on religion traditions or not. Additional confidential interview did not believe LS1 was imposing religion traditions on FC1. Additional confidential interview stated FC1 was allowed to practice FC1’s preferred religion. The allegation that LS1 did not afford FC1 privacy. It was specifically stated that LS1 came into the room at 1 AM. A confidential interview denied LS1 did not afford FC1 privacy. Confidential interview stated LS1 was not in FC1’s room. Another confidential interview believed FC1 was not provided privacy. The confidential interview further stated it was a rule to leave the door cracked. Additional confidential interview denied LS1 did not afford FC1 privacy. Additional confidential interview revealed FC1 had a health issue needing additional attention, therefore, FC1’s door was cracked for safety reasons. Based on confidential interviews and observations, the allegations that LS1 was forcing religion traditions onto FC1 and LS1 did not afford FC1 privacy, may have occurred, however, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report, and LIC 811 was reviewed and provided to licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On July 12, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Asana Small Family Home and met with the licensee Muhammed Ziblim to deliver investigative finding involving the small family home and the client listed in the confidential names (LIC 811). On September 15, 2023, at 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at the small family home to initiate the investigation and conducted interviews with licensees 1 and 2 (LS1 and LS2), foster child (FC1) LPA was unable to interview County Social Worker (CSW). On September 11, 2023, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging licensee was forcing religion traditions onto FC1and licensee did not afford FC1 privacy.

narrative:
On January 22, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Asana Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct an annual required inspection. LPA met with Licensee Asana Mutawakil who granted access into the home. Currently, there are no clients placed in the home but the home is licensed for a capacity of 2. The Facility was toured both inside and out with licensee. The home is a two story home and consists of the downstairs to have a dining room with a couch, television and a dining table. There is one client bedroom that is currently vacant that has two twin size beds to sleep two clients with closet and storage space. There is a fully functioning bathroom. There is also a closet that stores extra waters and tissues along with non-hazardous house supplies . The hallway leading to kitchen hold personal rights and SFH license. The living room is fully furnished with couch, television, fireplace that is properly screened, and games for children. The kitchen has a fully stocked refrigerator and pantry holding perishable and non-perishable foods, locked/stored away sharps, and a fire extinguisher that needs to be replaced for current year. The garage stores parked cars and storage and extra refrigerators/ freezers with stored foods. The upstairs consists of one master bedroom with king size bed and master bathroom, there is a office area, and hallway area storing books. There is a fully functioning bathroom and 2 bedrooms for biological children. The backyard is clear of any hazards or debris and is enclosed with a side gate that has a latch. Based on LPA's observation, the facility is cited for violation of Title 22, division six, chapter 4, regulation 83088(h) Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies: The licensee shall keep at least one operational fire extinguisher in the home, as required by Title 24, Part 9, of the California Fire Code. See LIC809D

LPA interviewed 2 licensees and 0 clients as there is no clients placed in the home. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the LIC 809D and 1 technical assistance was reviewed and provided to licensee.

On 4/20/2022, at 9:47 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA), Connie Goldie arrived at the facility to conduct an unannounced annual inspection. LPA Goldie made contact with licensee at 10:49 AM and licensee arrived at facility at 11:15 AM. LPA Goldie met with Program Administrator (PA)Marie Ysbelle Reyes . PA stated that current census is four clients and that three are at school and one is present. PA participated in a telephone zoom call at 11:30 AM with client's physician and LPA Goldie opened inspection tool and began file review. LPA Goldie conducted a tour with the PA of the facility inside and out. The tour began at the entrance of the home at 11:45 AM. LPA Goldie observed facility license, emergency plan, Client's personal rights poster along with all required posted documents, fire extinguisher up to date with pin and functioning smoke detector. The temperature on the thermostat was comfortable at 70 degrees. At 11:50 , LPA Goldie observed the laundry room with cleaning supplies stored in locked cabinetry. The tour moved to the kitchen where LPA Goldie observed five days of non-perishables in the pantry and two days perishables in the refrigerator and freezer. LPA Goldie requested PA to open locked cabinets at 12:00 PM and observed that the medication cabinet was unlocked. LPA Goldie asked what happened. PA stated, "I just opened it to get out medication for the doctor's appointment." LPA confirmed with PA that the cabinet was not locked after returning medication to cabinet and that this would result in a citation. The tour moved to the dining area at 12:07 PM where LPA Goldie observed a table with six chairs that was well-lit. The living room area had adequate seating and a calendar for the clients to view for educational purposes. At 12:10 PM, LPA observed a shared bedroom including two beds with clean linen, two dressers and a shared large desk for two. The closet was a walk in closet shared by the clients. Attached is a bathroom that has a walk in shower, soap and towels, hygiene products for C1 and C2 and water temperature was tested and read 105 degrees, The tour continued to two additional bedrooms each containing a bed with clean linens, dresser, desk and closet. The second bathroom also contained soap, towels and hygiene products for C3 and C4. At 12:20 PM, LPA observed garage to have additional cleaning supplies that were in locked storage. continued on LIC 809

The backyard was clear of debris and had activity equipment for the clients. LPA Goldie reviewed client files with PA. Additionally, LPA Goldie interviewed C1 and S1, S2 and S3. One deficiency is being cited today fro m Title 22 Regulations, See 809D for specifics. An exit interview was conducted, report was provided and appeal rights were discussed and left at the facility.

On 04/22/22, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie met with Program Administrator, (PA) Marie Ysbelle Reyes for the purpose of continuing the required Annual inspection. LPA Goldie reviewed with PA 1 Program Administrator record and 2 DSP staff records and completed the inspection tool. LPA Goldie observed that all records reviewed were in compliance. No citations are being issued today. An exit interview was conducted at 11:10 AM, report was provided and appeal rights were discussed and left at the facility.

On 09/09/2022, at 3:07 PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced case management visit. Program Administrator (PA) Marie Reyes assisted with the inspection. Currently PA, one staff and one client are present. LPA Goldie conducted a tour of the home at 3:20 PM. LPA observed a four bedroom, two bath home, a kitchen with 2 days non-perishable and 5 days non-perishable food with additional food in refrigerator in garage, dining area with adequate seating, spacious living room and laundry room with locked cabinetry for cleaning supplies. Outside in the backyard, LPA observed a basketball hoop and a debris free environment. LPA Goldie interviewed two staff regarding incident report involving altercation between two clients. LPA Goldie talked with 4 of the youth. All youth were happy and calm. (3 youth arrived after visit began.) No deficiencies were observed. Case Management closed. An exit interview was conducted at 4:40 PM. A copy of this report along with appeal rights was left at the home.

On August 17, 2023 at 11:15 A.M. Licensing Program Analyst Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility and conducted an unannounced annual facility inspection. Upon arrival, there was no response at the front door. LPA Verna contacted the Marie Reyes, Facility Licensee who then arrived at the facility at 11:45 A.M. LPA met with, Marie Reyes, Facility Licensee and announced the reason for the inspection. Facility Licensee assisted LPA with the inspection. LPA and the Licensee conducted a joint inspection of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant. The facility is licensed for a capacity of 4 ambulatory clients, ages 0 to 17 years old, including developmentally disabled/medically fragile clients. There was one client present at the time of the inspection. The home is one story and consists of four bedrooms, three single occupancy bedrooms and one double occupancy bedroom, and has two bathrooms, a garage, and a backyard with no swimming pool or pond. The home had a kitchen, dining room, laundry room and living room. There are no cameras utilized in the home. The facility license was posted in a prominent place, on the wall in the living room. The home had an Emergency Disaster plan, Facility Sketch, Client Personal Rights postings, Client menu, Client Daily Schedule, and a calendar of activities were posted in a prominent location in the facility. The living room contained two couches, and along with a television. There was a hall closet off of the kitchen and living room which stored toys and games. The kitchen contained a working landline phone. The home did not have a fireplace. LPA observed that the dining area was off of the kitchen and the table was set up for six and contained six chairs. LPA observed that the kitchen area was located off the dining and living room area of the facility and that the kitchen area had the stove, oven, dishwasher, microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The kitchen cabinets and drawers contained ample dishes, utensils, and cooking supplies. The sharps and cleaning chemicals were in locked cabinets. The pantry was located off of the kitchen in the entryway, with no lock on the door. continued on 809-c

LPA observed sufficient amounts of food in the pantry, refrigerator and freezer and fresh fruit on the counter for the number of clients in care. Supplies of staple nonperishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days. Fresh fruits were observed on the kitchen counter. The front and back yards were free of clutter; and the passageways and egress were unobstructed. No potentially hazardous items or areas were observed in the outdoor spaces. The backyard contains a seating areas with table, multiple chairs, and umbrella shades to shade from the sun. There were no locks on the side yard fence, and the side yard contains trash cans, and a lawn mower. The garage contained storage cabinets and storage supplies for clients in care. Clients are not given access to the garage. LPA observed that the facility has four bedroom, and each had a bed(s) and bedding including mattress cover, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket, and pillows, dressers with drawers for personal items, lighting and ample closet or storage space. Windows and screens were in good repair. There were two bathrooms observed in the facility. One bathroom was located in a client bedroom, and the other bathroom was located in the hallway. The bathrooms had a working toilet, shower/tub, and sink faucet. The water temperature was measured to be at 110 degrees Fahrenheit. The bathrooms contained soap and paper towels for hand washing. There were hand washing signs posted in the facility. Hygiene supplies were observed in the bathrooms for clients use. The hallway contained a laundry room, with cabinets. Cleaning supplies and detergents were locked in the cabinets. Cabinets also stored extra PPE supplies. Trash cans with lids were observed in the bathrooms and kitchen. It was observed that the hallway bathroom had wooden baseboard and dry wall that was soft to the touch, deteriorating internally, and in need of repair. continued on 809-c

LPA observed working Carbon Monoxide and smoke detectors, and they were tested and in working condition. LPA observed that there was a fire extinguisher in the hallway. The fire extinguishers were charged and last inspected in January 2023. The fire clearance was posted, and conducted in February 2017 and a copy was provided to LPA. LPA observed the first aid kit were stored in the kitchen. The confidential client medication, files and staff files were stored in a locked filing cabinet. LPA reviewed a total of five staff files and four client files. During the review of staff files LPA Verna observed: Two out of five staff records did not contain record of a completed criminal record statement, and one out of five records did not contain record of employee rights (S2); It was observed that five out of five staff files did not contain the driver’s license number for staff and one out of five staff files did not contain a Personnel Record (S3); two out of five records did not contain a mandated reporter statement (S2 and S3); five out of five staff records, including the Licensee’s, did not contain record of required training completed pertaining to the topics: California Student Safety and Violence Prevention Act of 2000, cultural competency, sexual and reproductive health services and information, contraception methods, some topics described in Section 16501.4(d) of the Welfare and Institutions Code, including substance use disorder and mental health treatments, including how to access those treatments and Reasonable and Prudent Parent Standard. continued on 809-c

During the review of client files LPA Verna observed: The facility maintained a register of clients, however it was observed that the register of clients was missing required information including client's restricted health information, ambulatory status, and physician address; and four out of four client files did not include a list of persons authorized to take the child from the home. It was determined through observation and interviews that the facility does not have or maintain a current written disaster and mass casualty plan. They do however, complete emergency disaster drills every six months with staff and at new hire. LPA Verna conducted three interviews. The facility is being issued three citations related to deficiencies to ILS section 83187(f), Building and Grounds; Title 22 section 80066(e), Personnel Records, and 80023(a), Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan. See 809-D for POC information. The facility is also being issued nine Technical Advisories related to the inspection, and pertaining to: Title 22 regulations sections, 80071(a); 80066(a)(2); 83064(f); 83064(g); 83064(h); 83064(i); 83064(j); and 83070(b)(6); and PEN 11165.7(c)(1). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to Marie Reyes, Facility Licensee.

On April 25, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jean Stidman and Angelique Hill made an unannounced annual inspection at 11:30 am. During the inspection LPAs met with Marie Ysbelle Reyes, Licensee who assisted with the inspection. LPAs conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. Facility staff-client ratio at time of inspection two staff and one client were present during the inspection. During the inspection, two more staff and three more clients arrived. LPAs observed home is one story facility with four bedrooms and two bathrooms. LPAs inspected and/or reviewed the following: Physical Plant Posting of license_ok_ Personal Rights_ok_ Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions inaccessible_ok_ Refrigerator Temperature at or below 45 degrees F _40.5 degrees Freezer Temperature at or below 0 degrees -7 degrees Nonperishable Foods one week and fresh perishable foods two days minimum_ok_ Menu present and posted_ok_ Working telephone _ok_Common Room available_ok_ Dining area (enough seating, furniture good condition, not broke or damaged) N/A Hot Water between 105-120 degree F (Properly labeled if over 125 degree F) 119 degrees Fire Extinguisher charged January 24, 2024_ Toilets wash basin, bath and shower fixtures in good repair/no leaks/hot water temperature _ok_ Soap and Paper towels ok_ Laundry Facilities(available)_ok_ Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80024(a) Waivers and Exceptions. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were left at the facility with Marie Reyes, Licensee.

On June 17, 2024, at 12:00PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelique Hill made an unannounced inspection and met with Marie Y. Reyes, Administrator to deliver a civil penalty assessment. During the inspection, LPA Hill observed that there were no staff and no children in the home at the time of arrival. On May 9, 2024 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Angelique Hill and Jean Sitdman made an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of an annual inspection. During this inspection, LPAs cited nine deficiencies to the facility (refer to LIC 809-D pages). One out of nine deficiencies cited, was for California Code and Regulation (CCR), Title 22 80019(E)(2) Criminal Record Clearance. As a result of the above deficiency, a civil penalty was assessed. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report along with appeal rights were discussed and provided to Marie Y. Reyes, Administrator.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jean Stidman and Investigator Fizza Shahzad conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility on 7/18/24 at 1:45pm met with LPA and Investigator met with Karren Mellegrito, DSP, for the purpose of a case management inspection. On 4/8/24 LPAs observed the facility was not storing client’s files in a confidential manner. On 7/3/24 LPA Stidman reviewed one child’s case notes for February-March 2024 and observed multiple times C1 would display self-injurious behavior which lasted for up to three hours. These incidents were not reported to the Department. On 7/18/24 during an inspection of the facility Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jean Stidman and Investigator Fizza Shahzad observed the closet doors are off the track and the dresser has drawers that will not open and/or are off the track in one child's bedroom. The facility is cited violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 4, Regulations 80070(c) Client Records, 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds and 80061(b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements on the attached LIC809D. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were left with Karren Mellegrito, DSP

deficiencies.description:
80070(c) Client Records All information and records obtained from or regarding clients shall be confidential. 
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: During the 4/8/24 inspection LPA Stidman and Hill observed the facility was storing client’s confidential files in the garage on rack style storage shelves in cardboard office storage boxes. The licensee stated the files were from previous clients over the last few years. LPA’s Stidman and Hill also observed a completed client roster (LIC9050) was posted on the bulletin board in the front hallway on this date which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: During the inspection on 4/8/24 the licensee removed the client roster from the bulletin board. On 6/6/24 the licensee submitted pictures via email of the files are stored in a metal file cabinet. On 6/17/24 during an inspection LPA2 Angelique Hill verified the file cabinet is in the garage and was locked.

deficiencies.description: 80061(b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. Events reported shall include the following: Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: During a review of daily case notes for child C1, LPA Stidman observed approximately 16 times C1 would slap their own face or staff’s face with an open palm, scratch their mom, bite, kick, bang their head on the floor, door or wall. These behaviors lasted for up to three hours. LPA reviewed the Departments incident folders for this facility and only one incident was reported during C1’s placement from 2/10/24-3/23/24 which poses a potential Health and Safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide documentation of staff have been trained on the reporting requirements as stated in Title 22 Regulation 80061 by 8/18/24.

deficiencies.description: 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: On 7/18/24 during an inspection of the facility Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jean Stidman and Investigator Fizza Shahzad observed the closet doors are off the track and the dresser has drawers that will not open and/or are off the track for one client's bedroom at the end of the hall.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide documentation of the closet doors and the dresser drawers for one client's bedroom at the end of the hall are working properly and/or no longer pose a potential safety hazard by 8/18/24.

narrative: discipline policy, and daily notes. LPAs reviewed two staff files and obtained documentation of background clearance, driver's license, offer letter, house rules, grievance form. LPAs reviewed 17 staff training documentation for dates 3/24/20-4/6/24. LPAs conducted interviews on 4/2/24, 4/8/24, 4/25/24, 5/9/24 and 6/28/24 with the reporting party, five staff, one client and one biological parent. Based on interviews and records review, the facility staff did not treat minor with respect when the staff spoke negatively to one child, staff did handle a minor roughly when three staff carried a child into the care home, and staff are not properly trained to deal with minor's behavior based upon records reviewed show the facility failed to provide staff training at least one time per month as stated in their Plan of Operation. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 4 83072(d) Personal Rights and 80022(e)(4) Plan of Operation are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Karren Mellegrito, DSP.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jean Stidman and Investigator Fizza Shahzad conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility on 7/18/24 at 1:00pm to deliver complaint allegation findings. LPA and Investigator met with Karren Mellegrito, DSP and discussed the above allegations. During the investigation of staff did not treat minor with respect, staff handled minor roughly, and staff are not properly trained to deal with minor's behaviors LPAs Jean Stidman toured the facility with Marie Reyes, licensee, on 4/8/24, 4/25/24 and 5/9/24. On these inspections, LPAs inspected the physical plant inside and out, and observed the facility is a single story four-bedroom, two-bathroom home. LPAs reviewed three children’s and one non-minor dependent’s files and obtained documentation of preplacement appraisal information, medical documentation, monthly weight record, Physician's report, Needs & Services Plan, individual Program Plan (IPP), Identification & Emergency Information, Regional Center, Internal Placement Screening Form, Consumer care daily record for February-March 2024, daily activity log for February-March 2024,

deficiencies.description:
83072(d) Personal Rights 
The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9 and below, as applicable: 
(10) To be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons.
(11) To be free of … actions of a punitive nature including but not limited to interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and records review, the facility staff violated the child’s personal rights when the staff spoke negatively to C1 on 3/22/24, and when three staff carried C1 going back to the care home for her safety on 3/19/24. These pose a potential Health and Safety risk to clients in care
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide docuemtation of training the staff on Chidren's Personal Rights by 8/18/24.

deficiencies.description:
80022(e)(4) Plan of Operation 
If the licensee intends to admit or care for one or more clients who rely upon others to perform all activities of daily living, the plan of operation must also include a statement that demonstrates the licensee's ability to care for these clients.  The evidence or ability may include, but not be limited to: Documentation of training the licensee and/or staff have completed specific to the needs of these clients. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review of staff training from 3/24/20 to 5/9/24 and interviews, 17 of the facility staff have not been trained “…to implement the consumer(s) IPP and ISP objectives…at least one time per month” as stated in the Plan of Operation Staff Training Plan, On-the-Job Training on pages 17-19. These staff were only trained monthly by facility staff on six times over the last four years. Additionally, the facility Plan of Operation Emergency intervention Plan as stated on pages 63-66 states “3. Staff training plan for new and existing personnel: All staff will receive training on Management of Aggressive Behavior (MAB) but only one out of 17 staff have documentation of MAB training over the last four years which poses a potential Health and Safety risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide documentation of monthly staff training on implementing the consumer(s) IPP and ISP objectives in July and August by 8/18/24.

narrative: On August 8, 2024, at 10:20AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Angelique Hill and Jean Stidman made an unannounced inspection for the purpose of a case management. LPAs met with Marie Reyes, Facility Administrator to discuss one clients’ needs and incident reports submitted. LPAs requested the following documents for one client: Individual Service Plan (ISP), two Residential Patch Requests dated April and June 2024, Individual Program Plan (IPP), and Functional Skills Assessment dated April 2024. LPAs conducted an inspection inside and outside of the facility. No citations were issued related to the case management. Further Investigation is needed. A copy of this report was left with Marie Reyes, Facility Administrator.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Angelique Hill and Jean Stidman made an unannounced Annual inspection on 5/09/24 at 9:30 am. During the inspection LPAs met with Marie Ysebelle Reyes, Licensee who assisted with the inspection. LPAs conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. Facility staff-client ratio at time of inspection two staff and one youth were present. During the inspection, three youth and two staff arrived. LPAs observed the facility is a one story home with four bedrooms and two bathrooms. LPAs inspected and/or reviewed the following: Carbon monoxide detector_ok_ Smoke Detector ok First Aid Kit fully stocked_ok__ Medication centrally stored, locked/inaccessible ok Fire Extinguisher inspected 01/2024, Bedroom (required bedding/furniture, furniture in good repair) ok, Disaster and mass casualty plan updated and available__X_ Quarterly Drills conducted and documented__X_ Disaster preparedness supplies verified __X__ Number of Staff files reviewed _five Criminal record clearances verified _three_First Aid Certificates__five__ Number of youth files reviewed four Individual Program Plan four Centrally Stored Medication and log reviewed four Psychotropic Medication and log reviewed four__Staff received training __X__ Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 83070(b)(11) Child's Records one youth's record missing documentation of a copy of the written authorization of the child's parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication. The following items were reviewed for compliance in the regional office prior to the facility inspection: Annual fees, Emergency Disaster Plan, Personnel Roster, Facility Sketch, LIC 500, and Waivers and Exceptions. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80019(e)(2) Criminal Record Clearance, 80071(a)(2)(A) Register of Clients, 80075(k)(7)(e) Health Related Services, 80070(c) Client Records, 83070(b)(11)(A) Children's Record's, 80075(k)(3), 80075(l), 80075(k)(7)(H) Health Related Services, 80069(c)(1) Client Medical Assessment, and 80068.2(b)(1) Needs and Services Plan Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report left at the facility with Marie Ysbelle Reyes, Licensee.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Angelique Hill and Jean Stidman conducted an unannounced case management inspection with the above facility on 10/22/2024 at 10:00AM and met with Marie Y. Reyes, Administrator. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility and observed the facility is a single story four-bedroom, two-bathroom home. One bathroom has a broken drawer under the sink. Confidential interviews with 13 individuals, six inspections of the facility were conducted, and records reviewed during the period of 4/8/24 to 9/12/24 by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jean Stidman, Angelique Hill, and Investigator, Fizza Shahzad. Based upon these interviews, inspections and records reviewed of application documentation, staff and facility files, and LPAs observations were consistent that the licensee, Marie Reyes, does not reside in the facility. Based on these interviews, facility inspections, and records reviewed, Facility Citation Violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 01 80001(s)(5) Definitions. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights and a copy of this report was provided to Marie Y. Reyes.

deficiencies.description:
"Small Family Home" means any residential facility in the licensee's family residence providing 24-hour a day care for six or fewer children who are mentally disordered, developmentally disabled or physically handicapped and who require special care and supervision as a result of such disabilities. 

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on 13 interviews, six facility inspections, and records reviewed during the period of 4/8/24 to 9/12/24 the licensee reported they are typically only in the facility Tuesday through Thursday from 3pm-11pm then they go to work for their spouse, Jeremiah Ongpauco, at the Ongpauco Small Family Home (SFH) where they “work the night shift and on the weekends”. Licensee stated their spouse rents a room from a friend at and they have been living apart since 2019. Licensee stated their daughter sleeps “in my room”, but LPAs did not observe clothing or personal items for the licensee’s daughter in the bedroom or the facility and the bed did not appear to have any bedding other than one sheet or blanket. Multiple interviews reported the licensee does not sleep at the facility and is usually only there three days a week for 8 hours each of these days and then goes to sleep at a room they rent, and that the licensee’s daughter does not live in the facility. At the house the licensee rents for their daughter LPA’s Jean Stidman and Elena Gonzalez-Soto observed on 8/21 at 2:37pm the facility van was in the driveway; on 8/21/24 at 2:39pm the facility van and Jeremiah Ongpauco’s truck were in the driveway; on 9/12/24 at 9:55am the facility van was in the driveway and at 1:33pm Jeremiah Ongpauco’s truck was in the driveway.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will provide documentation of the licensee residing in the facility by 11/22/2024.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis conducted a virtual Component II session via Microsoft Teams with Bahati Love SFH on March 05, 2025 at 2:30pm. LPA met with the Applicant, Aqueelah Bahati, and advised of the purpose and importance of the Component II session. During the meeting the following items were discussed: 1. Staff Associations 2. Small Family Home Program Statement revisions 3. Menus 4. Emergency Intervention Plan 5. LIC 200 6. Fire Inspection 7. Cameras 8. Client age ranges 9. LIC 500 10. Admission Policies 11. Medical/Dental 12. Chores LPA asked questions regarding the Applicant's Program Statement to assess their understanding of the regulations in place for a Small Family Home. LPA advised the Applicant that all revisions/corrections should be submitted directly to him for review. The Pre-Licensing inspection will take place on Thursday, March 27, 2025. LPA advised the Applicant that their program statement and all application materials will also be reviewed by his manager, LPM Yan Yeung. Exit Interview conducted

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to the Bahati Love Small Family Home on March 27, 2025 at 12:30pm for the purposes of an announced Pre-licensing inspection. The Department has received application materials from the applicant to become licensed at the site as a Small Family Home licensee. LPA met with the applicant, Aqueelah Bahati, and together they toured the home. The home is located in a secured residential apartment complex and consists of two bedrooms and two bathrooms. Bedroom #1 has one California king bed, dresser, desk and chair, and closet space. The bedroom is vacant. Bedroom #2 has one king bed, dresser, bassinet, and closet space. The bedroom is occupied by the applicant. Smoke alarms were operable in both bedrooms. Sharp knives, chemicals, and cleaning supplies are kept locked in areas inaccessible to children. LPA observed a fully stocked linen closet in bathroom #1. The living room and dining room areas were observed to be tidy and had sufficient seating. There are two swimming pools in the complex. The pools are located on the roof and on the third floor. The pools have self-latching gates and is only accessible with a resident key. Children have to be accompanied at all times with an adult to enter the pool areas. LPA observed two bathrooms to be in good repair and working order. Overall, the facility appeared clean, safe, and sanitary. LPA observed a fully charged fire extinguisher mounted on the wall in the dining area. The outdoor areas were observed to be free of debris and hazards. There is a ring camera doorbell outside the applicant's front door. LPA held discussions with the Applicant about cameras. LPA observed the kitchen area to be clean and the refrigerator was fully stocked with ample food supply. LPA observed adequate perishable and nonperishable food items in the cabinets and in the pantry. LPA also observed a complete food menu posted on the refrigerator in the kitchen.

The applicant stated that there weren't any firearms or other weapons in the home. There is adequate space for indoor and outdoor activities. LPA observed a fully stocked First Aid Kit with bandages, scissors, band-aids, tweezers, and thermometer. The Applicant has an adequate laundry area with a washer and dryer, respectively. There is a movie theater, basketball court, steam room, sauna, business center, and a computer room available for the residents of the complex. LPA found no Title 22 deficiencies on this date. Exit interview conducted LPA Davis discussed warm weather conditions and precautions with the applicant and provided the applicant with the Department's website address (www.ccld.ca.gov). LPA also conducted a Component III at the facility with Leah Wilson, applicant. During the Component III meeting, the following forms were given and/or discussed: LIC 311E Records To Be Maintained At The Facility - Small Family Home LIC 625 Appraisal/Needs and Services Plan LIC 602 Physician's Report for Community Care Facilities LIC 601 Identification and Emergency Information LIC 603 Preplacement Appraisal Information LIC 622 Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record LIC 624 Unusual Incident/Injury Report The provider was also briefed about the importance of incident reporting and client education.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Abdoulaye Traore conducted a pre-arranged pre-licensing tele-inspection as a result of COVID 19 related restrictions. This tele-inspection was conducted with applicant Judith Mugo via Microsoft teams. The Facility was toured both inside and out the applicant. The applicant is applying for Small Family home license of four ambulatory clients. The home is a two-story home and consists of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1 – it was furnished with two twin size beds. It will sleep two ambulatory foster children- vacant. Bedroom #2 – it was furnished with two twin size beds. It will sleep two ambulatory foster children- vacant The downstairs also consisted of a family room, a formal living room, a kitchen, a shared bathroom for foster children, a dining area, a garage and a patio. Upstairs: Bedroom #3 - Master bedroom- The room consists of a king bed and it sleeps applicant. Bedroom #4 - The room consists of a queen size bed. It sleeps the applicant 17-year-old daughter. Bedroom #5 - The room consists of a queen size bed. It sleeps the applicant 20- year-old son. Bedroom #6 – The room was furnished with a queen bed- to be used for playing and isolation area. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Inside the facility the fireplace was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access.

The medications and children files will be locked in a cabinet located at the dining area inaccessible to children. Sharp knives and objects were locked in a cabinet underneath the kitchen sink. Cleansers/chemicals were inaccessible and stored in a locked closed located in the laundry room downstairs by the garage. There was adequate food storage space and a suppl of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The applicant measured the water temperature and it was observed to be within the range. First Aid kit were accessible with all required items and it was located in the dining area. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. All the appropriate forms were posted in view of facility clients. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pool or other body of water. The backyard had a covered patio with two large doors also to be used for additional play area accessible for children. The other side of the backyard had an open patio free of hazards. Component III orientation was completed with the applicant/license. The orientation included incident reporting procedures, client’s records requirements, care and supervision, and client personal rights. On this date, Facility is recommended for licensure. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Facility will accept only ambulatory clients and licensed for a capacity of 4 foster children age 0-17. Facility prefers to serve 10 to 17-year-old foster children.

Due to COVID 19 related restrictions, a tele-inspection via WhatsApp was conducted on September 21, 2020 at 11:45 AM by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Abdoulaye Traore with Baraka Small Family Home Applicant Judith Mugo to go over revisions needed for the application prior to licensure. LPA emailed applicant a copy of this report, 184 (Notification of Incomplete Application), Letter of incomplete application and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed for the application. This report was emailed to Judith for signature. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.

On November 4, 2021 at 10:20 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie, met with facility staff (FS1) who granted access to the home. The purpose of this visit is to conduct an annual required inspection of the small family home. Presently there are three foster children in placement and three of three were in school during time of inspection (See LIC 811). The home is two story with six bedrooms and 4 bathrooms. Bedroom #1 has two twin beds, it is occupied by FC1 Bedroom #2 has two twin beds; it is occupied by FC2 and FC3 Bedroom #3 has a queen size bed; it is occupied by S1. Bedroom #4 has a queen size bed; it is occupied by S2 Bedroom #5 has a queen size bed; it is occupied by S3 Bedroom #6 is the master bedroom, has a queen size bed; it is occupied by Licensee. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room currently used for other purposes other than bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in are good condition.

The fireplace is properly screened. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications are locked and stored in the kitchen cabinet on the right to the living room. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the laundry room cabinet. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked in the kitchen cabinet. The first aid kit is in the locked kitchen cabinet. There are no guns or weapons as stated by S1 at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be within normal temperature limits. All facility smoke detectors are synchronized, carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. LPA observed Psychotropic medication for FC1, has current court order and written authorization. LPA interviewed one staff, three foster children FC1, FC2 and FC3.

Regarding resource parent does not adequately feed foster child, a confidential interview denied that FC1 was not adequately fed. A confidential interview stated that FC1 was diabetic and was usually guided to eat right type of food. A confidential interview stated that FC1 ate three times a day with snacks in-between meals. A confidential witness stated that there was adequate food in the home and FM monitored FC1’s food intake due to diabetic diagnosis. (CSW) stated that it was observed that FM monitored food intake for FC1 due to diabetic diagnosis. Based on confidential interviews, the Department determined there was not sufficient information to determine resource parent does not properly care for foster child and resource parent does not adequately feed FC1. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations, therefore, these allegations were unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to the licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On July 6, 2022 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Babatunde Aborchie and Anne Visaya arrived at Baraka Small Family Home (SFH) to deliver the findings of the investigation involving the small family home and foster child 1 (FC1). LPAs met with Licensee who granted LPAs access into the home. On May 5, 2022, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging that resource parent does not properly care for foster child (FC1) and resource parent does not adequately feed foster child. On June 1, 2022 at 10:14 AM, LPA conducted a safety inspection with S1. There were no immediate safety hazards observed at the time of inspection. LPA reviewed the child’s file and obtained copies. During the investigation, LPA conducted interviews with the foster mother (FM), foster children (FC1, FC2 and FC3) and S1. All confidential interviews denied foster mother does not properly care for foster child. Confidential interviews stated that there was proper care and felt the foster children were properly cared for. A confidential witness stated that during a visit to the home, it was observed that FM was taking proper care of FC1.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that FM left FC1 at the hospital for an extended period, a confidential interview denied leaving FC1 at the hospital for an extended period. Confidential interview disclosed that there was a mis-communication due to change in shift. A confidential witness believed FC1 was left at the hospital for an extended period due to a verbal order by physician that was miscommunicated during shift change. LPA received conflicting information during confidential interviews. Based on confidential interviews, the Department determined there was not sufficient information to determine FM left FC1 at the hospital for an extended period. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegation, therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was reviewed and provided to the staff.
investigation_findings: 13On January 26, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Baraka Small Family Home (SFH) to deliver the finding of the investigation involving the small family home and foster child 1 (FC1). LPA met with staff who granted access into the home. On August 23, 2022, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging that foster parent left minor at the hospital for an extended period. On August 24, 2022 at 11:11 AM, LPA conducted a safety inspection with foster mother (FM). There were no immediate safety hazards observed at the time of inspection. LPA interviewed FM and FC1. On August 24, 2022 LPA interviewed Social Service Supervisor II (SSP II).

narrative: Regarding the allegation that FM did not keep up with FC1’s hygiene needs, it was specifically reported that FC1 was filthy and when using baby wipes, they came out brown with dirt and when FC1 sat down on the toilet seat, FC1 left dirt on the seat. During investigation, confidential interview disclosed that FC1 was agitated and exhibited behaviors during showers. Another confidential interview denied FM did not keep up with FC1’s hygiene needs and disclosed that FC1 was showered daily. Another confidential interview disclosed that FC1 was not used to taking a shower, FC1 would fight not to get in the shower. A confidential witness disclosed that FC1 was placed at the SFH for only two weeks, hence FC1 was still adapting to the new placement. Based on confidential interviews, the Department determined there was not sufficient information to determine FM did not keep up with FC1’s hygiene needs. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegation, therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was reviewed and provided to the staff.
investigation_findings: 13On January 26, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Baraka Small Family Home (SFH) to deliver the finding of the investigation involving the small family home and foster child 1 (FC1). LPA met with staff who granted access into the home. On October 18, 2022, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging that FM does not keep up with FC1’s hygiene needs. On October 27, 2022 at 12:03 PM, LPA conducted a safety inspection with foster mother (FM). There were no immediate safety hazards observed at the time of inspection. LPA interviewed FM, Staff1 (S1) and Staff2 (S2). LPA was unable to collect information from FC1 due to FC1’s developmental age of being non-verbal. On October 28, 2022 LPA interviewed County Social Worker (CSW) and Social Service Supervisor II (SSP II).

narrative: Regarding the allegation that FM did not seek timely psychiatric care for FC1, a confidential interview denied not seeking timely psychiatric care for FC1. Confidential interview disclosed that all psychiatrist appointments were up to date. Another confidential interview disclosed that a Psychiatrist’s appointment was missed, however, the visit was later on done virtually. A confidential witness observed psychiatrist visits were up to date, but it was not specified if the visit was completed in a timely manner. In regard to the allegation that FM did not ensure FC1 was properly fed, while in care. It was specifically stated that FC1 was not eating food and only drank milk for three months. A confidential interview denied FC1 was not properly fed while in care. Confidential interview disclosed that FC1 was provided variety of meal options but FC1 preferred Pedi-sure and milk. A confidential witness observe FC1 was provided with variety of meals but FC1 refused to eat at every attempt made. LPA received a conflicting information. Based on confidential interviews, the Department determined there was not sufficient information to determine FM did not seek timely psychiatric care for FC1 and FM did not ensure FC1 was properly fed, while in care. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations, therefore, these allegations were unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was reviewed and provided to facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On January 26, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Baraka Small Family Home (SFH) to deliver the findings of the investigation involving the small family home and foster child 1 (FC1). LPA met with Staff who granted access into the home. On August 19, 2022, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging that foster parent did not seek timely psychiatric care for a foster child and foster parent did not ensure a foster child was properly fed while in care On August 24, 2022 at 9:08 AM, LPA conducted a safety inspection with foster mother (FM). There were no immediate safety hazards observed at the time of inspection. LPA interviewed FM and FC1. On December 13, 2022 LPA interviewed County Social Worker (CSW).

narrative:
On April 11 2023 at 11:15 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie, met with staff (S1) who granted access to the home. The purpose of this visit is to conduct an annual required inspection of the small family home. Presently there are three foster children in placement and three of three were at home during time of inspection (See LIC 811). The home is two story with six bedrooms and 4 bathrooms. Bedroom #1 has two twin beds, it is occupied by FC1 and FC3 Bedroom #2 has two twin beds; it is occupied by FC2 Bedroom #3 has a queen size bed; it is occupied by S1. Bedroom #4 has a queen size bed; it is currently empty Bedroom #5 has a queen size bed; it is occupied by little cousin 13 years old Bedroom #6 is the master bedroom, has a King size bed; it is occupied by Licensee. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room currently used for other purposes other than bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in are good condition.

The fireplace is properly screened. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications are locked and stored in the kitchen cabinet on the right to the living room. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the laundry room cabinet. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked in the kitchen cabinet. The first aid kit is in the locked kitchen cabinet. There are no guns or weapons as stated by S1 at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 110 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are synchronized, carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. LPA observed Psychotropic medication for FC1, has current court order and written authorization. LPA interviewed one staff, two foster children FC1 and FC2. LPA was unable to interview FC3 due to FC3 being nonverbal.

In regard to the above allegation that FM is not ensuring FC1’s teeth are brushed. A confidential interview denied not ensuring FC1’s teeth were brushed. A confidential interview disclosed that FC1’s teeth were being brushed every morning. Another confidential interview was not sure if FC1’s teeth was brushed, that it might be done during showers. A confidential witness had not seen FC1’s teeth being brushed but believed licensee had been taking good care of FC1 since placement at the home. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that licensee was not ensuring that FC1’s teeth were brushed may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegation. Therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was reviewed and provided to Licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On July 28, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Baraka Small Family Home (SFH) to deliver the findings of the investigation involving the Small Family Home and foster child 1 (FC1). LPA met with licensee Judith Mugo who granted access into the home. On February 2, 2023, at 1:52 PM, LPA conducted a safety inspection with staff (S1). There were no immediate safety hazards observed at the time of inspection. LPA interviewed foster mother (FM) and S1. Additionally, on February 3, 2023, LPA interviewed County Social Worker (CSW). On January 31, 2023, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging that resource parent is not ensuring that minor's teeth are brushed.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that L1 was not meeting foster child's educational needs, it was specifically stated that FC1 is failing all the school subjects. A confidential interview denied not meeting foster child’s educational needs. Confidential interview disclosed that FC1 is very playful at school, however, homework assignments were priority when FC1 returned from school. Another confidential interview indicated that homework assignments were not been given to FC1 lately. A confidential witness stated not observing L1 assisting FC1 with homework assignments but believed L1 helped with schoolwork as needed. In regard to the allegation that L1 was not providing adequate supervision, it was specifically stated that FC1 was using swear words or words with sexual content. A confidential interview denied not providing adequate supervision. A confidential interview did not know when FC1 used profane words and disclosed that FC1 did not use those words at home. A confidential witness did not hear FC1 using words with sexual content at home. Confidential witness believed there was adequate supervision at home, but not sure where FC1 got the words from. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that L1 not meeting FC1’s educational needs, L1 not providing adequate supervision may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was reviewed and provided to Licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On July 28, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Baraka Small Family Home (SFH) to deliver the findings of the investigation involving the Small Family Home and foster child 1 (FC1). LPA met with licensee Judith Mugo who granted access into the home. On January 31, 2023, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging foster parent not meeting foster child's educational needs and foster parent not providing adequate supervision. On March 24, 2023, at 10:23 AM, LPA B. Aborchie conducted a safety inspection with licensee (L1) Judith Mugo. There were no immediate safety hazards observed at the time of inspection. LPA interviewed licensee (L1) and two foster children (FC1 and FC2). Additionally, on March 29, 2023, LPA interviewed County Social Worker (CSW).

narrative: Regarding the allegation that (FC1) sustained unexplained injuries while in care; it was specifically reported that FC1 had red blisters on the bottom of the feet and a bruise on the left ankle. A confidential interview denied FC1 sustained unexplained injuries while in care. Confidential interview stated that there were no bruises on FC1 during body check. A confidential witness conducted a body check and did not see any bruises on FC1. The confidential witness was not sure if the bruises occurred at the home. Confidential witness believed the home was safe for FC1 while in care. LPA received conflicting information regarding the allegation. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that FC1 sustained unexplained injuries while in care may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegation. Therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was reviewed and provided to Licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On January 5, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Baraka Small Family Home (SFH) to deliver the finding of the investigation involving the Small Family Home and foster child 1 (FC1). LPA met with licensee Judith Mugo who granted access into the home. On October 4, 2023, a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging foster child (FC1) sustained unexplained injuries while in care. On October 6, 2023, at 1:38 PM, LPA B. Aborchie conducted a safety inspection with licensee Judith Mugo. There were no immediate safety hazards observed at the time of inspection. LPA interviewed licensee and a staff (S1). Additionally, on January 3, 2024, LPA interviewed County Social Worker (CSW). LPA was unable to interview FC1 due to FC1’s developmental age.

narrative: On 09/12/2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that LS is not providing adequate care and supervision to minors. It was specifically reported that FC1 showed some swelling as well as some black and blue bruising on the right side of FC1's face due to running and falling. It was further reported that another child (FC2) in the home kicked FC1 and caused FC1 to fall and hit FC1's face on the floor. During investigation, confidential interview stated that they did not see FC2 kicking nor pushing FC1. The confidential interview continued reporting that licensee was at the scene when FC1 fell. Additionally, the confidential interview emphasized that the children were playing and that the fall was an accident. Another confidential interview reported that children were always supervised by an adult while the children played. LPAs were unable to gather additional interviews regarding the incident. Based on confidential interviews and a review of pertinent documents, the allegation that licensee is not providing adequate care and supervision to the foster children may have occurred, however there is not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were explained and given to staff Billy Ngamau.
investigation_findings: 13On 01/19/2024, at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez conducted an unannounced visit to Baraka Small Family Home (SFH) and met with staff Billy Ngamau to deliver the investigative finding for the allegation listed above. On September 15, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie conducted a health and safety inspection with licensee. LPA B. Aborchie did not observe any safety hazards. In addition, LPA B. Aborchie interviewed LS, Staff 1 (S1), Foster child 1, & 3 (FC1 and FC3). LPA B. Aborchie also obtained documents pertinent to the investigation. Furthermore, LPA M. Perez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore conducted additional interviews with LS and FC2 to obtain more information.

narrative:
On August 6, 2024, at 10 AM, a Component II Office Visit was held to discuss the application received for Barbara Kayongo Small Family Home located at 20701 W. Deer Grass CT. Porter Ranch, CA 91326. Attending Component II were the following individuals: Barbara Kayongo, Applicant, Erika Butler, Licensing Program Analyst and JoAunne Griffin, Licensing Program Manager (LPM). The purpose of this Component II meeting was to review and discuss the incomplete application and Program Statement and to resolve any outstanding concerns that may have existed. The following incomplete application forms were discussed at the meeting: 1. Emergency Disaster Plan for Children's Residential Facilities (LIC 610C) 2. Health Screening Report 3. Criminal Record Statement (LIC 508D) 4. First Aid/CPR card 5. Personnel Record (LIC 501) 6. Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610 C) 7. Control of Property 8. All pages of your car insurance policy Continued on LIC 809-C

9. Criminal Record Clearance 10. Program Statement a. Program Purpose, Target Population, Intake Procedures b. Target Population c. Treatment d. Education e. Daily Activities f. Discipline g. Recreation h. Unplanned Termination i. Religious Services j. Basic Food Services k. Medication Storage l. Transportation m. Organization Information The Applicant was advised of the following revision and/or corrections needed to the application and/or Program Statement: Sections 1-29 of the Program Statement was reviewed and discussed. Revisions are due August 27, 2024. Pre-licensing visit has been scheduled for Friday, September 13, 2024, at 10 AM. A copy of this report was provided to Barbara Kayango.

On September 13, 2024, at 10 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Butler, (LPA) Cheri Wilkerson, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) JoAunne’ Griffin arrived at Barbara Kayongo's Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPAs and LPM met with Applicant, Barbara Kayongo, and her husband Robert Kayongo who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior of the home was conducted. Currently living in the home is the Applicant, her husband, her sister, and 3 biological children. The home is set up as follows: This is a 5 bedrooms, 5 1/2 bathrooms home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry area, office, loft, patio, and an attached garage. Living room: is equipped with 2 couches, love seat, coffee table, mounted TV. The living room also has sliding glass patio doors leading to the backyard. Dining room: is equipped with glass table with 12 chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a 6 burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), microwave, and a dishwasher. Sharp knives are kept in a locked drawer. LPA observed a covered trash can, cabinet space, plates, cups, and eating utensils. LPA observed perishable food items in the refrigerator, and non-perishable food items. The Applicant will ensure that 3 nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to the clients. Laundry room: is located upstairs. Continued on LIC 809-C

The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. Medications will be kept locked in the applicants bedroom. Medications requiring refrigeration will be in a locked box for the refrigerator. The home’s temperature is maintained by central air/heating. LPA observed 2 fully charged fire extinguisher. Extra linens are stored in the linen closet upstairs. The smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. First Aid kit was found to be be complete. The home has alarms on all doors and the monitoring device is located in the Applicant's bedroom. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. LPA reminded Licensee to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Applicant will ensure grievance process, Disaster Plan, Discipline policies and procedures will be posted in office area. During the inspection, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. LPA informed applicant that a Component 3 meeting will be held on October 10 at 1:00 p.m. Tele Orientation. Fingerprints for all adults and persons helping with the care of the clients in care will need to be completed. Applicant will submit revisions to the Program Statement by September 27, 2024. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of report will be emailed to Applicant, Barbara Kayongo at barbskay74@gmail.com.

Bedroom #1: Applicant's sister's bedroom has a twin bed, dresser, closet space, working lights, windows, with an attached bathroom. Bedroom #2: Applicant's son's bedroom has two 2 full size beds, dresser space, a closet, working lights, and windows, with attached bathroom. Bedroom #3: Applicant's daughter's bedroom has a full bed, dresser space, a closet, working lights, and windows. The applicants daughters bathroom is located outside her bathroom. Bedroom #4: Applicant's bedroom has a king size bed, crib, dresser, working lights, and windows. The room also has an attached bathroom, separate tub, shower, and a walk-in closet. Bedroom #5: Guest bedroom located downstairs, has a king size bed, closet, dresser, working lights, windows, and attached bathroom. LPA found all bathrooms to be clean and in working order. The hot water was tested and found to be with 105-120 (F). Backyard: Equipped with a patio set. Attached garage: used for storage. Vehicle: The Applicant will use a 2020 Honda Odyssey, and the 2005 Lexus GX 470 to transport clients in care. The vehicle is in good condition with current registration. The 2020 Honda Odyssey insurance is valid through February 2025 and the Lexus GX insurance is valid through January 2025. Continued on LIC 809-C

On December 16, at 9:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Erika Butler, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), JoAunne Griffin conducted a Small Family Home (SFH) Component III office meeting with Applicant, Barbara Kayongo. LPA Butler, and LPM Griffin met with Applicant to discuss forms required to be maintained, available, and posted at the facility for inspections. We discussed child and personnel records that are required to be documented, retained and available for inspection. We also discussed specific requirements, concerns and issues operating a SFH, such as, reporting requirements, personnel requirements, supervision, intake issues, compatibility, removal/discharge policies, complaint procedures, transportation, health services, food, hygiene, visitation, personal property, searches, and community sensitivity. Applicant will submit revisions of Program Statement by December 26, 2024. Pending final approval of SFH Program Statement LPA Butler and LPM Griffin will submit the application for licensure. A copy of this report was provided to the Applicant.

LPA met with Licensee, Barbara Kayongo. A health and safety assessment was conducted. This is a 5 bedrooms, 5 1/2 bathrooms home located in a residential area. Living room: is equipped with 2 couches, love seat, coffee table, mounted TV. The living room also has sliding glass patio doors leading to the backyard. Dining room: is equipped with glass table with 12 chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a 6 burner gas stove, microwave, and a dishwasher. Sharp knives are kept in a locked drawer, covered trash can, cabinet space, plates, cups, and eating utensils. Laundry room: is located upstairs. Bedroom #1: Applicant's sister's bedroom has a twin bed, dresser, closet space, working lights, windows, with an attached bathroom. Bedroom #2: Applicant's son's bedroom has two 2 full size beds, dresser space, a closet, working lights, and windows, with attached bathroom. Continued on LIC 809-C

Bedroom #3: Applicant's daughter's bedroom has a full bed, dresser space, a closet, working lights, and windows. The applicants daughters bathroom is located outside her bathroom. Bedroom #4: Applicant's bedroom has a king size bed, crib, dresser, working lights, and windows. The room also has an attached bathroom, separate tub, shower, and a walk-in closet. Bedroom #5: Guest bedroom located downstairs, has a king size bed, closet, dresser, working lights, windows, and attached bathroom. Camera(s): There is one cameras located in the front of the home over the garage. The camera is monitored through the Ring App Facility was observed to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Water temperature is within a safe range. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. Outdoor activity space (front yard) is free of obstructions. The first aid kit is complete with required items. The home has 2 fully charged fire extinguisher. All smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were observed to be in working order. All posting requirements are met. Licensee advised that all assistant caregivers are required to be fingerprint cleared prior to working in the facility. The home will utilize a 2020 Honda Odyssey, and the 2005 Lexus GX 470 to transport client in care. Current automobile insurance is with AAA and is current. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. The exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Licensee.

Living room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, an attached two car garage, a laundry room, storage closet, and the backyard. The Client’s bedroom was arranged so that no more than two clients will share the room. CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

***Continued from LIC 809*** The Client’s bedroom was arranged so that no more than two clients will share the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom and one carbon monoxide detector located in the hallway. The smoke detectors and the carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. The home’s central air conditioning module was located outside of the home in the side yard. The home’s hot water heater was located inside the garage. Inside the facility there are no fireplaces. The appliances were in working order. All sharp knives and medication will be located in a locked closet downstairs. The client’s files will be locked inside a locked file cabinet in the downstairs closet. Chemicals will be stored in the upstairs locked laundry room There was adequate food storage space. A proper storage of all food was discussed. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight fitting lid and was located in the kitchen. The client bathroom also had a trash can with a working lid. The water temperature of the house was observed to be 110.9 degrees Fahrenheit. The house temperature was observed to be 78 degrees Fahrenheit. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible with all required items included and located in the kitchen cabinet. A fire extinguisher was present in the home and located on the wall in the kitchen. It was observed to be properly charged. Applicant stated there were no weapons/firearms in the home. LPA observed there were no swimming pool. The backyard where clients will have access to play was completely fenced. The facility sketch, emergency plan, and client rights were hung on the wall by the downstairs bathroom. The applicant is signed up for the October 10, 2024 Component III training. The applicant was advised to contact their LPA within 30 days after the placement of the first client. The request for a license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval . An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Varainia Barkus
