On May 7, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Bates Small family Home for a pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Eugene Bates who led a tour of the entire home inside and out. Currently there are no children placed in the home. The applicant is applying to serve six ambulatory children ages 0 to 17. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. LPA observed the downstairs to be consisting of a kitchen, living room, office, laundry room, bedroom #1, and garage. The kitchen was clean and sanitary storing fire extinguisher, first aid kit and a locked cabinet with medications, client/personnel records. The refrigerator and pantry were stocked with perishable and non-perishable foods in the quantity to meet needs. LPA observed knives/ sharp objects to be locked and out of reach of children in a kitchen cabinet. The kitchen also had a bulletin board with all required postings such as personal rights, visitation policy, emergency disaster plan, menu, and facility sketch. The entry way was observed to have an office area with a desk and computer set up, the living room was fully furnished with a couch, TV, telephone land-line, and a locked fire place. The laundry room was accessible to clients with a locked cabinet storing laundry detergents and other cleaning supplies. There was a closet storing extra household items and bedroom #1 that sleeps applicants biological daughter with a full size bed and bathroom #1 that was fully functioning. The garage was a three car garage and stores a parked vehicle, locked cabinet with cleaning supplies/ chemicals, and extra storage. Trash cans were observed to have tight fitting lids. The upstairs consisted of bedroom #2 which was the master bedroom with a cal-king bed that sleeps applicant, a crib for an infant, and bathroom #2. Upstairs also had bedroom #3 that sleeps applicants

biological daughter that was fully furnished with a queen size bed. There was bedroom #4 that had two twin size beds with required bedding, two dressers, and a closet that will be utilized for two clients and is currently vacant. There was bedroom #5 that had two twin size beds with required bedding, dressers and adequate closet space that will be utilized for two clients and is currently vacant. Bathroom #3 was fully functioning and had water temperature measuring 115.1 degrees Fahrenheit. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. All bedrooms were arranged for one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate linen/ towels, fire blanket, and emergency ladder in the hallway cabinets. There was also fire extinguisher #2 in the upstairs hallway. LPA observed there to be five beds for client use which is not sufficient enough for the capacity of six that the applicant is applying for. Applicant understands there needs to be adjustments made to LIC200. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pools or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: Request for a capacity decrease on LIC200 After corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA so that the request for licensure can be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Component III orientation was also completed this day of May 7, 2025. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Eugene Bates.

LPA gave a copy of the notification of incomplete application (LIC 184), letter of Incomplete Application, and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed to the application. facility_name: BEC'S HAVEN HOUSE SMALL FAMILY HOME
narrative:
On November 7, 2024 at 1:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Bec's Haven House Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicants Kenyon and Quierra Bragg who led a tour of the entire home. The applicants are applying for a capacity of 3 children ages 12-18. The home is a two story building with 4 bedrooms and 3 and a half bathrooms. The downstairs consists of one bedroom that needs to be furnished to sleep up to two foster children- currently vacant, a half bathroom, a locked closet storing first aid kit with all required items, medication, client files, sharp knives/ objects, another locked closet used for storage, a full furnished living room, a full stocked kitchen with working appliances, a dining room with a table, and a locked garage with a back up deep freezer. The second floor consists of a master bedroom for the applicants, an office/loft with furniture and television, a bedroom furnished with a full size bed that will be utilized for one child- currently vacant , another bedroom furnished with a full size bed that will be utilized for one child- currently vacant, a full size bathroom, a laundry room with a locked closet for detergents/ cleaner/chemicals. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than one child share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closets for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. There is no fireplace in the home. There was an open landline telephone service with no phone available.

There was adequate food storage space and a supply of three days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The water temperature was observed to be at 118.4 degrees. The Facility Sketch and Emergency Disaster Plan were posted at this time. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. There are no firearms or weapons as stated by applicants Quierra and Kenyon Bragg. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: Obtain a house phone furnish downstairs bedroom to be utilized as a foster child room After corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA so that another inspection can be completed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicants Quierra and Kenyon Bragg.

On July 31, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Betzy Small Family Home (SFH) pre-licensing inspection for a relocation. Currently, there is no client in care, during the inspection. The home was licensed for a capacity of two clients, one ambulatory client and one bedridden client. The applicant is requesting to relocate. The Facility was toured both inside and out with the licensee. The home is a two-story building with seven bedrooms and three and half bathrooms. During the inspection, LPA observed that the downstairs consisted of living room, family room, a kitchen, two dining areas with a bathroom, a half bathroom, storage and a pantry. Medication will be locked in the kitchen cabinet. The garage was inspected, and it will be used for parking cars. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked kitchen cabinet. The water temperature was tested and measured at 108 degrees F. LPA observed a minimum of seven-day non-perishable and a three-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients. In addition to the downstairs space, there was also a laundry room and a large storage. A trash can was observed to have tight fitting cover. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: personal rights, visitation policy, and current menu. The clients’ medication log records will be kept updated and locked in the kitchen cabinet where the medications were. The First Aid Kit was in the pantry and contained all required items. Two fire extinguishers were observed and operable. There were two bedrooms downstairs. Bedroom #1 will sleep one bedridden client, it was vacant. Bedroom #2 will sleep on adopted son aged 6 years, it was vacant.

Upstairs was bedroom #3, it will sleep one ambulatory client, it was vacant. Bedroom # 4 will sleep biological son, aged 15 years. It was vacant. Bedroom #5 it will be used as a guest room. It was vacant. Bedroom #6 will sleep two adopted daughters, ages 8 and 9 years. It was vacant. Bedroom #7, master bedroom, will sleep licensee and spouse. The licensee’s bedroom is not accessible for the clients, it was vacant. All bedrooms were arranged for one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was an adequate drawer and closet space for each child’s belongings. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and working properly. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room downstairs. The upstairs space includes an additional bathroom used by the clients. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients have access. All windows and screens were in good repair. There were no guns or weapons in the home as stated by Licensee. There was a total of two cameras, located outside which met the title 22 camera policy. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. It has a pool enclosed with a fence 5 feet height with a self-closing and self-latching gate, that met the title 22 pool regulation. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. This report will be submitted to the licensing program manager for approval. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Licensee.
